DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Orders Temporary Halt to State's Drug Testing
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday ordered Georgia to stop mandatory drug testing for job applicants until he holds another hearing on a lawsuit contending the state's new drug testing law is unconstitutional. U.S. District Judge Robert Hall granted a request for a temporary restraining order that will allow Atlanta lawyer Ed Martin to take a job with the state Department of Human Resources without undergoing the test. The lawsuit opposing the drug testing law, which took effect July 1, was filed by the Georgia Association of Educators, Martin and two teachers. The plaintiffs contend the law violates state job applicants' constitutional guarantee of privacy. Hall scheduled a hearing on a request for a preliminary injunction in the case for Aug. 16 and 17, and ordered testing of all state job applicants halted until then. Michael Kramer, an attorney for the association, argued that the new law is too sweeping because it requires testing for all state job applicants, from teachers to maintenance workers. Under the law, anyone refusing to submit to the test or testing positive for drugs would be banned from public employment for two years, and their names would be placed on a state list for an indefinite period of time. Association attorneys estimated that 1,500 applicants have submitted to the drug tests since July 1. Martin found the idea of submitting to the test ``deeply offensive,'' Kramer said. Kramer also argued that Martin, who has been offered a legal job in the Department of Human Resources' Office of Regulatory Services, which oversees nursing homes, posed no risk to the state and should not be required to take the test. The state passed the new law ``to make a statement,'' Kramer said. ``They have no evidence there was any need for this across-the-board testing.'' Senior Assistant Attorney General Wayne Yancey argued that the drug testing law is necessary, especially for teachers who ``are the frontlines in trying to educate the students and stop use of drugs.'' ``We don't need to have the public work force to be the haven for all drug users in the state of Georgia,'' Yancey said. Martin said he was pleased with the judge's ruling. ``I couldn't see where they had a right to do that to people,'' he said of state legislators who approved the law. ``I had to take a stand.'' The other two plaintiffs in the Atlanta lawsuit are Mary Smith, a six-year teacher who did not teach during the 1989-1990 school year and wants to return to the classroom, and Richard Schmidt, who has applied for science teaching jobs. In granting the temporary restraining order, Hall said a 1989 ruling by the U.S. Supreme Court cannot be used to uphold all parts of the Georgia law. In that case, the high court approved tests for U.S. Customs Service workers after the government contended drug use by workers in sensitive jobs could make them likely targets of bribery or blackmail.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Insurance Commissioner, Wife, Brother Plead Innocent
DOC.TEXT: Louisiana Insurance Commissioner Doug Green and his wife and brother entered innocent pleas Thursday to charges they took bribes to keep a floundering insurance company from going under. The trio was indicted by a grand jury in East Baton Rouge Parish on June 28. Doug Green is accused of accepting bribes from Champion Insurance Co. officials while he was a candidate for the commissioner's post in 1987, with an eye toward helping the company stay alive once he took office. The second count in the state indictment charged that while Green was in he and his wife, Linn, and brother, Donald accepted or offered to accept bribes to influence Green's conduct. Judge L. J. Hymel set bond at $25,000 for each of the three, and they were booked and released. Hymel said he would set a trial date in September. Green also faces federal charges stemming from the Champion scandal. Champion failed on June 5, 1989, more than a year after Green took office. The company left unpaid claims in Louisiana estimated at between $150 million and $180 million, a debt that will be covered by state taxpayers under Louisiana's insurance system. Champion was the third-largest automobile insurer in the state. The company also left an estimated $45 million in claims in Alabama and an undetermined amount in Tennessee. Champion owner John Eicher Jr., his son Naaman and other members of their family already have pleaded guilty to various federal charges stemming from the Champion failure.

DOC.HEAD: Business Consultant Reaps Benefits of Trump Alias
DOC.TEXT: Things have been looking up for John Baron since flamboyant developer Donald Trump disclosed his favorite alias _ John Baron. Baron's mother calls him ``The John,'' he says his children look at him with new respect and his business partners toyed with the idea of renaming their management consulting firm Greenberg, Trump, Simon & Miller. Trump acknowledged during testimony in a civil lawsuit in New York last week that he has used the name John Baron on occasion. In a letter dated Wednesday, Baron wrote Trump that use of the alias has ``my mother very proud.'' ``I ask only that you consider inviting my mother, the estimable Betty Baron, to lunch in New York as a way of thanking her. After all, it was she who came up with the name by which we both have prospered,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: AP Speeds Up PhotoStream and Picture Desk Schedules
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press will accelerate implementation of its PhotoStream network and installation of the AP Leaf Picture Desks, aiming at completing the nationwide program by the end of 1991, a year earlier than previously announced. AP President Louis D. Boccardi said Thursday the decision to attempt to speed up the installation schedule was made in response to encouragement from AP member newspapers to put the news agency's new photo system in place as soon as possible. Installations of PhotoStream and the AP Leaf Picture Desks will start in September in New York, the state in which AP will save the most money by switching from land-line transmission to satellite delivery of pictures. Installations will start in October in other northeastern states. In February 1991, installations will commence simultaneously in the three other divisions of the AP's domestic photo service _ Southeast, Central and West. Within each region, AP teams will be working in more than one state at a time, but the general order for installations is determined by where the greatest savings can be made to help pay for the program. The original timetable had called for a 28-month implementation schedule. ``But development of hardware and software has proceeded at a pace that indicates we should attempt to accomplish this enormous task in 16 months,'' Boccardi said. The pace of progress on the installations will depend on several factors, including site preparation, newsroom training and decisions by newspaper executives on how they wish to integrate the AP Leaf Picture Desk with their production systems, Boccardi said. ``We anticipate that the pace of installations will grow as AP and the members gain familiarity with what happens when the Leaf Desk arrives in the newsroom,'' Boccardi said. ``AP expects to make 30 installations by the end of 1990 and the rest through 1991.'' He said that the AP would give its members at least a quarterly update on the progress of the installation program. AP's U.S. photo network is divided into four regions with headquarters bureaus in New York, Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington. In addition to the land-line savings, the northeastern region is the first to begin conversion because of its proximity to AP's photo and computer headquarters in New York, AP's technical center in New Jersey and Leaf Systems Inc. in Massachusetts. Leaf Systems is the company that produces the AP Leaf Picture Desk. The New York region states, in order of installations, are: New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, Rhode Island, New Jersey, Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire and Connecticut. Installation will begin simultaneously in the other three regions in February 1991 in this general order: Chicago region: Texas, Ohio, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan, Iowa, Nebraska, South Dakota, North Dakota, Minnesota, Illinois, Kansas, Missouri, Wisconsin, Arkansas, Oklahoma, Colorado and Wyoming. Los Angeles region: California, Nevada, Oregon, Washington, Arizona, New Mexico, Idaho, Montana, Utah, Alaska and Hawaii. Washington, D.C., region: Louisiana, Mississippi, Tennessee, Alabama, Georgia, Florida, North Carolina, West Virginia, Virginia, South Carolina, Maryland and Delaware. Additional photo editors will be hired for the four control bureaus to edit and transmit pictures from bureaus and newspapers in the states under their jurisdiction. Additional staff also will be hired to install the darkrooms and train member newspaper staffs. Technical training for the AP staff has begun and a member training program is being designed. In addition, AP will set up a full-time Help Desk to assist members with the changeover. In the present analog photo network, black and white pictures are transmitted in about nine minutes and color pictures in 30 minutes. When fully implemented, PhotoStream will allow digital delivery of black and white pictures in one minute each and color pictures in three minutes. The AP also announced that it would use the AP Leaf Picture Desk for its internal photo computer system and would discontinue development and marketing of the AP VAX Picture Desk, which runs on Digital Equipment Corp. computers. ``The AP Leaf Picture Desk exceeds our expectations in power, speed and functionality,'' said John Reid, AP vice president and director of communications and technology. ``Work on new features is proceeding rapidly. Members attending ANPA-TEC saw the difference and demonstrated an overwhelming preference for the Leaf.'' If an AP member newspaper does not want an AP Leaf Picture Desk, it may elect to keep its present photo receiver or accept a two-minute receiver. Or it may choose to buy an electronic darkroom from another company, in which case AP will provide that member with a rebate of $47 weekly for five years, effective on the date the member would have received its AP Leaf Picture Desk. The present photo receiver will be left in place at sites where an AP Leaf Picture Desk is installed. Members receiving an AP Leaf Picture Desk and PhotoStream will be assessed a surcharge of between $15 and $80 weekly, depending on circulation.

DOC.HEAD: Decline and Fall of a Legend
With PM-Rose Sentencing, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology of the Pete Rose case:

Jan. 25 _ A Pik-Six at Cincinnati-area racetrack has two winning tickets worth $132,834.60 each. Rumors surface that Rose was one of ticket owners. March 20 _ Baseball commissioner's office releases statement that it is investigating ``serious allegations against Rose'' and that Washington lawyer John M. Dowd is heading inquiry. March 21 _ Sports Illustrated story contains allegations tying Rose to baseball betting. March 25 _ Turfway Park statement says Rose was an owner of winning Pik-Six tickets. March 26 _ The Cleveland Plain Dealer reports Rose was target of undercover gambling investigations conducted by Cincinnati police department in 1978 and 1983. April 5 _ Plain Dealer reports a man listed in court documents by code name ``G-1'' and identified by sources as Rose bet between $8,000 to $16,000 daily on baseball games during the 1987 season. April 21 _ Robert C. Brichler, an assistant U.S. attorney, says Rose is being investigated by grand jury on tax matters. May 9 _ Baseball Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti receives 225-page report on Rose from Dowd. June 21 _ The Associated Press reports baseball's handwriting expert determined Rose's writing is on betting slips. Aug. 24 _ Giamatti announces Pete Rose is banned for life from baseball for gambling. He may apply for reinstatement after one year.

April 20 _ In U.S. District Court in Cincinnati, Rose pleads guilty to two counts of filing false incomes taxes by failing to report income. July 19 _ U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel sentences Rose to five months in prison and three months in a halfway house, fines him $50,000, and orders him to perform 1,000 hours of community service with inner-city youths.

DOC.HEAD: Brando's Daughter Subpoenaed in Tahiti to Testify in Killing
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's daughter was served with a subpoena in Tahiti to testify against her half-brother, who is charged with killing her boyfriend, authorities said Thursday. It was not immediately clear whether Cheyenne Brando will return to Los Angeles in time for Monday's hearing for 32-year-old Christian Brando. An American diplomat served the notice to her in Papeete on Wednesday. Miss Brando, 20, left for French Polynesia after refusing to testify against her half-brother, who is accused of the May 16 shooting death of Dag Drollet at her father's estate in the Santa Monica mountains. The case is complicated by reports that authorities in Tahiti filed a complaint allowing them to question Miss Brando in the killing and that she was forbidden to leave French Polynesia for the time being. Further clouding the matter is that Miss Brando is believed to hold both American and French passports. Sandi Gibbons, a spokeswoman for the Los Angeles County district attorney's office, said that extradition procedures would be unnecessary in any case because Miss Brando is wanted by Los Angeles authorities as a witness, not as a suspect. Drollet, the father of Miss Brando's unborn child, was gunned down at Marlon Brando's estate. The actor was home at the time of the slaying, but he was elsewhere in the house and did not see it. Christian Brando reportedly told police that Drollet died during a struggle over a gun. Miss Brando, a native of the South Pacific islands, is the daughter of Brando and his current wife, Tarita Teriipia. Miss Teriipia is the Tahitian actress who played his love interest in the 1962 remake of ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' Miss Brando returned to French Polynesia eight months pregnant with the child of her slain boyfriend. She gave birth and is now in a Tahitian hospital undergoing treatment for nervous exhaustion. Marlon Brando maintains a home in Tahiti.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Follow Nixon Crowd
DOC.TEXT: The dedication of former president Richard Nixon's presidential library prompted protesters to show up Thursday, but not in the numbers known when he was the nation's 37th chief executive. Hundreds of noisy, clamoring demonstrators gathered Thursday evening outside the Los Angeles Century Plaza Hotel, where Nixon loyalists gathered for a gala black tie dinner. ``Heil, heil, the gang's all here,'' said one sign. ``Republican Leaders Fail People With AIDS,'' said another. ``Stop the U.S. War In El Salvador,'' said one other. A girl who appeared to be no older than 16 laid down in the middle of the street in the midst of about 50 policeman with billy clubs at the ready. The girl was wearing a sign that said, ``I died in the streets of Los Angeles homeless.'' Suddenly, without apparent provocation, three policeman rolled her on her stomach and cuffed her hands behind her back. A few minutes later, she was put aboard a police bus, loaded with what appeared to be a dozen or more people. Meanwhile, the party goers walked under the bridge on which the demonstrators were standing, few of them looking back. But some of the guests in the hotel sat on their balconies watching the scene below. At the dedication of the Nixon library earlier in the day, dozens of protesters registered objections to the former president and also criticized President Bush's handling of policy for AIDS victims. Two were ejected from the site of the dedication ceremonies in Nixon's home town of suburban Yorba Linda. Outside the library on Yorba Linda Boulevard, people waved signs saying ``He's still Tricky Dick,'' and ``Richard Repent.''

DOC.HEAD: Star-Studded Cast in Tribute to Queen Mother's 90th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Queen Mother Elizabeth sang with gusto at a gala celebrating her 90th birthday that included actors Michael Caine, Roger Moore and Howard Keel and singer Placido Domingo. The show Thursday night at the London Palladium highlighted the changing face of entertainment throughout the queen mother's nine decades, from the Edwardian music hall to pop music and the hit musical ``Phantom of the Opera.'' The 2,298-seat theater was packed and millions of Britons are expected to watch the gala when it is shown on BBC-TV on Aug. 4, the queen mother's birthday. A Noel Coward sequence was introduced by Sir John Mills, who reminded the queen mother that her ``great friend'' would also have been 90 this year. ``And I know he would have wanted to have been the first to salute you,'' Mills said. The queen mother sang along enthusiastically with Bernie Winters and Leslie Crowther when they re-enacted Flanagan and Allen routines ``Underneath the Arches'' and ``Strolling.'' After the show, she told Winters, who was a great favorite of her late husband King George VI: ``I had a little weep. The show brought back some very happy memories of my late husband.'' Placido Domingo flew in from Austria where he is rehearsing for the Salzburg Festival to sing an aria from ``Tosca,'' and ``You Are My Heart's Delight.'' Howard Keel interrupted rehearsals for ``Dallas'' in the United States to recreate the part he originally played at the Theater Royal Drury Lane in 1947 _the cowman Curly in the musical ``Oklahoma.'' Dame Kiri Te Kanawa sang both opera and songs from ``My Fair Lady'' and Michael Caine and Roger Moore hammed away as a pair of top-hatted punters in the musical's Ascot scene seeking a tip from the ``one person who knows more about racing than anyone.'' The queen mother, wearing pale green and gold and a diamond tiara, was flanked by her daughters, Queen Elizabeth II and Princess Margaret. The two-hour show ended with the whole cast led by Dame Kiri singing a special birthday song composed by Carl Davis _ ``The Most Wonderful Birthday of All'' _ and director Sir Richard Attenborough calling for three rousing cheers. Eleven service and allied charities are to share the nearly $2 million expected to be raised.

DOC.HEAD: Government Runs Home for Wayward Plants
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of the world's endangered plants, from tiny Indonesian orchids to the giant saguaro cactus of Arizona, have found a home in a cluster of government-run greenhouses where they are nursed back from the brink of extinction. ``We keep the Noah's Ark of the plant world,'' said Rob Pennington, superintendent of collections at the U.S. Botanic Garden's 20-acre Poplar Point Nursery in southeast Washington. Among the 25,000 plants that flourish in the nursery's two dozen greenhouses on the Anacostia River banks are about 3,000 rare and exotic specimens seized by customs officials at U.S. ports of entry. The plants were removed from import shipments that violated the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, a multinational accord that forbids trafficking in a long list of endangered plants and animals without strict certification. Diseased plants are destroyed immediately. The others are sent to 15 government ``plant rescue stations'' around the country, including Poplar Point, where they are nurtured and bred for scientific study and display at botanical gardens. The Botanic Garden, established by Congress in 1821, also grows plants at Poplar Point to landscape the Capitol and adjacent federal buildings and for seasonal floral displays at its conservatory, a formal greenhouse on the Mall at the foot of Capitol Hill. There are no man-eating plants in Pennington's collections, but there are extremely rare specimens of Encephalaratos lehmannii cyads from the desert region of Africa. These primitive, palm-like plants survived the dinosaur era because of their toxic trunk and roots. For centuries, they have poisoned human beings who beat the pulp into bread flour. Poplar Point also acquired hundreds of Javanicum Tortipelatum, a small, endangered orchid from Indonesia, from a grower's shipment that was confiscated in Los Angeles. They had spent six weeks in boxes without light or water. Pennington said it's a miracle that many managed to survive. Domestically, the greenhouse is the last refuge of a ``sneeze weed'' that the state of Virginia spent 30 years trying to eradicate. Also here is the insect-gobbling Saracenia Oreophila plant, now nearly extinct in its natural habitat along the Carolina and Gulf Coast shores. Poplar Point also is salvaging a majestic saguaro cactus of Arizona, once commonplace as a travel poster symbol of the arid Southwest until it was nearly bulldozed into oblivion by land developers. Pennington delights visiting school children with tales about his Pittosporum boninensis, a nondescript shrub that's nearly extinct on its native island of Chichi Jima in the Pacific Ocean. A cannibal supposedly lived there at one time. Chichi Jima became a footnote in the history books when George Bush, a young Navy pilot who later became president, ditched his crippled plane a few miles offshore after a bombing run against Japanese forces in World War II. ``I tell the kids that the cannibal used to hide in this shrubbery waiting to eat downed pilots, and that George Bush escaped with his life,'' Pennington said with a laugh. ``When you have a plant this plain and ugly, you have to think of something to tell them.'' Pennington, 36, a horticulturist trained in plant pathology, said the biggest threat to the world's tropical plants comes from runaway population growth. More and more people means destruction of forests and vast amounts of foliage for food, housing and commercial development. ``These plants are endangered because they no longer have a home when their environment is removed,'' he said. ``We provide a home for wayward plants, you might say.''

DOC.HEAD: Muslim Candidates Exploring Political Mainstream
DOC.TEXT: Like Douglas Wilder in 1989 and Andrew Young this year, Abdul Alim Muhammad is waging an uphill battle for political office. Like them he is black. But there is a difference. There is nothing colorblind about Muhammad's campaign for Congress. He is the candidate of the Nation of Islam, the fundamentalist Muslim organization long regarded as a bastion of black separatism. This year, for the first time, the group headed by Louis Farrakhan is exploring the political mainstream, running three candidates with its official endorsement. ``It is highly likely this is not the last time we are going to be involved in electoral politics,'' Muhammad said in an interview at his storefront campaign headquarters in Maryland's Prince George's County just outside Washington. The other two candidates are George Cure, a legal adviser to the Nation of Islam who is running for the District of Columbia's non-voting delegate seat in Congress, and Shawn Brakeen, a schoolteacher candidate for the district's school board. The Muslim movement has espoused racial separation since it began nearly 60 years ago, but Muhammad said, ``We have never been isolated. We believe that where we are dominant in numbers we should have a position of leadership that is representative of our numbers.'' ``My objective in Congress will be to inspire and organize and secure resources ... so that Prince George's County will be a shining light, an example of what highly motivated blacks can do to pull themselves up by their own bootstraps, so to speak,'' said Muhammad. Farrakhan has been criticized for making comments offensive to Jews and other ethnic groups, but he said recently that the Muslim candidates would represent all people, regardless of their ``race, creed or color.'' The emergence of Nation of Islam candidates comes amid growing black prominence in American politics. Wilder, the former Virginia lieutenant governor, became the nation's first elected black governor last year after successfully courting both black and white voters. Young, a civil rights leader and former mayor of Atlanta, finished second in Georgia's Democratic gubernatorial primary on Tuesday and faces a runoff Aug. 7 against Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. Some black leaders have criticized Young for running a colorblind campaign in an effort to woo white support in a state where about 22 percent of the registered voters are black. Muhammad said it was understandable for Wilder and Young to reach out to white voters, but he said such ``crossover'' politicians do not provide the same leadership for the black community as would a ``black leader.'' ``Andy Young can't win with the black vote in Atlanta,'' he said. ``He needs some of the rural white vote. To win at least some of those voters he has to be what is called a crossover candidate. ``Blacks have to understand that it is possible for blacks to be leaders in that sense. But they should not expect from this kind of crossover politician the kind of thing you would expect from a black leader.'' ``Doug Wilder has become governor of all the people of Virginia, but he should not be mistaken for a black leader who is going to do very much to correct the wrongs in the black community,'' he said. Muhammad, 42, a surgeon who is Farrakhan's spokesman, is running in the Sept. 11 primary against Steny Hoyer, chairman of the House Democratic caucus. Hoyer, 50, has represented Maryland's 5th Congressional District for four terms and is strongly favored for re-election. The district, which includes most of Prince George's County, is about evenly divided between black and white, with the black population increasing. As almost all candidates do, Muhammad said he expects to win. Hoyer, however, has a strong lead in fundraising, having raised $453,000 for his campaign before he announced. Muhammad has been raising funds among blacks in the Washington area as well as in Philadelphia and other cities. Muhammad declined to say how much had been raised but said the campaign had been advised it need not file with the Federal Election Commission. An FEC spokesman said a campaign must file with the commission if it has raised more than $5,000. Although the Nation of Islam has not previously endorsed candidates, Muhammad said, individual members have run from time to time on their own. Dr. Talib-Karim Muhammad, for instance, already has announced his candidacy for mayor of Memphis, Tenn., in an election to be held Oct. 3, 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Incendiary Device Sent to Princess Diana
DOC.TEXT: A crude incendiary device has been sent to Princess Diana at Buckingham Palace, Scotland Yard said. The palace's security system spotted it Thursday within minutes and anti-terrorist squad officers took it away for forensic examination, a police statement said. ``It must be emphasized that this crude incendiary device was not a bomb and did not originate from any terrorist organization,'' the statement said. Police sources said it was believed the work of ``a crank.'' Scotland Yard said no member of the royal family was ever at risk in the incident. The device was contained in a package addressed to the Princess of Wales and delivered to Buckingham Palace Thursday morning, the statement said. It is not known where the princess was when the package arrived. She and her husband, Prince Charles, live about a mile away at Kensington Palace when they are in London. Diana kept to her official schedule and visited a center for the elderly in southwest London Thursday morning.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Salmonella Bacteria Turning Up in U.S. Eggs
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Last year, a healthy 40-year-old man died from severe dehydration brought on by food poisoning blamed on the eggs in a meringue pie. Twenty-one guests at a baby shower in New York became ill after eating an undercooked pasta dish made with raw eggs. Six people developed the same infection after eating homemade ice cream made with eggs in Illinois. The guilty bacteria, salmonella enteritidis or SE, is turning up in more and more eggs around the country and beginning to alarm the egg industry, public health officials, agricultural community and Congress. The House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations was hearing today what the Agriculture Department is doing to stem its spread. ``The World Health Organization has characterized SE as an international epidemic,'' said a memo from the panel, chaired by Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich. ``In the United Kingdom, where the issue of SE resulted in the resignation of the minister of health, the existence of the Phase 4 SE strain has plagued the European egg industry and the health ministries.'' This particularly virulent strain has not spread in the United States, although isolated incidents have been reported in Canada and health officials here are worried, the memo said. Before 1979, only cracked eggs were believed to be likely carriers of the bacteria. Now it is believed that it comes from the hen's ovaries and can exist in the egg's yolk, according to the federal Centers for Disease Control. ``In 1982, the CDC confronted the first outbreak of egg-associated salmonella enteritidis in a restaurant in Boston's Logan Airport,'' said the memo from Dingell's committee. ``Although the CDC suspected that there may be a problem with this little-known strain of salmonella, it was not until 1986 that the CDC became convinced that the theory of bacterial transmission in an intact egg via the yolk was plausible.'' From 1985 through October 1989, a total of 6,604 illnesses and 43 deaths were blamed on the bacteria. Last year, there were 2,394 illnesses and 14 deaths and in the last six months there have been 450 cases of illness but no deaths, according to CDC statistics. The problem so far has been the worst in the Northeastern states, although it has shown up across the country. How worried should you be? Cooking expert Julia Child said it's a little like playing Russian roulette, but she protects herself by knowing where her eggs are produced. ``I eat eggs all the time, but I'm very careful where I buy them,'' Child said in a telephone interview from her home in Massachusetts. Her advice to consumers is to make sure their eggs are refrigerated from the time they are laid until they are eaten. ``If the eggs have been refrigerated, the danger is low you will have a problem,'' she said, advising that consumers leave the eggs in the box when they refrigerate them at home. The egg containers on refrigerator doors don't keep eggs as cold, she said. Eggs must be cooked at 140 degrees to kill the salmonella, according to Child. That's more heat than is needed for scrambled or poached eggs, for example. The very old, very young and very sick are the most vulnerable to death from the eggborne salmonella. ``In Pennsylvania, six nursing home patients died after eating stuffing that contained undercooked eggs,'' said the Dingell committee memo. ``Eleven died and 512 were sickened in a New York hospital after being served contaminated eggs from Maryland.'' The states and United Egg Producers are seeking action from the Agriculture Department, which is looking into the situation along with the Food and Drug Administration.

DOC.HEAD: Killer is Executed in Virginia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lead to fix dateline, logo; picks up 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A young killer was put to death in the electric chair Thursday night for the 1984 murder and robbery of an elderly widow who was serving him tea.
DOC.HEAD: Richard T. Boggs, 2nd graf
Poland Complains of Restrictions on Visitors To Soviet City
DOC.TEXT: The government has protested anti-profiteering measures in a Soviet city near the Polish border that bar foreign visitors from taking home scarce goods. The Polish Foreign Ministry will send a delegation to Lvov, 50 miles east of the border, to ``discuss the liquidation of these restrictions,'' government spokeswoman Malgorzata Niezabitowska said Thursday. The new rules that which began last Friday in Lvov apply to all foreign visitors to the former Polish city in the western Ukraine. Poles say the move is aimed mainly at them, part of a growing crackdown by Poland's neighbors on international commerce by private traders. As the Polish government has eased limitations on travel by Poles, they have gained a reputation as voracious traders, especially in goods scarce in East bloc countries or available more cheaply because of socialist-system subsidies. Meanwhile, to the north along Poland's eastern border, the crossing into Lithuania will reopen Saturday, the official Polish news agency PAP reported, quoting the Lithuanian agency ELTA. The crossing at Ogrodniki has been closed since April, when Soviet authorities imposed an economic blockade on the independence-seeking republic. The Lithuanian parliament on June 29 accepted a compromise that traded a 100-day moratorium on the declaration of independence for an immediate end to the blockade and the start of negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Drug and Child Abuse Charges Filed Against Chuck Berry
DOC.TEXT: Authorities charged rock 'n' roll great Chuck Berry with child abuse and possession of marijuana based on evidence seized in a raid on his home last month. Three charges of child abuse allege that Berry, 63, made films of nude youths under age 17 for sexual gratification. A fourth charge alleged possession of more than 35 grams of marijuana. William Hannah, St. Charles County prosecutor, announced the charges Thursday. His office said he wouldn't comment further. In a raid last month at Berry's estate near Wentzville, about 40 miles west of St. Louis, authorities said they turned up several plastic bags of marijuana, some hashish, two .22-caliber rifles and a shotgun, plus $122,000 and various pornographic videotapes, slides and books. Berry's telephone number is unlisted and calls to the office of Berry's attorney, Wayne Schoeneberg, went unanswered Thursday. After the raid, Schoeneberg had questioned the basis for Hannah's investigation. He said he believed the investigation was related to a lawsuit filed in December by a former cook at Berry's Southern Air restaurant in Wentzville. She alleged he made videotapes of her and other women as they dressed, undressed and used the toilet in the women's restroom. Last month, a class-action lawsuit was filed against Berry on behalf of 200 other women. Last month's raid came after an informant told authorities Berry had received a large amount of cocaine and would have it at his home, court documents said. But police found no cocaine. Berry, who made a surprise appearance at a news conference Hannah held after the raid, said he had never used cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Gun That Killed Colombian Presidential Candidate Came from Antigua
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian government official says a weapon used to assassinate a presidential candidate in Colombia last year was part of an arms shipment sent by Israel to Antigua. Pablo Gonzalez Monge of the Colombian attorney general's office testified Wednesday before a commission investigating the shipment of Israeli arms from Antigua to Colombian drug lord Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. Gonzalez Monge said the shipment included one rifle that was used in the August assassination of Colombian presidential candidate Luis Carlos Galan. He said the weapon was identified by its serial number. The killing sparked the Colombian government's crackdown on cocaine traffickers. Israel has accused a son of Prime Minister Vere Bird of ordering weapons for Antigua's army that wound up at a farm owned by Rodriguez Gacha. An earlier investigation determined that the arms arrived in Antigua on April 24, 1989, and left the same day. The weapons included machine guns, submachine guns, assault rifles and shoulder-fired rockets. They were seized from the farm in Colombia during an army raid in February. The Antiguan government has said it never sanctioned the arms purchase, but Israeli officials claim former National Security Minister Vere Bird Jr. made the order.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Genie Francis says she left ``General Hospital'' in 1981 at the height of her popularity as Laura because she was on the verge of an emotional breakdown. ``I was sobbing, and late to work, and you know I would go out to my car at the end of the night and just sit in the car and cry,'' Francis said Thursday on ``The Joan Rivers Show,'' which recently moved from syndication to CBS. Francis, 28, has a new role on another soap, ``All My Children.'' She was 14 when she began on ``General Hospital'' and 19 when she left. ``Most people feel that I left because I thought I was so hot that I had to go to become hotter. ... I was too embarrassed to admit that I was having all of these problems,'' she said. She said she spent thousands of dollars on therapy.

Gov. Mario Cuomo was about to sign an asset-forfeiture bill along the East River when a young woman in a passing motorboat did some forfeiting of her own. As the boat passed the pier where Cuomo stood Thursday with a small group of police and prosecutors, the woman shouted ``Hey!'' Then she waved her bra and pulled down her bathing suit bottom to moon them. Cuomo's response: ``This could never happen in Queens,'' the New York City borough where he grew up. The bill he signed allows seizure of narcotics dealers' assets.

Walter Cronkite, an avid sailor, took to the waters of San Diego Bay as the narrator of a video documentary on pollution. ``Clean air and clean water should be a birthright,'' Cronkite said after working Wednesday aboard the 68-foot yacht of naval architect Art DeFever. ``Anybody who gets out in nature understands ... what the problems are. I'm just another Joe out there worrying about what's going on,'' he said. Cronkite, 73, who owns his own yacht, donated his time to the documentary, ``Marine Pollution in San Diego _ It's All of Us.'' The video is sponsored by the non-profit San Diego Oceans Foundation, which hopes to get it aired this fall on television. It also will be made available to schools and organizations. Cronkite, the retired CBS anchorman who was once dubbed the most trusted man in America, has made several other pollution-related videos.

Kennedy matriarch Rose Kennedy, not her husband, got the family into politics, four of her five surviving children say in a story being published Sunday, her 100th birthday. The children told Parade magazine that their father, Joseph P. Kennedy, a businessman and U.S. ambassador to Great Britain, had other concerns besides politics. ``Dad was interested in achievement, not necessarily politics,'' Sen. Edward Kennedy said. Eunice Kennedy Shriver said her mother's ``great love was politics'' and recalled that her brother John F. Kennedy credited ``all the ladies' teas mother gave'' for winning him his seat in the U.S. Senate before he went on to become president.

Cable and radio talk show host Larry King will make his network TV debut Oct. 28 with an NBC interview and variety special. ``Sunday Night with Larry King'' will run for an hour and feature celebrity interviews and performances. King is the star of CNN's ``Larry King Live'' and Mutual Broadcasting's ``The Larry King Show.''

Roseanne Barr won't be trying for laughs when she sings the national anthem Wednesday before a baseball game between the Cincinnati Reds and San Diego Padres. Barr was asked to sing the anthem by Padres managing general partner Tom Werner, who is co-creator and executive producer of her ABC sitcom, ``Roseanne.'' ``I'm totally available (to sing pre-game anthems) for anybody who wants me if they pay my way,'' Barr said Thursday. Singing is part of her new standup act, but this will be the first time she has sung at a ballgame.

Singer Anita Baker says she battles paralyzing fear every time she goes on stage. ``If I let fear stop me I would never leave my house,'' the Grammy winner said Thursday on ABC's ``Good Morning America.'' ``I'm afraid to get on a plane, but I don't let it stop me. ... Every night I'm paralyzed. I have to have a few minutes of quiet just to get myself together,'' Baker said. Baker's hits include ``Giving Him the Best I've Got.'' Her new album, ``Compositions,'' sold more than 1 million copies in its first week.

DOC.HEAD: Government Wants Bigger Concession Fees
DOC.TEXT: Profits are good for food vendors and gift shops at the national parks and the Interior Department believes the government should get a bigger part of the action. Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said Thursday that in future contract talks with park concessionaires he will press for higher franchise fees. He said Uncle Sam now gets only about 2.5 percent on average of what customers pay. Lujan told a news conference he also intends to seek other changes in the park concession system to provide more competition. Several congressional panels are looking into park concessionaire profits and the lack of competition for contracts. Two recent investigations by the Interior Department concluded that park concessionaires are reaping millions of dollars in profits, while paying in some cases less than 1 percent of gross receipts to the federal government. In 1988, gross receipts of concessionaires were reported at more than $500 million, of which only $12.5 million went to the National Park Service. Lujan said he had no quarrel with the quality of park concessions in general, but he said the government should receive more money from concession revenues so parks can be improved. ``I don't think we will put any concessionaires in a position of losing money'' but the intent is to cut into ``the excessive profits,'' he said. He said the park service will push for higher franchise fees as contracts come up for renewal over the next few years. Lujan declined to say specifically how much more concessionaires should pay, saying that would tip his hand in upcoming contract negotiations. But he noted that he considers Yellowstone National Park, where the government collects fees of about 22 percent of concession receipts, as a model. Financial information from concessionaires has been difficult to obtain. When the recent Interior studies included profit figures at specific parks, the Conference of National Park Concessioners, a trade group, successfully won a court order barring disclosure of the information. Environmentalists called Lujan's announcement a good first step. ``For too long now, too many concessionaires have been getting a sweetheart deal,'' said Paul Prichard, president of the National Parks and Conservation Association. George Frampton, president of the Wilderness Society, said that while Lujan is aiming in the right direction, Congress should pass legislation to open the park concession business to competition. The Wilderness Society is considering bidding for concession rights at some parks, including Yosemite National Park in California, but Frampton said entry into the business is almost impossible because of the advantages given an incumbent concessionaire. Under the law, concessionaires are given preferential contract renewal rights that allow them to match any other bid. The government also has allowed incumbent concessionaires to value their capital improvements at parks artificially high, making it difficult for a competitor to purchase these facilities. As a result, there has been little competition for concession rights, although business at some of the parks has been highly profitable. Lujan said that of 29 contract bids that have gone out, only one has attracted competitive interest. Lujan said he hopes to make the bidding system more competitive by seeking shorter contracts, redefining what should constitute ``preferential rights'' and adopting new accounting methods when setting values for capital improvements by concessionaires. In addition, the National Park Service plans to use outside consultants to analyze concessionaires' financial statements, appraisals and other documents as part of future contract negotiations. Contract talks traditionally have been conducted by local park officials who have little financial background. While some park concessions continue to be run by small companies, concessionaires at large parks often are subsidiaries of major entertainment conglomerates, such as MCA Inc., whose Park & Curry Co. subsidiary runs concessions at Yosemite.

DOC.HEAD: Meat Critics Don't Snap at Hot Dogs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: k.d. lang correct in 8th graf bgng Lilygren noted
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights groups, at least one country singer and a former Beatle have been snapping at meat eaters lately. But none has bitten down hard on the hot dog. That's came as something of a surprise, considering it's National Hot Dog Month, the industry says. And critics might be expected to challenge this extravaganza and the 5 billion hot dogs consumed by Americans each year. But Sara Lilygren of the American Meat Institute, a national trade association, says she has heard no specific protests about hot dogs. She did, however, mention some of the general meat protests now making the rounds. ``Hot dogs have not been attacked in any big way that I know of,'' Lilygren said Thursday in a telephone interview. ``But there's something about a hot dog that's so all-American, maybe that's the reason.'' In Ames, Iowa, this week, Paul McCartney stirred resentment among many farmers in the big corn-beef-and-pork state when his anti-meat sentiments were publicized. But the former Beatle played down his vegetarianism during his concert there Wednesday night. ``We haven't come on this tour to preach against meat,'' he said. ``We're pro-corn, very pro-corn.'' That didn't stop the Maryland-based animal rights group, People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, from offering concert goers tofu ``not dogs'' as an alternative to the meat kind. Lilygren noted that Canadian-born singer k.d. lang also has been controversial with her ``Meat Stinks'' commercials for PETA, causing some Midwest radio stations to ban her albums. The institute and the National Hot Dog and Sausage Council said a joint ``full course hot dog lunch'' in Washington, D.C., recently was a howling success. More than 400 attended, including Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, who proclaimed hot dogs to be ``an American tradition,'' they said. For those who pursue trivia, the hot dog industry also provided some background: Frankfurt-am-Main, in West Germany, is traditionally credited with inventing the frankfurter in 1484. In the late 1800s, hot dogs _ also called dachshund sausages because of their shape _ gained popularity in the United States, as they had in Europe. A German butcher in New York City opened the first Coney Island hot dog stand in 1871. Hot dogs were sold at the 1893 Chicago world's fair, and they quickly became standard fare at baseball parks. ``Hot dogs earned their unique name in 1901 at the New York Polo Grounds,'' the report said. ``On a cold April day, concessionaire Harry Stevens was losing money with ice cream and cold drinks.'' Stevens, goes the legend, sent out for dachshund sausages and rolls. His vendors began hawking hot dogs from portable hot water tanks, yelling, ``They're red hot! Get your dachshund sausages while they're red hot!'' Sports cartoonist Tad Dorgan heard the vendors and drew a cartoon of barking dachshund sausages on a roll with the caption, ``Hot dog!'' The new name stuck.

A conservation group says a new survey shows most farmers would support changes in federal law that would help protect the environment. Officials of the American Farmland Trust said Thursday the survey provided ``strong evidence that farmers are more supportive of environmentally sound farming practices than their Washington lobbyists admit.'' The survey results were released as the Senate began debate on the 1990 farm bill, a complex measure that will guide U.S. farm programs and policy for the next five years. In recent months, the trust said, much of the debate about farm bill amendments has centered on alleged farmer resistance to changes in federal law that would help clean up the environment, including reduced use of chemicals and fertilizers. According to the survey, more than 70 percent of about 1,000 farmers interviewed in 22 states were ``interested in participating in a federal cost-sharing program that would reduce contamination of water through the adoption of new farm management practices.'' Further, it said, majorities of these farmers approve of pesticide and fertilizer use plans that would help farmers economize on the use of these materials. Ralph Grossi, president of the Farmland Trust, a membership organization, said he gave congressional agriculture committees high marks for their efforts to protect wetlands and set the right course on water quality planning and flexible cropland use. But he added, ``I give them very low marks on long-term soil protection, promotion of environmentally sustainable farming, and protection of farmland from urban encroachment.'' Officials said the survey was designed to reflect national attitudes. It did not show state breakdowns. The states where the survey was conducted are: Alabama, Arkansas, California, Georgia, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, Nebraska, New York, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Texas, Washington and Wisconsin.

Milk prices at the farm declined last winter but regained some of their lost ground during the spring, an Agriculture Department report said. ``However, continued substantial growth in milk production and reductions in probably swollen user inventories of non-fat dry milk likely will limit further advances in milk and dairy product prices,'' the report said Thursday. Milk production in the second half of 1990 probably will rise about 3 percent from a year earlier, the report said. That would raise total 1990 milk output by about 2 percent from last year. If wholesale prices hold relatively steady the rest of 1990, analysts said the average price increase for farm milk prices may be in the range of 3 percent to 5 percent for the entire year. Retail prices for dairy products in 1990 may be up an average of 8 percent to 10 percent from last year, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Toll Passes 600; U.S. Rescue Plane Crash Kills Crewman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. rescue plane crashing, crewman killed. Pickup 3rd graf `De Jesus...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Quake-Media, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The death toll from a devastating earthquake on central Luzon island surpassed 600 Friday, and a U.S. Marine plane crashed during rescue operations near this mountain resort. One crewman was killed. U.S. and Philippine officials said the OV-1 observation plane crashed Friday morning in the mountains near the Baguio airport, 110 miles north of the capital Manila. One crewman died and the other was rushed to a U.S. hospital in Baguio, the U.S. Embassy said. The victim's name was withheld pending notification of kin. The plane was from the Subic Bay naval base and was taking prt in efforts to rescue hundreds feared trapped by landslides triggered by Monday's quake. Jose de Jesus, chairman of presidential task force supervising recovery operations, said at least 224 people were killed in this mountain resort during the earthquake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter Scale. Two of the dead were Americans. De Jesus said more than 1,800 people were rescued from the wreckage of 27 buildings, including eight hotels severely damaged or destroyed during the temblor. He said another 129 people died in surrounding Benguet province. The latest figures brought the number killed in the quake to at least 608 with more than 1,200 others injured. The toll was expected to rise as new reports of casualties were still being received four days after the quake. About 190 people were believed buried in ruins of seven other hotels and in a factory in Baguio that caught fire after the quake, de Jesus said. Rescuers feared most were dead. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos said there were indications more deaths may have occurred in the northern province of Nueva Vizcaya than the 27 so far reported. Social Welfare Secretary Mita Pardo de Tavera said more than 70 people may have been killed in Nueva Vizcaya although the reports were still being verified. Ramos said about 900 motorists were believed stranded by landslides along the national highway along the border between Nueva Ecija and Nueva Vizcaya province, about 100 miles north of Manila. U.S. Marines and the Philippine air force planned air missions Friday to rescue passengers in about 50 buses, trucks and cars stranded along the Kennon Road, a major highway near Baguio. On Friday, a Philippine air force helicopter flying relief supplies to Baguio was forced to land in the mountains because of strong winds. There was no word on whether the crew was injured. As many as 30,000 people fled on foot from Baguio resort for the lowlands along a highway blocked by landslides, an official said. Scores of people crowded aboard military aircraft which were flying relief supplies. The U.S. military also flew about 500 Americans and Filipinos from Baguio to Clark Air Base. All roads to the city were cut off by the quake and army engineers worked to try to clear one highway. Highways Secretary Fiorello Estuar complained the exodus was delaying clearing operations. President Corazon Aquino imposed price controls Thursday on rice, pork and other staples in the quake-affected areas. American rescuers halted rescue operations Thursday at the Nevada Hotel in Baguio after recovering the bodies of Richard Finley, an official of the U.S. Agency for International Development, and Alice Laya, wife of former Education Minister Jaime Laya. Both had been attending an agency conference. Officials said about 20 Filipinos working for the organization were missing and feared dead in the hotel. U.S. officials said an American woman was killed but her name was withheld pending notification of kin. ``The rescue effort (at the Nevada) is over,'' said John Mitchell, a fireman from Miami, who was among Americans sent by the U.S. government for the rescue effort. ``Nobody's alive in there.'' Rescue efforts continued at the Hyatt, where more than 50 people were believed trapped, including five Americans. Mario Say-Ocha, a miner who volunteered to search for survivors, said the stench of death was so strong that ``it can turn your stomach.'' Benumbed survivors complained they were receiving little help from the government. ``We are trying to bring my daughter down to Nueva Ecija but we are given the runaround,'' said Ricardo Manalastas, whose daughter Marissa, 21, was killed. ``If I can just carry my daughter's body over my shoulders, I will do so.'' In Cabanatuan, 60 miles north of Manila, British technicians using sensor devices found no signs of life in the debris of the six-story Philippine Christian College. Hundreds of students and teachers were trapped when the building collapsed. Rescuers found 137 survivors and 60 dead in Cabanatuan. British rescuers said sensors indicated about 25 bodies remained buried. In La Union province, officials reported widespread damage in several towns, including Agoo where the municipal hall, public market and a church collapsed. Officials complained aid was slow in coming. Edgar Bacungan, mayor of Caba in La Union, said most of the 15,000 residents were camping out in front of the town auditorium because so many homes were damaged or destroyed. ``We don't have any tents,'' he said. ``The children are getting sick.'' In Manila, Rep. Rolando Andaya, chairman of the House appropriations committee, said he would propose a two-year suspension of payments on the country's $26 billion foreign debt to free funds for reconstruction. The House resumes sessions Monday after the summer recess, and Andaya said he expected the resolution to pass easily. Preliminary estimates place quake damage at more than $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: French, Italian Presidents Mark Anniversary of Mont Blanc Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of Italy and France celebrated the 25th anniversary of the Mont Blanc tunnel that runs through the Alps and connects their countries. They said it symbolizes European unity. About 100 environmentalists demonstrated at Thursday's celebration to protest a proposal to double the capacity of the tunnel under 15,000-foot Mont Blanc, the highest peak in the Alps. French President Francois Mitterrand, with Italian President Francesco Cossiga at his side, said no decision had been made on expansion but that the nations ``must look ahead to new passages through the Alps.'' He praised the tunnel as ``a precursor to the barriers falling around Europe.'' Any expansion proposal should include a high-speed train link between France and Italy, Mitterrand said, although a final decision can wait for a few years. Annual traffic through the tunnel has more than tripled since it opened 25 years ago. In 1989, 1,821,698 vehicles passed through, compared to 592,450 in 1966. An estimated 29 million vehicles have since made the 7.2-mile passage between Chamonix, France and Aoste, Italy.

DOC.HEAD: In a Summer of Sequels, Along Comes a Spider ... and a Bear
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Forget Bruce Willis, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Tom Cruise. The new stars of the summer are a spooky spider and a bubbly bear. The mega-budget, male-oriented films ``Die Hard 2,'' ``Total Recall'' and ``Days of Thunder'' have yet to excite moviegoers the way last summer's ``Batman'' did. But the Walt Disney Co. hopes its ``Arachnophobia'' and ``Jungle Book'' can find loyal patrons in the crowded summer film season. There's no way ``Arachnophobia'' will match ``Batman,'' which made $252 million in 1989. The eight-legged drama does have the potential, though, to emerge as one of the season's sleeper successes. In a campaign littered with hardware-laden projects aimed at young males, ``Arachnophobia'' and Paramount's ``Ghost,'' two modest, original works, appear to have a good chance of reaching a broader audience. There are signs that a share of the audience is more interested in novel, non-sequel titles than the more heavily promoted and expensive cookie-cutter films. ``Jungle Book,'' the 1967 film re-released last Friday by Disney, enjoyed the best opening ever for an animated movie with $7.7 million last weekend, surpassing the $7.5 million collected by ``The Land Before Time'' in its debut weekend in 1988. On Wednesday, ``Arachnophobia,'' starring Jeff Daniels and John Goodman, opened to moderate but unspectacular business of about $1.2 million on more than 1,200 screens. ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit,'' by comparison, grossed $1.8 million in its first night on 999 screens two summers ago. On Tuesday, Walt Disney Co. President Frank Wells predicted the thriller, the first release from Disney subsidiary Hollywood Pictures, would be one of the season's biggest hits. The head of marketing for a competing studio, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said ``Arachnophobia'' should open slowly and build forcefully on strong word of mouth. (It's pronounced ah-rak'-nah-foh'-bee-yah.) CinemaScore, which tracks audience reactions to movies, said the film scored a B+ in surveys of 335 patrons Wednesday. That places it alongside ``Dick Tracy,'' but below ``Ghost,'' ``Days of Thunder'' and ``Die Hard 2,'' all of which earned an A rating. Among the summer releases that have been savaged by reviewers are ``RoboCop 2,'' ``Betsy's Wedding,'' ``Fire Birds,'' ``The Adventures of Ford Fairlane,'' ``Cadillac Man,'' ``Quick Change'' and ``Ghost Dad.'' ``Arachnophobia'' is about the invasion of a small California town by a deadly South American spider. In ``Ghost,'' a murdered man's spirit comes back to protect his lover and solve his own slaying. On Monday and Tuesday nights, ``Ghost'' quietly made more money than Bruce Willis' noisy ``Die Hard 2,'' even though the latter film, made at an estimated cost of a staggering $62 million, was playing on more than twice as many screens. While there's no ``Batman'' this summer, the season, now halfway finished, is hardly fizzling. In fact, it likely will be the second-best in Hollywood history, and it easily should exceed the 1988 holiday season returns of $1.7 billion. ``The business of some of these movies is incredible,'' said Tom Sherak, president of domestic distribution and marketing for 20th Century Fox. ``Shame on everybody for comparing it to last year.'' Said Barry London, president of Paramount's motion picture group: ``Some films, depending on who was in them and the kind of film they were, were coming in with unreasonably high expectations.'' The trade newspaper Daily Variety is predicting this summer's box-office take will be about $1.85 billion, compared with the record-setting 1989 summer when moviegoers spent $2.04 billion. ``You can't expect records to be broken every week,'' said John Krier, president of Exhibitor Relations Co. Inc., which tracks box-office figures. ``But it's a good summer.''

DOC.HEAD: House Of Commons Votes To Make TV Coverage Permanent
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons has voted to make television coverage of its often rowdy proceedings permanent. The 131-32 vote Thursday night followed an eight-month experiment that began Nov. 21 with TV cameras recording selected sessions of the proceedings. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was among those who initially opposed TV coverage, but the Conservative Party leader later changed her mind. Opponents said they feared for the reputation of the House because of frequent boisterous behavior among legislators. Bruce Grocott of the opposition Labor Party, a member of the committee and a former TV producer, said TV audiences for ``question time,'' the twice weekly session when the prime minister answers legislators' questions, ranged from 800,000 to 2 million. The sessions are noted for sharp exchanges between Mrs. Thatcher and Labor leader Neil Kinnock. Mrs. Thatcher's replies and questions by Kinnock and other legislators are often drowned out as rival legislators bellow insults and the Speaker of the House, Bernard Weatherill, bawls ``order! order!'' The House of Lords, the unelected upper chamber of Parliament, has had TV coverage since 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Launches Study of Mercury Contamination in Amazon Rivers
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to clean up one of the largest waterways in the Amazon rain forest where illegal gold miners have dumped mercury, officials say. ``Without a doubt, there is an ecological time bomb set to go off in the Tapajos river,'' geologist Elmer Salomao, director of the National Department of Mineral Production, said in an interview Thursday. Salamao said about 600 tons of mercury have been dumped since 1980 into the Tapajos, a 37,200-square-mile basin and tributary of the Amazon river located in the northern Amazon state of Para. The government plans to decontaminate the river with a $200 million World Bank loan after a study is completed in December, Salamao said. Prospectors use mercury in gold panning to join gold dust particles.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Leader Says Further Durenberger Sanctions Unwarranted
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate Republican conference says Sen. Dave Durenberger is being punished enough for ethics violations and he doesn't plan to take any action against him. The GOP caucus could strip the 12-year senator from Minnesota of his seniority or choice committee assignments. ``He has been examined quite thoroughly here,'' said Ed Quinlan, a spokesman for Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I. ``It would seem that there's no need for another entity to deal with these events.'' The Senate Ethics Committee on Thursday recommended the full Senate denounce Durenberger for ``reprehensible'' financial conduct and require him to make up to $124,000 in restitution. The committee said Durenberger violated Senate rules by laundering speaking fees through a book contract and claiming reimbursement for staying in a Minneapolis condominium in which he owned an interest. The committee referred its findings to the Senate Republican conference as well as the Justice Department and the Federal Election Commission. The GOP conference has no plans to pursue the matter and no member has suggested disciplining Durenberger, Quinlan said. ``The language in the (Ethics Committee) report states that there was no criminality, that there was no malice demonstrated by his behavior, that Sen. Durenberger has publicly apologized for his judgment and that's where it should lie,'' Quinlan said. Chafee, who considers Durenberger a personal friend, contributed $1,000 to Durenberger's legal defense fund, according to records released this week. He was the only sitting member of Congress to do so. During its secret deliberations, the Ethics Committee rejected a proposal to recommend that Republicans take away Durenberger's committee seats, including a prized spot on the tax-writing Finance Committee, said Lois West, Durenberger's press secretary. Durenberger agreed to reimburse the Senate $29,050 plus interest for payments on his Minneapolis condominium and give to charities $95,000 that he received in excess speaking fees, less whatever taxes he paid on the income. Durenberger has already repaid $11,005 in condominium payments to which the Senate Rules Committee said he wasn't entitled. He has paid $212,000 in legal fees, mostly from his campaign treasury, and says he still owes about $377,000.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Adviser Disputes `Prophets of Decline-ism'
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's chief economic adviser is taking out after ``prophets of decline-ism'' who are forecasting America is fast becoming a second-rate economic power. Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, says he is tired of hearing America is losing its competitive edge to countries such as Japan or that the country is losing control of its economic destiny to foreign investors who are buying up America. ``The United States has not lost and is not losing its position as the world's leading economic power,'' Boskin said Thursday in a speech to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. ``The fact is that with less than 5 percent of the world's population, we produce 26 percent of the world's gross national product,'' Boskin said. Boskin conceded that the country does face problems, listing in particular the need to shrink the federal budget deficit and improve a weak elementary and secondary school system, which he called ``an outright disgrace and a ticking time bomb.'' But Boskin said the United States can muster the political will to correct its own problems. ``The real challenges facing the American economy are significant, but this does not mean that the U.S. economy will inevitably become second-class as the prophets of decline-ism would have us believe,'' Boskin said in a speech previewing economic themes likely to be used by Republicans during the fall congressional campaigns. ``The United States is large and strong, indeed pre-eminent in the world. Its future is neither bleak nor predetermined,'' he said. ``Our destiny is overwhelmingly in our own hands.'' Boskin attacked Democratic critics who have been pushing for the administration to close U.S. markets to foreign goods in retaliation for other countries erecting barriers to American products. He said it is ``wrongheaded'' to call for the federal government to take a more active role in promoting commercial research and development projects normally done by private industry. This approach, sometimes called an industrial policy, is modeled after the success Japan's powerful Ministry of International Trade and Industry has supposedly achieved in promoting the economic interests of Japanese businesses. Boskin said proponents of this approach chose to ignore the failures of Japanese government planners, such as their suggestion many years ago that Sony Corp. would have more success if it did not get into the home electronics field. Boskin also dismissed forecasts that the current economic expansion of nearly eight years _ the longest in peacetime history _ is in imminent danger of ending in a recession. ``This expansion can, should and most likely will continue for some time to come,'' he said. ``The most likely outcome is that after a period of a few quarters of slower growth, we will see the economy pick up the pace in the second half of this year.''

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Insist on Purge of Military in Peace Talks Opening Today
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders are sticking to a stance they had when the last peace talks failed _ that the government must purge the army of rights abusers. The talks scheduled to resume today in San Jose, Costa Rica, are the third round of U.N.-mediated negotiations that started in Venezuela in May. Rebel leaders say they are preparing for a military offensive like one in November, their largest ever, if the new round of talks fails to produce results on the issue of the armed forces. The leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, has fought a series of U.S.-backed governments in a 10-year-old civil war that has claimed some 72,000 lives. ``There is a sector of the armed forces that must pay the bill for so much oppression imposed on the counry,'' guerrilla commander Schafik Handal, the chief rebel negotiator, said in an interview with The Associated Press at the rebels' Mexico City office. This issue of the role of the military was a major sticking point in the last round of talks held in Mexico in June between the rebels and the conservative government of President Alfredo Cristiani. Salvadoran Defense Minister Gen. Humberto Larios said the army will handle the hiring and firing in its ranks. ``We do not reject the idea of purifying our institution. The armed forces, like any other insitution is subject to evolution, to improvement,'' Larios said in a recent interview. But he said, ``We are purifying ourselves.'' Since 1979, troops and death squads linked to them have executed about 30,000 people suspected of leftist sympathies, international human rights groups say. No officer has been tried or found guilty for such crimes. The U.S. Congress, the financial underwriter of the Salvadoran government's war effort, plans to tie military aid for 1991 to progress made in peace talks and to prosecution of army officers responsible for a November massacre of six Jesuit priests. The war could drag on for years if the military is not restructured, Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn, said this week, adding that about 50 high-ranking army men should be eliminated. ``Fifty seems to us a low number,'' said Handal. Top guerrilla leaders have suggested that 200 officers should be dropped from the ranks. Handal said the army's efforts at self-purification have been so ineffectual that rebel leaders are proposing abolishment of the institution in a ``demilitarization'' process that would also mean the disappearance of the guerrilla fighters. ``If Larios maintains that the army is being constantly `purified' and nevertheless it continues to play the role of repressor, then it's obvious that `purification' is not enough to clean it up. It should be abolished flat-out, which is our conclusion,'' Handal said. The Costa Rican army was abolished in 1949. Costa Rica is the only country in Central America that can claim a stable democracy throughout recent decades. The rebels proposes a police force under civilian command to maintain law and order after demilitarization. The military is dead set against the idea, and has gotten Cristiani's backing. ``The continued existence of the armed forces is not a subject of discussion,'' the president said after last month's five-day round of negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Yeats Notebook Sells for $360,000
DOC.TEXT: A notebook in which William Butler Yeats wrote much of his poetry and prose over three years sold at Sotheby's for $360,000, the auctioneers said. The notebook was part of a sale Thursday of English literary and historical manuscripts and books that totaled $2.13 million, Sotheby's said. Other items included letters written by Indian independence leader Mohandas K. Gandhi and a script for a James Bond movie. H.D. Lyon, a London dealer, bought the Yeats notebook. The seller was not identified but was believed to be a collector. In 1923, Yeats became the first Irishman to win the Nobel Prize for literature. The Great Vellum Notebook, as the manuscript is known, contains 380 pages and was used by Yeats from November 1930 to the summer of 1933, six years before his death. A collection of 76 unpublished autograph letters written by the Indian independence leader, Mohandas K. Gandhi, to his eldest son, Harilal, between 1900 and 1914 was bought anonymously for $50,000. In the letters, Gandhi offered advice on sex, counseling celibacy, and on diet, praising onions and deploring chocolates. The working film scripts for the first James Bond film, ``Dr. No,'' by British screenwriter Wolf Mankowitz, sold at three times their estimate for $5,000. They were bought by Quaritch, a London dealer known for rare books.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,421.52, down 634.10, or 1.92 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Government Shelling Forces Cambodian Guerrillas From Town
With PM-US-Cambodia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Non-communist Cambodian guerrillas say heavy government shelling has forced them out of a central Cambodian town that functioned as the capital of the territory they control. Guerrillas loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk retreated along with civilians Thursday to the outskirts of the town, Stoung, in Kompong Thom province, said spokesman Roland Eng. He said government forces had rained artillery and multiple rocket launchers for two days, and some civilians were hurt. Neither side held Stoung today, but some guerrillas have returned there, Eng said in a telephone interview from his Bangkok office. The guerrillas said they took Stoung on April 12, and since used it as an administrative and communications base for wide areas of the province they have seized. Eng denied a statement from the Vietnamese-installed government that it had retaken Stoung last Sunday. Stoung is only about 95 miles north of the national capital, Phnom Penh. It was the most populated town under guerrilla control with tens of thousands of residents. Sihanouk's forces are allied in a guerrilla coalition with the communist Khmer Rouge and the non-communist fighters of former Prime Minster Son Sann. They are fighting the government Vietnam installed in Phnom Penh after invading the country in late 1978 to topple a Khmer Rouge government. Sihanouk said Thursday his forces were more determined than ever to fight after the U.S. announced a day earlier that it was withdrawing recognition of the coalition's seat at the United Nations. The U.S. shift was prompted by fears of a return to power of the Khmer Rouge, the strongest rebel force. While in power from 1975-78, hundreds of thousands of people died as a result of a radical program to turn the country into an agrarian commune.

DOC.HEAD: Income Growth Shows Sun Belt-Frost Belt Split
DOC.TEXT: Regional economic growth in the United States is shifting away from the bi-coastal pattern of the 1980s and returning to the Sun Belt-Frost Belt split of the 1970s, a government report indicates. The Commerce Department said Thursday that personal incomes grew fastest in western states and slowest in New England between the first quarter of 1989 and the January-March period of this year. By region, incomes in the Far West grew 8.5 percent; Southeast, 7.2 percent; Rocky Mountain states, 7.1 percent; Southwest and Mid-Atlantic states, 7 percent; Plains states, 6.8 percent; Great Lakes states, 5.5 percent and New England, 5.2 percent. Eight of the 11 states with fastest income growth were in the West, while four of the nine states with the slowest growth were in New England. Economists who follow regional patterns said Thursday's report provided evidence that the bi-coastal economy of the 1980s, in which California and the Northeast enjoyed more prosperity than the nation's heartland, is over. ``We are returning to an economic pattern that we saw 15 to 20 years ago,'' said economist Robert Dye of The Wefa Group, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., forecasting firm. Growth rates among the top 11 ranged from Nevada's 12.2 percent, the fastest in the United States, to Oregon and California's 8.2 percent. That compares with a national average over the period of 6.9 percent. Rates in other states in the top 11 were: Hawaii, 9.9 percent; Alaska, 9.8 percent; Washington, 9.6 percent; Idaho, 9.2 percent; Kansas, 8.9 percent, and Utah, Florida and Minnesota, 8.4 percent. The states with the slowest income growth were: North Dakota, 2.3 percent; South Dakota, 3 percent; New Hampshire, 3.6 percent; Montana, 4 percent; Indiana and Maine, 4.4 percent; Massachusetts, 4.6 percent; West Virginia, 4.9 percent and Rhode Island, 5 percent. Economist Mark Zandi of Regional Financial Associates, a West Chester, Pa., consulting firm, said a booming casino industry and related construction are keeping Nevada growing. Growth in the Northeast is being fueled by strong lumber exports, a flood of orders for civilian aircraft to Boeing Co. and heavy migration of Californians looking for a more affordable place to live, he said. Meanwhile, declines in real estate construction, high-tech companies, defense contracting and banking are crimping New England's income growth, he said. ``In New England, all the industries that supported the economy are in recession,'' he said. According to the Commerce Department, a rebound in farm income helped Kansas this year after drought shriveled the state's winter wheat crop in 1989. Zandi said Florida and California were two high-growth states in danger of cooling off. Migration and tourism have been supporting the Florida economy, but when national economic growth softens, as it has this year, fewer people take vacations, he said. Also, lackluster real estate markets in the Northeast make it more difficult for retirees to sell their houses and move south, he said. ``California is at risk because ... housing is extremely unaffordable in most parts of the state. Crime, pollution and congestion are all problems that are going to slow migration flows,'' he said. ``You're probably not going to see a California recession, but you will see much slower growth,'' Zandi said.

DOC.HEAD: House Restores Proposed Cuts in Drug Program Funding
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats are backing away from a threatened $231 million cut in the administration's anti-drug programs following a name-calling exchange with drug policy director William J. Bennett. The House agreed Thursday to restore the proposed cut in fiscal 1991 drug education and treatment programs as it approved a $170 billion appropriations bill covering labor, health and education spending. The outspoken Bennett had denounced Congress as ``cheap, dishonest and sneaky'' after the House Appropriations Committee last week approved a bill that contained cuts in President Bush's requests for drug demand-reduction programs. Bush had sought $252 million, but the panel approved only $21 million. ``I just resent that,'' Rep. Silvio Conte of Massachusetts, ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee, said of Bennett. ``He didn't just say Democrats. He said we're all a bunch of clowns up here.'' ``Bill Bennett has lost his effectiveness with the Congress,'' said Rep.
