Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., chairman of the House select committee on narcotics. ``He has now seen fit to insult the Congress rather than consult the Congress.'' The House approved the appropriations bill 359-58, after defeating a series of amendments that would have cut total spending. Democrats have strongly criticized Bennett in the past for not putting enough money into and emphasis on treatment and education. Bennett's discovery of the hidden cuts _ which were never debated in public sessions _ politically embarrassed House Democrats. Rep. William H. Natcher, D-Ky., chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that wrote the bill, offered an amendment on the floor that restored the cuts. The amendment was sought by House Democratic leaders and approved on a voice vote, but only after congressmen paraded before the podium to attack Bennett. ``If our drug czar is going to wind up hyperventilating in public every time he doesn't get a dollar he wanted, then I suggest he go back to chain smoking so he can calm down,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis. Bennett said later he was pleased the money was restored and that the changes represented drug treatment for as many as 100,000 people. ``I know Democrats are upset. I know some Republicans are upset, too. And I'm sorry about the rancor this has caused,'' Bennett said. ``But we needed this money. We were taken completely by surprise on these cuts, and raising a ruckus seemed the only way to get this money back.'' Appropriations Committee members said they had agreed to the cuts because much of the money in the programs' 1990 budget had not yet been spent. Natcher, in an interview, said only 29 percent of $1.1 billion in block grants to the states for drug treatment had been spent in the first 9{ months of the current fiscal year. ``I don't want to get in any disagreement with Bill Bennett,'' Natcher said. ``Sometimes you can get a little mad and say things you shouldn't. ... Bill Bennett was mad, and I'm not.'' The programs targeted for cuts included a block grant program to states to finance drug treatment programs, an Education Department program for drug education in the schools and funding for local assistance for treatment. The bill provides $7.6 billion for the Department of Labor in fiscal 1991. It authorizes $135.7 billion for the Department of Health and Human Services, $26 billion for the Department of Education, and $1 billion for related agencies. The total represents a $17.3 billion increase over 1990 spending and a $4.2 billion increase over the amount requested by Bush in his proposed 1991 budget.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush Shows Practical Side Again
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush had lots of practical reasons to decide to open talks with Vietnam about the war in neighboring Cambodia. The question now is whether he acted in time. The Khmer Rouge, which massacred hundreds of thousands of Cambodians when it ran the Southeast Asian country from 1975 to 1978, is advancing toward the capital, Phnom Penh. The Khmer Rouge poses a far more serious threat to the Cambodian people than the pro-Vietnam government the United States has been trying to upset with millions of dollars of aid to insurgents, some of it covert. Bush's decision, which was urged on him by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, means talking to the Vietnamese about holding multi-party elections in Cambodia. It also may lead to U.S. recognition of Vietnam, a lowering of a 15-year trade embargo and perhaps a slowdown of the tragic exodus of ``boat people.'' Many of these Vietnamese economic refugees, if they survive, reach Malaysia or Hong Kong only to be pushed off. Those are some of the practical steps that could follow this latest decision by a practical president who won the White House disguised as a conservative ideologue but mostly is a politician who keeps his ear close to the ground. Another step could be to encourage Vietnam, which has sent troops and advisers back into Cambodia after last year's pullout, to step up the pressure on the Khmer Rouge. Whether Bush takes that nervy last step remains to be seen. But for now, at least, he has stopped trying to isolate Vietnam diplomatically. Even though he isn't ready to normalize relations with Hanoi or authorize talks with the Cambodian government, Bush is no longer shunning the two countries as puppets of Moscow. The policy shift is hardly unprecedented. Bush has switched on taxes. He has dropped his suspicions about Mikhail Gorbachev. And, most of all, he has concluded the Cold War is over and is making military decisions accordingly. Pressure from Congress played a part in these turnabouts. And Congress was moving to choke off aid to the Cambodian guerrillas when the policy shift was hatched last Friday at the White House. But Bush and Baker, his pragmatic adviser, also were guided by other practical considerations. One was successful cooperation with the Soviet Union in other regional disputes. The next dividend could be an agreement on how to end the 12-year war in Afghanistan. The most practical reason of all, however, was to try to staunch the bloodletting in Cambodia. The guerrillas were unable to contain the Khmer Rouge, Baker said in announcing the policy shift Wednesday in front of the U.S. Embassy in Paris. ``The fighting continues,'' he said. ``Cambodians continue to suffer and Cambodians continue to die.'' So Bush has put aside two decades of U.S. hostility toward Hanoi and effectively withdrew diplomatic recognition of the rebels trying to overthrow Prime Minister Hun Sen in Phnom Penh. The Khmer Rouge are by far the most powerful of the three guerrilla factions. Until now, the Bush administration hoped the coalition with the factions headed by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann would be able to defeat the Cambodian army or at least fight it to a draw, thereby bringing about elections. This scenario depended also on the Khmer Rouge playing a benign role in the transition to a new government. But the history of the Khmer Rouge provides no evidence of restraint or of submission to popular will. The massacres they conducted in the name of agrarian reform when they ran the country matched the worst holocausts of the century. Jeremy Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists, has been campaigning for the policy shift for a long time. ``It was probably inevitable,'' he said Thursday. ``The one question smart guys all over town have been asking the administration was what if your coalition wins? At some point before a Khmer Rouge victory the State Department had to come to its senses.'' Stone is convinced that Vietnamese military advisers combined with Cambodian forces can stop the Khmer Rouge. And, he said, ``we've got to stop threatening the Phnom Penh government so it can hold the multi-party elections it has already agreed to hold.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is The Associated Press' chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: Banking Committee Chairman Giving Donations to Government
DOC.TEXT: Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle says he is giving away the campaign money he got from savings and loan interests and will accept no more. ``The magnitude of the problems in the S&L industry _ stemming from multiple causes over a 15-year period _ leave a shadow across the industry and across any campaign contributions from that industry,'' Riegle, D-Mich., said in a statement Thursday. Riegle is one of five senators under investigation by the Ethics Committee for intervening with federal regulators on behalf of Charles H. Keating Jr., former owner of the failed Lincoln Savings and Loan. The government seized the Irvine, Calif. thrift last year, a move expected to cost taxpayers $2 billion. Riegle said he would give the federal government a check for about $120,000. It will cover all the money he has received from thrift interests except for $78,250 from Keating and his associates, which Riegle returned in 1988. He said he no longer will accept contributions from political action committees representing any company whose principal business is under his panel's jurisdiction. He also is forswearing donations from officers of such companies, as well as fundraising events of their sponsorship. Riegle said there were ``no personal conflicts of interest in any of these contributions given in past years,'' and that ``all were legal, proper and publicly recorded.'' He said he considered it appropriate to give his remaining S&L money to the government rather than to the original contributors. In March 1987, Keating hosted a fund-raiser for Riegle at the Pontchartrain Hotel in Detroit. A year later, Riegle returned $78,250 given by 77 individuals who listed 13 separate business connections after The Detroit News disclosed their ties to Keating. The News reported last week that Riegle received $7,250 from individuals associated with Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver, Colo., in 1987. He visited the thrift and met with board members, including President Bush's son, Neil. Silverado collapsed a year later and its bailout is expected to cost $1 billion. Riegle was re-elected to a third term in 1988. He became chairman of the Banking Committee last year. He has come under fire in Michigan for accepting generous contributions from the thrift industry while a ranking member of the banking committee _ particularly after the S&L crisis arose. Common Cause, the self-styled citizens' lobby, reported recently that Riegle was Congress' second-largest recipient of S&L donations in the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: New Technique May Give Earthbound Telescopes Clearer View Than Hubble
DOC.TEXT: New technology may give ground telescopes a clearer view of the stars than is possible from a repaired Hubble Space Telescope and at only a fraction of the cost, according to a study published today. Horace W. Babcock, the former director of the Carnegie Institution observatories, said in the journal Science that new telescope systems now being developed hold the promise of seeing stellar objects as far away as those thought to be visible only by a perfectly working Hubble. Babcock said the new system uses a mirror that can be warped, or deformed, in a systematic way to compensate for the distortion of the atmosphere. The process is called ``adaptive optics.'' ``Adaptive telescopes in the infrared will not match the resolution of the HST (Hubble Space Telescope), but in the visible they may exceed it,'' Babcock's paper said. Babcock said in an interview that even if the new telescope concepts fulfill their promise, orbiting observatories still are needed because the Earth's atmosphere scatters light in some parts of the spectrum, such as the ultraviolet. Only telescopes in space, above the atmosphere, could collect such light, he said. But for visible light, he said, adaptive optics could allow ground telescopes to match or exceed the capabilities of Hubble. ``These are more than just dreams,'' Babcock said. The European Southern Observatory in South America already is experimenting with adaptive optics and ``has proven the value of these systems'' in the infrared portion of the spectrum, he said. To adapt the technique for the visible spectrum will require more experiments, he said, but researchers already have proven elements of the system. Installing adaptive optics in a new telescope, Babcock said, would be ``only a fraction of the total cost'' of the Hubble. He said an 8-meter telescope could be built at some locations for about $40 million. NASA spent $1.5 billion to build the space telescope. Engineers learned last month that it is crippled by a mirror that gives an out-of-focus view of the universe. The flaw may be corrected in 1993 when a new camera is installed. John Manges, an optics engineer on the Hubble project at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, said adaptive optics on ground telescopes could exceed the clarity of Hubble ``in years to come, eventually.'' Even now, he said, ``adaptive optics are getting competitive with the Hubble in the visible region.'' But Manges pointed out that even with new ground systems, an orbiting telescope would have an advantage because it would not be affected by weather or clouds. Ground observatories cannot work on cloudy nights and some are affected by high winds. An orbiting telescope also is able to observe in the ultraviolet portion of the spectrum, which is impossible from the ground, he said. Babcock said the adaptive optics system works by using a mirror that changes shape rapidly with computer instructions. ``When the right instructions are sent to a deformable mirror, it deviates from flatness in such a way to correct for the distortions caused by the atmosphere,'' he said. ``This will compensate almost entirely for the distortion.'' A telescope with adaptive optics will first focus on a bright star and use the twinkling light to establish a pattern. The shape of the deformable mirror then is changed as needed to compensate for the twinkle caused by the atmosphere. Babcock said the optics, in effect, create a circle of compensation through which the telescope could look far into the universe. ``Any faint object, if it falls within that circle, can be observed with very high resolving power,'' he said. Asked if such a telescope could see objects 14 billion light years away, which is the range expected from a perfectly working Hubble, Babcock said, ``There is no reason why it shouldn't work at such a distance.'' Science, which published the report, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Find Molecule That Blocks AIDS Spread to Healthy Cells
DOC.TEXT: A synthetic protein molecule attaches itself tightly to an AIDS virus in test tube experiments and prevents the virus from infecting healthy cells, according to a report published today. Researchers at Harvard said in a study in the journal Science that the manmade molecule, called CPF, prevents a molecule on the surface of the AIDS virus from adhering to the immune cells it usually attacks. ``The CPF very effectively prevents the AIDS virus from binding (sticking to a target cell) and this inhibits the spread of the virus,'' said Steven J. Burakoff, a researcher at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute, an affiliate of Harvard University. Burakoff said CPF ``is also very inexpensive and very simple to synthesize.'' The Harvard researchers found CPF while studying the chemistry of how the AIDS virus _ called human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV _ is able to attach itself to T-lymphocytes, blood cells that are part of the immune system and a principal target of the AIDS virus. HIV attacks T cells by using its surface molecule, called gp120, to attach to a molecule called CD4 on the outside wall of a T cell. In effect, the gp120 acts as a key to open the lock on the surface of the T cell. The virus can then move inside. A molecule that sticks to the gp120, would, in effect, prevent the key from fitting in the lock on the T cell surface, Burakoff said. This, he said, would keep healthy cells from becoming infected. In laboratory experiments, Burakoff said, the Harvard group exposed AIDS virus to CPF and found that the manmade molecule stuck so firmly to gp120 that it could not be washed off. Burakoff said the group then exposed an AIDS virus bound with the CPF to healthy T cells. The AIDS virus, which would normally attack the T cells with ease, was unable to cause an infection. Next, Burakoff said, AIDS-infected T cells were put in a test tube with both healthy T cells and CPF. The synthetic molecule, he said, prevented the virus from spreading from the infected T cells to the uninfected cells. ``We found it to be very, very effective,'' said Burakoff. ``In the test tube, anyway, the CPF molecules look very interesting.'' The researcher said that tests of the molecule in laboratory animals are just beginning and that there are ``many hurdles to go over'' before the compound could be tested in human patients. Another AIDS researcher, Dr. Allen Goldstein of the George Washington University School of Medicine in Washington, said the research was ``very solid'' but noted, ``There's a long way to go before you could translate that into a clinical application.'' Goldstein said that CPF joins ``a whole bunch of potential antivirals'' that need to be tested further. Before such a molecule is useful as a drug, he said, researchers will have to show that it is effective in a concentration that the body can tolerate and that it affects only the target virus. ``It would have a major problem in the body if it will stick to lots of other things,'' said Goldstein. Burakoff said CPF is composed of two amino acids, proline and phenylalanine, and is a small molecule. ``Being small, there is a reasonable chance that it can be given orally,'' he said. ``And the fact that it can be synthesized means it can easily be modified to improve it.'' The CPF research was a combined effort by Burakoff's Dana-Farber group and the Harvard University Department of Chemistry. Science magazine is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Chronological Highlights of North and South Korean Relations
With PM-Korea, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Korean peninsula was divided into Communist North Korea and capitalist South Korea at the end of World War II in 1945. Following is a chronology on relations. Aug. 15, 1945: Korea was liberated from 35 years of Japanese colonial rule. In the post-war politics Korea was divided along the 38th parallel with Soviet Union troops in the North and U.S. troops in the South. 1948: North Korea established a communist dictatorship headed by Kim Il Sung. South Korea held elections and established a U.S.-supported government headed by Syngman Rhee. 1950: North Korea invaded South Korea, triggering a bitter three-year civil war. An estimated 2.4 million soldiers and 4.4 million civilians were killed or wounded on both sides. 1953: The Korean War ended with an armistice and a 2.5-mile-wide Demilitarized Zone was established, dividing the peninsula. A peace treaty was never signed. 1968: A group of 31 North Korean commandos tried unsuccessfully to assassinate then-president Park Chung-hee; the U.S. reconnaissance ship Pueblo was captured by North Korea for allegedly sailing into its territorial waters. The crew was released 11 months later. 1972: The Koreas issued a joint statement renouncing hostilities and pledging peaceful unification of the peninsula, but talks fail. 1974: The first of four tunnels allegedly dug by North Korea for an invasion under the Demilitarized Zone was unearthed by South Korea. Other tunnels were found in 1975, 1978 and 1990. North Korea denied digging them. 1976: North Korean security guards killed two U.S. soldiers with axes in a dispute over pruning a tree in the Demilitarized Zone. 1983: North Korean commandos bombed a cemetery in Rangoon, Burma, killing 17 South Korean officials, including four Cabinet ministers accompanying then-president Chun Doo-hwan. 1985: 151 people including art performers and journalists from each side visited the Korean capitals in an exchange and reunion of separated families. 1987: Two North Korean terrorists bombed a South Korean airliner over the Andaman Sea near Burma killing all 115 people aboard. One terrorist was captured and sentenced to death in Seoul. She was pardoned and released in 1990 on grounds she had been duped and repented her actions. 1988: The Summer Olympic Games were held in Seoul with 160 nations attending. North Korea boycotted the games. 1989: South Korea jailed five people, including a radical student and and an opposition lawmaker, for defying a government ban on travel to North Korea. 1990: North Korea boycotted inter-Korea talks for six months, demanding the annual U.S.-South Korean military maneuvers be canceled and U.S. troops be withdrawn. January: North Korea demanded South Korea tear down a Berlin-type border wall. South Korea says the alleged wall is a series of tank traps. July 3: The two Koreas agreed to hold their first prime ministers' talks, propably in September. An accord arranging the date and an agenda was to be signed July 26. July 6: North Korea said it would open a small portion of its border inside the Demilitarized Zone Aug. 15 to welcome South Koreans desiring unification. It also said Seoul must abolish anti-communist laws. July 20: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo proposes to open the border for five days beginning Aug. 13.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Join To Approve Eastern European Aid Bill
DOC.TEXT: A plan to provide U.S. support for emerging Eastern European democracies is tangled in a political dispute as Senate Foreign Relations Committee Democrats go forward with an aid package despite a Republican boycott. The Democrat-controlled panel on Thursday voted 10-0, with all nine Republican members absent, to send the $535 million bill to the full Senate. The measure would give President Bush a long menu of ideas for advancing economic reform in the former Warsaw Pact nations, including ``technical assistance'' for the Soviet Union. The committee's senior Republican, Sen. Jesse Helms of North Carolina, said in a letter to Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., who chairs the panel, that ``the feeling of comity has collapsed'' during work on the East Europe aid bill. Helms complained that the measure was being rushed into action without time for Republicans to review it and his aides said the Bush administration had an extensive list of concerns about the measure's overall cost and its specific provisions. Unlike foreign aid legislation passed last year, in which U.S. help was limited to Poland and Hungary, the measure approved Thursday makes assistance available to any Eastern European country that Bush believes needs help on its road to democratic and economic reform. The bill makes available $535 million for the programs in the year that begins Oct. 1, well in excess of the $300 million Bush had sought and an increase from the $489 million already approved by the House.
DOC.HEAD: Spy Suspect Tries To Quit Foreign Service
DOC.TEXT: Felix Bloch, target of a U.S. spy investigation, wants to quit the Foreign Service, but the State Department is trying to decide whether to fire him instead, a spokesman says. Bloch, 55, lost his job in the European Affairs bureau in February and his $80,000-a-year pay stopped with his suspension. In the meantime, the Justice Department looked into suspicions Bloch gave sensitive information to the Soviet Union and had been paid by Moscow. However, law enforcement sources have said the FBI was unable to prove that Bloch passed along specific classified information, which is necessary to prove espionage. A grand jury, meanwhile, had examined his finances in an attempt to trace any Soviet payments. If Bloch is fired, he will be branded a violator of U.S. national security. Spokesman Richard Boucher, confirming an account in The Washington Times, said Thursday Bloch submitted his resignation on July 5 and also withdrew a request for a hearing on the State Department's attempt to fire him. ``The department has informed Mr. Bloch that it will continue with the proceedings initiated last February to remove him from the Foreign Service for national security reasons,'' Boucher said. ``The department will take no action on Mr. Bloch's tendered resignation pending the outcome of these proceedings.'' Although Bloch was the subject of FBI surveillance for months, he was never arrested or charged with a crime. As a senior Foreign Service officer he would be eligible on retirement to receive up to 70 percent of his salary, or about $56,000 a year.
DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Accuse Administration of Withholding Owl Information
DOC.TEXT: The administration suppressed a government report that offered ways to reduce significantly the timber job losses that would result from protection of the rare northern spotted owl, two Northwest lawmakers say. Reps. Peter DeFazio, D-Ore., and Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash., said Thursday the May 1 report was leaked to them by ``a source in the administration.'' The White House declined comment. A spokesman for Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said the report was an internal document that never was intended for release. ``They are just playing partisan politics,'' said the spokesman, Steve Goldstein. The report prepared by the Forest Service, an arm of the Agriculture Department, and the Bureau of Land Management, part of the Interior Department, outlines ways to save as many as 21,000 timber jobs by, among other things, adding new restrictions on log exports and boosting spending on Forest Service programs, DeFazio said. He said it was prepared for release at the same time the two agencies projected that one controversial plan to save the owl would cut timber harvests in the region by nearly 50 percent and cost the region more than 28,000 jobs by the end of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Peacekeeping Force Proposed
DOC.TEXT: The foreign minister of Liberia and other prominent Liberians say their president will soon resign and leave the country and asked for a temporary U.S. peacekeeping force in the war torn nation. A State Department official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the department received the appeal and may respond in some way today. Foreign Minister J. Rudolph Johnson, Washington Ambassador Eugenia Wordsworth-Stevenson and eight other Liberians wrote President Bush Thursday that they expect the ``resignation and departure from Liberia'' of President Samuel Doe ``and the establishment of an interim government.'' The letter proposed that ``a limited U.S. force be provided, on the invitation of that interim government, to play an initial peacekeeping role'' in the vicinity of Monrovia, the capital now under siege by rebel forces. The appeal did not explain how the resignation and departure of Doe would be carried out. While agreeing not to seek re-election, the president has refused to leave the country and is sitting out the approach of rebel forces in his heavily fortified residence in Monrovia. The State Department said the letter was being studied by its task force monitoring the crisis in the African nation founded by freed American slaves 150 years ago. The letter and its signatures were regarded as authentic, the U.S. official said. U.S. warships with Marine units embarked were moved close to Liberia several weeks ago. Ambassador Wordsworth-Stevenson and former Liberian U.N. Ambassador Winston A. Tubman, listed as a press spokesman, did not answer their telephones Thursday night. Without foreign peacekeepers, victory ``by any faction'' will not end the civil war and ``is far more likely to trigger a more violent ethnic-based bloodbath,'' the letter said. This is because the war has spawned ``rival armed factions now threatening the capital, has inflamed tribal animosities and endangered the whole country as never before,`` it said. ``Liberians are now at the mercy of advancing bands of foreign-armed combatants, each with its own agenda and none capable of averting massive plunder and tribal revenge,'' the letter added, not naming the arms providers. Because of its moral authority in Liberia going back to the country's founding, ``the United States is uniquely positioned, with minimum risk, manpower and expense to halt the breakdown of law and order in Liberia and prevent even worse carnage,'' the letter said. ``Neighboring African states can thereafter play, as it is intended they should, a more sustained peacekeeping role,'' it added. ``This crucial help would not be viewed as colonial paternalism, Mr. President,`` the appeal said. ``It would be welcomed by all Liberians as the generous assistance of ...the same friend that helped create Liberia nearly a century-and-a-half ago and has been our constitutional ideal ever since.'' Hopes for reform ``have turned to dust'' under Doe, who took power in a 1980 coup, the letter said. The rebels accuse his government of corruption, mismanagement and widespread abuse of human rights. Other signers of the letter were Tubman, former armed forces chief George Toe Washington, former Customs Commissioner George Toukolon, former Post and Telecommunications Minister Abdulai Vandi, former Commerce Minister A. Romeo Horton, Senator Hilary F. Gbunblee, former Justice Minister Lawrence A. Morgan and Winifred Massaqquoi, former student adviser at the Liberian Embassy in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Frank Ethics
Key Dates in Frank Ethics Case
DOC.TEXT: Here are some key dates in the ethics investigation into Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass.: _July 1985. After paying male prostitute Stephen Gobie for sex, Frank hires Gobie, using personal funds, as a housekeeper and driver, hoping to change his way of life. _May 1987. In response to a reporter's question, Frank publicly acknowledges for the first time that he is gay. _August 1987. Frank ends his relationship with Gobie after learning that Gobie was running a prostitution ring out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment. Gobie later claims Frank was aware of the prostitution all along and that claim becomes a major issue in the ethics case. _November 1988. Frank wins election to a fifth term by a 70-30 margin. _Aug. 25, 1989. The Washington Times reports that Frank paid Gobie for sex and hired him to do chores. It is the first public word of Frank's relationship with Gobie. _Sept. 10, 1989. A Boston Sunday Globe editorial calls on Frank to resign for ``his own good, and for the good of his constituents, his causes and Congress.'' _Sept. 11, 1989. The House ethics committee votes to conduct an investigation into Frank's relationship with Gobie. Frank says he won't resign and will decide his political plans after the committee completes its investigation. He apologizes to his constituents for ``some serious mistakes in judgment several years ago. What I did was wrong.'' He says in a Newsweek interview that Gobie was not the first prostitute he hired. _Oct. 20, 1989. The Washington Times reports that Gobie claims he and Frank had sex in the House gymnasium. Frank denies it. _Oct. 30, 1989. The ethics committee holds the first of several closed-door meetings on the Frank case. _Dec. 5, 1989. Gobie testifies. _Jan. 23, 1990. Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., says he plans to demand that the House cast a roll-call vote on a proposal to expel Frank. _Feb. 6, 1990. Penthouse magazine publishes an interview of Gobie, who received $50,000 from the magazine, that breaks little new ground. _April 17, 1990. Frank announces plans to seek a sixth term. _April 25-26, 1990. The ethics committee holds two marathon sessions. Sources indicate that Democrats want to issue Frank a letter reproving his conduct; Republicans are said to be pushing for a tougher sanction. _May 10, 1990. A former prostitute testifies before the committee after alleging publicly that Frank knew the sex-for-hire ring was being operated from his apartment. Frank denies it, producing an affidavit from his landlady that she believed Frank was unaware of the prostitution. _July 19, 1990. The ethics committee recommends that the House reprimand Frank.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Favor of Newspapers in Confidential Source Case
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper cannot be held liable for breaking a promise of confidentiality to a source, Minnesota's highest court ruled today in rejecting a $700,000 award against the state's two biggest daily papers. Lawyers for both sides agreed the 4-2 ruling by the state Supreme Court has far-reaching implications for the nation's news organizations. The court rejected a jury's award of $200,000 in compensatory damages and $500,000 in punitive damages to Dan Cohen. Cohen had sued the Saint Paul Pioneer Press and the Star Tribune of Minneapolis for 1982 stories identifying him as the source of documents showing a Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor had been convicted of shoplifting 12 years earlier. Cohen, then a Republican gubernatorial candidate's consultant, had given the newspapers' reporters the information in return for assurances of confidentiality. But the newspapers' editors overruled the reporters, believing readers should know the information came from the GOP candidate's campaign. The Supreme Court today upheld an appeals court's dismissal of Cohen's claim of fraudulent misrepresentation, but reversed that court's ruling allowing him to claim breach of contract. ``To impose a contract theory on this arrangement puts an unwarranted legal rigidity on a special ethical relationship, precluding necessary consideration of factors underlying that ethical relationship,'' Associate Justice John Simonett wrote. The court also said enforcement of the promise of confidentiality under a doctrine that implies a legal contract where none exists would violate the newspapers' First Amendment rights. The case involved ``the classic First Amendment context of ... a political source involved in a political campaign,'' the majority wrote. ``It's a very important case, one with far-reaching implications,'' said Cohen's lawyer, Elliot Rothenberg. ``The issue is, to what extent do newspapers and the media have a constitutional right to violate promises to which everyone else in society would be held liable?'' Rothenberg said he would appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court. The Associated Press filed the only friend-of-the-court brief in the case. Louise Sommers, an attorney for the AP, called the ruling a major victory for the news media. Cohen's victory at trial had produced a spate of similar lawsuits around the country, the AP's attorneys said. Today's ruling is ``the first definitive opinion by a supreme court of a state directly addressing'' the issues in Cohen's case, said Dick Winfield, another attorney for the AP. He said the media ``can take considerable comfort'' in the decision. Cohen was doing public relations work for 1982 gubernatorial candidate Wheelock Whitney when he gave reporters documents showing that Marlene Johnson, a candidate for lieutenant governor, was convicted of shoplifting in 1970. Johnson's conviction was vacated in 1971 with no sentence. She was elected as Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich's running mate in 1982, was re-elected in 1986 and is running with Perpich this year. Editors at the newspapers testified that they believed the public had a right to know the information about Johnson's past came from the Whitney campaign. Reporters for the AP and WCCO-TV also promised Cohen anonymity and received the documents. The AP published the story and honored its promise; the TV station did not run the story. In rejecting Cohen's argument that he had a contract with the newspapers, the Supreme Court said, ``We are not persuaded that in the special milieu of media newsgathering a source and a reporter ordinarily believe they are engaged in making a legally binding contract. ``The parties understand that the reporter's promise of anonymity is given as a moral commitment, but a moral obligation alone will not support a contract,'' the court said. The court said it had to balance the constitutional rights of a free press against the common-law interest of protecting a promise of anonymity. ``The potentiality for civil damages for promises made in this context chills public debate, a debate which Cohen willingly entered albeit hoping to do so on his own terms,'' the court said. ``In this context, and considering the nature of the political story involved, it seems to us that the law best leaves the parties here to their trust in each other.'' In a dissent, Associate Justice Lawrence Yetka said the result of the ruling was to ``carve out yet another special privilege in favor of the press that is denied other citizens.'' Associate Justice Glenn Kelley, who also dissented, said the decision ``serves to inhibit rather than to promote the objectives of the First Amendment by `drying up' potential sources of information on public matters.'' Saint Paul Pioneer Press attorney Paul Hannah said the court recognized the difficulties editors and reporters face in ``making decisions about what voters are going to know about the candidates and campaigns.'' Star Tribune Executive Editor Joel R. Kramer said the newspaper was ``especially pleased that the court has ruled that the decision to publish true facts relating to the activities of `a political source in a political campaign' is one that is protected by the First Amendment.''

DOC.HEAD: Emotional Return to Airport for Crash Survivors and Relatives of Victims
LaserPhotos SCX1,2
DOC.TEXT: United Flight 232 survivors wandered pensively about the runway where a year ago their crippled jumbo jet cartwheeled in flames, killing 112 of 296 people aboard. ``I want to see it without bodies and luggage and airplane parts strewn all over,'' Brad Bayless of Littleton, Colo., said during a reunion of survivors and victims' relatives on the crash anniversary Thursday. Little evidence of the crash remains. The cornfield where the wreckage came to rest is now planted in soybeans, the torn runway has been patched and pieces of the shattered United Air Lines DC-10 are locked away in a hangar. Bayless and other survivors walked around the crash site and into another cornfield, where they picked tassels as reminders. ``At first I thought, oh, no, they took away the corn because they didn't want me to see it, to remember. But they explained it was normal crop rotation,'' said Bayless' wife, Sharon. The couple suffered minor injuries in the crash. Organizers of the reunion said 104 of the 184 people who survived the crash returned for the gathering. ``I wanted my boys to know that Sioux City is a place where normal things happen, that it's a place of mending as well as catastrophe,'' said Brownell Bailey, of Bowmar, Colo. Bailey's wife, Francie, died in the crash. Mrs. Bayless said: ``I have a lot of memories of some pretty gruesome things, and we both feel guilty that we walked away unharmed while so many others didn't. I knew it would be hard to come back. ``But I realized I needed to feel some things that I have kept under the surface over the last year, feelings like, was I really here?'' At a memorial service timed to coincide with the moment the plane crashed, people huddled in a hangar at the Sioux Gateway Airport to get out of heavy rain. Many cried quietly as the Rev. Gregory Clapper, a United Methodist minister, led the survivors and families of victims in part of the 23rd Psalm. Some survivors described feelings of guilt. When National Guard jets roared off to form a ``missing man'' formation, some put their hands over their ears and held their fists to their mouths. They gave a standing ovation to Capt. Al C. Haynes, the pilot who guided the crippled plane to the airport. Haynes' voice cracked as he addressed the group. ``It's been an emotional roller coaster for all of us, but even so, the remembering has been an important part of the healing process,'' he said. ``But somehow, we must find a way to take them (memories) away from our present and make them part of the past.'' Pilots have marveled that Haynes got the jet even close to an emergency landing after an engine shattered and severed the hydraulic lines used to control the plane. Lori Michaelson used the reunion to call on Congress to require child restraints on airliners. Currently, small children may sit on their parents' laps. ``Let's have something positive come out of this crash,'' said Ms. Michaelson, whose 11-month-old daughter, Sabrina, was torn from her grasp in the crash. A passenger heard the baby's cries and pulled her from the wreckage.

DOC.HEAD: Sun Shines Bright to Power Solar Cars to Finish
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Sunrayce is cq, 5th graf
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY8
DOC.TEXT: The cars in this race whirred across the finish line in the Motor City with faint whines and hums, not booming exhausts and smoking tires. They were solar-powered, and the 11-day Florida-to-Detroit race they completed Thursday gave a big boost to the technology that harnesses the sun's energy, organizers and participants said. ``This race has definitely raised awareness of engineering and science,'' said Bill Kaliardos, a member of the University of Michigan's Sunrunner team, which won the 1,641-mile race. ``This is about as good as engineering can get.'' ``What these young people have learned will contribute to the future technological developments in our country,'' said Robert C. Stempel, president of General Motors Corp. The company sponsored the GM Sunrayce USA along with the U.S. Energy Department and the Society of Automotive Engineers. Sunlight glinted off the panels and heated the solar cells of the lightweight, low-slung cars as they zipped across the race's last leg. The cars _ just over 3 feet high but 19 feet long and 6.6 feet across _ are designed to expose the maximum area of solar cells to the sun and run on minimum power. In Sunrunner's case, that's 1.5 horsepower. The 575-pound Sunrunner finished in 72 hours, 50 minutes and 47 seconds, averaging 22.5 mph. The cars started July 9 at Disney World in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., and traveled over secondary roads in Georgia, Alabama, Tennessee, Kentucky, Indiana, Ohio and Michigan. GM is sending the top three finishers to Australia's World Solar Challenge, a 2,000-mile race across the Australian outback from Darwin to Adelaide. It starts Nov. 11. Western Washington University's Viking XX finished second and the University of Maryland's Pride of Maryland was third. Viking XX was one of just three two-passenger vehicles in the race. ``It's very radical,'' said Bill Lingenfelter, 23, an industrial technology student and the Viking XX team captain. Student engineer-racers said they hope to change the face of the auto industry _ and further their own careers. ``I love cars,'' said Susan Fancy, 27, a mechanical engineering student who was Sunrunner's project manager. ``I'm interested in the environment and alternative power vehicles. I'm hoping to work for one of the Big Three.''

DOC.HEAD: Library to Maintain Nixon Legacy Opens
DOC.TEXT: The new Nixon library and birthplace is open today for the people of his hometown and everyone else curious about the successes and failures of the first president to resign his office. It requires only $3.95 for adults, and children can get in free to examine subjects ranging from Richard Nixon's triumph in China to aspects of the Watergate scandal that forced the 37th president from office. President Bush and former Presidents Ford and Reagan were among guests at Thursday's dedication of the library. Bush gave advice to those who visit the museum, which chronicles Nixon's career from his first run for Congress, through his resignation and his post-White House life. ``Look at Richard Nixon the man,'' said Bush. ``He was an author ... he worked in the most pragmatic of arenas, yet insisted that `politics is poetry, not prose.' He believed in love of country, and in God _ in loyalty to friends, and protecting loved ones.'' Fifty thousand spectators turned out for the dedication, according to police estimates and the count from metal detectors at the library. The $21 million library was built with private funds and will receive no federal funds to operate. Many donors attended a fancy black-tie party Thursday night in Los Angeles, wrapping up the celebration. Those guests arriving at the front door of the Century Plaza Hotel were confronted by several hundred demonstrators, espousing causes as varied as pro-choice in abortion to AIDS research and the war in El Salvador. Fourteen demonstrators were arrested. Guests were carefully screened and those without invitations were turned away. That included reporters, who have never been favorites of Nixon and his supporters. ``Much has been written and said about Richard Nixon _ some has even been true,'' Ronald Reagan said in his speech at the dedication. ``Journalists, historians, political pundits and just plain folks will talk for decades about his career and what it meant to our country and the world. ``It will come as no surprise to anyone here that there will always be a good deal of debate about Richard Nixon.'' Gerald Ford, got a laugh from the crowd by turning to each of the men who have occupied the Oval Office and saying ``Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. President.'' He said Nixon was proof that ``you can come home again.'' The only living former president who was not there was Jimmy Carter, who also is the only Democrat in the bunch. He sent regrets. The word Watergate was mentioned only once, and that was by Bush, in passing. Bush called Watergate the ``seventh crisis,'' a reference to ``Six Crises'' the first of Nixon's eight books. ``Mr. President, you worked with every fiber of your being to help achieve `A Generation of Peace,''' Bush told Nixon. ``Today, as the movement toward democracy sweeps our globe, you can take great pride that history will say of you: `Here was a true architect of peace.''' For Nixon, the dedication was a triumphant day, one widely regarded as a milestone in his 16-year effort to overcome the disgrace of the Watergate scandal in which burglars broke into the Democratic headquarters, spurring a White House cover up. ``Over the past years, Pat and I have had the opportunity to visit some wonderful places,'' Nixon told the crowd. ``But nothing we have ever seen matches this moment _ to be welcomed home again so warmly on this day by our friends in California.''

DOC.HEAD: Friends Dismiss Resignation Calls
With PM-Durenberger-Ethics
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the state Republican Party dismissed Democratic calls for Sen. Dave Durenberger to resign now that a Senate committee has recommended that the full Senate denounce him. Other state Republicans agreed, but said it's too early to tell how much the senator's chances of re-election in 1994 have been hurt. The Senate Ethics Committee said Thursday that Durenberger violated Senate rules by laundering speaking fees through a book contract and claiming reimbursement for staying in a Minneapolis condominium in which he owned an interest. The panel recommended the full Senate denounce Durenberger for ``reprehensible'' financial conduct and require him to make restitution. State GOP Chairman Bob Weinholzer said most callers to party headquarters supported Durenberger. ``There have been a few callers who said they think he should resign, but that was the minority,'' Weinholzer said. Lois West, Durenberger's press secretary, said most people who called the senator's Washington office also were supportive. ``We're getting a lot of calls of support, and a few who say things like, `Get out of town,' '' West said. ``But they are overwhelmingly supportive.'' Democratic Senate candidate Paul Wellstone said denouncement by one's colleagues is a ``real disgrace'' that would make it difficult for Durenberger to be an effective lawmaker. ``The people back here in Minnesota should figure in somewhere,'' Wellstone said. ``What makes sense is for Dave Durenberger to resign and the governor to appoint a caretaker senator and for us to have an election in November. And if Durenberger wants to run again, he should.'' In Washington, Republican Sen. Rudy Boschwitz said he hopes that ``we are close to the point where David can put these mistakes behind him and get back to being the strong, effective senator for Minnesota that he has been for the past 11 years.'' Weinholzer said calls for Durenberger's resignation were ``nonsense.'' ``Some of these charges already were known to the electorate in 1988,'' when Durenberger won re-election to a 6-year term, he said. ``If he were to resign now, he would be disenfranchising those voters.'' If Durenberger were to step aside and then win re-election this November, he would lose the seniority he earned during nearly 12 years in the Senate, Weinholzer said.

DOC.HEAD: Hot, Humid Weather Prevails in East, Rain Dominates Forecast
DOC.TEXT: Hot, humid weather prevailed in the East early today, a hazy prelude to intense, gusty thunderstorms. Parts of the Midwest got rain and the Southwest was in for more heat. A wide line of storms was expected to be strongest in the Ohio Valley and New England. Sunshine mixed with cloudy skies was forecast for the Southeast, followed by spotty showers that also were to plague portions of Texas and Louisiana. Much of the United States was rained on Thursday. Thunderstorms in Ohio flooded streets and knocked out power. Lightning killed a 57-year-old maintenance man as he worked outside. A state of emergency was declared in flooded Sutton, Neb., after more than 9 inches of rain drenched the area, forcing the evacuation of homes and flooding streets. Iowa also had some street flooding Thursday. High winds tore down trees and covered roads with water in south-central New York state. The high temperatures Thursday in the Lower 48 states was 116 degrees in the Arizona towns of Bullhead City and Lake Havasu City and in Laughlin, Nev. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Secretary of State to Visit Mongolia
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia said today that U.S. Secretary of State James Baker will pay a visit next month, becoming the first high-level American envoy to do so since the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1987. Among other things, Baker will sign an agreement for American Peace Corps volunteers to work in the remote, Soviet-bloc nation, said Tepbishiin Chimeddorg, spokesman for Mongolia's Foreign Ministry. His announcement, made at a news conference in the Mongolian capital of Ulan Bator, was reported by China's official Xinhua News Agency. Chimeddorg said Baker will visit from Aug. 2-5. He will sign an agreement on consular affairs and discuss a range of political, economic and trade matters with Mongolian leaders, the spokesman said. The State Department already had announced that Baker will attend a July 30 meeting in Singapore on Pacific economic cooperation, and will meet Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Schevardnadze in the Soviet city of Irkutsk on Aug. 1. Irkutsk is in Siberia about 140 miles north of Mongolia. It appeared that Baker would not stop in Beijing. The Chinese capital is a main gateway to Ulan Bator, and it normally would have been natural for Baker to spend a day in Beijing en route north. However, the United States still has not announced a resumption of high-level visits to China, halted since China used the army to crush the nation's pro-democracy movement in June 1989. China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Jin Guihua, said last week he had no information on any plans by Baker to visit. Mongolia, the world's second-oldest communist nation, has undergone dramatic political changes in the past year. Spurred by reforms in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, young urban Mongolians began street protests last winter that led to the resignation of top Communist Party and government leaders. The party voted to allow opposition parties after seven decades of monopoly rule, and to separate its functions from those of the government. The first multiparty elections in Mongolian history are scheduled for July 29. Primaries are to be held Sunday. The United States joined the six other leading industrialized democracies at the Houston summit this month in welcoming movement toward greater political openness in Mongolia.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Proposed to Abolish Flogging
DOC.TEXT: The government today proposed legislation to abolish flogging as a means of punishing male criminals. The proposal will be debated by the law-making Legislative Council in October, and the government said it hoped flogging would be abolished this year. The punishment, administered with a light cane, was introduced in Hong Kong in the heyday of the British empire. Its use has declined in recent years; Hong Kong courts ordered only two floggings last year, compared with 476 in 1952, officials said. Under existing laws, only men can be flogged. The number of strokes range from 18 for offenders age 17 or older to six for offenders under 14. A court can order floggings for offenses that include indecent assault, robbery, rape of a woman under 16, weapons possession and piracy. Flogging was abolished in Britain about four decades ago, and the Hong Kong government has been encouraged to end the practice because of international criticism.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Delayed Nuclear Plant Reaches Full Power
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook nuclear plant, focus of debate over atomic energy, has reached full power for the first time. The $6.6 billion reactor _ among the nation's most expensive _ went to full throttle at 9:52 p.m. Thursday, plant spokesman Ron Sher said. The plant generated 1,150 megawatts, electricity for 1 million New England homes. It's the most important milestone yet for the decade-late project and another setback for anti-nuclear activists whose mass civil disobedience demonstrations had made Seabrook a symbol of their movement. ``Reaching full power fulfills the dream we have all worked so hard to achieve,'' said Edward Brown, president of the plant's operator, New Hampshire Yankee. For plant opponents, the milestone was the latest in a series of disappointments since the Nuclear Regulatory Commission gave Seabrook a commercial operating license in March. ``What they're doing now is another step in the long process of the abuse of power,'' said Roy Morrison of the anti-nuclear Clamshell Alliance. ``It's a complete disregard of the public safety. The plant is unsafe. It's operating in a place where there is no evacuation possible.'' The project, conceived 22 years ago, is located less than two miles from Hampton Beach, New Hampshire's most popular summer resort. The peak summertime population within Seabrook's 10-mile emergency planning zone is estimated at nearly 250,000. The NRC and Seabrook supporters say evacuation plans would adequately protect the public in the unlikely event of a serious accident. Plant supporters include White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, who as New Hampshire governor during the 1980s helped keep the project afloat despite financial troubles. The lead owner, Public Service Company of New Hampshire, finally had to take bankruptcy refuge in January 1988 because of Seabrook delays. Opponents were led by Gov. Michael Dukakis of Massachusetts, which has six communities within 10 miles of Seabrook. Dukakis contended that evacuation wouldn't be feasible, considering the beach crowds and limited roads in the area. Many people interviewed on the beaches near Seabrook this week have placed their trust, willingly or otherwise, in plant operators. ``I think they got everything pretty much under control or they wouldn't be going up to full power,'' said Tom McDermott, 28, of Lowell, Mass. ``I guess I'm just relying on them to take care of it, to let us know if something's wrong.'' Public Service proposed a nuclear power project in 1968 but shelved it the next year, then proposed Seabrook in 1972 as a twin-reactor plant with a cost of less than $1 billion. The first reactor was planned for commercial operation in 1979, the second in 1981. Anti-nuclear acitivists began using civil disobedience to publicize their cause in 1976. A protest that resulted in more than 1,400 arrests in May 1977 was, at the time, the largest ever against an American nuclear plant. In all, anti-Seabrook demonstrations have resulted in more than 3,200 arrests. Construction delays and billions of dollars in cost overruns forced owners to scrap Seabrook 2 in the mid-1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Soldiers Offer Truce to Help Quake Relief Work
With PM-Philippines-Quake
DOC.TEXT: Rebel soldiers who led a coup attempt against President Corazon Aquino in December offered a truce today to help relief efforts following this week's killer earthquake. ``We call on the present leadership to set aside all political differences in order to squarely face this catastrophe,'' the underground Revolutionary Alliance of the Masses-Soldiers of the Filipino People said in a statement. Monday's earthquake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter Scale, was the strongest to hit the country in 14 years and officials say hundreds of people were killed. The rebel group said its members were prepared to help in the relief effort but asked that the government agree to a ``temporary and finite'' halt to the search and capture of rebel members. It said the rebels have declared a unilateral stop to all anti-government activities ``during this time of national tragedy.'' The statement was signed by former Lt. Col. Gregorio ``Gringo'' Honasan, who led the August 1987 coup attempt and was among key leaders of the last coup attempt. The December attempt left at least 113 people dead and more than 600 injured. It was the sixth and most serious bid by rebellious soldiers to topple Mrs. Aquino since she took power after a ``people power revolution'' ousted the late Ferdinand Marcos in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Failure To Find Perpetrators Shocks Italy, Pains Relatives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf `Experts have...' with 2 grafs to ADD background on arrests and trials ending in acquittal and release. Pickup 9th graf `Adding to...'
DOC.HEAD: By VICTOR L. SIMPSON
DOC.TEXT: A court decision this week throwing out convictions in a terrorist bombing has added to public frustration that judges and investigators have failed to pin down the blame in several attacks in the past 20 years. An appeals court on Wednesday overturned the convictions of four people sentenced to life in prison two years ago for the 1980 bombing that killed 85 people at Bologna's train station. The verdict meant investigators are back to square one in trying to solve one of Europe's worst terrorist acts a full decade after it occurred. ``How shameful for the state,'' said Il Messaggero, a moderate Rome newspaper, in a front-page editorial. The leading Milan daily Corriere della Sera called Italy ``a country without truth.'' Some commentators blamed investigative incompetence, political interference and the dark deeds of a secret service that may have compromised the truth forever. The Bologna bombing was only the latest in a series of major cases dating back more than 20 years that have gone unsolved. They include the bombing at a Milan bank in 1969 that left 16 dead and ushered in more than a decade of terrorism from the left and right, bomb blasts in the city of Brescia and on trains in the 1970s and the mysterious crash of an Italian jetliner in 1980 that killed all 81 aboard. In the Milan bombing there were arrests and at least three trials, but in the end the suspects were acquitted. A trial of Brescia suspects ended in acquittal. There were arrests in at least one of the train bombings in the 1970s, but a trial never determined the perpetrators. There have been no arrests in the plane crash. And experts have still failed to make a firm determination on the cause _ whether a bomb exploded aboard or whether it was downed by a missile fired by an unidentified plane. Adding to the anguish of the victims' relatives, the judge investigating the crash has just quit the case over a dispute with a Socialist politician regarding his handling of it. ``Before the Bologna verdict, Italians were diffident if not distrustful toward the system of justice,'' said Franco Ferrarotti, a University of Rome sociologist in a telephone interview. ``The verdict has delivered a powerful blow to the relationship between citizens and institutions in Italy,'' he said. Prosecutors in the Bologna case described the attack as a neo-Fascist plot to undermine Italy's democracy and the four convicted of planting the bomb as right-wing terrorists. Seemingly strengthening this theory was the indictment and conviction in the first trial of Licio Gelli, former grandmaster of the secret Propaganda Due (P-2) Masonic lodge which had been accused of seeking to install a right-wing dictatorship with the help of secret service officials. Gelli had been given 10 years in prison on charges of misleading investigators, but he was also acquitted by the appeals court. The technique seemed to fit the pattern attributed to Italy's neo-Fascist gangs: striking at masses of people in the city that is the heart of Communist Party strength. Leftist terrorists were said to be more selective in their targets, aiming at individual politicians or businessmen. It was in this highly politicized atmosphere that the trials in the Bologna case were held. The Communist Party reponded to the verdict Thursday by leaving the front page of its party newspaper blank but for a photo of a rescue worker carrying a victim of the train station bombing. Sociologist Ferrarotti said other countries carry the burden of doubt-creating crimes, pointing to the theories on the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy. ``But other countries make an attempt to deal out justice swiftly.'' It took six years to complete the investigation of the Bologna bombing and two more years to bring it to trial. The appeals court handed down its verdict just a few seeks before the 10th anniversary of the bombing on Aug. 2. ``I don't know what was behind the reversal of the verdict,'' said a bitter Paolo Bolognesi, spokesman for the families of the victims. ``I only know this this the court's anniversary present.'' The trials have served as an unpleasant reminder of the dark days of terrorism, in sharp contrast to the economic boom and relative social peace enjoyed by Italians over the last decade. Leftist terrorism, responsible for the kidnapping and killing of former Premier Aldo Moro in 1978, was crushed when dozens of the urban guerrillas decided to turn state's evidence. ``The rich Italy of today will have to come to terms with its past sooner or later,'' said the Il Messaggero editorial. ``A true democracy can't exist with so many dark areas.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Trump Can Be Questioned About Extramarital Affair
DOC.TEXT: A judge ruled that Donald Trump can be questioned by attorneys representing his estranged wife, Ivana, about an alleged extramarital affair. Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Phyllis Gangel-Jacob ruled on Thursday that Trump would have to divulge his intentions toward Marla Maples when he and Mrs. Trump updated a prenuptial agreement in December 1987. Mrs. Trump contends she was tricked into signing papers that would give her $25 million if she and Trump divorced. She said she would not have signed the agreement had she been aware of his ``adultery and philandering.'' The judge also ruled that Trump would not have to discuss his relationship with Maples after the 1987 agreement. The agreement, which Trump attorney Jay Goldberg has called ironclad, was fraudulently obtained, according to Mrs. Trump's lawyer, Michael Kennedy. The New York Post reported today that Mrs. Trump revealed in court papers obtained Thursday, that her relationship with Trump began to sour four years ago. ``In 1986, he mentioned that he thought an open marriage might be interesting, but he knew I was too old-fashioned a girl to even tolerate any other sexual relationship or affair,'' she said. ``He did not tell me that ... he was seeing another woman and having an affair with her,'' she said. Mrs. Trump had also sought to have the contract nullified because of alleged adultery by Trump after December 1987. Trump's attorney, Goldberg, told the Daily News that decision is ``extremely valuable to Mr. Trump's cause and solidifies his position that the 1987 agreement will be upheld.''

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori's Prime Minister Names New Government's Cabinet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to RAISE HIGHER Fujimori's plan for a widely divergent Cabinet. Pickup 3rd pvs, ``Fujimori, of...''
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister has appointed nine men and a woman to a new Cabinet that will assume power July 28 and include politicians representing a wide diversity of opinions and platforms. Prime Minister Juan Carlos Hurtado announced the 10 appointments Thursday and said the ministers of labor, justice and industry would be announced later. The 10 ministers represent a range of political parties and reflect President-elect Alberto Fujimori's plans for a government of conciliation that will replace that of President Alan Garcia. Fujimori, of the centrist Change 90 party, on Wednesday named Hurtado, a former agriculture minister, to be his prime minister and economics minister. Hurtado had announced his resignation from the center-right Popular Action party Wednesday morning. Fujimori's choice of Hurtado was the strongest indication yet that in order to satisfy foreign creditors the new president will pursue a more market-oriented economic policy than he spoke of during his campaign. Before the June 10 election, Fujimori sharply criticized the type of market-oriented ``economic shock therapy'' advocated by his opponent, novelist Mario Vargas Llosa. The Cabinet members named Thursday were: Luis Marchand, current ambassador to Chile, as foreign minister; Fernando Sanchez as energy minister; Carlos Amat y Leon as agriculture minister; Dr. Carlos Vidal as health minister; Eduardo Toledo as transportation and communications minister. Army Gen. Rodrigo Alvarado was named as interior minister; Army Gen. Jorge Torres as defense minister; Gloria Helfer as education minister; Retired Navy Admiral Raul Sanchez as fisheries minister; and Guillermo del Solar as housing and construction minister. Hurtado said the people selected to head the ministries of industry and justice were out of the country and that their names would be announced later. Hurtado said a labor minister had not been selected, and that he planned to consult with labor leaders before making that choice. Alvarado was the most controversial appointment. As head of the Interior Ministry he will oversee the national police forces, and analysts say the appointment could aggravate the longstanding rivalry between Peru's police and military. The rivalry is strongest in the country's emergency zones, where the military has been given broad powers to fight leftist guerrillas. More than one-third of the country is currently under emergency regulations. The two major leftist guerrilla groups fighting the government are the Maoist-inspired Shining Path and the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement.

DOC.HEAD: Condemned Man Used Meditation for Control
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CLARIFY that Florida officials said problem was with sponge, not chair itself.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto RM1
DOC.TEXT: Richard T. Boggs meditated to calm himself as he sat in the electric chair for 12 minutes before he was executed for the 1984 murder and robbery of an elderly neighbor. Head tilted back and eyes closed, Boggs walked slowly into the death chamber at 10:50 p.m. Thursday. He appeared sedated, but state Department of Corrections spokesman Wayne Farrar said Boggs, 27, had not taken any tranquilizers. ``He was meditating,'' said Farrar. ``He was into meditation.'' Guards strapped Boggs into the wooden chair in the basement of the State Penitentiary, placed a brown leather mask over his face and attached electrodes to the crown of his head and his right calf. Comforted by prison chaplain Russ Ford, Boggs, his shaven head still tilted backward, occasionally touched thumb to fingers on his upwardly cupped hands as he waited for his execution, which took place shortly after 11 p.m. Prison officials said that condemned prisoners are usually not kept waiting on the chair but had no immediate explanation for the delay. Earlier in the evening, Gov. L. Douglas Wilder refused to commute Boggs' sentence to life in prison after the U.S. Supreme Court denied a stay. The execution was the first during the 6-month-old administration of Wilder, a former death penalty opponent who successfully pushed for an expansion of the state's capital punishment law this year. Boggs was sentenced to death for the Jan. 25, 1984, robbery and slaying of his Portsmouth neighbor, Treeby M. Shaw, 87, whom he had known all his life. She had just poured tea for Boggs when he beat her with a metal bar and stabbed her because he needed money for drugs, he told police. He took diamond rings from her fingers and family silver from the house. Boggs' back arched as he was hit with the first 2,500-volt surge of electricity. The electricity was administered for 55 seconds, stopped for 5 seconds and turned on for an additional 55 seconds. Boggs, who had no final words, was pronounced dead at 11:07 p.m. The execution was the ninth since Virginia resumed executions in 1982 and the 135th nationwide since the Supreme Court reinstituted the death penalty in 1976. It was the 15th this year. U.S. District Judge Richard L. Williams turned down Boggs' request for a stay of execution Thursday morning and a three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling late in the afternoon. Defense lawyers claimed the state's electric chair might malfunction and that Boggs suffers from brain damage. Boggs' attorney, David Bruck, told Williams that Virginia's electric chair is virtually identical to the one in Florida that malfunctioned during the electrocution of Jesse Tafero in May. Flames and smoke appeared from under the man's head covering. Florida officials contend that the problem was that a synthetic sponge rather than a natural sponge was used under the hood. They have replaced the sponge, but defense attorneys who argue that the chair is still not fixed are continuing to raise objections to executions in that state.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Deter Dissent As Opposition Leader Passes First Year of Detention
DOC.TEXT: Burma's most prominent opposition leader marked a year under house arrest today, and the military government sent troops and armored cars into the streets to quash any calls for her freedom. Burma's military rulers were overwhelmingly defeated in May 27 elections, but have so far refused to hand over power or free Aung San Suu Kyi, whose National League for Democracy won the balloting. Ms. Suu Kyi was put under house arrest July 20, 1989, after the government accused her of subversion. A government spokesman said at that time she would serve a one-year term, which could be renewed. There was no word from the government today on prospects for her release. Diplomats contacted by telephone said troops with automatic rifles and armored cas patrolled the streets of the Burmese capital, Rangoon, apparently to deter rallies by Ms. Suu Kyi's supporters. Security was especially tight around her lakeside compound, they said. On Thursday, 150 youths staged a march in Rangoon, shouting for Ms. Suu Kyi's release and hoisting the National League for Democracy's symbol. The league has asked the government to release Ms. Suu Kyi, but has also been trying since the election to avoid antagonizing the military. A military spokesman has said the government would not bow to foreign pressure for her release. In a July 13 letter, 39 members of the U.S. Congress and 19 senators urged military leader Gen. Saw Maung to hold a dialogue with civilian political parties and rapidly transfer power. The U.S. lawmakers called on the Burmese government to lift martial law, free all political prisoners including Ms. Suu Kyi and take steps to ensure basic human rights are protected. Ms. Suu Kyi was a leader of the national pro-democracy uprisings that military officers crushed in September 1988 by killing hundreds of people. The May elections were the first multiparty balloting allowed in three decades. The military severely restricted campaigning by the opposition, but Ms. Suu Kyi's party still won 396 of the 485 seats in Parliament. Thursday's protest came hours after a peaceful commemoration of Martyrs Day, which marks the the assassination 43 years ago of independence leaders. Those leaders include Gen. Aung San, Ms. Suu Kyi's father. Small groups of high school students staged demonstrations in the city Tuesday and Wednesday calling for her release, a Western diplomat said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Settles $30 Million Lawsuit Against TV Personality
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys say they have settled out of court a $30 million lawsuit filed against television personality Geraldo Rivera by a woman who was arrested during a drug raid carried live on national television. Terry Rouse, 32, of suburban Channelview filed the libel suit against Rivera in 1987 stemming from the Dec. 2, 1986, telecast of ``American Vice: The Doping of a Nation.'' The settlement, involving an undisclosed amount of money, came after Rivera was questioned for six hours during a deposition Thursday. Before the settlement, Rivera had said he suspected the lawsuit was pursued by attorneys ``with greedy motives.'' The lawsuit was scheduled to go to trial Aug. 20. State District Judge Ann Cochran on Thursday ordered Rivera to turn over a copy of his most recent financial data, but she also ordered that it would remain confidential. Dale Jefferson, attorney for Ms. Rouse, speculated the other side settled because it did not savor discussing Rivera's salary in open court. During the 1986 program, Rivera was broadcasting live outside a duplex where Ms. Rouse was staying when Harris County Sheriff Johnny Klevenhagen and several deputies raided the home. Rivera said that the people inside were an alleged pimp and prostitute who were supplying drugs to truckers. Ms. Rouse was dragged from the duplex and handcuffed as an estimated 15 million viewers watched, she said in the lawsuit. Ms. Rouse has maintained she was hired to paint the house, which belonged to a friend. Cocaine possession charges against her stemming from the televised bust were later dismissed. Attorney Wayne Fisher, representing Rivera and the production companies, said the settlement was the result of ``all the parties sitting down together in one place.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Shows Strict Diet, Stress Management Can Reverse Heart Disease Damage
DOC.TEXT: A strict, low-fat vegetarian diet can reverse damage caused by heart disease, according to the findings of an American study published in the weekly British medical magazine The Lancet. ``The Lifestyle Heart Trial'' was conducted on 41 heart disease patients by the Preventive Medicine Research Institute in Sausalito, Calif. The study found that 82 percent of the heart disease patients who adopted such a diet, quit smoking and attended stress-management classes reversed their coronary artery blockages. ``What we're finding is that heart disease may be completely preventable for most people if they are willing to make changes in their lifestyle,'' the study's coordinator, Dr. Dean Ornish, said in a telephone interview. The patients, all from the San Francisco area, were recruited from Pacific Presbyterian Medical Center and from Moffitt Hospital at the University of California at San Francisco for the study, published in Lancet's July 21 issue. The 41, aged 35-75, were randomly divided into two groups. The experimental group comprised 22 of the 41. The 22 followed a low-fat vegetarian diet, took regular exercise, attended stress management classes and did not smoke. Eighteen of the 22, or 82 percent of the group, showed an overall reversal in coronary artery blockages, the study found. The other 19 among the 41 were assigned to a control group which followed the standard program recommended for people suffering from coronary artery disease _ a diet of 30 percent fat, moderate excercise and no smoking. Ten of the 19 _ 53 percent of the control group _ experienced a worsening of their artery blockages, the study found. ``This finding suggests that conventional recommendations don't go far enough for many people,'' Ornish said. ``The guidelines may be enough to prevent heart disease but not to reverse it.'' The low-fat vegetarian diet included fruits, vegetables, grains and beans, the report said. The only animal products allowed were egg whites and a cup a day of non-fat milk or yogurt. Cholesterol intake was limited to five milligrams a day and caffeine was eliminated. Alcohol was limited to two units a day, although drinking was not encouraged. The study took place over a year. Ornish said follow-up testing will continue for four years to see whether blockages continue to reverse.

DOC.HEAD: US Team Heading for Angola to Discuss Food Aid
DOC.TEXT: An American team is heading to Luanda at the invitation of Angola's Marxist government to discuss how to get food aid to all areas of the country, including those held by U.S.-backed rebels. The four-person team will leave Saturday for the war-torn country where hundreds of thousands of people are starving. The team also will focus on efforts to achieve peace in the region. Guarded optimism that a solution could be found to the impasse over food aid came Thursday after Angola's ambassador to the United Nations, Manuel Pedro Pacavira, met with State Department officials and Rep. Tony Hall, D-Ohio, chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger. Pacavira, in an apparent turnaround in his government's position, said his country is willing to ``work closely'' with State Department officials to bring food to hundreds of thousands of people suffering hunger because of drought. ``What I heard was that the government of Angola is interested in working with the United Nations to deliver food through `corridors of safe passage' to all hungry Angolans, whether they are in government-held or UNITA-held territory,'' Hall said. UNITA is a U.S.-backed rebel group headed by Jonas Savimbi. ``That is a turnaround from what we were hearing a few weeks ago and it is very, very encouraging,'' Hall said. Angolan officials have said they are concerned that food deliveries to people in UNITA-held territory in Southern Angolan could be used as a cover for supplying weapons to Savimbi. UNITA, which has waged a civil war for more than 15 years against the Soviet-supported central government, controls major portions of land in southern Angola where some of the 250,000 Angolans are at risk because of food shortages. The State Department was similiarly encouraged by Pacavira's statements, a spokesman said. The ambassador had a ``frank and honest'' discussion with Jeffrey Davidow, deputy assistant secretary of state, and one of the four people who will travel to Angola, the official said. But the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the logistics of actually delivering food to parts of Angola could be sticky. Generally, an agreement on ``corridors of safe passage'' calls for both sides to stop hostilities on clearly marked airways and roads. If the United Nations is to monitor the arrangement, the Angolan government will have to contact officials of the international agency, an aide to Hall said. The United States had criticized the Angolan government for blocking food shipments to UNITA-held territory. Some $2 million in aid is already to be moved to areas where people are starving, officials said. Although the United States does not have diplomatic relations with Angola, State Department officials say since 1980 some $4 million in food has been sent to people in government-held territory as a humanitarian gesture. Pacavira's visit coincided with secret deliberations in Congress over how much military aid to provide Savimbi in 1991. A House subcommitee started marking up the intelligence authorization bill, which includes aid to Angola, on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Report Says Immigration Contributes to Measles Outbreak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `20 weeks' is cq in 6th graf
DOC.TEXT: Measles vaccination programs should target all eligible people, but especially Hispanics who recently immigrated to the United States, federal health officials say.
