A report issued Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control also said measles continues to be transmitted in medical settings, especially hospital emergency rooms, because cases often are not diagnosed and isolated promptly. The CDC's weekly report, which highlighted information gathered by the Washington State Department of Health, said at least 26 percent of the measles cases recorded there this year were acquired in Mexico, or linked to cases acquired there. In contrast, 15 percent of the 55 cases reported in 1989 were linked to Mexico. Washington health officials reported 266 cases of measles during the first 26 weeks of 1990 _ nearly five times the number of cases reported statewide during all of 1989 and the largest number in the state since 1979. Nationwide, 7,653 cases were reported during the first 20 weeks of this year, the CDC said. Nearly half the cases in the Washington epidemic occurred among unvaccinated people, the CDC said. Of those unvaccinated, more than half were Hispanics, who account for 4 percent of Washington state's population of 4.5 million and make up its largest ethnic minority group. Detailed data available for 218 of the cases showed 97 cases, or 45 percent, occurred among Hispanics. Hispanic children showed the highest incidence rate, with 59, or 81 percent, under 5 years old. Of those, 32 were younger than 16 months old. Although measles vaccination coverage for Washington's total Hispanic population was unknown, the high attack rate for Hispanics suggests that coverage was low, the CDC said, noting that the state's Hispanic population increased by nearly 40 percent from 1980 to 1988. Barbara Baker, Washington's immunization director, said many of the state's Hispanics are migrant workers who take seasonal jobs harvesting fruit crops, including apples, cherries, peas and asparagus, and hops, used to flavor beer. In response to the measles epidemic, the state Department of Health spent $1.1 million for 76,000 doses of measles vaccine this spring, Ms. Baker said. The vaccination clinics were publicized in Spanish and English on radio and television, in newspapers and by sound trucks driven through areas with a high number of Hispanic residents, she said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: congressional testimony.
DOC.TEXT: North was convicted on May 4 of three counts stemming from the Reagan administration's secret arms clandestine effort to aid the Nicaraguan Contras. The divided three-judge panel held that North was entitled to a new trial on the charge of altering and destroying sensitive NSC documents because U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell gave erroneous jury instructions. The court also held that North was entitled to a full hearing delving into whether North's nationally televised testimony seeped into the case. The court also held that if Gesell determines at the hearing that such tainted evidence was used to convict North on the other two charges, he would be entitled to a new trial on those counts as well.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Serviceman Killed in Quake Relief Effort; Quake Toll Over 650
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 23 grafs, bodies found at Hyatt, moves up reference to searchers at hotel. Pick up 20th graf pvs, `Philippine television...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Marine plane crashed today while searching for people stranded after a devastating earthquake that killed more than 650 people. One serviceman died in the accident and one was hurt. President Corazon Aquino, in her first televised statement on the disaster, today defended her administration's response to the quake. The government has been widely criticized for being slow and disorganized in its rescue and relief operations. Also today, rebel soldiers who led a December coup attempt against Mrs. Aquino offered a truce to help relief efforts. In the mountain resort of Baguio in the heart of the quake zone, two bodies were found today in the ruins of the Hyatt Hotel, where nearly 50 people were believed trapped. The rescuers had worked through the night after finding fresh human blood in a tunnel they dug under the rubble of the hotel, indicating some people could still be alive. They pulled out the body of a woman and found the body of a man, who could not be immediately extricated. Power was restored to parts of Baguio today. Many city residents, fearing they will be buried in their homes by aftershocks, were camped in makeshift tents in a park. The crash of the observation aircraft occurred near Baguio, 110 miles north of Manila on Luzon island, the U.S. Embassy said. One crewman was killed and the other was airlifted to a U.S. military hospital, the U.S. Embassy said. Their names were not released pending notification of relatives. Officials said at least 224 people _ including two Americans _ were killed in Baguio during Monday's earthquake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale. Hundreds of people may have died in remote areas of the stricken region that are only now reporting damage and deaths, officials said. The latest official figures say 659 people died and more than 1,300 were injured in the earthquake. About 190 people were believed buried in ruins of seven hotels and in a factory in Baguio that caught fire after the quake, according to Jose de Jesus, chairman of the presidential task force supervising rescue efforts in Baguio. Rescuers fear most are dead. De Jesus said Marines and Philippine troops had begun operations to rescue more than 100 people believed stranded on highways near Baguio. Heavy casualties were also concentrated in Cabanatuan, 60 miles north of Manila, where more than 60 students and teachers were killed at the Philippine Christian College. One girl who was injured at the college told ABS-CBN television today that her class was in the middle of a lesson on earthquakes when the quake struck and the classroom collapsed. Mrs. Aquino pledged in a nationally televised address that her government would rebuild areas devastated by the quake, and defended its much-criticized relief effort. ``Let us not blame others,'' she said. ``Let us stop making snide remarks. What we need now is to help each other.'' Rebels who tried to topple Mrs. Aquino in December offered a truce to help with the relief effort. ``We call on the present leadership to set aside all political differences in order to squarely face this catastrophe,'' the underground Revolutionary Alliance of the Masses-Soldiers of the Filipino People said in a statement. It said the rebels have declared a unilateral stop to all anti-government activities ``during this time of national tragedy'' and called on the government to temporarily stop its operations against the rebels. The Marine OV-1 light observation plane crashed while searching the mountains for motorists and others stranded along highways closed by landslides during the quake. Officials said the aircraft was from the U.S.-run Subic Bay naval base 50 miles west of Manila. Philippine television, whose crews flew aboard some of the search planes, showed several buses and cars wreckaged by landslides. Some residents had apparently used gravel and limestone to write `SOS'' along the highway. Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos said more than 900 others also were feared stranded in a mountain pass along the border of Nueva Vizcaya and Nueva Ecija provinces.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules He Doesn't Have Authority to Change Movie Ratings
DOC.TEXT: A judge said he does not have the authority to change the ``X'' rating given to the Spanish film ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' But acting state Supreme Court Justice Charles Ramos in his ruling Thursday also denounced the system that issued the ``X'' rating. The state Supreme Court is Manhattan's trial level court. The movie's American distributor, Miramax Films Corp., and its producer-director, Pedro Almodovar, asked the court to change the rating. They said the ``X'' designation was arbitrary, capricious, unfair and a form of censorship. Ramos agreed that the rating system used by the Motion Picture Association of America seven-member ratings board ``is an effective form of censorship.'' But he said the petition before his court was not the proper vehicle for relief. The MPAA says its rating system is a guide for parents to make judgments about which movies they want their children to see. It is not designed to rate the merits of a film, the MPAA says. The MPAA said Almodovar's movie, whose Spanish title is ``Atame!'', was rated ``X'' because of ``a prolonged and graphic sex scene photographed from numerous angles and accompanied by an explicit sound track.'' Ramos said nothing supports the MPAA's claim that its ratings are designed to protect children. No physicians, child psychiatrists or child care professionals are on the board, nor is guidance from such professionals sought, the judge noted. Ramos said that ``the rating system's categories have been fashioned by the motion picture industry to create an illusion of concern for children, imposing censorship, yet all the while facilitating the marketing of exploitive and violent films with an industry seal of approval.'' ``Notably absent (from the ratings system) is any sensitivity to the offenses suffered by women, minorities, the disabled and those who may not share the values'' of the average American parent, Ramos said. ``A film may be viewed by children that may contain `hard violence' and `drug use' but not explicit sex,'' he said. ``It may be that the MPAA ratings are skewed toward permitting film makers huge profits pandering to the appetite for films containing `hard violence' and `drug use' while neglecting the welfare of children.'' The judge also said the MPAA needs a system that would distinguish between movies for adult audiences like ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' and pornography. William Kunstler, lawyer for Miramax and Almodovar, said he will appeal the decision. ``As the rest of the world moves toward freer and open expression in politics and art, it is deeply disturbing, that in the United States the censors, bigots and blue noses exert increasing control over what we may see and what we may say,'' Kunstler said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Factions Battle With Artillery and Tanks for Fifth Day
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with PLO-Hezbollah fighting. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `Hezbollah wrested...'
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian guerrillas ringed a stronghold of pro-Iranian militiamen today after three PLO fighters were killed by grenade-throwing fundamentalists, police reported. They said seven other Palestinians were wounded as fighters of the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, charged out of the hilltop town of Jarjou overnight and staged six hit-and-run grenade attacks on the guerrillas. The PLO responded by rushing in 200 more guerrillas with multibarreled rocket launchers from its main bases near the port city of Sidon, police said. A 600-member Palestine Liberation Organization force arrived Tuesday in Iqlim al-Tuffah, or the Apple province, in a vain bid to halt a new round of fighting between Hezbollah and the pro-Syrian Amal militia. The 5-day-old battle between the two Shiite Moslem factions in Jarjou and a cluster of surrounding villages overlooking Israel's self-designated security zone in southern Lebanon has left 70 Shiites dead and 232 wounded, by police counts. Lt. Col. Anwar Madi, commander of the PLO intervention force, reported the Palestinian casualties in Hezbollah's attack. He also told reporters at his headquarters in the village of Houmine that ``we have shot and killed or wounded many of them'' but did not provide a specific figure. Hezbollah wrested Jarjou from Amal on Monday in renewed fighting in the 3-year-old power struggle for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect. Today's casualties raised the overall toll to 1,114 killed and 3,374 wounded. Red Cross teams managed to get into Jarjou on Thursday for the first time since the clashes began and removed 11 bloated corpses that had been sprawled in the village square for four days. But the fighting flared anew, forcing them to dive for cover as shells exploded around the village. They fled Jarjou in a seven-car convoy. Red Cross officials said there were many other bodies lying around Jarjou. Officials of the International Committee of the Red Cross said today they did not know when they would try again to evacuate dead and wounded. Most of the region's 50,000 inhabitants fled their villages in January, when Hezbollah began a campaign to break out of its mountain enclave and reach the Mediterranean coast to open up a new supply route. A 600-man Palestine Liberation Organization force was deployed Tuesday along a four-mile line between Amal and Hezbollah, ostensibly to stop the fighting. But the primary objective of Yasser Arafat's PLO, which has its main bases in the port city of Sidon 10 miles northwest of Jarjou, was to block Hezbollah's push to expand its area of control. A thrust toward Sidon would allow Hezbollah to link up with anti-Arafat Palestinian radicals and threaten Arafat's forces. If Hezbollah reached the coast, it would cut off Amal's stronghold in the south from Beirut. The fundamentalists want a sea outlet to bring in weapons and supplies from Iran. Their main supply route is vulnerable because it runs through the Bekaa Valley in eastern Lebanon, which is controlled by the Syrian Army. The Apple Province covers 50 square miles of a rocky panhandle and abuts the supply route into the Christian town of Jezzine from the Israeli-held border zone. Jezzine, 11 miles east of Sidon, is controlled by an Israeli-armed militia, the South Lebanon Army. Its 3,000 mainly Christian fighters patrol the 440-square-mile Israeli enclave. The South Lebanon Army commander, retired Lebanese Army Gen. Antoine Lahd, warned Thursday night that his force might intervene in the Shiite fighting if it escalates and threatens his territory.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Says Black Will Serve as Spokesman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lede to clarify Black will be party spokesman; adds 4 grafs at end further describing Black and his role
DOC.TEXT: Republican Chairman Lee Atwater, who has been battling a brain tumor since March, said today that GOP consultant Charles Black will serve as the party's chief spokesman until he returns to work fulltime. Atwater said in a statement that his recovery is going very well. ``The doctors tell me that my tumor has stopped growing and is dying,'' he said. He said in recent weeks he has become more active in developing strategy and themes for the party, but still must spend several hours a day in physical therapy. Atwater said Black will serve as a daily spokesman for the party _ a role ``too important to let slip as we head toward Election Day'' _ until he can return to work on a fulltime basis. Atwater described Black as his ``best friend and political eyes and ears'' for the last 18 years. Black is also close to President Bush and has been helping run the Republican National Committee in Atwater's absence. Atwater said last week's RNC meeting in Chicago pointed up to him ``the need to have the strongest possible spokesmen available to carry our message to the public on a day-to-day basis.'' He said the meeting was a success because ``we did what we do best _ used aggressive politics on offense.'' He accused the Democrats of ``trying to use issue after issue for political gain'' and promised that his party would stay on the offensive. RNC spokesman Leslie Goodman said Black has been a consultant to the party since Atwater became chairman 18 months ago. She said his new role as chief spokesman will involve more public appearances and press interviews. ``It's more formalized. People will realize he speaks for Lee and the party,'' she said. ``Lee's got a lot on his mind and a lot of things he wants to say. Charlie's the best vehicle for doing that.'' Goodman said RNC chief of staff Mary Matalin also will continue to speak for the party. She said Black's new visibility will be an enhancement of his role, ``not a diminution of anybody else's.'' Black will continue his work as a GOP consultant and attend to party business as needed, Goodman said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Reformer Sues Party for Firing Him From Job At Party School
DOC.TEXT: The former director of a school that teaches Communist ideology has filed a lawsuit claiming he was wrongfully fired after announcing he was quitting the Communist Party, Tass reported today. In a suit filed against Moscow's Communist Party organization, Vyacheslav Shostakovsky asked a district court to protect his ``professional honor and human dignity,'' the official Soviet news agency said. Shostakovsky had been the rector of Moscow's Higher Party School, a party-run institution concentrating on continuing ideological education for party members. He was fired after telling the Communist Party Congress last week that he and other members of the Democratic Platform reform group were quitting the party to form an independent political group. Shostakovsky's was one of a wave of defections from the party that began after reform politician Boris N. Yeltsin shocked the congress by announcing his resignation from the party. Since then, some of the party's leading reformers, including the mayors of Moscow and Leningrad, have announced that they, too, are quitting the party. The Moscow party organization is led by Yuri Prokofiev, who was elevated to the national party organization's Politburo after the congress ended. Tass said some of Shostakovsky's staff wrote to Prokofiev to protest the firing. They said he was fired without consulting the local party body that had sent Shostakovsky to the congress, or the council that had elected him rector of the school. The report gave no further information on the suit.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Blames Democrats for `Gridlock in Washington'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs grafs 10-11 to reflect speech as delivered
DOC.TEXT: President Bush lashed out today at the Democrats, saying their ``stranglehold on Congress'' is to blame for the skyrocketing deficit and ``government by gridlock in Washington.'' ``Twenty-nine out of the last 35 years of Democrat control is long enough. We must have more Republicans in Congress,'' Bush said at a $100-a-plate fund-raising breakfast for GOP Senate candidate Allen Kolstad, Montana's lieutenant governor, who is trying to unseat incumbent Democratic Sen. Max Baucus. Bush reiterated his promise to negotiate a budget agreement ``without preconditions'' and said ``we are getting some good cooperation with the leadership on the Democratic side of the aisle'' in those talks. He devoted most of the speech to a strident attack on the opposition, who control the Senate by a 55-45 margin and the House by 257-176. Bush is hoping to wrest back control of the Senate for the GOP in this fall's 34 Senate races. ``With the Democrats now in the control of the United States Congress, both houses, we're facing government by gridlock in Washington, with spending skyrocketing out of control, good legislation thrown aside for pork barrel programs and a budget deficit looming over our children's children,'' Bush said. ``While the Republican Party is using everything we've got to build a strong, competitive America, the Democratic stranglehold on the United States Congress has finally taken its toll,'' he said. ``Enough is enough. We must end this 'deficits don't matter' mentality,'' Bush said. ``I do not want to preside over these godawful deficits that are saddling these young people here with billions in debt.'' He attacked Congress for not passing his educational excellence act and his version of child care legislation, and blasted it for adding $3.5 billion to his request for $800 million in emergency aid for Panama and Nicaragua last spring. It took 108 days to win passage of the bill, Bush said, a delay that ``jeopardized the hard-won freedom of the brave people of Nicaragua and Panama. That's more than a difference between parties. In my view that was a disgrace.'' Later, at an anti-drug rally in Daylis Stadium, Bush criticized Congress for not passing his anti-crime package. Standing in front of a huge banner with a map of Montana and the legend, ``Don't Let Drugs Cloud The Big Sky,'' Bush declared, ``It's time for Congress to act. Our children, our communities and our cops have waited long enough.'' Bush was flying later to Cheyenne, Wyo., to attend a Frontier Days parade and rally, inspect the nation's only squadron of 50 MX missiles in their silos at Warren Air Force Base and get in a quick fishing trip to the Middle Crow Creek Fishing Area before heading back to Washington. Asked why Bush was going out of his way to inspect the newest nuclear missile in the U.S. arsenal at a time of reduced East-West tensions, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the president wanted to underscore ``the need to maintain a strong defense during changing times.'' Soviet missiles are still ``aimed at us. Our relations are changing, but both countries have millions of men under arms,'' Fitzwater said aboard Air Force One. ``We can't let down our guard.'' At a GOP fund-raising dinner in Boise, Idaho, on Thursday, Bush defended his reversal on tax increases and blamed Congress for the looming $160 billion deficit. Addressing 900 people at an event that raised upwards of $200,000 for Rep. Larry Craig's Senate race, the president said Congress ``appropriates every dollar and tells the president how to spend every single penny.'' ``I have said I will negotiate without preconditions. And I will,'' he said. ``You've seen the firestorm about revenues being on the table,'' aid Bush, who sowed discord in Republican ranks last month by abandoning his ``no new taxes'' campaign pledge in acknowledging that ``tax revenue increases'' are needed to cut the deficit. ``Well, I've done my part and now it's their turn. A truly comprehensive package, not a temporary Band-Aid. There must be reform of the budget process and there must be real spending control,'' Bush said, his voice rising to a shout. ``The American people are entitled to that!''

DOC.HEAD: Alcohol Not the Cause of Bus Crash Involving American Students
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with police releasing bus driver, no signs of alcohol. Pickup 5th pvs, `Police identified...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON4,8
DOC.TEXT: Police today ruled out alcohol as a factor in a bus accident that killed two American students and injured dozens of others. The yellow double-decker bus was carrying summer school students and staff to an arts festival when it overturned Thursday as it turned off a highway near Wheatley, six miles east of Oxford, said Thames Valley Police Chief Inspector John Wheeler. No other vehicle was reported involved in the incident, in which 59 people were injured, most of them American teen-agers. Police today said the bus driver, who was slightly hurt, was detained Thursday but released on bail after a breath test showed no signs of alcohol. ``Alcohol wasn't the cause. It was a negative test,'' said a police spokesman on condition of anonymity. One witness said the accident scene was filled with ``utter chaos and mayhem.'' ``There were girls and boys trapped in the coach and others strewn up the bank,'' said ambulance superintendent Robin Finlayson. ``They were crying, bawling and bloody. ... Many had crush injuries.'' Police identified the two dead students as Autumn Dubose, 18, of Lilburn, Ga., and Lawrence Levine, 16, of Chappaqua, N.Y. Police said today they also were interviewing passengers. Four of the 59 injured people were seriously hurt, said Police Chief Inspector Laurie Fray. Authorities said the 61 people on the bus included 47 Americans, five Britons, two Japanese and one each from Canada, France, the Netherlands, Austria, Italy, and Mexico. The nationality of one student was not known. Most of the Americans were gifted students on a four-week summer school course at Oxford University's Magdalen College organized by the Oxford Advanced Studies Program in New York, said American coordinator Paul Beresford-Hill. Their ages ranged from 16 to 20. David Watson of the Bus and Coach Council, speaking on behalf of the bus owner, Bee Line, said it overturned on its right side as it turned left off the highway for the arts festival. He said Sharma, who has worked for the company for 14 years, appeared to have made a wide turn. Authorities said some of the passengers were thrown through windows and others crawled out of the bus. Some were pulled free and at least three were trapped inside for an hour. Max Koltuv, a 16-year-old New Yorker who suffered a broken hand, said he and three others were sitting in the front row on the top deck of the bus. ``I knew it was going too fast when it began to turn off the road. Suddenly, it began to tip and it rolled right over onto the embankment. The four of us were thrown through the front window and out into the grass, clear of the bus,'' he said. ``I blacked out but came around about 30 seconds later and all the people left on the bus were shouting and were hysterical,'' Koltuv said. A spokesman at John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford said most of the 35 people admitted had back and neck injuries ``of varying severity.'' A few suffered head injuries and others friction burns and lacerations but ``very few'' were in critical condition, said the spokesman, speaking on condition he was not identified. The 24 less seriously injured were taken to Wycombe General Hospital in nearby High Wycombe.

DOC.HEAD: Shrimper Boat Captains Arrested for TEDs Violations
DOC.TEXT: Five shrimpers were arrested off the Texas coast in a federal crackdown on fishermen working without net equipment to protect sea turtles. Two shrimp boat captains arrested Thursday off Freeport and Galveston were headed for the Harris County Jail in Houston. Three others arrested off Port O'Connor were held without bail in the Nueces County Jail in Corpus Christi pending court hearings. All are accused of violating federal laws that require them to use turtle excluder devices, or TEDs, to protect turtles that can get caught in shrimp nets and drown. The penalty for criminal TED violations can be up to six months in federal prison and $25,000 per incident. The arrests bring to six the number of captains accused of TED violations after their shrimp boats were boarded in Texas waters. Authorities announced earlier this week they were beefing up enforcement along the Texas coast after more than 31 sea turtles, including 17 endangered Kemp's ridley turtles, were found dead. The cause of the turtles' deaths has not yet been determined, but environmentalists have blamed the shrimpers.

DOC.HEAD: 82-Year-Old Artist Completes Mural after 56 Years
DOC.TEXT: It took four months, but 82-year-old Wilfrid Berg finished the mural he started 56 years ago in the children's reading room of the city's public library. The Hackley Public Library dedicated on Thursday the 29-foot-long mural that had been curtailed when a New Deal program was cut in 1934. ``I'm just overwhelmed,'' Berg said, tears welling in his blue eyes. ``I've always wanted to finish it.'' The mural, featuring characters from classic children's literature, stands above bookcases and a doorway directly opposite from another mural Berg painted in 1934. They both had been commissioned by the Works Progress Administration. When funding was canceled, Berg's sketches were stored in the Muskegon Museum of Art. They surfaced a few years ago, and they supporters of the library decided to sponsor the project. ``I realized that after all this time, there was the possibility he couldn't do it,'' said Robert Youngman, the museum's assistant curator of graphics. ``But he still has a very sure hand.'' Thursday's ceremony was part of the 100th anniversary celebration of the library. Berg kept the mural's original design and theme, ``Idle Hours with Good Books is Time Well Spent.'' The mural depicts two children sitting on a hill reading _ portraits of Berg's siblings as children _ with such characters as Cinderella, Huck Finn, Pinocchio and Peter Rabbit around them. Geese, frogs and fairies are scattered throughout. Berg said he was satisfied with the result but was eager to get out of the public spotlight. ``I'll be glad when this is all over,'' Berg said of the ceremony. ``I've got a lot of projects I want to get started on.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Archbishop Offers Resignation In Sex Abuse Scandal
DOC.TEXT: A report blaming Newfoundland's Roman Catholic Church for failing to stop priests who were sexually abusing boys has led Archbishop Alphonsus Penney of St. John's to offer his resignation to Pope John Paul II. Penney made a public apology to the victims and their families on Wednesday after the scathing report accused him of ignoring and then denying claims that boys in Newfoundland, an island province off the east coast of Canada, had been sexually abused by priests for more than a decade. Penney, 65, said he accepted full responsibility for failing to deal with the scandal, which first became public in 1987. Five men _ including priests and former priests _ have been convicted on sexual abuse charges in the past three years. Several others are awaiting trial. For 2{ years Penney refused calls to step down while more than 20 of his priests and lay members of the Newfoundland Catholic community were charged with or convicted of sexually abusing boys. The report, written by a commission set up by the archbishop a year ago, said church officials showed little compassion for the victims and aligned themselves with the accused. ``We are sorry for the times you were not believed, were not supported or were ostracized in any way in our community,'' Penney told a Catholic audience in St. John's. ``For every word and action which may have deepened your pain, we are profoundly sorry. The commission said the church adopted a policy of ``minimal response'' to the scandal, even though it was receiving complaints about some sexually deviant priests from parishioners, police officers, social workers and other priests. That response, the report said, ``was woefully inadequate and may have been psychologically damaging to all concerned.'' The boys, it said, were the victims of men they had been brought up to trust, men who ``abused their position of priestly status and power by acting out their regressed sexuality with children.'' The commission's findings stunned Newfoundland's 120,000 Roman Catholics. ``It pulled no punches on the state of affairs within our diocese,'' said Barbara Crosbie, vice chairman of a committee established to help the church respond to the report. The 700-page document will be sent out to parishes for study. A public meeting is scheduled for Oct. 11. ``I think the essence of the report will be embraced,'' Mrs. Crosbie said.

Penney made no defense of his actions. He has said in the past that he had no knowledge of allegations of sexual abuse by priests until November 1987, but the report found evidence he heard allegations in 1979 and in 1984. The 55 recommendations the commission made included the following: _That the church formally acknowledge its portion of guilt and apologize to the victims. _That the church compensate victims financially. _That it should revise policies on reacting to sexual abuse complaints. _That the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops be asked to ``fully, directly, hontestly and without reservation'' examine problems created by forcing priests to be celibate.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Say US Policy Still Helping Khmer Rouge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. policy is still helping the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia, despite changes announced by the Bush administration this week, witnesses told a Senate committee today. Senators of both parties and private witnesses said continued U.S. financial aid to a rebel coalition that includes the Khmer Rouge, and a continued U.S. economic embargo against Cambodia, lend indirect support to the feared rebel group. Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, a member of the intelligence committee, said Bush's withdrawal of recognition for the rebel coalition is insufficient. He called on Bush to help forge a coalition against the Khmer Rouge between the non-communist rebel factions and the current Cambodian government which they are fighting. ``Are we supporting a coalition we hope will win?'' asked Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., who made a trip to Cambodia earlier this year. ``I think the answer is likely no'' because a rebel victory would almost certainly install the Khmer Rouge _ the faction with the strongest military force, he said. Former Secretary of State Edmund Muskie, who traveled to Cambodia last year as chairman of the liberal Center for National Policy, said he believed the Bush administration will make further policy changes because ``the administration finally understands that the U.S. government could have on its record, if not on its conscience, the death of a nation.'' U.S. intelligence reports show a pattern of military activity by the Khmer Rouge much like the moves that led them to power 15 years ago, say sources familiar with the reports. The information, including indications of military cooperation and shared supply lines between the Khmer Rouge and the U.S.-backed non-communist rebels, was contained in briefings the CIA and Defense Intelligence Agency gave to congressional and executive branch officials, the sources said. The Khmer Rouge presided over a massive agrarian reform experiment in Cambodia during its 3{-year rule that resulted in the deaths of more than 1 million countrymen from execution, starvation and disease. Fearing a comeback by the communist guerrillas, the administration announced Wednesday it was withdrawing support for a United Nations seat for the three-party resistance that includes the Khmer Rouge, the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and the faction of former Cambodian prime minister Son Sann. Secretary of State James A. Baker III also said the United States would open talks with Vietnam, which installed the current Cambodian regime. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said U.S. intelligence sees the events in 1974 and 1975 that led to the takeover of Cambodia by the Khmer Rouge as a virtual ``model'' for events occurring now. Those events include attacks on provincial capitals and other significant targets, a near-permanent presence in the northern part of the country and deeper penetration since Vietnamese occupation forces withdrew last year. The stepped-up rebel attacks pose a threat to the Hun Sen government, and there are reports that in some instances the government's soldiers have stopped fighting, according to the analysis. The Khmer Rouge has about 30,000 to 40,000 troops, while government forces number 60,000 to 100,000. Soviet and Vietnamese aid to the Cambodian government has declined, and while Phnom Penh remains a bustling capital with a robust economy, the economy in government-controlled parts of the countryside is fragile and inflation is rising, the analysts said. Some government workers and military personnel are not being paid, they said. U.S. intelligence believes that all of the 140,000 Vietnamese troops who were in Cambodia have been withdrawn, with only a few advisers remaining. The intelligence agencies estimate China's military aid to the Khmer Rouge at about $100 million a year. Other sources have said the United States provides $13 million a year in covert aid to the non-communist resistance forces, together with $7 million in public, ``non-lethal'' aid. Singapore gives an additional $10 million yearly to the non-communist forces. The U.S. aid remains the subject of hot debate on Capitol Hill, where the Senate Intelligence Committee has voted to end the covert program. Some congressional opponents of past U.S. policy say it makes no sense to continue to send aid while withdrawing recognition of the resistance coalition.

DOC.HEAD: Customs Service Worker Charged With Leaking Confidential Information
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Customs Service worker was been charged with passing confidential information from a nationwide computer network to a second man who shared it with a suspected drug smuggler, officials said. Assistant U.S. Attorney Tom Stahl said the alleged leak scuttled a drug-smuggling investigation. ``The loss to the government is that a drug smuggler learned that he was being investigated for drug smuggling, and the investigation was impaired,'' and subsequently dropped, Stahl said Thursday. The compromised drug investigation involved no undercover agents, and apparently no law enforcement figures were endangered by the alleged leak, Stahl said. A five-page indictment identified the Customs Service worker as David Henry Brown, 48, of San Diego. The Customs Service said Brown is an information management specialist employed in the agency's San Diego computer center. Customs Service spokesman Mike Fleming said that Brown, who had worked for the Customs Service since 1972, was placed on administrative leave Thursday and a decision was pending on whether he would be fired. The information Brown allegedly passed came from the Treasury Enforcement Communications System, a nationwide computer network containing confidential law enforcement intelligence information. The data pool provides ``awide variety of information'' to Customs Service agents, Fleming said. Included in the network is information on warrants, pending criminal investigations and smuggling operations. None of the information is classified for national security purposes, but the network contains confidential law enforcement information, and thus ``is sensitive in a general sense,'' Fleming said The indictment alleged that Brown passed the computer information to Joseph Philip Souza, 47, of Newport, R.I., in 1988 and earlier this year. Souza was charged with Brown; both men face one count of conspiracy to defraud the United States and two counts of conversion of government property. Neither Brown nor Souza has been arrested; both are expected to appear early next week for arraignment before a U.S. magistrate in San Diego, Stahl said. The indictment said Souza passed the confidential information to a third man _ Jerald Bacal, 33, of Escondido _ who was the target of the scuttled Customs Service drug-smuggling investigation. If convicted, Brown and Souza could each face maximum prison terms of 25 years and fines totaling $750,000, according to the government.

DOC.HEAD: United States Postpones Annual Defense Meeting With Israel
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 3-5 and 11-12 to UPDATE with Baker planning meeting with new Israeli foreign minister. Edits to conform. Picks up 9th graf pvs, Arens was scheduled...
DOC.TEXT: The United States is postponing an annual meeting with Israeli representatives to review joint defense projects, but officials say the move is not related to U.S. efforts to prod Israel into accepting peace talks with the Palestinians. The talks, known as the Joint Security Assistance Program, were scheduled to be held in Washington next week. Diplomatic sources said today, however, that Secretary of State James A. Baker III has scheduled a meeting in Washington with David Levy, the new Israeli foreign minister. The session could set the stage for a new Bush administration drive to propel Israel into talks with Palestinian Arabs. Baker and Levy had planned to meet in Paris last week but Levy was recuperating from surgery for a circulatory ailment. His physicians advised him against traveling to France. The U.S. postponement of the Joint Security Assistance Program talks took Israeli officials by surprise, coming as it did shortly before the director general of Israel's defense ministry, David Ivri, and the new defense minister, Moshe Arens, were scheduled to arrive in Washington, said a source who spoke on condition of anonymity. A State Department official said the postponement was caused by the budget meetings under way between the administration and Congress, which he said have created some uncertainty about the amount of money that will be available for foreign aid. The session with Israel was to focus on U.S. aid for fiscal year 1992 that starts Oct. 1, 1991. ``We still don't know what our budget will look like then, how can we discuss it with the Israelis?'' said the State Department official. Israel is the largest recipient of U.S. aid, getting $3 billion annually in military and economic assistance. ``We are not sending any signals,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official said Israel had agreed to the U.S. suggestion that the talks be held in September. Last March, a formula devised by Baker for talks between Israel and Palestinian Arabs was rejected by the Israeli government, which collapsed over the dispute. Levy, a hard-liner, has since taken over as foreign minister. Baker, preparing to try again, has met in Washington with Egyptian and Jordanian officials. But talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, held through U.S. Ambassador Robert Pelletreau Jr. in Tunisia, were broken off after a failed terrorist attack against Israel. The secretary of state has been pressing Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to agree to peace talks with Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. But Shamir has resisted the pressure and Baker has in recent weeks displayed marked impatience. Arens was scheduled to arrive in Washington today for talks with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Israeli and U.S. officials insisted Arens' visit was not connected to the postponement of the talks despite the fact that it had only been arranged within the past week and officially announced on Thursday. Israeli officials said Arens had taken Cheney up on an invitation delivered by telephone soon after Arens took office last month. But other officials said Arens was anxious to discuss with Cheney the question of continued U.S. financing for the Israeli-developed Arrow anti-missile project. Arens also wants to discuss with Cheney recent threats by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein against Israel and against Kuwait. The annual sessions are designed to review joint defense projects such as research and development of weapons systems, exchange of military and intelligence information and the allocation of U.S. money for various projects in Israel. The talks involve representatives from Israel's treasury department, its defense and foreign ministries, along with their U.S. counterparts.

DOC.HEAD: New Mooove: Summer Jackets Developed to Shield Cows from the Sun
DOC.TEXT: A university professor says he has developed summer jackets with matching hats to shield cows from the sun, insects and diseases _ and allow them to produce more milk. The outfit consists of three straw pieces that cover the head, back and abdomen, Mosaku Sakurai, of the Tokyo University of Agriculture, said Friday. He said he had developed the jackets after observing cows for more than eight years. Sakurai, an agriculture professor, said cows lose their appetites and produce less milk when they are exposed to the sun during summer. The back of a black-haired cow can reach 140 degrees if it is outside for about 20 minutes in summer, he said. By wearing the jacket, a cow can spend more time eating grass and can produce more milk, he said. The jacket is not yet being produced commercially.

DOC.HEAD: Byelorussian Parliament Approves Aid For Chernobyl Victims
DOC.TEXT: The Byelorussian legislature has approved compensation for 1.8 million people living on land contaminated by the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear plant accident, Tass reported Friday. The decision was made Thursday, one week after the legislature declared the republic a ``national ecological disaster zone,'' the official Soviet news agency said. Everyone living on land contaminated above a certain level will receive $25 per month beginning in August, Tass said. Byelorussia took the brunt of the radioactivity spewed from the Chernobyl plant in the neighboring republic of Ukraine.

DOC.HEAD: Iberia Air Line Begins Madrid-Moscow Service
DOC.TEXT: Iberia Air Lines inaugurated non-stop service from Madrid to Moscow Friday, but only two of the 155 passengers aboard were actually bound for the Soviet capital. An Iberia official said the rest of the passengers on the Boeing 747 were to continue on to Tokyo, where the twice-weekly flight ends. The official told the independent Spanish news agency Europa Press that he expected the number of passengers would increase once the flight's existence became better known. The flight leaves Madrid on Fridays and Saturdays and returns from Tokyo on the following days. The Soviet airline Aeroflot has one-stop flights between Moscow and Madrid.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens of Works Stolen From Museum Of Religious Art
DOC.TEXT: Thieves broke into a chapel housing a museum of religious art and stole about 40 paintings and statues made in the 17th and 18th centuries, police said Friday. Officials said it was difficult to estimate the value of the items, stolen late Wednesday or early Thursday by thieves who broke in through a window at the Chapel of the Penitents in the southern town of Val. Investigators said they were examining footprints at the scene, but no arrests have been made. Earlier this month, authorities reported four thefts from museums in Paris, including ancient jewelry and a Renoir painting stolen from the Louvre. The thefts prompted a major review of museum security.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Woman Who Set Her Dog On U.S. Professor And Policeman Jailed
DOC.TEXT: A homeless woman has been sentenced to three months in jail for setting her dog on an American professor who filmed her without permission and a policeman who came to the professor's aid. Gloria Allison-Grey, 43, became angry when Richard Passman, 44, of Shorewood, Wis., filmed her on June 27 in a squalid area of London dubbed Cardboard City, the prosecutor said. She pleaded guilty to assaulting the policeman with intent to resist arrest. She was not charged with assaulting Passman and his wife because they had returned home and would not have been available to give evidence. ``An innocent tourist, taking pictures, happens to catch you on his film and this is what happens _ a violent attack on him,'' the London magistrate said at Thursday's sentencing. The woman's lawyer said she suffered from epilepsy and had no recollection of the incident.

DOC.HEAD: President to Nominate Farm Board Member
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate John C. Datt, executive director of the American Farm Bureau Federation, to the Farm Credit Administration Board, the White House said Friday. Datt would succeed Marvin Duncan on the board for a term that runs through May 1996. The appointment was announced while Bush was here for a political fund-raiser and anti-drug rally.

DOC.HEAD: Heat Wave Sparks Fires On Siberian Tundra Near Arctic Circle
DOC.TEXT: A heat wave near the Arctic Circle set off fires in the tundra around the western Siberian city of Nadym, Tass reported Friday. A dense cloud of smoke hung over the city after two dozen fires broke out in peat bogs over an area of 1,730 acres, the official Soviet news agency said. The mayor of Nadym, a gas-production center, told Tass that firefighters were battling to keep fires away from gas pipelines. ``A tundra fire is a terrible scene,'' said construction worker Igor Shapovalov. ``We do not have special-purpose equipment or well-trained units to fight tundra fires. But we have still been able to stop fires moving toward fuel mains in two locations.'' Tass did not say what temperatures had been during the heat wave.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Spent Vacation Working, Playing With Son, Witness Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs today's testimony; picks up 4th graf pvs, fOutside the...
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry spent a Virgin Islands vacation working and playing with his son, not drinking and using cocaine as prosecutors allege, a police bodyguard testified today at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. But the witness, detective Ulysses Walltower, also testified that he was not in Barry's presence during much of the time that government witness Charles Lewis has said he used drugs with the mayor. Testifying on the second day of the defense's presentation, Walltower said Barry split his time between official duties and playing with his son Christopher during the four-day trip to the Virgin Islands in 1988. Lewis has testified that during Barry's first afternoon in the Virgin Islands, the two smoked crack cocaine together when others were absent from the mayor's hotel room. The detective said that on that afternoon he accompanied Barry's son and the boy's companion to a nearby beach. ``They went down several times, for 30 or 45 minutes,'' Walltower testified. ``Then they would go back to the room, mess around, and go back down to the beach.'' Walltower also acknowledged he spent little time with the mayor in the evenings _ periods where Lewis and other witnesses have said drugs were used. Walltower, a 20-year police veteran, also said he saw Barry in the company of only two women. Lewis, a convicted drug dealer, has testified that he brought three women to Barry's hotel room. On Thursday, two of the mayor's other security guards said they frequently drove the mayor to the homes of people who allegedly provided him with drugs. And a contract supervisor said he understood the mayor was interested in a city contract for Barry's girlfriend, former model Rasheeda Moore. Outside the courthouse, Barry characterized some of the government's questioning as ``satanic, dirt-like tactics.'' The two security guards, who are city police officers, and the supervisor, were called by the mayor's lawyers in an attempt to attack the credibility of prosecution witnesses who said they saw Barry use drugs. Instead, officer James Stays testified reluctantly that he took Barry to the homes of alleged drug suppliers Lloyd Moore and Jeff Mitchell and the restaurant of a man who said he gave drugs to Barry about 30 times. Officer Warren Goodwine testified that he drove the mayor to the home of Doris Crenshaw on at least two occasions. Crenshaw testified she saw Barry use drugs about a dozen times. Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin questioned Stays about allegations that he had used cocaine. Stays denied that and also denied telling another security officer that a friend of the mayor's was providing him with cocaine. Retchin said a witness had given grand jury testimony that Stays had used cocaine. She also said that Stays earlier this year had refused to undergo a urinalysis for drugs. Goodwine told investigators earlier this year that he did not want to know what the mayor was doing and that he stayed away from Barry's activities as much as possible. Those statements were ``probably taken out of context,'' Goodwine testified Thursday. He said he felt he should stay out of Barry's ``personal business ... that was not my business.'' Stays testified that he never delivered money to Rasheeda Moore so that she could buy drugs for the mayor. Darryl Hardy of the city's summer youth program said his boss had given him the ``impression'' that Barry and top city officials wanted a no-bid $57,000 contract awarded to Moore for a modeling project. Hardy also told investigators earlier this year that he understood that Barry wanted the dollar amount of the contract doubled in 1987. But he testified that he couldn't recall making the earlier statement. Hardy said he judged Moore's program on its merits and that there was no interference to approve it in 1986 and 1987 or cancel it in 1988. Moore has testified that Barry refused to help her get it renewed in 1988 because she rejected his request for sex. Barry, 54, is accused of 10 counts of cocaine possession, one count of conspiracy count and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Had Little Warning Before Blasts
LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with officials crediting one man for pulling alarm. No plans to change operations at other plants. Picks up 3rd graf, `Firefighters continued ...'
DOC.TEXT: A quick-thinking chemical plant foreman ``very likely saved a lot of lives'' when he sounded an alarm just seconds before explosions ripped through the building, killing one worker and injuring 68, authorities said. ``One of the maintenance foremen noticed a vapor cloud, immediately ran over and pulled the alarm,'' Ron Leisner, a quality assurance manager for BASF Corp., said at a news conference. ``He was very calm under pressure and very likely saved a lot of lives by doing so.'' Leisner said the foreman, Joe Brock, was outside the resin building when he saw the vapor, what Leisner described as being similar to the shimmering effect above a blacktop road on a hot day. ``Our fire alarm went off, I got about five steps ... The explosion hit and it knocked everybody off their feet,'' said Thomas Borst, a chemist who was working in an adjacent building at the plant when the blast hit. Larry Jameson, president of BASF's Coatings and Colorants Division, said the company had not determined the cause of the explosion, but suspected that something went wrong with equipment that processes chemical polymers into paint. He said the process is used at other BASF plants, and there were no plans to suspend those operations. ``We really have no reason to suspect that this is an unsafe practice,'' Jameson said. Firefighters continued to douse the building with water today to prevent chemicals from reigniting, Fire Chief Bill Miller said. It took about 2{ hours to bring the fire under control. About 2,000 residents were evacuated from their homes Thursday night while inspectors checked for structural damage. By this morning, Norwood Fire Chief David Cartuyvelles said, everyone was allowed to return to their homes. Only some businesses near the plant remained closed today, he said. Most of the evacuees were in Norwood, a suburb surrounded by Cincinnati. The plant is on the line between the two municipalities. ``I thought an airplane hit the building,'' said Charles Moore, a resident who said he was in his 80s. ``The concussion knocked me out of my chair. It sounded like a bomb.'' The cause of the explosions in the building on the 9-acre site remained under investigation. ``We don't have any idea what started the blaze,'' BASF spokesman Helmut von Moltke said. The first explosion sent a cloud of thick, black smoke pouring from a four-story brick building containing resins and solvents. About 150 people were in the plant, which makes coatings for the insides of soft drink cans and for paper cups, said Kenneth Diedenhofer, a plant production manager. Diedenhofer said the building was ``engulfed in flames. I saw one guy hanging from the steps outside the building. The steps were blown out from the wall. His leg was tied into the steps. I was able to get him out.'' A second blast about a half-hour later blew out storefront windows as far as a quarter-mile away in the neighborhood of small, two-story homes. Smaller explosions sent balls of fire rolling into the sky. Malcolm Adcock, assistant city health commissioner, said preliminary findings by city investigators suggested that ``volatile and explosive'' industrial solvents leaked from a mixing vat and were ignited by a spark. Police Chief Lawrence Whalen identified the dead man as Lawrence D. Krechting, 55, of Norwood, a BASF maintenance worker. He apparently was killed by flying debris in the building where the explosions occurred, Whalen said. Hospitals in the city reported treating 68 people for burns, broken bones and cuts caused by flying glass. Three people remained in critical condition today. The company has accounted for all of the workers who were in the plant, Miller said. Tests by the city and by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency showed no toxic fumes in the smoke from the fire, Miller said.

DOC.HEAD: Lyme Disease Noted in Proclamation
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has signed an order proclaiming July 22-28 as Lyme Disease Awareness Week, the White House said Friday. The proclamation, issued in conjunction with a joint congressional resolution, notes that the tick-borne disease has spread to 45 states since its discovery in Lyme, Conn., in 1975. The disease, which can affect the heart, nervous system and other parts of the body, is caused by a bacterial infection transmitted to humans through tick bites. The ticks, frequently no larger than the head of a pin, feed primarily on deer and field mice, but can also attach themselves to cats, dogs, birds, horses and other animals. ``Although it is easily treated when diagnosed early, Lyme disease can become very serious if it remains undetected,'' Bush said in his proclamation. The proclamation was released here while Bush was addressing a political fund-raiser and anti-drug rally. He actually signed the proclamation Thursday.

Thirty years after he took out a loan on five acres of land at Perth in the first step toward building a multinational empire, the businessman and yachtsman has offered to quit as chairman of his flagship Bond Corp. DOC.TEXT: MOSCOW _ Even McDonald's couldn't bring fast food to Moscow. Hundreds of young Soviets are selling ``Beeg Maks'' as fast as their hands can move, ricocheting off each other in the crush behind the counter at the McDonald's less than a mile from the Kremlin. But even 5,000 sandwiches an hour is not enough to satisfy Soviet hunger for a taste of the West. Slug AM-Soviet-McDonald's. New, should stand. By Ann Imse. Moving on FFF- and AAA-level news wires.

DOC.HEAD: A Growing Trend: Hydrant Locks to Reduce Illegal Summer Showers
DOC.TEXT: The spray of an open fire hydrant _ for generations, an escape from urban summer swelter _ is going the way of such lost childhood pleasures as marbles and mumbletypeg. Newark is among a small group of cities that have turned to The Custodian, a magnetic locking device, to crack down on the illegal diversion of city water from hydrants. Hydrants have long offered children the easiest, cheapest way to cool down on a summer's day. But the practice has a dangerous downside _ it diverts water that may be needed to fight fires. Some children say they know about the dangers in opening hydrants, but they need some relief from the sweltering conditions of the city. ``They should and they shouldn't do it,'' said Latasha Harris, 14, who used to play under open hydrants. ``In a way, it's dangerous, because people could be hurt in a fire if there's no water. ``But it's hot. I mean, some people can't afford to go places to go swimming. They should at least let people use the sprinklers. That doesn't waste as much water.'' Officials in Newark, Paterson and Passaic in New Jersey, and in Boston, Chicago and Kansas City, Mo., say the magnetic lock that slips over the top of a fire hydrant has sharply reduced the amount of water loss. The lock comes equipped with a key wrench, which is needed to open the hydrant. They are also used in Washington, D.C., and New Haven, Conn. ``This is the first thing we've found so far that has worked,'' said Bob Kerns, director of the Kansas City Board of Public Utilities. Installing 1,500 caps on the most popular of the city's 5,200 hydrants saved Newark enough money on salaries, repairs and water to pay for the devices, said Andrew Pappachen, a supervising engineer in the Water Department. Hydra-Shield Manufacturing Inc. of Irving, Texas, sells The Custodian and its special wrench for about $500, said salesman Ron Green. Sales primarily have been in northeastern cities, he said. The average number of open hydrant reports on a typical summer weekend dropped from 200 two years ago to 10 this summer, said Newark Fire Department spokesman Larry Krieger. Vandals have used blow torches, chain saws, drills and sledgehammers to damage the locking device, officials said, but only on a few occasions have they succeeded in getting water from the hydrants. ``Some people really attack them,'' said Mark Durham of the Chicago Water Department. ``There have been cases where hydrants were damaged and rendered inoperable, but no water was lost.'' The Custodian is an improvement over earlier hydrant security devices, said Wendell Inhoffer, general superintendent of the Passaic Valley Water Commission, which installed 400 caps in Paterson and Passaic. ``Some early devices needed scissor wrenches to open, so we made sure all the fire departments had them. The kids found a way to open them with coat hangers,'' Inhoffer said. Illegal taps were virtually eliminated in Boston after the caps were installed on all hydrants in public housing projects, said Fred Famolare, an aide to the Fire Department's deputy chief. ``But nothing's foolproof. We've noticed lately that some people are putting a large magnet on top of the hydrant and then using a plumber's wrench,'' Famolare said. Boston firefighters also have discovered a new problem: out-of-town fire companies helping Boston units have found they cannot open the hydrants. Famolare said wrenches are being supplied. Open hydrants can spew more than 1,000 gallons of water a minute and reduce water pressure in a system, a potentially dangerous problem when there is a fire. In Newark, Krieger said community groups are no longer allowed to open hydrants with sprinkler caps. ``The drain on the water system was tremendous,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agencies Say No Investigation Planned of Rare Cancer
DOC.TEXT: Two federal health agencies say they won't investigate an outbreak of a rare cancer suffered by three babies here unless asked to do so by the state health department. The cancer, neuroblastoma, strikes the adrenal glands and nervous system and occurs primarily in children under age 10. Usually found in just nine of every million children, three children under the age of 22 months in this central Illinois city of 11,000 suffer from it. Earlier this week, some residents petitioned the federal Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to study whether the cancer might be linked to a hazardous waste site in town, which the ill children live near. Some residents of the town 50 miles south of Springfield fear the cancer may be caused by a former coal gasification plant of Central Illinois Public Service Co., where contamination was found in surrounding soil and water. On Thursday, representatives of the CDC and the federal Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry said the petition for help probably won't bring an immediate response. The Illinois Department of Public Health this spring completed an initial health assessment and is reviewing all cancer cases, childhood cancers and the neuroblastoma in Taylorville. It doesn't plan to ask for federal help until the studies are completed, in two to three months. The Taylorville children diagnosed with neuroblastoma since March 1989 are 8-month-old Erika May, 22-month-old Zachary Donaldson, and 7-month-old Chad Hryhorysak. Erika and Zachary have been successfully treated. Chad is undergoing chemotherapy. The condition can be fatal if left untreated but usually can be caught in time. All three children lived within three miles of the abandoned plant when they got sick.

DOC.HEAD: North Korea Calls South Korea's Open-Border Offer Propaganda
LaserPhotos SEL2, NY13
DOC.TEXT: Communist North Korea on Friday dismissed as propaganda a South Korean proposal to open temporarily the heavily fortified border that has divided the peninsula for 45 years. South Korea offered to open its border at the border village of Panmunjom for five days beginning Aug. 13, allowing North Koreans to travel freely anywhere in the South. The Korean border is the last major outpost of the Cold War, guarded by more than 1 million troops on either side behind concrete bunkers and barbed wire. Neither side has ever allowed citizens to freely visit the other side, and there is no telephone, mail or any other communications between the two. Only once, in 1985, the Koreas exchanged 151 people from each side for the first reunion of separated families in their capitals. South Korea's President Roh Tae-woo suggested the five-day border opening as a trial period. It would include Aug. 15, symbolically important to both Koreas as the day that ended 35 years of Japanese colonial rule. Panmunjom, the Korean War truce village, is in the Demilitarized Zone located 35 miles north of Seoul. The village is manned by U.S., South Korean and North Korean soldiers and is the site for sporatic North-South talks. No civilians can enter the area without approval. ``The time has come to end total division,'' Roh said in a radio and television address. ``Korea must not remain the world's only land still partitioned by Cold War politics.'' North Korea's Pyongyang Radio, monitored in Tokyo, called Roh's offer a ``fradulant propaganda'' ploy. The official North Korean news agency, reacting to Roh's offer, urged the demolition of barriers along the border, the repeal of South Korean security laws that forbid unauthorized travel to the north, and the release of prisoners jailed for making such visits. But the Korean Central News Agency report used unusually polite and restrained language. Typically, the agency refers to Roh as a ``traitor.'' However, Friday's story referred to him as ``the South Korean chief executive.'' South Korea said it had suggested the two sides meet July 30 to discuss the border-opening offer. Two weeks ago, North Korea offered to open a small portion of its border beginning Aug. 15 at Panmunjom, but with passage to be restricted. The two Koreas have already scheduled a meeting July 26 to sign an accord setting up the first meeting of the two countries' prime ministers, expected to be held in Seoul as early as August. Radical South Korean students claimed Roh's announcement was aimed at diverting public attention from troubled domestic politics. They demanded the immediate release of all political prisoners, including a student and a pastor jailed last year for travel to North Korea. Lee Hong-koo, one of Roh's top aides, said those arrested for making illegal trips to North Korea would not be released. Korea was divided into Communist North Korea and capitalist South Korea in 1945 at the end of World War II. The two fought a three-year civil war in the early 1950s.

DOC.HEAD: The Boggses' Husband-Wife Congressional Dynasty Ending
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from gathering. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `Mrs. Boggs...'. ADDS one graf on end with further background on other candidates.
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Rep. Lindy Boggs announced today she is retiring, ending a husband-and-wife congressional dynasty spanning nearly half a century. ``This chapter in my service to the public is ending,'' Mrs. Boggs, 74, said in a statement released this morning announcing her decision not to run again. ``This is not the end of my career. I will continue to actively participate in community activities here and in Washington ...,'' the statement said. ``Although there are challenges that remain to be met, together we will go forward.'' Later, she was applauded by a gathering of 150 colleagues, supporters, friends and family when she said ``I am proud of my small role in opening doors to blacks and women.'' It had been widely reported in the New Orleans media that Mrs. Boggs would retire to spend more time with her daughter, Barbara Sigmund, who is suffering from cancer. Mrs. Sigmund is mayor of Princeton, N.J. At the Tulane University gathering, Mrs. Boggs made no specific reference to her daughter's illness. However she did say that the decision to retire was a wrenching one because so many people offered to help run her office and campaign and let her take care of family obligations. ``I don't think I can share with you all of the things that ran through my mind, because some of them are very personal,'' she said. Mrs. Boggs is the only white member of Congress representing a black-majority district. She has been on Capitol Hill 17 years and her withdrawal would offer an opportunity for Louisiana to elect its first black congressman. Her husband, Hale, then a young New Orleans lawyer, won the 2nd Congressional District in 1940. The district covers most of New Orleans. He lost a re-election bid in 1942, but reclaimed the job in 1946, beginning a string of 22 consecutive victories by him or his wife. Hale Boggs eventually became House majority leader. He was presumed dead in the disappearance of a plane in Alaska in 1972. Mrs. Boggs took over his seat in March 1973 after winning a special election. She was re-elected nine times, never getting less than 60 percent of the ote. She was appointed to the House Appropriations Committee, which approves federal spending. Apart from her political strength, some black potential candidates have not challenged Mrs. Boggs out of respect for the family's steady support of civil rights issues. But two blacks have already announced their candidacies this year _ State Sen. Jon Johnson and lawyer Marc Morial, a son of the late Mayor Dutch Morial. State Sen. William Jefferson had said he would probably enter the race if Mrs. Boggs stepped out.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Announced to Clean Up Contaminated Ghost Town Of Times Beach, Mo.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with comment from news conferennce; CORRECTS that Syntex did not make chemical, explain why it was held responsible. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Federal and state environmental officials announced an agreement today intended to clear the way for the cleanup of dioxin-contaminated Times Beach, which has been an untouched ghost town since 1983. Morris Kay, regional director of the federal Environmental Protection Agency, announced the settlement with Syntex Agribusiness Inc., a Palo Alto, Calif.-based chemical and animal health company, at a news conference. Today's agreement calls for Syntex to incinerate the dioxin-contaminated soil from Times Beach and 27 other sites in eastern Missouri. Syntex will design and build the incinerator at Times Beach, and then tear it down and remove it when the cleanup is complete. Times Beach, about 20 miles southwest of St. Louis, made headlines seven years ago when health officials discovered that dioxin in waste oil had been sprayed on the town's streets. The federal government bought out the town _ 801 homes and businesses _ in 1983 and began trying to figure out how to clean up the contaminated streets. Syntex, which was not the producer of the dioxin, became involved in the settlement because it leased a plant owned by one of its subsidiaries to a company that produced the dioxin as a byproduct in making a disinfectant. Under federal environmental laws, Syntex is considered a responsible party. ``We very pleased with the agreement and we believe the agreement addresses the local people's concern,'' Kay said. ``We're not going to allow anything that's unsafe.'' The EPA has said the entire cleanup of Times Beach and other Missouri sites will cost about $118 million and could take up to 10 years; Syntex estimates it will take seven years. The company declined to say how much it expects to spend on the cleanup. ``We have accepted this settlement because it allows us to use our scientific and technical expertise to help rid Missouri of contamination,'' said Syntex spokesman Ray Forrester. The agreement was first proposed in 1988, but negotiations, public hearings and other required procedures had to be held before today's settlement could be reached. Although the settlement brings the start of work closer, it remains unclear when the first loads of soil will actually be burned. A 30-day comment period is required before the company can even take the next step, which is to look for a company to design and build the temporary incinerator. And some people who live near Times Beach have threatened to file lawsuits to block the project, saying that the incinerator is unsafe and may never be dismantled. ``There's no doubt in my mind that it will be permanent,'' said Barney Nelson, mayor of nearby Eureka.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion Rips Through London Stock Exchange
LaserPhotos LON5,9,10,12, LaserColor LON112
DOC.TEXT: A bomb blew a hole in the London Stock Exchange on Friday, but no one was injured and trading hummed along without interruption on computers. A telephone caller earlier had warned of an IRA bomb. Authorities rushed to the exchange and evacuated scores of traders and other employees just minutes before the market was to open to hundreds of visitors. Glass and chunks of concrete showered down on Old Broad Street in the heart of the city's financial district. The stock exchange index was up for the day, but options trading was suspended until Monday. Five hours after the blast, employees returned to the building. ``If the purpose of this callous act was to bring the City (financial district) to a halt, they have failed singularly,'' said Andrew Hugh Smith, chairman of the Stock Exchange. George Churchill-Coleman, commander of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist unit, said the bomb had been planted in a men's restroom in a visitors' area, and contained 5 to 10 pounds of high explosives. Asked if he believed the Irish Republican Army was responsible, Churchill-Coleman said, ``That is a reasonable assumption.'' Police evacuated the building and cordoned off streets after the first warning was received at 8:02 a.m. The bomb exploded at 8:49, just 11 minutes before the visitors' area was scheduled to open. ``We had only half an hour to reach the scene, evacuate the building and clear the surrounding streets,'' said police Commander Hugh Moore. ``If we have been a few minutes later getting there, it would have been too late.'' Police, firefighters, evacuated workers and sightseers jammed the district's narrow streets, marked out centuries ago for foot and horse traffic. Hundreds of commuters were delayed in cars and buses caught in traffic jams. Churchill-Coleman said a man with an Irish accent made warning calls to a newspaper, a news agency, the fire brigade, police, the Salvation Army and the Stock Exchange. Police said the caller used a code word to confirm that it was an IRA attack. There had been no warning before the IRA's bomb attack June 25 at the Carlton Club, a gathering place for Britain's governing Conservative Party. The IRA, seeking to undermine support for British rule in Northern Ireland, generally has concentrated its attacks on government and military targets. Churchill-Coleman said it was ``the first time in recent years'' that a code had been given with the warning. Police said the bomb destroyed the men's room next to the public visitors' gallery, which was heavily damaged. The explosion tore a jagged hole about 20 feet high and seven feet wide in the modern concrete building, about 10 feet above ground level. Liz Rowe, 26, a trader at Sumitomo Trust in the Royal Bank of Scotland building opposite the exchange, said police told her to run, but she had only traveled half a block when the bomb went off. ``It was not as loud as I would have thought. It sounded like loads of scaffolding falling,'' Ms. Rowe said. Joe Phillips, a 21-year-old options trader, said a recorded warning was broadcast inside the exchange. ``Normally they say this was a test, but a proper voice came on the tannoy (address system) saying, `This is not a test. Get out of the building,''' he said. There had been 30 to 40 people on the trading floor, standing around reading The Financial Times, looking at their screens and waiting for trading to start, Phillips said. Churchill-Coleman said the restroom had been cleaned Friday morning but nothing suspicious had been reported by the cleaning crew. It was not known when the device had been planted, he said. A uniformed guard normally searches bags and parcels carried by visitors before they enter the gallery, which accomodated up to 100 people. Stock Exchange staff enter through a separate entrance and are required to show their photo identification cards, a spokeswoman for the Stock Exchange said. Security television cameras are used in the exchange but they do not make videotape recordings, Churchill-Coleman said. He said police had found no witnesses to the planting of the device. Churchill-Coleman said posters advertising a confidential telephone number to report suspicious activities were going up around London. ``The public must be our eyes and ears,'' he said. ``Somebody out there knows where these individuals are.'' Police have made similar pleas after other IRA bombings. ``There is clear evidence that people are being vigilant,'' said a Scotland Yard press spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``We are attending a large number of false alarms. We have always said we'd rather attend a large number of false alarms and it is clear people are keeping their eyes open and being careful.''

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Defends Quake Rescue Efforts; Toll Climbs Near 700
LaserPhoto MLA3
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino on Friday defended her government against criticism that it has been tardy and ineffective in aiding victims of a devastating earthquake that killed nearly 700 people. ``Let us not blame others,'' she said in a nationally televised address, her first since Monday's quake. ``What we need to do now is help each other.'' Five days after the earthquake, measuring 7.7 on the Richter scale, officials said reports of damage and deaths were still trickling in from remote areas. By latest counts, 674 people were killed and more than 2,600 injured. Mrs. Aquino ordered several aides to take over relief operations, apparently bypassing the disaster-coordinating agency led by Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos. The president, already beset by Communist rebels, rebellious military officers and popular discontent, has come under criticism for a government rescue effort described by many as inadequate. The rescuers, for their part, battled poor communications, fatigue, supply shortages and and equipment problems. On Friday, a U.S. Marine OV-1 observation plane taking part in rescue operations crashed near Baguio, killing one of the two crewmen. The victim's name was not released pending notification of kin, and the cause of the crash was under investigation. Also Friday, a helicopter carrying Ramos on an inspection tour made an emergency landing after a cockpit warning light came on. Ramos transferred to another aircraft and continued his tour. Both incidents were near the mountain resort of Baguio, 130 miles north of Manila. Rescuers in Baguio dug through the night after finding fresh blood in a tunnel they had dug under the rubble of the Hyatt Hotel _ indicating there could be victims alive in the debris. But they found only the bodies of a man and a woman. As many as 50 people were believed to have been caught in the hotel when the quake struck. Members of a British rescue team said it was unlikely there were any survivors in the rubble of seven other Baguio hotels that collapsed during the quake. At least 224 people, including two Americans, were killed in Baguio during the quake. In addition, more than 120 were feared dead in eight factories of the Baguio Export Processing Zone, which caught fire during the quake. Power was restored to parts of Baguio, and banks resumed operations. But more aftershocks rocked the city, terrifying the city's 120,000 people. Many refused to sleep indoors. More than 100 people were believed stranded on highways near Baguio, and Marines and Philippine troops mounted rescue operations. Officials said more than 900 people also were feared stranded in a mountain pass along the border of Nueva Vizcaya and Nueva Ecija provinces.
