Rebels who tried to topple Mrs. Aquino in December offered a truce to help with the relief effort. The underground Revolutionary Alliance of the Masses-Soldiers of the Filipino People said in a statement that ``during this time of national tragedy'' the rebels would suspend anti-government activity. Many leaders of the rebel movement are graduates of the Philippine Military Academy, located in hard-hit Baguio. Heavy casualties were also concentrated in Cabanatuan, 60 miles north of Manila, where more than 60 students and teachers were killed at the Philippine Christian College. One girl who was injured at the college told ABS-CBN television that her class was in the middle of a lesson on earthquakes when the quake struck and the classroom collapsed.

DOC.HEAD: City Stops Selling Bat Guano Because of Health Concerns
DOC.TEXT: The mayor stopped selling bat guano because of health concerns, but officials say small amounts of the natural fertilizer pose little danger. Mayor Jay DeYoe stopped filling orders for the bat droppings this week after a Delaware woman warned that the brown, gritty substance could spread the fungal disease histoplasmosis. ``I got to thinking that if there was any possibility we might be doing something that might be hurting somebody, we ought to check it out,'' DeYoe said Thursday. However, histoplasmosis is very rare in the West and the chance of getting it from a small amount of bat guano is remote, said Gary Stevens, program manager for Jackson County Health Department's environmental health services. ``The disease is normally common in individuals exposed to large quantitites of chicken manure or bat guano and some type of disruptive activity such as mining it or removing large quantitites ... where there is lots of airborn potential exposure,'' he said. Jacqueline Burgess called City Hall from Marydel, Del., after reading about the bat guano in her local newspaper, which also published a picture of DeYoe sniffing a bag of droppings. ``It really concerned me that he was doing this,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``Years down the line he could get it.'' Eight years ago, Burgess underwent laser surgery to repair a blood vessel in her eye damaged by histoplasmosis. She said she probably contracted it as a child when she lived near chicken coops in southern Delaware. Histoplasmosis is a systemic fungal disease that begins in the lungs and can spread to other organs, according to the Encyclopedia and Dictionary of Medicine, Nursing and Allied Health. It can cause pneumonia and is sometimes fatal. The disease is caused by the inhalation of contaminated dust and is common in the rural Midwest, the dictionary said. Stevens said he was working with the national Centers for Disease Control and the state Health Division to learn how to sterilize the bat guano and make it safe to gather. If all goes well, sales could resume by next week, he said. More than 20 orders of the $1 and $5 bags are waiting to be filled, said DeYoe. An employee of this 1,000-resident town discovered a mother lode of bat manure in a Gold Hill cave recently and DeYoe decided to sell it to help support the police department, which has only one paid officer and six volunteers.

DOC.HEAD: Buckey Jury Reaches Verdict In One of Eight Counts
DOC.TEXT: The jury in Raymond Buckey's second trial told the judge today that it has reached a verdict on one of eight counts against the former teacher at the McMartin Pre-School. Superior Court Judge Stanley Weisberg told the panelists to resume their talks, and the one verdict submitted in a sealed envelope was held in court custody until jurors resolve the remaining charges. The jury has been deliberating for two weeks and heard nearly three days of repetition of testimony earlier this week. Buckey is charged with molesting three young girls who attended his family's nursery school in Manhattan Beach in the 1980s. He and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted of 52 molestation counts in an earlier trial. But the jury deadlocked on some of the charges against Buckey and eight of them were refiled.

DOC.HEAD: Glitch Puts Launch Of Atlas Rocket In Doubt For Today
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with equipment problem delaying launch at least until later in day. Picks up 3rd graf, `The three-year...'.
DOC.TEXT: A problem with ground equipment delayed today's blastoff of an Atlas rocket at least an hour, putting off the rocket's commercial launch debut on a flight to carry a satellite that will illuminate Earth's magnetic field. NASA and General Dynamics had planned to launch the unmanned rocket from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station sometime between 3:33 and 3:46 p.m. But workers could not start a compressor that furnishes gaseous nitrogen to the rocket to keep the satellite cool. If the compressor can be started in time, officials planned to try to launch the rocket during the next opportunity, a 12-minute period beginning at 4:49 p.m. That will be the last chance for liftoff until Saturday afternoon. The three-year science mission, costing about $258 million, comes at a critical time for NASA. The space agency is under attack for the crippled Hubble Space Telescope and a shuttle fleet that, until this week, had been grounded by fuel leaks. ``I don't think we've felt any additional stress,'' NASA manager Sid Saucier said Thursday. ``But we have a job to do, and we know what is required to get the job done. We've tried to make sure that everything was done according to the game plan.'' The Atlas 1 rocket was to boost the Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite, known as CRRES, to an elliptical orbit 217 miles by 22,236 miles high. The satellite is a joint program of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and the Defense Department. NASA is overseeing the satellite's release of 24 aluminum canisters at various altitudes during the next year. One or two canisters will be ejected at a time, releasing chemicals that will form large, glowing clouds similar in appearance to the aurora borealis, or the northern lights. The clouds will spread along Earth's invisible magnetic field lines, making them visible to the naked eye. Scientists will study the clouds' interaction with charged particles in the ionosphere and magnetosphere. The first canisters will be released in September over the South Pacific. The first releases visible over North America will be in early 1991. Two such releases already have been made over northern Canada, originating from a Pegasus air-launched rocket in April. Unmanned sounding rockets will drop similar canisters this summer and again in 1991. Air Force instruments aboard the 2-ton satellite will probe the Van Allen radiation belts encircling Earth. Micro-electronic components also will be exposed to space radiation to determine whether they could fail in future flights. The satellite originally was to have been deployed in 1987 from the space shuttle. But the 1986 Challenger disaster pushed back the mission by more than five years, and program managers opted for a quicker launch and redesigned the satellite to fit into the Atlas. Under a barter agreement, the San Diego-based General Dynamics Space Systems Division received Atlas spare parts and ground support equipment from NASA in exchange for two launches. The Atlas 1 rocket was to have gone up in June. A series of problems, including a damaged pressurization line and malfunctioning software, delayed the mission until July. Today's launch was to be the eighth commercial rocket launch by an American company. McDonnell Douglas sent up the nation's first commercial rocket, a Delta, last August. Martin Marietta followed four months later with its Titan.

DOC.HEAD: Seismology Is Low Priority Of Earthquake-Prone Philippines
With AM-Philippines-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In one of the world's most quake-prone nations, the study of earthquakes and their effects commands so little government attention that only one of its 12 seismic stations has a telephone. The U.S. Geological Survey said about 30 significant earthquakes have struck the Philippines since 1976, including a strong quake that devastated central Luzon island last Monday, killing nearly 700 people. Raymundo Punongbayan, director of the Institute of Vulcanology and Seismology, acknowledged that despite frequent quakes, there was little interest in studying then. ``We have to know how to deal with earthquakes and prepare for this,'' Punongbayan said. ``We are so helpless.'' While modern seismological institutes use computers, digital monitoring devices and acoustical sensors to measure quakes, Punongbayan said his staff must rely on 15-year-old instruments. The institute operates 12 seismological stations nationwide. The station on Leyte island, 350 miles south of Manila, is the only one with a telephone, he said. The Philippines lies along the so-called Pacific Ring of Fire, where 80 percent of the world's quakes occur. Between 1966 and 1988, the Philippines, which lies on 10 faults and tremor tracks, recorded 9,678 quakes, or an average of five a day. First reports of earthquakes in the Philippines often come from monitoring services in Hong Kong or the United States. Last February, a quake measuring 6.9 on the Richter scale shook central Philippine islands. The quake was first reported by seismologists in Australia. Punongbayan says his institute got first word of it when Manila radio stations telephoned for confirmation. Punongbayan said his institute, established in 1986, is alloted less than 1 percent of the $11.4 billion national budget. Before 1986, the onstitute was an obscure department of the Manila weather service.

DOC.HEAD: Explosion on Train Kills 5, Injures 10
DOC.TEXT: An explosion rocked a Moscow-bound passenger train in southern Russia overnight, killing five passengers and injuring 10, Soviet media reported Friday. The cause of the blast, which occurred around midnight Thursday between the second and third passenger cars of the train, was under investigation, according to the Tass news agency. The explosion occurred on the Matveyev Kurgan-Zakadychnoye section of the Donetsk railway line in southern Russia, just south of the Ukrainian border near the Sea of Azov, the government newspaper Izvestia said. The train had departed Thursday from Tshkaltubo in the republic of Georgia. The evening television news program ``Vremya'' showed footage of the forest-green train, with the heavily damaged second and third cars. Both cars had a gaping holes blasted outward from where they were connected. Several windows were blown out, with curtains flapping in the breeze. The newscast said 10 passengers were injured. Tass reported the injured were taken to the central hospital in Matveyev Kurgan. Police were working to identify the dead, Izvestia said. Traffic on the line has been restored, it added.

DOC.HEAD: Family Leave Law Signed in D.C.
With AM-Family Leave-States
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry on Friday signed a law requiring larger businesses to provide up to four months of unpaid leave for workers seeking time off to care for ill family members, including gay partners. ``Too many employees have had to choose between caring for their families and keeping their jobs,'' Barry said. The legislation, which sponsors said was the broadest of its kind in the country, would apply to workers who want leave to care for a ``family member,'' including newborns, ill relatives or partners in ``committed relationships.'' Federal workers are not covered. ``This is a very compassionate piece of legislation designed to protect those who are often most vulnerable _ working women, gays, children, the elderly,'' said Ivy Young, spokeswoman for the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force. The measure also would provide the same leave for an employee unable to work because of serious illness. District officials could not say how many of the estimated 320,000 civilian work force would be affected. The District measure is broader than legislation passed by Congress but recently vetoed by President Bush. That bill envisioned leaves up to three months in fewer circumstances. The House is scheduled to vote Wednesday in an attempt to override the presidential veto, but bill supporters say they probably won't have enough votes. The District law would apply immediately to businesses with at least 50 employees _ including the city government. Compliance would be required after three years by businesses with 20 employees. Claudia Withers, spokeswoman for the Women's Legal Defense Fund, a public policy advocacy group that monitors laws dealing with family and women's issues, praised the bill. ``Although we always think that paid leave is best ... we think it'll be the best in the nation,'' she said. However, Pedro Alfonso, president of the local Chamber of Commerce, said the bill goes too far. ``It's going to be a tremendous burden on many of the small businesses, which won't be able to afford to carry the costs of just letting employees go,'' he said. All District of Columbia legislation is subject to override by Congress, but there was no immediate indication whether an attempt would be made to do so in this case.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Campaign Holds First Legal Rally
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of pro-democracy campaigners held their first legalized public meeting Friday and said they would form an alliance to fight for the end of two decades of one-party rule. ``The changes in the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and South Africa have woken us up from years of indifference and despondency,'' said former finance minister Arthur Wina. In what Wina called ``an atmosphere of utmost urgency,'' labor leaders, businessmen, lawyers, academics and at least two other former ministers attended the gathering at a motel hall outside Lusaka, the capital. The meeting follows President Kenneth Kaunda's end Tuesday to a ban on multiparty campaigning for the Oct. 17 referendum on Zambia's political future. In recent months, protests have broken out in Zambia and several other sub-Saharan African states demanding an end to traditional one-party rule. Speakers who denounced one-party rule and demanded an end to a 26-year-old state of emergency received prolonged applause from about 300 people in the crowded motel hall. Conferees gave a standing ovation to a founder of the ruling United National Independence Party who declared a new allegiance to reform. ``I was once an advocate of a one-party system,'' said farmer and businessman Simon Zukas. ``However, I would like to apologize to the nation for the stand I have taken because it was wrong.'' The ruling party has been Zambia's only legal political organization since 1973. Frederick Chiluba, head of the powerful Zambia Congress of Trade Unions, said reformers were demanding the government give up its emergency powers before the October referendum. He said their were fears the referendum would not be conducted fairly and called for the presence of international observers to monitor the polling. Last month, South Africa ended a state of emergency in all but one province, and neighboring Zimbabwe earlier this week said it would give up 25-year-old emergency powers on Wednesday. In April, Kaunda announced plans for the referendum and banned public debate on the issue until arrangements for the vote were worked out. The government drew sharp criticism from conferees Friday for apparently refusing to update the voters roll. Voters were last registered in 1987 for parliamentary elections that took place the following year. Many of those attending the meeting Friday said they would not be allowed to vote in the referendum because they deliberatly had not registered under the one-party system. About 2.6 million people in this southern African nation of 7.5 million are registered as voters. The gathering, organized by a group calling itself The Emerging Alliance For Democracy And Development, disputed claims by Kaunda that pluralism will cause tribal strife and factional fighting. ``We represent a new breed of Zambians for whom tribe is not a factor in politics. We are talking about national issues,'' said Akashamba Lewanika, head of the Zambia Economics Association, a private business lobby. Zambia in June experienced the worst civil unrest since independence from British colonial rule in 1964. At least 26 people died in police and army gunfire during student-led demonstrations protesting food price increases and continued one-party rule.

DOC.HEAD: Park Thieves Out For Green Stuff But It's Not Money
DOC.TEXT: The city horticulturist wants thieves to leave the municipal parks alone. The theft of plants from the parks is growing so fast, the city's greenhouse sometimes gets bare. Park Director Melvin Miller said that shrubbery seems to be the most popular loot because the plants are easy to yank. Tulips, roses and trees also are stolen. ``No sooner do we plant a bush than someone comes and rips it out,'' Miller said. Along one boulevard, ``the average life of a shrub is about an hour and a half,'' said Alex Vare, landscape architect. ``I guess when everybody's yard is filled up they'll leave the parks alone,'' said Carl Mattil, Birmingham's horticulturist. ``We used to be able to go out once a month with about 25 plants and replace all the ones that had died or been stolen,'' he said. ``Now we have trucks going out weekly with 100 plants.''

DOC.HEAD: Valenti Sees No Change in Ratings System Despite Judge's Comments
DOC.TEXT: The founder of the movie industry's rating system said Friday that moviegoers can be assured the system will continue to operate despite a judge's recommendations it be revised or abandoned. ``There is no evidence that American parents are clamoring for change,'' said Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America and creator of the 22-year-old rating system. Valenti said that film critics and a few movie distributors criticize the system but that parents have consistently praised it as ``very useful'' in deciding what movies their children should see. The MPAA's rating system was upheld _ but strongly criticized _ Thursday by New York Supreme Court Judge Charles Ramos, who said he lacked the authority to change the X rating given to a Spanish film, ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' The movie's American distributor, Miramax Film Corp., and its producer-director, Pedro Almodovar, had asked the court to change the rating, saying the designation was arbitrary, capricious, unfair and a form of censorship. Earlier this week, the National Society of Film Critics, in a letter to Valenti and Richard Heffner, head of the ratings board, recommended a new A rating for non-pornographic, adults-only movies. In his ruling, Ramos ``strongly advised'' there be some revisions or abandonment of the present system. ``The rating system's categories have been fashioned by the motion picture industry to create an illusion of concern for children, imposing censorship, yet all the while facilitating the marketing of exploitive and violent films with an industry seal of approval,'' he added. The judge noted there are no physicians, child psychiatrists or child-care professionals on MPAA's 11-member ratings board. Valenti contended that the judge and others err in concluding that the system was designed to protect children. ``Our mission is very simple. We try to give some advance cautionary warning to parents and parents make the decision about what pictures their children should and should not see,'' he said. The association said its ratings board is comprised of ``parents'' but won't reveal the identities or other details of individual members. The plan provides for five rating categories _ G, for general audiences with all ages admitted; PG-13, which cautions parents about viewing by children 12 and under; PG, for mature audiences with parental guidance suggested; R, for restricted audiences in which children under 16 must be accompanied by parent or guardian; and X, in which no one under 16 is admitted.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater Designates Charles Black as Party Spokesman
DOC.TEXT: Republican Chairman Lee Atwater named his best friend as chief spokesman for the party on Friday, saying the GOP needs a high-profile presence that he can't provide while he's fighting a brain tumor. Atwater, 39, said GOP consultant Charles Black would serve as his and the party's spokesman until he can return to work fulltime. Atwater said his medical treatment does not allow him to be a daily spokesman, ``and that role is too important to let slip as we head toward Election Day.'' The GOP move comes as the party tries to cope with internal splits on taxes and abortion as well as assaults from the Democrats on the savings and loan scandal and other issues. Atwater, who has been spending his limited work time developing strategy and advising the White House, has urged the party to take the offensive against the Democrats. ``For the last 18 years, Charlie Black has been my best friend and political eyes and ears. I've now asked him to also be my mouthpiece,'' Atwater, 39, said in a statement. ``Charlie speaks for me and for the party.'' Black has been the senior consultant to the Republican National Committee since Atwater became chairman 18 months ago. In his new, more public role, Black will be available to the media and give occasional speeches. Atwater said his recovery is going well, but he still must spend several hours each day in physical therapy. A parade of officials, including Black, Vice President Dan Quayle, RNC chief of staff Mary Matalin, and others tried to put the party on the offensive as the Republicans held their mid-year meeting in Chicago last week. Atwater pronounced the meeting a roaring success. ``Watching it all made it clear to me the need to have the strongest possible spokesmen available to carry our message to the public on a day-to-day basis,'' he said. Black said the Chicago meeting and the approach of the campaign season prompted Atwater's move. ``We need more spokesmen, more people out there carrying the ball,'' he said. Asked in Atwater was being supplanted, Black said no _ ``not since it's me he's designated to speak for him. I've been his alter ego all along. Even before he got sick, if he was too busy or traveling or something ... I'd be the guy to do it a lot of times. This is just formalizing what I've been doing.'' Black said Atwater would do occasional interviews. But he said the RNC chairman would spend most of his limited time and energy as a behind-the-scenes party strategist. RNC spokeswoman Leslie Goodman said Black's new visibility will be an enhancement of his role, ``not a diminution of anybody else's.'' He will continue his work as a GOP consultant and attend to party business as needed, she said. In his statement, Atwater said his doctors have determined that ``my tumor has stopped growing and is dying.'' In an interview this week with the Columbia (S.C.) State, he said he might be able to work five to eight hours a day by mid-August. ``I feel good. The doctors are optimistic. I'm optimistic,'' Atwater told the newspaper. ``But this is a big enemy. I'm not going to say anything premature.''

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Get New Instruction, Resume Deliberations in Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT: Jurors having problems deciding on racketeering and murder charges in the 1985 slaying of a drug agent were given new legal instructions Friday by a federal judge. ``You should follow the law regardless of where it takes you,'' U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie said in trying to clarify the charges for jurors who had expressed confusion about them. Rafeedie told jurors their only duty ``is to determine whether the government proved its case.'' He rejected a defense request to ask jurors about the problems they reported they were having Thursday. They sent a note to the judge then, asking to break off their deliberations an hour earlier than usual. The panel began weighing the evidence Monday after a nine-week trial in the case of three Mexicans and a Honduran charged in the Guadalajara slayings of drug agent Enrique Camarena and three other men. Rafeedie summoned jurors into court before they resumed their deliberations Friday and told them he was changing one legal instruction to clarify an accusation. In order to find the defendants guilty of conspiracy to commit violent acts in aid of racketeering, he said they must find the men conspired to kidnap and murder Camarena rather than an unspecified drug agent. The Honduran defendant is Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros. The three Mexican defendants are Ruben Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican homicide officer and Javier Vasquez Velasco, who is accused of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing. Prosecutors allege that Camarena was murdered because of his skill in wiping out marijuana and cocaine plantations in Mexico. They said he had cost drug barons $5 billion in profits.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Paul Simon is planning a benefit concert _ call it ``Bluff Aid'' _ to rescue the landmark lighthouse at Montauk Point from the erosion threatening its existence. The 18th-century lighthouse is endangered by two centuries of pounding water that has cut 240 feet off the bluff where it stands. The erosion has left the lighthouse just 57 feet from the water. The show by Simon, who has a house near the lighthouse, will raise part of the $500,000 needed to save the lighthouse. Officials said 6,000 tickets at $25 apiece will go on sale Saturday for the Aug. 30 show at Deep Hollow Ranch in Montauk. Sales of programs and souvenirs, along with program advertising, also will go to the lighthouse. The Lighthouse Committee of the Montauk Historical Society contacted Simon last year and discussed with him the difficulty of raising money to combat the erosion problem, said panel Chairman Richard White. The singer subsequently volunteered to help.

Soviet-born cellist-conductor Mstislav Rostropovich has accepted an invitation to stage Dmitri Shostakovich's opera ``Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk District'' in Leningrad, Tass reported Friday. Valery Gergiyev, chief conductor of the Kirov Theater, told the official Soviet news agency the production is scheduled for the 1992-93 season. Rostropovich, music director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, D.C., had his Soviet citizenship restored earlier this year and made a triumphant concert return to Moscow in February. His citizenship was taken away in 1978, four years after he and his family moved abroad. They had angered Soviet officials by giving refuge to dissident author Alexander Solzhenitsyn.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Court bailiffs entered retired tennis star Bjorn Borg's seaside home Friday to assess its value before a possible sale. Bjorn Mellin, a court official, said after a two-hour inspection that the property could be auctioned if Borg fails to pay a $1 million debt. But, Mellin added, the auction won't take place until September at the earliest because of vacations in the department that handles such cases. The bailiffs previously visited Borg's home June 21 to establish a valuation, and nobody was home. Borg was out Friday, but one of his employees opened the door. The house's value is put at $1.7 million-plus. The courts put a lien on Borg's house until he honors a personal guarantee to a finance company for his former business partner, Lars Skarke. Skarke, managing director of Borg's fashion business until it collapsed last year, owes the finance company $1.1 million. Borg's lawyer, Henning Sjostrom, said earlier Borg planned legal action against Skarke aimed at getting the money back. Skarke has sued Borg for $82 million to compensate for profits he claimed the company would have made if Borg had kept it in operation. The business, though successful, became overextended and could not meet its debts. Borg refused an offer of outside capital because he wanted to keep control. Borg, who retired in 1983, won an unprecedented five straight Wimbledon titles from 1976 to 1980 and six French Open crowns, and amassed a personal fortune of about $105 million.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also moved on financial and sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Everyone knows the ``Bo Knows ... '' advertising campaign. And that success created a problem for Jim Riswold, associate creative director at Nike's ad agency Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. ``It was a hard act to follow,'' said Riswold, copywriter on both campaigns. ``We kept coming back to the question: How does Bo do all these things? And we decided, well, Bo is more than one person. We decided to use the dumbest joke in the history of advertising.'' For the new ad, Nike's admakers decided to have Bo Jackson don gear used in a dozen different sports _ not only his Kansas City Royals baseball uniform and his Los Angeles Raiders football suit. Each Bo was shot separately; skillful editing made it appear they were gathering one by one in a locker room. Bo Football tries to guess Bo Baseball's name. Bo Cyclist screeches to a halt and asks, ``Where's that Tour de France Thing?'' Bo Hockey sports ``Le Bo'' stitched across his jersey. Cher's one-time beau _ and husband _ Sonny Bono even wanders in and says: ``I thought this was another Bo-Knows commercial.'' By the time Bo Director joins the scene and calls ``cut'' at the end of the commercial, the screen is full of Bo's.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Family Leave
DOC.TEXT: At least 25 states have some kind of family or medical leave program, according to the National Womens Legal Defense Fund. Connecticut, Maine and Wisconsin have family and medical leave legislation similar to the law signed Friday by District of Columbia Mayor Marion Barry, but the definition of family is more limited. New Jersey has a family-leave only legislation, while Minnesota, Oregon, Rhode Island and Washington state have parental leave laws. Kentucky has an adoption leave law only. Ten other states _ California, Hawaii, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Montana, New Hampshire, Tennessee and Vermont _ and Puerto Rico have pregnancy disability leave laws in which women are permitted time off only for the time they are physically unable to work because of pregnancy or recovery. Florida, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania and West Virginia have a variation of family or pregnancy disability leave for state employees only. Illinois has passed a medical leave bill similar to the district's but it only provides six weeks of leave for every two years. Missouri passed a pregnancy leave law but it was vetoed by the governor. The fund said its tally was as of January.

DOC.HEAD: `Protection Plan' Announced for 25 Civil War Sites
With BC-Battlefield List
DOC.TEXT: The federal government will ask private groups and state and local governments to cooperate in preserving the nation's historic battlefields, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said Friday. The ``American Battlefield Protection Plan'' eventually will cover all wars fought on U.S. soil, but will begin by focusing on 25 key Civil War sites, Lujan said. Because the government can't afford to buy all the land involved, he said, a cooperative effort is needed to make sure the farms and fields where Union and Confederate soldiers fought aren't overwhelmed by shopping malls and industrial parks. ``We want the governors, local governments, foundations, corporations and owners to all join,'' Lujan said in an interview on NBC-TV's ``Today'' program. ``Some of the battlefields, for example, would be purchased, but some of them can be commemorated simply by easements, some of them maybe the owner would want us to put a plaque there commemorating that particular battle,'' he said. ``We don't have enough money just to go off and buy all these sites.'' Details of his plan, which includes a request for $15 million in seed money, will be explained Saturday when Lujan speaks at Manassas National Battlefield Park in Virginia in ceremonies marking the 129th anniversary of the First Battle of Bull Run. Lujan said he also planned to discuss his ideas with the governors of the states where the sites to be protected are located. Florence Kennedy, director of the battlefield preservation drive for the private Conservation Fund, praised Lujan's project. ``I think the secretary's initiative is a very important one because it's placing great importance on partnership,'' she said in an interview. ``This partnership cooperation will be a catalyst to encourage private sector cooperation.'' A bitter fight broke out in 1988 over a developer's plans to build a mall on land adjacent to the Manassas park. Congress later voted to add the disputed tract to the park, with a final cost expected to exceed $100 million. ``I was in the Congress when we went through the Manassas fight,'' said Lujan, who represented a New Mexico district in the House of Representatives for 20 years. ``At that time I thought it was the worst way to do it. It's more expensive, you have to file suits. If we have a planned program, everything works much better,'' he said. As an example of the better way, Lujan cited the Richard King Mellon Foundation's donation to the federal government three weeks ago of 10 parcels of land, including important sites from the Civil War battles of Antietem and Gettysburg. Lujan's plan has four parts: _Encouraging ``creative public and private land-use tools'' such as zoning, easements, land-banking and historic district designation to protect imminently threatened sites. _Distribute information on public and private projects to protect battlefields. _Use limited federal funds to encourage land purchases by private conservation organizations and other public agencies. _Develop a national strategy to protect other significant battlefield sites that aren't imminently threatened, but may be in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Germanys Mark Anniversary of Failed Attempt to Kill Hitler
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's defense minister told a batch of army recruits Friday to put justice ahead of blind obedience and remember the officer who once tried to kill Adolf Hitler. People in East and West Germany marked a rare moment of resistance to an evil dictatorship by commemorating the 46th anniversary of a famous attempt on the Nazi ruler's life. Rainer Eppelmann, a clergyman and pacifist who is now defense minister in East Germany's new democratic government, used the anniversary to make a point as he swore in 400 new soldiers. He told them not to let unthinking obedience to authority dull their sense of right and wrong. He said ``soldiers should reconcile the need for order and obedience with law and conscience.'' ``With that, members of the National People's Army stand in the tradition of the men who opposed the Nazi dictator,'' he said. Eppelmann, at a ceremony in the city of Strausberg just outside Berlin, swore in the first batch of army recruits who were asked to defend democracy rather than communism. The traditional pledge of the People's Army was rewritten to reflect the democratic revolt that overthrew the Communist government last autumn. The July 20, 1944, attempt on Hitler's life was supported by a group of high-ranking German officers, some of whom had earlier supported the dictator. It came after the German army had suffered several military reverses during World War II. Col. Claus Schenk von Stauffenberg, a German count, put a briefcase containing a bomb at Hitler's feet during a conference, then went outside the headquarters room to answer a pre-arranged phone call. Another officer then inadvertantly moved the briefcase because it was in his way. It was placed behind a partition that shielded Hitler from the blast. He survived and staggered from the rubble. The attempt was one of several made on Hitler's life, but it was the one that came closest to success. In East Berlin, East German lawmakers stood up in a salute to the would-be assassins. ``The heritage of these men and women of July 20 should oblige us to fight dictatorships in every form, to keep peace in Germany and Europe forever,'' said a declaration endorsed by all parties in Parliament. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl also praised the assassination plotters in a statement from the West German capital, Bonn. ``The men and women of the German resistance gave in dark times a shining example of their unshakeable yearning for freedom,'' he said. Hitler killed himself in 1945 as Allied troops marched on Berlin. Nazi Germany was divided, and now East Germany and West Germany are preparing to unify in December. Kohl sought to put the anniversary in a historical perspective of German unification. ``Forty-six years after July 20, 1944, we are entering a new epoch in the history of our nation.''

DOC.HEAD: House Ethics Committee Recommends Frank Be Reprimanded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee recommended today that Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass. be reprimanded for aspects of his relationship with a male prostitute. Committee Chairman Julian C. Dixon, D-Calif., said the committee voted unanimously for a full House reprimand of Frank, an acknowledged homosexual. The recommendation will go to the House floor next week for a vote on whether to accept it. The committee said Frank violated a House rule stating that a member ``shall conduct himself at all times in a manner which shall reflect creditably on the House of Representatives.'' Frank violated that rule, the committee said, when he: _ Used his congressional privilege to fix 33 parking tickets incurred by male prostitute Stephen L. Gobie when Gobie was using the lawmaker's automobile for non-House-related business. Frank, who used Gobie as a personal aide paid with the lawmaker's own funds, was ordered to make restitution of an unspecified amount to the District of Columbia. Frank has admitted there were occasions when he had parking tickets waived, but he said that only happened when Gobie used the congressman's car for official business. Frank said tickets Gobie received for non-official business were paid. _ Wrote an April 16, 1986, memorandum to the commwealth's attorney in Alexandria, Va., that contained misleading statements favorable to Gobie. The misleading statements ``could be perceived as an attempt to use political influence to affect the outcome of the administration of Mr. Gobie's probation,'' the committee said. There was no immediate reaction from Frank, who was traveling to Boston and scheduled a news conference for late in the afternoon. Expulsion is the most severe punishment the committee have recommended. The next most serious would be censure, in which a member stands before his colleagues to hear the speaker read a letter condemning his conduct. The third most serious is reprimand. The decision followed a 10-month investigation that was one of the most troubling in the history of the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. In considering whether Frank's behavior brought discredit upon the House, the panel had to judge conduct that largely was personal between the liberal lawmaker and Gobie. Two key aspects of the case involved official actions, however. Frank said he paid Gobie $80 for sex in 1985 and then hired him as a housekeeper and driver with personal funds in an effort to improve his life. He said he fired Gobie in August 1987 after learning that his aide was running a prostitution ring out of the lawmaker's Capitol Hill apartment. Frank repeatedly has denied Gobie's allegation that he was aware of the prostitution operation, and submitted testimony by his landlady saying the lawmaker was ``stunned'' to learn of the activity. For months, the committee was unable to reach a consensus and for a time, those favoring a milder letter of rebuke appeared to have the upper hand. But it gradually became apparent to Chairman Julian C. Dixon, D-Calif. and others that the rebuke lacked the necessary votes. A reprimand would not satisfy the House's most conservative lawmakers, however. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif. will be ready when the committee report reaches the floor to propose expulsion instead, said his spokesman, Paul Mero. That normally is reserved for those convicted of serious crimes. Frank, a five-term liberal Democrat from suburban Boston, is one of two acknowledged homosexual members of the House. The other member, Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass. was censured for an affair with a male page. Frank is seeking re-election in a race against Republican John Soto, who has never held public office and who was soundly defeated two years ago in a bid for state representative in his home town. Six members of the House have been reprimanded previously, a relatively recent punishment that was first used in 1976.

DOC.HEAD: Leukemia Victim Will Undergo Bone-Marrow Transplant
DOC.TEXT: A 21-year-old leukemia victim who gained national attention when more than 50,000 people were tested as possible donors will undergo a bone-marrow transplant within 10 days although an ideal donor has not been found. Allison Atlas of Bethesda, Md., told WUSA-TV on Thursday that her mother will donate the bone marrow. Her mother's bone marrow is a near match, but not a perfect one. ``Ultimately, my condition is progressively getting worse, and if I don't have the transplant soon and I get a bad infection, I won't be able to have a transplant,'' Miss Atlas said. ``And I just don't feel I have the luxury of waiting any longer.'' She said her mother is looking forward to the operation. ``She's excited about doing this. She can't wait to be my donor,'' she said. Fifteen of those tested as a match for Miss Atlas eventually donated bone marrow to other leukemia patients.

DOC.HEAD: Advocates Press for Right To Die Legislation
DOC.TEXT: Julianne Delio said her husband made her promise she would never let him live in a vegetative state connected to artificial life support machines. Keeping that promise took more than a year of court battles, cost Delio her job and left the 36-year-old New York woman emotionally brutalized, she told a Senate subcommittee on Friday. ``You cannot imagine the psychological trauma involved in pleading for the death of the person you love most in this entire world,'' she said. Delio urged lawmakers to pass a bill that would help inform people of their right to determine their own medical treatment through such things as living wills and other advance directives that legally enable others to speak for them if they cannot speak for themselves. But an official of the Health Care Financing Administration, which handles Medicaid and Medicare, said the bill could allow some patients to be pressed into making a hasty choice. Living wills moved to the forefront of medical issues with the Supreme Court's decision last month denying the family of Nancy Cruzan their request to have her feeding tubes removed. Cruzan is permanently unconscious but is not terminally ill and could live for years in this condition, doctors say. Julianne and her husband, Daniel, were well educated, both with doctorate degrees and working in the medical field. But he, like Nancy Cruzan, did not have a living will and had never put his wishes in writing, Delio said. ``We were young and enjoying a happy life,'' she said. ``Who would have known what was to happen to us?'' In 1986, when Danny Delio was 33 he underwent a minor operation. Because of a problem with the anesthesia, he was left brain dead, permanently unconscious, she said. ``His life was essentially over,'' she said of her husband, a Ph.D. in exercise physiology, an expert in cardiac rehabilitation and, until then, a marathon runner. She and her husband had had extensive discussions about vegetative states, and ``he made me promise never to let him live even one day in such a condition,'' she said. She requested that his life-support systems be shut off and he be allowed to die, but the Westchester County Medical Center refused and she filed a lawsuit. Shortly after that, she was fired from her job as an assistant professor of medicine at New York Medical College, which is affiliated with the hospital where her husband was being treated. An appeals court eventually agreed with Delio and ordered the hospital to terminate treatment or transfer her husband to another facility that would abide by her wishes. Ten days after he was transferred, he died in her arms. ``Even though the court system eventually worked for us, we were brutalized by it,'' she said. ``No one should ever have to go to court under these circumstances. Court is the last place a family belongs when they are facing their darkest hours.'' Delio urged the Senate Finance subcommittee on Medicare and long-term care to approve legislation that would require the federal Department of Health and Human Services to develop an educational program to give people information about their options in determining their own medical treatment. Hospitals, nursing homes and other facilities that provide services to Medicare and Medicaid patients would be obligated to provide such information as a condition for participating in these programs, under the bill. ``What this issue is about is people's ability to make their wishes known ... so when they can no longer speak for themselves, they will already have spoken,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., sponsor of the bill. ``This is a communications problem,'' he said. ``It's an issue of letting people know ... how they can take steps so that worst nightmare doesn't come to pass.'' Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., who is sponsoring similar legislation in the House, said the bill ``is about empowerment of the individual. Without knowledge there is no power.'' Gail Wilensky, who heads the Health Care Financing Administration, testified that while she agrees with the goal of educating people about living wills and other advance directives, she opposed making such activities a federal requirement. She said the bill does not provide adequate safeguards for poor and vulnerable patients, who could be pressured into making hasty decisions. Decisions about living wills should be made before someone gets to a hospital, she said. Wilensky said awareness of living wills was ``not directly and immediately related to quality of care,'' and therefore should not be made a requirement for participation in the Medicare or Medicaid programs. Delio took strong exception to that saying, ``if (informing patients of their rights) is not quality of care, I don't know what is.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Detained for Threatening President
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A man jailed on charges of threatening to shoot President Bush said Friday he did not even know Bush was going to be in Cheyenne. Gregory Joseph Hill, 34, of Fremont, N.H., was charged with the felony of making a threat to kill the president and was ordered held without bond at least until Bush completed his trip to Cheyenne on Friday afternoon. Hill is accused of twice telling someone in a Cheyenne bar Wednesday: ``I'm here to shoot the president.'' But the unemployed data processor told U.S. District Judge Clarence Brimmer on Friday that when he arrived in Cheyenne as part of a cross-country trip, he did not know the president was planning to visit. ``I realize the seriousness of this,'' he said. ``I can't believe something like this could happen to me. I'm not a violent person.'' Hill was arrested at a motel Thursday evening after the man he spoke to in the bar reported his statements to Secret Service agents. A complaint filed in U.S. District Court on Friday said at the time of his arrest, Hill admitted making the statement. ``Oh, God, I should have never said what I did,'' Hill was quoted as saying at the time of his arrest. U.S. Attorney Richard Stacy said Hill possessed no weapons when he was arrested. Brimmer ordered Hill held without bond after Stacy argued he posed a threat to the community and would likely flee the state if released on bail. The judge also agreed with Stacy that Hill should be held at least until Bush's departure Friday evening, and said he would hold a bail hearing for Hill on Saturday or Monday. ``Because this is such a serious matter, I will order you to be detained without bond at least until the president's visit is over,'' he said. ``While you speak well, look well and don't appear to be a violent person, I have no way of judging that except through what you say. ``The safest bet, for the sake of the nation, is to have you detained.'' If convicted, Hill could face a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Court Reverses One of North's Iran-Contra Convictions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court panel today vacated Oliver North's three Iran-Contra felony convictions and ordered a lower court to determine whether his trial was tainted by congressional testimony he gave under a grant of immunity. One of the three was reversed outright. The 2-1 ruling ordered a ``witness by witness'' hearing into whether the evidence presented at North's trial violated his constitutional right against self-incrimination. The former National Security Council aide was convicted on May 4, 1989, of three of 12 counts stemming from the Reagan administration's clandestine effort to sell arms to Iran and aid the Nicaraguan Contras. The divided three-judge panel reversed North's conviction on the charge of altering and destroying sensitive NSC documents, finding that U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell gave erroneous jury instructions. North also was convicted of accepting an illegal gratuity and aiding and abetting the obstruction of Congress. The court held that North was entitled to a full hearing on all three counts delving into whether his nationally televised testimony seeped into the case. The ruling also could signify problems for the conviction of former national security adviser John Poindexter, who was convicted earlier this year of five felonies in the scandal. Poindexter, like North, gave immunized testimony to Congress. Independent counsel Lawrence Walsh, who supervised the Iran-Contra investigation, said he was considering what his next step will be. ``Everyone familiar with these proceedings has recognized the difficulties presented by the grant of immunity by Congress,'' he said in a statement. ``We have diligently tried to work around these difficulties.'' He said the Iran-Contra investigation was continuing. The grand jury hearing the matter was in session Friday. Neither North nor his lawyer, Brendan Sullivan, was immediately available for comment. North, a former Marine lieutenant colonel, described for Congress and a spellbound national television audience in July 1987 how the Reagan administration secretly sold arms to Iran and then used the profits to aid the Nicaraguan Contras. He was guaranteed that his testimony would not be used in any criminal case against him. If Gesell determines at the hearing that such tainted evidence was used to convict North on the other two charges, the court said he would be entitled to a new trial on those counts as well. Gesell ``must hold a ... hearing that will inquire into the content as well as the sources of the grand jury and trial witnesses' testimony,'' said the court. ``That inquiry must proceed witness-by-witness; if necessary, it will proceed line-by-line and item-by-item,'' said the appeals court. ``We readily understand how court and counsel might sigh prior to such an undertaking,'' the appeals court said of the prospect of such a hearing. ``Such a ... proceeding could consume substantial amounts of time, personnel, and money, only to lead to the conclusion that a defendant _ perhaps a guilty defendant _ cannot be prosecuted,'' the court said. The government must show by a preponderance of the evidence that ``no use whatsoever was made of any of the immunized testimony either by the witness'' or by the Iran-Contra prosecutor's office in questioning the witness, said the court. ``This burden may be met by establishing that the witness was never exposed to North's immunized testimony, or that the allegedly tainted testimony contains no evidence'' that wasn't obtained before North testified, the panel added. ``Unless the District Court can make express findings that the government has carried this heavy burden as to the content of all of the testimony of each witness, that testimony cannot survive the ... test,'' said the opinion. The major rulings were supported by two Reagan administration appointees, David Sentelle and Laurence Silberman. Chief Judge Patricia Wald, a Carter administration appointee, dissented. North was convicted on May 4, 1989, by a federal court jury after a two-month trial and placed on two years' probation. North also was fined $150,000 and ordered to perform 1,200 hours of community service. The obstruction of Congress conviction focused on North's concealment of the fact that U.S. officials knew about a CIA-assisted shipment of Hawk missiles from Israel to Iran at the time the delivery was occurring, in November 1986. The gratuity involved his acceptance of a $13,800 home security system from Richard Secord, whom North had enlisted to airlift arms to the Contras. Secord is a retired Air Force major general turned businessman. North said he had received terrorist threats against his family and that the security system was not compensation for his official duties. On the conviction that it reversed, the court held that Gesell's jury instruction ``allowed the jury to convict without unanimously concluding that North committed any one of the criminal acts charged'' in that count. The ``jury could have found that North violated (the statute) in several different ways'' without agreeing unanimously that he committed a single illegal act, the court said. ``The circumstances of his destruction, alteration, and removal of documents were distinct; any of those activities could serve as an underlying criminal act,'' the court said in its unsigned opinion. The verdict makes it impossible to determine whether the jury agreed unanimously that North, who claimed that he considered his actions lawful, actually intended to violate the law when he altered or destroyed documents, the majority said. Wald said that ``I ... am satisfied that North received a fair trial _ not a perfect one, but a competently managed and a fair one.'' She said North received ``all of the constitutional protections to which he was entitled.'' ``As in all trials of this magnitude, a few errors were made, but ... I do not find, singly or cumulatively, that any of them rose to the status of reversible error,'' said Wald.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Rejects Plan To Allow Additional Grain Production
DOC.TEXT: Associated Press Writer= WASHINGTON (AP) _ The Senate on Friday voted down a proposal to allow farmers to grow additional amounts of grain before being subjected to government management controls. The amendment to the 1990 farm bill was offered by Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., who said the acreage reduction program in the legislation hurts the ability of U.S. farmers to compete in the world market. But supporters of the acreage reduction plan prevailed in their arguments that it was needed to control the size of surpluses and stabilize prices. The amendment was defeated 50-37. Boschwitz said the program requires farmers to idle some of the most fertile land in the country. ``We have foregone production and in the process given the markets to the Europeans,'' said Boschwitz. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., argued that the Export Enhancement Program was designed to get those markets back and could be used more effectively by the Bush administration. Kerrey said huge grain surpluses are expensive for the government. ``One of things we're trying to do is balance the taxpayer desire to keep costs down and producers need for stability,'' he said. The Boschwitz amendment was the second major attack on the bill, designed by the Senate Agriculture Committee to set farm policy for the next five years. The first came Thursday in the 66-30 defeat of an amendment offered by Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., that would have eliminated subsidies to farmers with gross sales over $500,000 a year. An Agriculture Committee source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said defeat of the two amendments was a good indication that the general provisions of the committee's bill would stand. Debate will continue next week, with a battle over the sugar program expected Tuesday. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., has introduced an amendment that would reduce the loan rate on raw sugar from 18 cents to 16 cents a pound. It is supported by the Bush administration. The sugar program is one of the most controversial support systems in U.S. agriculture policy. Though it does not require direct government payments, it controls supply by limiting the amount of sugar that can be imported, thereby keeping prices high. Candy makers and other sugar users dislike the program because they are kept from buying the cheaper world-price sugar. Foreign policy makers say it works against U.S. objectives in places like Central America, where sugar is so easily grown. ``While the taxpayers shell out considerable sums of money for military and foreign assistance to the region, the sugar program blithefully undermines our national security by closing our market to one of the few ways these same countries have to earn money,'' said Bradley. The House begins debate on its version of the farm bill on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Measure Would Reimpose Ad Limits On Children's TV
DOC.TEXT: A Senate-passed bill would reimpose advertising time limits on children's television shows and require stations to provide some programs just for kids. The bill, sent to the House after a unanimous consent vote late Thursday, would limit commercials to 10.5 minutes per hour on weekends and 12 minutes per hour on weekdays for kids' programs on both broadcast stations and cable. Similar restrictions were lifted from broadcasters in 1984. The measure also would: _Require the Federal Communications Commission to complete an investigation that could affect so-called program-length commercials that feature toys. _Require broadcasters to provide more educational and informational programming for kids. _Establish a $10 million public TV endowment for children's educational programs. Broadcasters were able to water down provisions that would have required stations, in order to gain an FCC license renewal, to show they had substantially increased airings of programs ``specifically designed'' for kids' educational and informational needs. The bill would allow the FCC to consider non-broadcast efforts on behalf of kids by stations, such as programming guides. Despite the last-minute compromises, the bill marks a sharp turnaround from Reagan-era deregulation of children's TV and post-1984 FCC policy that children's needs can be served by the ``broad marketplace,'' including cable TV, public television and VCRs. The bill also represented a personal victory for longtime advocate Peggy Charren, head of Boston-based Action for Children's Television. ``I've only been waiting for this for something like 22 years _ for children to be part of the audience the broadcast licensee is obligated by law to serve,'' Charren, who founded ACT in 1968, said in a telephone interview. ``We think this is the first step in getting millions of points of educational light into American living rooms without raising the deficit. I'm sure that everyone who cares about children will be applauding the president when he signs the bill into law,'' she said. A similar bill is pending in the House, where quick passage also is expected. President Bush has not indicated whether he would sign a children's TV bill, but the Justice Department last year recommended that he veto the bill because it intrudes into program content. President Ronald Reagan vetoed a similar measure in 1988. The National Association of Broadcasters generally has supported the bill, but resisted a competing measure by Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., that would have imposed tighter ad limits, required the larger amount of educational and informational programs and outlawed program-length commercials. NAB maintained that family-type programs such as the ``Cosby Show'' or National Geographic specials should count towards broadcasters' obligations to children. The House bill allows broadcasters to serve the needs of children through their ``overall programming.'' NAB spokesman Walt Wurfel said the compromise bill ``does a lot to protect the interests of children, but it still recognizes that the essential element of broadcasters being able to provide this programing is a healthy flow of advertising revenue.'' Until 1984, the FCC had limited commercials on children's TV programs to 9.5 minutes per hour weekends and 12 minutes weekdays. During congressional hearings on the House and Senate bills, there was testimony that the amount of commercial ad time has grown dramatically on kids' shows since 1984, while the amount of informational and educational programs for kids had declined sharply.

DOC.HEAD: NBC's New Direction Set to Fresh Rap Rhythm
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Last week ...,' to RESTORE dropped word `publicized.'
DOC.TEXT: NBC entertainment chief Brandon Tartikoff went so far as to perform a rap duet with Fresh Prince in acknowleding the challenge posed by Fox Broadcasting Co. and his own network's subpar performance last year. Tartikoff, 41, and rapper Prince, aka Will Smith of NBC's new fall series ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' closed their rap duet Thursday with ``We're hungry and we got a taste for Fox.'' ``The Simpsons,'' the highest-rated Fox Broadcasting Co. show, is scheduled against NBC's top-rated ``Cosby Show'' this fall. Tartikoff has dismissed it and other Fox hits as tasteless appeals to the lowest common denominator. NBC's biggest hope for new steam is the Fresh Prince series, in which Smith plays an inner city youth who moves to the affluent Los Angeles enclave. NBC's 1989 fall schedule ``had our share of disappointments,'' Tartikoff said. Those disappointments, he said, including ``Mancuso, F.B.I.'' and ``Hardball,'' which have been canceled. ``We got off our game,'' he said. Much of Thursday's news conference concerned NBC's plan to start its fall season early. Last week, Fox announced plans to air one of its highly publicized fall series, ``Babes,'' on Thursday, Aug. 23 _ the same night ``The Simpsons'' moves to 8 p.m. Thursday against ``The Cosby Show.'' On Thursday, NBC said its series ``Ferris Bueller,'' a spin-off on the hit teen-age feature film, will preview on August 23 against ``Babes.'' Others of NBC's nine new programs, including ``Parenthood,'' ``Working It Out,'' and ``Law and Order,'' also will be ``double-pumped,'' or shown twice before the traditional fall schedule begins, Tartikoff said. Most of Tartikoff's remarks concerned his newly created job as NBC Entertainment Group president. He said his new job as a kind of network guru for all programming and NBC's in-house production company comes at a time when he was growing tired of the daily grind. Tartikoff said even though he is credited with making NBC the No. 1 network, he has been doing it for 10 years, and felt ``I may get to a point where I don't want to do this anymore.'' Four top-level managers have new titles, but the realignment apparently means only that Tartikoff no longer will be involved in day-to-day network entertainment, and if you have a new pilot to pitch, ask for Warren Littlefield, not Tartikoff. Littlefield, former executive vice president of prime time programming, takes Tartikoff's old title of entertainment president. Replacing Littlefield is Perry Simon, formerly senior vice president of prime time shows. John Agoglia, executive vice president of NBC productions, takes on the additional duties of heading the recently formed NBC Enterprises, which handles international distribution and satellite business ventures.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Nations Try to Mediate Kuwait-Iraq Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Arab leaders worked Friday to try to settle a Persian Gulf dispute that flared when Iraq launched a series of verbal salvos at its neighbor and former ally, Kuwait. Kuwaiti officials and diplomats have suggested Iraq's sudden outburst of belligerence is aimed at getting its creditors _ including Kuwait _ to write off billions of dollars in debts from the 1980-1988 Iran-Iraq war. The Arab League's secretary-general, Chedli Klibi, flew to Kuwait Friday, and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt have also appealed for moderation. Mubarak urged the two states to settle their differences by ``brotherly, constructive dialogue.'' Baghdad has denounced Kuwait for what it says are border violations and oil overproduction. Kuwait denies border encroachments and has asked an Arab League committee to help settle the longstanding border dispute. Iraq has also demanded compensation for an estimated $2.4 billion worth of oil it says Kuwait stole from a border field. Kuwait denies the charge. Iraq's President Saddam Hussein has accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of costing Iraq $14 billion in oil revenues by overproducing and driving down prices. Saddam said production by the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait beyond ceilings set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries caused a recent fall in oil prices. He threatened use of force to retaliate. In reports on the dispute, Kuwait's pro-government media played up the ``noble Kuwaiti stance and sacrifices'' during the Iraq-Iran war, when the emirate was a target of Iranian missile attacks, attacks on its vital oil shipping lanes and terrorism by pro-Iranian activists. Kuwait was second only to Saudi Arabia in an Arab effort that pumped about $40 billion into Iraq's coffers during the war. The United Arab Emirates also contributed. Gulf-based diplomatic sources said Saudi Arabia's King Fahd, using the strong personal link he forged with Saddam during the war years, has been in frequent contact with Baghdad over the dispute. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also said United Arab Emirates President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan, in Morocco on a private visit, had expressed willingness to help settle the financial aspects of the dispute. The Kuwait government Thursday night called off a state of alert for its armed forces, which had been declared Wednesday. Iraq, with a population of 17 million, has a 1-million-man army, as well as an arsenal of chemical weapons. Kuwait, with only 1.7 million residents, has 20,300 members of the armed forces. Despite the apparent cooling down, officials in Baghdad reported that thousands of Kuwaitis visiting Iraq were heading home. Iraqi media continued to accuse Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of ``usurping Iraq's rights.'' The Gulf region includes about two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves, so instability in the area brings nervous reactions among oil consumers. However, the prospect that Kuwait and the U.A.E. will stop producing over their OPEC ceilings has brought a rally in oil prices.

DOC.HEAD: Move Over, Cow Pie Bingo; Rubber Ducky Races Are Here
DOC.TEXT: So you say your favorite charity's hurting for a good fund-raiser? Masquerade balls are a bore; bachelor auctions are passe; Cow Pie Bingo has come and gone. Catch hold of the latest craze: rubber ducky races. In such places as Nashua, N.H., San Jose, Calif., Kansas City, Mo., and Chicago, men, women and children are flocking to reservoirs, rivers and ponds to cheer on the little yellow critters, according to a company that has leased the non-toxic ducks to organizations in those communities. It's all in the interest of their favorite good cause. ``We've had the golf outings, the dinner dances _ pretty standard things,'' Northern Illinois Medical Center administrator Bob Blazier said Friday. ``But this, this is different.'' On Saturday, about 5,000 ducks hit the waters of Boone Creek in McHenry, 20 miles northwest of Chicago, on the hospital's behalf. For the past few weeks, hospital supporters have been buying duck ``adoption papers'' at $5 a pop, or a flock of 10 ducks (complete with duck T-Shirt) for $50. Adoption papers sport a number corresponding to a number on a rubber ducky's bottom. On Saturday, the duckies themselves will be ceremoniously dumped from a truck into Boone's Creek for a race to the finish line. First duck through the ``duck trap'' _ a contraption rigged across the finish line that pulls the ducks in order from the water _ wins. But that's not until after the ``guess the ducks in the truck'' contest, to determine just how many of the fist-sized rubber ducks will be paddling for the finish line. Boone Creek's duck race is just a drop in the bucket compared to Illinois Masonic Hospital's August duck dash, in which participants can, for $250, become VID's _ Very Important Ducks. In that contest, about 30,000 rubber ducks will be dropped off Chicago's Michigan Avenue bridge for a race down the Chicago River. If the current isn't strong enough that day, a Chicago Fire Department boat will be standing by with water cannons to propel the ducks forward. The fund-raising ducks are largely the brainchild of a Phoenix, Ariz., company that says it drew on a 19th century Irish pastime for its inspiration. Three years ago, during their first year in business, Great American Duck Races managed to convince just eight organizations that duck racing was the way to raise money. This year, 95 groups have gone to ducks and next year, 103 have already been scheduled. ``Racing rubber ducks _ it sounds so silly, but it is serious,'' Michele Brown, the company's event coordinator, said Friday. Unlike Cow Pie Bingo, in which fields are divided into squares and players guess on which square a cow will leave its mark, much planning has gone into the duck-race business. ``We're still working on perfecting the duck,'' said Brown. Among the considerations: ducks that can withstand high temperatures and strong blowing winds. Ducks that have paddled too far are even retired, spending their golden years as promotional ducks sold as part of the fund-raiser. But the birds are no laughing matter. Brown said 10 races were conducted last year for a youth charity, Children's Miracle Network. The races raised $1.3 million for the group, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Feedlot Inventory Up from 1989
DOC.TEXT: Cattle feedlot inventories in the nation's 13 leading beef states totaled 8.76 million head as of July 1, up 1 percent from a year ago but down 6 percent from two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Increases from a year ago were reported in Arizona, California, Idaho, Illinois, Iowa, Minnesota, Oklahoma and Texas. Nebraska was unchanged, and decreases were reported for Colorado, Kansas, South Dakota and Washington. Marketing of fed cattle for slaughter during April, May and June totaled 6.01 million head, down slightly from the same period of 1989 but 2 percent above 1988, the report said. The placement of new cattle and calves on feed during the second quarter of the year totaled 5.11 million head, down 2 percent from 1989 and 14 percent below 1988. Officials said it was the smallest second-quarter placement of new cattle in fattening pens since 1975. Cattle feeders indicated they expect to market 5.91 million head during July, August and September, up fractionally from last year's third quarter but 6 percent below 1988, the report said. State feedlot cattle inventories are listed here for the 13 states, which account for about 85 percent of the nation's beef. The first number is the number of cattle, in thousands, as of July 1, and the second number is the percentage of a year earlier.

Arizona 160 103 California 425 106 Colorado 770 92 Idaho 226 106 Illinois 265 102 Iowa 835 109 Kansas 1,380 91 Minnesota 290 105 Nebraska 1,680 100 Oklahoma 295 102 South Dakota 230 92 Texas 2,060 109 Washington 145 93

DOC.HEAD: House Adopts Bill To Help States Meet Education Goals
DOC.TEXT: The House on Friday overwhelmingly passed a bill aimed at helping states meet national education goals set by President Bush and the governors. The bill, approved 350-25, authorizes $1 billion in new federal education spending in fiscal 1991 and a total of $5.3 billion over the next five years for education initiatives. The House also voted overwhelmingly, 315-59, to adopt an amendment requiring suspension of federal student financial aid for any student convicted of a drug offense. Rep. Peter Smith, R-Vt., also won support for an amendment to allow states and the Education Department to pool resources for special projects targeted at specific needs in a district. The projects could be exempt from a wide range of federal and state requirements. ``I think it is a major opening, major reform initiative to encourage schools to reinvent themselves for sure-fire performance for all students,'' said Smith, noting he had won endorsements from the National Governors Association and the president's education advisory council. The bill arose from the education summit Bush and the nation's governors held in Charlottesville, Va., in September 1989. It includes several of the statements of education policy goals requested by Bush as well as broader Democratic plans for spending programs. Bush's original version called for an estimated $400 million in 1991 spending. The House version increases authorization for remedial assistance to disadvantaged children. It would authorize $280 million for awards to exemplary schools, and includes money for Bush's proposed National Science Scholars Program and programs to fight illiteracy. It authorizes more money for financial assistance to college students willing to enter the teaching profession and for professional development of teachers. The Senate has passed a more limited version of the bill, and differences will have to be resolved in a conference committee.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Biography of Liberia's Samuel Doe
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a biography of Liberian leader Samuel Kanyon Doe:
BORN: May 6, 1950, Tuzon, Grand Gedeh County, Liberia.
MARRIED: Nancy B. Doe.
MILITARY SERVICE: Joined Liberian Army in 1969.

BIOGRAPHY: Master Sgt. Samuel Kanyon Doe led a bloody coup April 12, 1980, that ended the rule of President William Tolbert, who was killed. Doe's presidency has been characterized by numerous coup attempts, murders and detentions of opposition leaders and suppression of the country's press. Doe permitted elections in October 1985. When opposition parties appeared to have won the voting, Doe's men burned and destroyed ballots. The election commission Doe had appointed declared him the winner. The election rigging triggered the worst violence yet under Doe's rule. At least 1,500 people were estimated to have died, including Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa, who led a coup attempt. Quiwonkpa had been a popular commander from Nimba County and his killing made his home area a fertile base for the Dec. 24, 1989, invasion of Liberia by rebel leader Charles Taylor.

DOC.HEAD: Brief Biography of Liberian Rebel Leader Charles Taylor
With AM-Liberia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a biography of Liberian rebel leader Charles Taylor.
AGE: 42.
EDUCATION: Bachelor's degreee in economics, Bentley College, Waltham, Mass.
GOVERNMENT POSITION: Former head of General Services Administration.

BIOGRAPHY: Charles Taylor returned to Liberia from the United States, where he worked as a factory mechanic, after Samuel Doe took power in a 1980 military coup. Doe named Taylor head of the General Services Administration. Taylor fled to the United States in 1983 to escape charges of embezzlement. He was arrested in the United States but escaped before he could be extradited. Taylor's revolt began Dec. 24, 1989, when he crossed the Ivory Coast border into Liberia with a small band of men. They accused Doe of corruption, mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor based his men in Nimba County, an area hostile to Doe. Doe's forces responded with savage attacks on tribal groups that supported Taylor. International agencies say hundreds were killed, and the atrocities appeared to have increased support for Taylor. As a civilian, however, Taylor insists he is different from Doe, who made his career in the military. He said he was leading ``a grassroots civilian uprising to get rid of a dictator'' but harbored no dictatorial ambitions himself.

DOC.HEAD: Aspin Held Ready to Oppose B-2
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee is poised to oppose the B-2 bomber, according to congressional sources. But Rep. Les Aspin, questioned about his plans Friday, was coy. ``Stay tuned,'' the Wisconsin Democrat said in response to persistent queries from reporters. Aspin did confirm that he will deliver a major speech on the House floor Monday. Congressional sources, who requested anonymity, said Aspin will likely announce his support for an amendment that calls for ending the stealth bomber program at the 15 planes now in production. Meeting with reporters, Aspin cited five strategic weapons systems _ the B-2 bomber, the Advanced Tactical Fighter, the Advanced Tactical Aircraft, the C-17 transport plane and the light helicopter _ which together would cost more than $300 billion. ``You can't have declining defense budgets and buy full bore,'' Aspin said. Opposition to the stealth bomber has grown in Congress, where lawmakers have criticized the price tag of about $860 million a plane. Faced with a declining Soviet threat and fiscal constraints, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced in April a revised plan for the program that cut the total number from 132 to 75 and reduced this year's purchases from five planes to two. The revised proposal has had little effect in Congress, especially in the House, where opponents of the Northrop Corp.-manufactured aircraft say they are a handful of votes short on a measure to terminate the program. The Armed Services chairman made the comments days before his panel crafts a defense bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The House will draw up legislation based on $283 billion in military spending, $24 billion less than President Bush proposed in January. To reach the lower total, the committee plans to cut $11 billion from weapons procurement and $1.9 billion from research and development of those systems. In crafting its version of the bill, the Senate Armed Services Committee last week approved a $289 billion defense budget that trims $1 billion from Bush's request of $4.7 billion for the Strategic Defense Initiative and cuts active duty troop strength by 100,000, including 50,000 troops in Europe. Aspin predicted that his committee will produce a lower number for SDI, commonly known as Star Wars, than the $3.7 billion the Senate panel approved. The chairman also indicated his support for a reduction of at least 100,000 troops from the armed forces' current level of 2.1 million. The committee is looking to cut $800 million from the Pentagon's military personnel budget for fiscal 1991, which amounts to a cut of around 120,000 people plus the cost of benefits packages, severance pay for enlisted personnel and other programs. Aspin also used the session with reporters to renew his support for an independent commission to determine what military bases should be closed. The chairman vowed to include an amendment calling for a commission to the defense bill. Earlier this year, Aspin criticized Cheney's list of base closings as an attack on Democrats in Congress.
