DOC.HEAD: Hedgehogs and Barristers Suffer in the Heat
DOC.TEXT: Barristers were allowed to doff their heavy wigs and animal lovers fretted over thirsty hedgehogs as Britain sweltered in a heat wave Friday. Temperatures reached 90 degrees in Oxfordshire _ not all that hot by standards in some parts of the world, but enough to pose a problem for hedgehogs. The Vale Wildlife Rescue Centre said it had treated a dozen dehydrated hedgehogs this week, and appealed for people to put out bowls of water for them. ``Unlike other animals they can't travel large distances in search of water and the nights are so dry there is never any dew,'' said Caroline Gould at the hedgehog hospice in Corpthorne, in western England. To slake human thirsts, Young's Brewery in London announced it would operate through the weekend _ for only the second time since World War II. A company spokeswoman said beer sales had ``gone through the roof'' during the hot weather. In Wales, Cardiff Crown Court Judge John Rutter gave barristers permission to take off their bristly ceremonial wigs and gowns Friday. The judge, however, sweltered in the traditional way, with his wig in place.

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Defector, Two Others Executed in Taiwan for Kidnapping
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese defector and two other men were executed at dawn Friday for kidnapping the son of Taiwan's richest tycoon, the Justice Ministry said. Relatives of the three men, including Ma Xiaoqin, a sister of Ma Xiaobin, who defected to Nationalist-ruled Taiwan in 1986, spent five hours on their knees outside the residence of President Lee Teng-hui pleading for clemency. They ignored presidential guards who told them Lee was out of town. Ma, Wang Shih-chieh and Doung Lung, a Chinese-Vietnamese, were convicted of kidnapping Chang Kuo-min, 33, the son of shipping magnate Chang Yung-fa for a ransom of $1.9 million last year. Chang was eventually released unharmed and the ranson recovered. A statement from the Justice Ministry said the three men, all 27, were executed by shots fired into their backs at Taipei's Tucheng Prison. They were sentenced to death earlier this year. Forbes magazine this month listed the elder Chang, chairman of the Evergreen Group, a conglomerate based on shipping, as Taiwan's richest man. His fortune was estimated at more than $2 billion. The Taiwan government granted Ma Xiaoqin special permission earlier this month to enter Taiwan to see her brother before his execution. She said he told her he kidnapped Chang to get money to return to China. Ma and 18 other Chinese defected to Taiwan four years ago after sailing a fishing boat to South Korea. Human rights groups and lawyers held rallies to oppose the executions. They criticized laws that dictated executions for kidnappers, saying this could encourage kidnappers to kill their victims to avoid recognition.

DOC.HEAD: Court to Congress: Televised Testimony and Trials Don't Mix
DOC.TEXT: The court that set aside Oliver North's Iran-Contra convictions warned Congress that compelling the testimony of suspected wrongdoers in major scandals is likely to scuttle future prosecutions. The court, in effect, told Congress that it must choose between its desire to quickly air the details of a major scandal such as Watergate or the Iran-Contra affair or wait quietly while prosecutors investigate the participants and put them on trial. By compelling testimony of witnesses such as North, lawmakers are ``taking a great chance that the witness cannot constitutionally be indicted or prosecuted'' because of Fifth Amendment protections against self-incrimination, the court said. The ruling dealt a severe blow to the work of Independent Counsel Lawrence E. Walsh, raising the possibility that the conviction of former National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter could meet the same fate as North's. Both men testified before televised congressional hearings on the Iran-Contra affair under limited grants of immunity from prosecution. This ``use immunity'' guaranteed that North and Poindexter's words would not be used as evidence against them. But the court felt North's testimony received so much publicity that his words might have influenced the memory of the witnesses who gave evidence against him at his 1988 trial. ``It may be that it is possible in the present case to separate the wheat of the witnesses' unspoiled memory from the chaff of North's immunized testimony, but it may not,'' the ruling said. The court ordered the federal judge who presided over the North case, Gerhard A. Gesell, to conduct a ``witness-by-witness'' and if necessary a ``line-by-line'' review the trial testimony to make that determination. The 2-1 ruling by the panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here made it clear the majority believes that Walsh will have a difficult time proving that the evidence was not infected with the taint of North's congressional testimony. ``The fact that a sizable number of grand jury witnesses, trial witnesses and their aides apparently immersed themselves in North's immunized testimony leads us to doubt whether what is in question here is simply `stimulation' of memory by `a bit' of compelled testimony,'' the ruling said. ``Whether the government's use of compelled testimony occurs in the natural course of events or results from an unprecedented aberration is irrelevant to a citizen's Fifth Amendment right.'' If allowed to stand, the ruling would give hard choices in the future when it is in a race with prosecutors to get to the bottom of a scandal that shakes the nation like a Watergate or an Iran-Contra affair. ``The government must occasionally decide which it values more: immunization (perhaps to discharge institutional duties, such as congressional fact-finding and information dissemination) or prosecution,'' the ruling said. As Congress prepared to hold hearings in 1987, Walsh warned that it ``would create serious _ and perhaps insurmountable _ barriers to the prosecution of the immunized witness.'' In these situations ``you must weigh in the balance whether a public disclosure of all the facts is more important than a criminal prosecution,'' said Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill, a member of the Iran-Contra committee. ``It's very difficult to have both without trespassing on immunized testimony. We made a judgment, Congress did, that we wanted the public hearing,'' Hyde said. The ruling on Friday makes the dilemma even harder for lawmakers. ``It makes it almost impossible to have both a public congressional inquiry and a subsequent court proceeding against the wrongdoers,'' said Paul Rothstein, a criminal law professor at Georgetown University's law school. ``One or the other is going to have to do,'' Rothstein said. But when the next scandal breaks, ``there is really no way of restraining Congress,'' said Gerald Caplan, a George Washington University law professor. ``I am not sure in a matter of this importance whether public information about what happens isn't more important than guaranteeing the accuracy of the jury verdict,'' he said. ``We lawyers tend to think that guaranteeing the integrity of the factfinding process is the most important thing,'' Caplan said. ``But I think in matters of national importance _ Watergate or Irangate _ there is arguably an overriding public need for information to make judgments, for example electoral judgments.''
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S' NOTE
DOC.TEXT: James Rowley, who followed the investigation and prosecution of Oliver L. North, covers the Justice Department for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: How About a Real Headline to Go With the `Fake Byline'?
DOC.TEXT: It's fine to let bygones be bygones, but it was a tad disconcerting for The New York Times on Friday when the byline that was supposed to be gone wasn't gone. Instead, it said the story was written by ``Fake Byline.'' Byline's first _ and, the Times hopes, last _ appearance in the paper came on page A8, where a story about a Texas-Mexico ferry appeared under bold type declaring ``By Fake Byline.'' ``The story was not supposed to have a byline on it, but our computer format doesn't work without one,'' explained Times spokeswoman Nancy Nielsen. ``We plug in `Fake Byline' so the format works. It's supposed to be deleted, but ...'' But an inexperienced computer operator, unsure of working the equipment, failed to remove the bogus byline and out it went, she said. The byline did not appear in all editions of The Times, so it was unknown how many readers saw it, she said.

DOC.HEAD: No Current Plan for Peacekeeping Force as Siege Intensifies
DOC.TEXT: The United States has no immediate plans to send a U.S. peacekeeping force to Liberia as requested by officials of the West African nation besieged by civil war, the State Department said Friday. ``Our policy is to continue to urge both sides to participate in negotiations to prevent the further loss of life,'' spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters. The United States, she said, strongly supports negotiations aimed at a cease-fire and international peacekeeping force by the Economic Community of West African States and ``regrets that the talks have broken down,'' she said. Ms. Tutwiler confirmed that President Bush had received an appeal from Foreign Minister J. Rudolph Johnson, Washington ambassador Eugenia Wordsworth-Stevenson and eight other prominent Liberians for a temporary U.S. force to prevent bloodshed until international peacekeeping machinery is set up. Most Liberians would welcome U.S. help in ``averting massive plunder and tribal revenge'' and in having President Samuel Doe evacuated from the country, said one of the Liberian signers, former U.N. Ambassador Winston Tubman. They letter said Doe's ``resignation and departure from Liberia ... and the establishment of an interim government'' was expected soon. Rebels on Friday overran most of northern Monrovia, the capital city, pushing several hundred remaining government troops into a narrow strip of land on both sides of Doe's executive mansion. Witnesses reported many government casualties, and shipping sources said two Liberian coast guard cutters were sunk in the port by gunfire. U.S. warships with Marine units aboard were moved close to Liberia several weeks ago. The African nation, founded by freed American slaves 150 years ago, has traditionally had close ties with the United States.

DOC.HEAD: State Officials Say Feds Not Doing Enough About Salmonella
DOC.TEXT: State health officials complained Friday that the Agriculture Department has left them to their own devices in the fight against salmonella enteritidis, a potentially fatal form of bacteria found in raw or undercooked eggs. ``The absence of a coordinated federal response has left states with no alternative but to take strong action to protect their citizens from contaminated food often produced in other states,'' John J. Guzewich of the New York State Health Department told a congressional oversight panel. Robert Flentge of the Illinois Public Health Department complained about ``mixed signals at the federal level'' and interference with his department. A.B. Park of the Maryland Agriculture Department said state officials began tracing eggs and testing chickens while federal officials were debating whether salmonellosis is a poultry disease. The witnesses appeared before the oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The panel's chairman, Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., alleged that the Agriculture Department was late in recognizing the growing number of outbreaks traced to the bacteria and withheld information from the Food and Drug Administration, which also regulates the food supply. Poisoning from the enteritidis form of salmonella has been increasing steadily since 1982 and is most likely to be fatal among the very old, the very young and others whose immune systems are weak, according to the Centers for Disease Control. The agency says the increase is directly related to contamination of Grade A eggs that are eaten raw or undercooked. Infection has been spread through scrambled, poached and over-easy eggs, as well as in home-made ice cream, cole slaw, sauces and dressings. Since 1985, there have been 217 outbreaks responsible for 7,370 cases of infection. Of those cases, 44 resulted in death, CDC says. Health officials say tracing the food poisoning to a particular flock is by nature difficult and is made more difficult by the lack of effective regulation. Even an infected flock may produce only one contaminated egg in 1,000, said Dr. Robert Tauxe of the Centers for Disease Control. Testing all chickens before allowing their eggs to be shipped is also impossible for now, he said. Organ cultures are required to find the bacteria. The problem can become worse when the eggs reach a restaurant, nursing home or institution, said Tauxe. One contaminated egg can contaminate a bowl of 500, he said. The state officials complained that federal inspections are limited to brood hens that produce the laying hens, even though environmental contamination remains a real risk. They also complained that no recall provision exists for eggs that have reached the market, and that no effective way exists for tracing eggs.

DOC.HEAD: Costs Higher, Benefits Lower for Land Retirement Program
DOC.TEXT: Costs of a popular farm conservation program are expected to be higher and its benefits lower than previously estimated, an Agriculture Department report said Friday. A reassessment of the Conservation Reserve Program, or CRP, shows federal outlays may be $6.6 billion to $9.3 billion over the lifetime of the program, 1986 through 1999. Meanwhile, the report said, benefits may be $4.2 billion to $9 billion. The Conservation Reserve Program is a long-term plan designed by Congress in 1985 to take 40 million to 45 million acres of highly erodible cropland from production for 10 years, planting it to grass and trees. In return, farmers get one-time assistance to plant the protective vegetative cover plus annual rental payments averaging about $50 per acre. An earlier assessment had put net benefits of the program, assuming the full 45 million acres to be retired, at $3.4 billion to $11 billion, and net federal costs at only $2.6 billion to $6.6 billion. ``The reassessment is based on current enrollment of 34 million acres and reflects the reduced crops stocks and higher prices caused by uneven weather other the past few years,'' the report said. ``Higher prices lessened the commodity program savings that might otherwise have been attributed to the CRP.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Fines Indianapolis Station for Sexually Explicit Broadcasts
DOC.TEXT: An Indianapolis radio station has been fined $10,000 for broadcasting sexually explicit material in violation of federal indecency rules, the Federal Communications Commission said Friday. The action against WFBQ-FM, owned by Great American Television and Radio Co. in Cincinnati, was the latest in a spate of moves in the past year by a newly constituted FCC bent on cracking down on disc jockeys often called ``shock jocks.'' The FCC, led by new chairman Alfred Sikes, has issued a number of warnings and fines against stations, most recently a $20,000 fine in June against a San Jose, Calif., radio station, KSJO-FM. In all cases, the commission cited ``indecent'' material involving sexual innuendo or descriptions of sexual organs broadcast between 6 a.m. and 8 p.m. The commission earlier this month repeated its intention to try to extend the ban on indecent broadcast material to 24 hours a day. A court ruling on a 24-hour ban is pending. The FCC warned Great American officials a year ago that material broadcast in 1987 on a show featuring disc jockeys Bob Kevoian and Tom Griswold on WFBQ-FM and its sister station, WNDE-AM, may have violated the FCC's indecency rules. Those rules prohibit the broadcast during daylight hours of ``language or material that ... depicts or describes, in terms patently offensive as measured by contemporary community standards for the broadcast medium, sexual or excretory activities or organs.'' The commission also reviewed material the station broadcast in 1989 and considered the company's arguments. In a letter to Great American officials dated Thursday, the FCC agreed with the company's assertion that two skits in question were not indecent. But the commission said that material in several other programs ``fit squarely within our definition of indecency.'' Station manager Chris Wheat said the company had not decided whether to appeal. The fines stem from a complaint filed by John R. Price, a Carmel, Ind., lawyer who founded Decency in Broadcasting.

DOC.HEAD: Barney Frank: From Rumpled Rebel to Reprimand
LaserPhoto WX10
With AM-Frank-Ethics
DOC.TEXT: One of Barney Frank's earliest campaign posters showed the rumpled, pudgy, bespectacled candidate under the caption ``Neatness isn't everything.'' Later, the liberal congressman cleaned up his act. He lost weight, spiffed up his wardrobe and shed glasses for contact lenses. That's also when Frank _ whose life had been dominated by political work _ turned to a sex ad on his 45th birthday. The ad put him in contact with Stephen Gobie, the male prostitute whose disclosure of the relationship became the big blot on Frank's 10-year career in Congress. Two years later, in 1987, Frank publicly disclosed his homosexuality. Observers have said that the sharp-tongued politician was naive about private personal relationships. Frank himself said he took Gobie under his wing, believing he could help reform the man he acknowledges he paid for sex. Before the Gobie affair, Frank was best known as one of the most liberal members of Congress, with a deadly political wit. It was Frank who once quipped of the conservative bent of the anti-abortion lobby: ``Sure, they're pro-life. They believe that life begins at conception and ends at birth.'' Frank, 50, a graduate of Harvard Law School, cut his political teeth as chief of staff to then Boston Mayor Kevin White in the years 1968-1971. Frank then went to work as a congressional aide. Frank first entered the political arena on his own in 1980, winning the old 4th Congressional District seat after the Rev. Robert Drinan was ordered to retire by the Roman Catholic Church. Then, in 1982, Frank's district was folded into a new area that stretched from the working-class mill city of Fall River to the rich Yankee suburbs of Boston. The race pitted Frank against incumbent Margaret Heckler, a Republican who had carved out a strong political base in the suburbs where some of the state's most affluent families live. Most of the new district was on Heckler's turf, but Frank raised $1 million and won with a 60 percent margin. Now, despite his troubles over Gobie, Frank is considered a safe bet to win this year's election. Frank is still popular with constituents. His lone Republican challenger, John Soto, is a lawyer-accountant from Attleboro with no experience in elected office and a stormy relationship with the state GOP hierarchy. Soto has played up Frank's homosexuality in the race, calling on the congressman to take a test for AIDS and make the result public. But the move has backfired. Audiences have booed Soto, and he has drawn criticism in the media. James Nuzzo, another Republican challenger considered a more serious threat to Frank's seat, recently dropped out of the race. Soto called the House ethics panel's decision to reprimand Frank a slap on the wrist. ``Mr. Frank's admitted high-risk behavior sets a terrible example for the youth of America, that is in desperate need of positive role models,'' he said. Although Frank has a strong hold on his district in this year's race, he could face a tougher fight in the next election if Massachusetts loses a congressional seat because of its lack of population growth in comparison to the Sun Belt. Massachusetts could lose two seats in Congress, according to some demographers, basing their predictions on Census projections. The Legislature will decide which seats go, and conservative legislators may be inclined to take Frank's seat. If the state loses only one seat, and if Rep. Silvio Conte, the lone Republican in the Massachusetts delegation, retires after more than 30 years representing the 1st Congressional District, Frank's seat could be safe. But a loss of two seats, or a decision by Conte to stay on, could pit Frank against another incumbent Democrat. For now, though, Frank has regained the fiesty attitude he admits he lost in the first moments of embarrassment over the Gobie affair. ``There is no question about it. I was unhappy and disappointed and angry with myself,'' Frank said recently. ``It brought back a whole lot of things that I had been dealing with in terms of emotions and some in terms of action that I thought I had dealt with.''

DOC.HEAD: Savings Institutions Show Decline In Deposits
DOC.TEXT: The nation's savings institutions lost $19.9 billion in deposits during the first two months of 1990, nearly matching the record outflows of a year earlier, the government said Friday. Depositors at institutions still under private ownership withdrew $13.7 billion more than they deposited during January and February, the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said in a long-delayed statistical report. Account holders at failed institutions under government control withdrew a net $6.2 billion. At all institutions net withdrawals totaled $13.3 billion in January, a record topping the previous mark of $10.9 billion in January 1989, and $6.6 billion in February. The two-month total fell just short of the $20 billion drain in January-February 1989. February marked the 20th deposit drain in 21 months and left the industry's total deposit base at $926.5 billion. Economists attributed the outflow to three factors: _Deliberate shrinkage by solvent S&Ls trying to meet stringent capital requirements imposed by last August's bailout bill. _A cut in the high interest rates offered by failed institutions after they come under government control. _Lingering confidence problems among depositors at failed thrifts, despite government insurance guaranteeing each account up to $100,000. ``I would expect we'll have deposit outflows for quite some time to come. I don't think we'll see the end of it until next year. This industry is undergoing monumental restructuring,'' said economist Martin Regalia of the National Council of Savings Institutions. Friday's report was the first 1990 data released for thrifts. Normally by this time, deposit flow information current through May would have been available. But computer problems plus disarray caused by the reorganization of the S&L bureaucracy under last year's law delayed the reports. Economist James Barth of Auburn University, a former chief economist at the thrift office, criticized the information drought and said it may even be hurting the governments' efforts to find acquirers for failed thrifts. ``It makes it more difficult to induce people to come to the table to do deals if they don't have timely information. ... If you're going to buy an institution, you need to know how it compares to the rest of the industry,'' he said. The thrift office also reported that S&Ls wrote $23.7 billion in new mortgages during January and February, down from $29.4 billion in the same period of 1989. Regalia attributed the decline partly to a deliberate pull-back by S&Ls to meet new financial standards and partly to an anemic housing market in many areas of the country. ``The housing market is really atrocious,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jim Smith, Meet Jim Smith
DOC.TEXT: With all the Jim Smiths reserving rooms for the national Jim Smith Society annual meeting, the Sheraton Park Place Hotel needed a way to keep track. ``We're giving them all numbers. That's how I can keep up with them all,'' Reservations Manager G'Ann Shannon said Thursday as she grappled with 39 Jim Smith reservations. For example, if you wanted to get to Jim Smith of Dayton, you asked for Jim Smith No. 2. The gathering, which began Friday, is an opportunity for Jim Smith to talk with Jim Smith about the trials and tribulations of having one of the most common names in the United States. Jim Smith of Dayton remembered all the confusion when he tried to buy a house. ``When I bought my house, I had to sign affidavits saying that I was not the Jim Smith that was sentenced to 15 to 20 years in prison. And that I wasn't the Jim Smith that's been dead for 10 years,'' he said. ``Things like that have really been a nuisance.'' Jim Smith of Braintree, Mass., said that a Sears store got him confused with another Jim Smith. ``I used to keep getting these bills for baby stuff. And I didn't have a baby,'' he said. The Jim Smith Society, founded in 1969, has 1,533 members worldwide, including eight females. The annual convention includes the Jim Smith golf tournament, the all-Jim Smith softball game, ``Meet Jim Smith'' mixers and JIMGO, a version of bingo. Jim Smith of Camp Hill, Pa., said he started the organization because he met so many people with the name and because of all the teasing he got.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Living in Cadillac After Losing $4 Million Townhouse
LaserPhoto NY28
DOC.TEXT: Mylene and Joseph Liggett are living a riches-to-rags existence, sleeping in a 1977 Cadillac to publicize their claim that a bank fraudulently snatched their $4.25 million townhouse. ``We're trying to get a message across _ that the bank has stolen our money,'' Liggett, 67, said as he stood beside his decaying Sedan de Ville in front of the house Friday. ``The humiliation doesn't bother me. All I want is justice.'' The bank denied all allegations made by the Liggetts. The five-story townhouse is just off exclusive Sutton Place, where the Liggetts say they have lived for 14 years. The tree-shaded street is just large enough for cars to park in front of the tony townhouses that overlook the East River. They claim that Bank Leumi Trust Co. took possession of their home Wednesday, changed the locks and installed round-the-clock guards, forcing the Liggetts and their poodle, Ferrari, into the Cadillac. Two guards at the house Friday acknowledged the 24-hour presence. Taped to a front window is a November 1989 order from state judge Burton S. Sherman giving Bank Leumi the property and ordering the Liggetts out. The bank has since bought the house for $50,000 at an unadvertised auction where it was the sole bidder _ all illegal, according to the Liggetts. Bank President Richard Kane said, ``Every single allegation they are making now they have made in a series of courts over the last six years. Every time, they have been thrown out. There continues to be no substance to the claims they make.'' The couple's older son, John, said Liggett made his money from plastics patents used by a company he founded in the late 1950s and then sold for millions of dollars in the late 1970s. The couple once had Manhattan and Westhampton condominiums and traveled abroad on the Concorde. Next to the Cadillac is a non-working Mercedes, also from 1977. The couple claims they now have no money because they have been defending themselves for years against what they say are the bank's fraudulent claims. They said the bank claims it is owed more than $1 million because they did not repay a $327,000 business loan from 1979. Mrs. Liggett said they never got the loan money and, on top of that, she deposited $327,000 in certificates of deposit as collateral, which the bank has taken. They also claim that the bank continuously removed money _ up to $3.6 million _ from their accounts without their permission. ``They locked me out of my house. The only thing I got out of my house is what I have on. All the records I need to fight them are in the house,'' Liggett said. ``I feel very angry, very hurt, very upset,'' said Mrs. Liggett, who is French and, according to her husband, ``50-something.'' The Liggetts said they could stay somewhere else but they wanted the publicity from living in the Cadillac so they could get a good lawyer. ``We have a good case against the bank,'' Mrs. Liggett said. ``Any attorney who works for us would be rewarded handsomely.'' Her husband concurred. ``They blew us away,'' he said. ``Now we will blow them away.''

DOC.HEAD: Mass Grave of Policemen Found in Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Government troops unearthed the bodies of 110 policemen in a mass grave in eastern Sri Lanka, a Defense Ministry statement said Friday. The policemen had surrendered to Tamil Tiger rebels last month after the guerrillas rejected a 13-month-long cease-fire with government forces. The bodies had been shot a single time in the head, the statement said. Also Friday, 45 policemen escaped from rebel captivity after killing three guerrillas, police said. At least 830 policemen were captured by the rebels soon after fighting resumed in northern and eastern Sri Lanka on June 11. Many of the captives have been killed, the government says. A senior police official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said 45 policemen reached government lines in Polonnaruwa, a town 103 miles northeast of Colombo, after escaping rebel captivity. They were being held at a Tamil-dominated village 42 miles southwest of Polonnoruwa, the officer said. At least 2,600 combatants have been killed since the fighting began. Many civilians also have died. Meanwhile, in India, the government of the southern state of Tamil Nadu organized a daylong strike Friday to protest the killings of Tamils. United News of India said the strike was total and peaceful. All state government offices and schools were closed and there was no traffic on the streets. Tamil Nadu, separated from northern Sri Lanka by a narrow strip of sea, is home to India's 50 million Tamils, many of whom sympathize with the rebels in Sri Lanka. A Sri Lankan parliamentary delegation is in New Delhi to express concerns the rebels are using bases in Tamil Nadu. Sri Lankan Industries Minister Ranil Wickramasinghe, who is on the delegation, told reporters Indian government officials had promised to ensure that no sanctuary was given to the guerrillas. The fighting in SriLanka is the latest phase of the 7-year-old war for an independent Tamil homeland in the island nation's north and east. Tamil militants accuse the majority Sinhalese community of discrimination in jobs, education and language. The insurgency has killed at least 13,600 people. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and Sinhalese, who dominate the government and armed forces, comprise 75 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Uniform Libel Law for States Criticized for Alleged Bias
DOC.TEXT: A proposed uniform libel law under which courts would decide whether statements are true or false before determining appropriate damages would not guarantee First Amendment rights for defendants, critics say. The Uniform Defamation Act is the first proposal for a nationwide standard in libel disputes. It was discussed Friday by the National Conference of Commissioners on Uniform State Laws _ a group appointed by the nation's governors to draft model legislation. The 28-page draft outlines a two-stage procedure for libel trials. A court would first determine whether a statement under question is true or false. Only later _ during the trial's second stage _ would a court decide what, if any, damages to assess. Safeguards for the press _ protection if a reporter acted without malice or allowances made if a plaintiff is a public official _ would not apply in the trial's first stage. ``The substantive question is whether constitutional privileges can be delayed until the truth is determined,'' said the draft's author, Harvey Perlman, dean of the University of Nebraska's College of Law. The committee said the draft was based on the premise that plaintiffs are more interested in clearing their names than in receiving damages. Perlman said the proposed law's intent was to protect plaintiffs' reputations better, but it also would benefits news organizations. Under the proposal, news organizations could print retractions or pay a plaintiff's legal fees after the first stage _ a provision proponents say would shorten trials and reduce the amount of damages awarded. ``We wanted to create some incentives for the plaintiff to stop early,'' Perlman said. But critics argue the committee's desire to design safeguards for a person's reputation would create a ``chilling effect'' on the First Amendment. ``One of our central concerns is the committee's desire to move the law in favor of the plaintiff,'' said Henry R. Kaufman, counsel for the Libel Defense Resource Center. ``There will be a chilling effect if the media believes it is going to face higher costs and greater burdens of libel and litigation.'' Others at the annual conference questioned creating one standard for an intricate field of First Amendment law and court decisions. ``I don't feel it's an area of the law where you can provide a uniform act,'' said delegate John McClaugherty, a lawyer from Charleston, W.Va. ``The First Amendment is constantly being reinterpreted and by the time a law was passed it would already be out of date.'' Some delegates said they feared legislators with a grudge against the press would attempt to draft legislation unfavorable to the media. But Perlman said the criticism did not worry him. ``Traditionally, it is the people that have concerns that stand up,'' he said. ``But I would be naive not to think there is substantial concern about it.'' The earliest a proposal would be redrafted and returned to the 350-member conference would be next year, he said, but no date was set for a vote.

DOC.HEAD: INS Resumes Denial of Asylum to Nicaraguans
DOC.TEXT: Immigration authorities have resumed issuing letters of denial to Nicaraguans seeking asylum in the United States, after a five-month suspension, a spokesman said Friday. In coming months, letters will go out to some 12,000 Nicaraguans whose requests for asylum have been rejected, said Duke Austin, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The INS stopped sending the letters last February to see whether Nicaragua's Sandinista government would fulfill its pledge to hold free elections, Austin said. The INS also wanted to evaluate the performance of the new government elected to replace the Marxist Sandinistas, he said. Having satisfied themselves that the U.S.-backed government of Violetta Chamorro has asserted control over the country and resisted several challenges by the Sandinistas, U.S. authorities decided to resume sending the denial letters on July 1. ``This does not mean that these people are in imminent danger of being sent home involuntarily,'' Austin said. Applicants denied asylum have recourse through a lengthy appeals process, which often takes several years. Another estimated 25,000 asylum requests from Nicaraguans are still pending. Privately, immigration officials concede a successful switch to democracy in Nicaragua may sharply curtail U.S. granting of asylum. In addition, improved conditions may lessen the number of applicants. But Robert Boyer, an immigration attorney in Miami who specializes in Nicaraguan cases, said he's been flooded with calls from worried Nicaraguan refugees who have received notices from the INS. ``To wait only three months with the new situation in Nicaragua and decide that things are stable enough to move ahead on this now is really imprudent,'' he said. In fiscal year 1989, the INS granted just under 6,000 requests from Nicaraguans for asylum, denying more than 10,000. Between October 1989 and January of this year, about 500 were granted and 650 denied. The United States provides asylum to people who can prove they will face persecution if they are sent back home. Most denials occur because analysts rule applicants are economic, rather than political, refugees. INS officials predict 65,000 foreigners will ask for asylum this year, most of them from Latin America. The INS announced this week it was improving its system for examining such requests by forming a corps of 70-90 examiners who will deal only with asylum and be versed in international affairs.

DOC.HEAD: Wreckage of Stolen Plane Found Near Syria, Ending Long Search
DOC.TEXT: Searchers found the wreckage of a missing Air Force plane near the Syrian border Friday, along with the body of the reservist pilot who stole the craft, the army said. The discovery ended the largest air, land and sea search in Israel's history, launched a week ago following the first theft of an Israeli air force plane. The plane was stolen from an air base in central Israel by a 33-year-old reservist pilot, Hagai Morry, who made an unauthorized takeoff shortly before he was scheduled to fly on a routine mission. A military communique said Morry's body was found near the remains of the plane on the western slopes of the Golan Heights, which were annexed from Syria after being captured in the 1967 Middle East war. The theft had fueled speculation that Morry, a captain in the reserves, might have defected to a neighboring Arab country. But Maj. Gen. Avihu Bin Nun, the air force commander, told reporters Friday he believed Morry intended to commit suicide by crashing his plane. The aircraft was a West-German made twin-engine Dornier-28, a common reconnaissance plane. Officials said earlier they believed Morry had personal problems. Newspapers said he had been having marital problems and was was not living with his wife. Morry, who was studying for a doctorate in physics, reportedly flew over most of the country before disappearing. He buzzed his home in the northern city of Haifa and was last seen flying north toward the Lebanon border, newspapers said.

DOC.HEAD: Study Says Healthy Living Can Reduce Heart Disease Damage
DOC.TEXT: A low-fat vegetarian diet, clean living and stress management can reverse heart disease in many patients in as little as a year, according to a study published in this week's edition of The Lancet. Dr. Dean Ornish of the Preventive Medicine Research Institute of Sausalito, Calif., who coordinated ``The Lifestyle Heart Trial,'' said it is the first evidence that heart disease can be reversed without surgery or drugs. ``Comprehensive lifestyle changes may be able to bring about regression of even severe coronary atherosclerosis after only one year,'' the study said. Researchers stressed that ``adherence to this lifestyle program needs to be very good for overall regression to occur, although more moderate changes have some beneficial effects.'' The study noted only two other controlled studies had shown regression of coronary atherosclerosis and both used cholesterol-lowering drugs as the main treatment. The 10 researchers participating in the study cautioned that important questions remained unanswered. The study involved only 41 patients and the researchers said it was important to determine whether these results can be sustained in large numbers of patients with coronary heart disease. Further research is also needed to determine the relative contribution of each component of the lifestyle program, the researchers said. Scientists should also study just how the disease regresses and compare the results of changing lifestyles vs. using drugs or surgery, they said. The study said 41 patients from the San Francisco area, aged 35-75, were randomly assigned to an experimental group and a control group. The 22 patients in the experimental group ate a low-fat, vegetarian diet. Smoking and caffeine were banned and alcohol was limited to two drinks a day, although drinking was not encouraged. They exercised regularly and attended stress management training classes. Eighteen of the 22 patients showed a reversal of coronary artery blockages; three showed slight deterioriation, and one patient with ``poor adherence'' to the diet became markedly worse, the study reported. The 19 control group patients stuck to a program generally recommended for heart disease patients. They ate a diet of 30 percent fat, did not smoke and had moderate exercise. Ten of the 19 patients in the control group experienced worsening of their coronary artery blockages. Eight improved. One showed no change. ``This finding suggests that conventional recommendations don't go far enough for many people,'' Ornish said in an interview. ``The guidelines may be enough to prevent heart disease but not to reverse it.'' ``The amount of chest pain improved within a week or two and there was a 91 percent reduction in chest pain. When you feel that much better you are willing to make the changes. The healthier lifestyle becomes self-reinforcing.'' By contrast, the study found the control group patients experienced a 165 percent rise in the frequency of chest pains. Ornish said the study turned up two unexpected findings. ``We found that women didn't have to change their lifestyle completely to see a change,'' Ornish said. ``Men may have to do more.'' Four of the eight patients in the low-fat control group who improved were women, he said, while 17 of the 18 in the experimental group who improved were men. But he added that with only five women participating in the study additional research on a possible gender variable was needed. Ornish said researchers were also surprised to find that the more severe artery blockages showed the most improvement. ``Though the finding was unexpected, they (severe blockages) are the most dangerous,'' he said. Ornish said follow-up testing will continue for four years to see whether blockages continue to reverse. The study was funded by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute of the National Institutes of Health and more than 16 other organizations and foundations.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Dip To Six-Month Low
DOC.TEXT: Interest on fixed-rate home mortgages dipped below 10 percent this week for the first time in six months, raising hopes that the sluggish real estate market may pick up slightly as a result. The fixed rate for 30-year mortgages averaged 9.99 percent this week, down from 10.11 percent last week, said the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The corporation is a congressionally-chartered but shareholder-owned company indirectly financing about one in eight American home purchases. It was the lowest since fixed-rate mortgages averaged 9.90 percent during the week ending Jan. 19. One-year adjustable-rate mortgages fell from 8.45 percent to 8.39 percent, also the lowest since Jan. 19, when the average was an identical 8.39 percent. The rates, which do not include add-on fees known as points, hit a high in May for the year so far of 10.67 percent for fixed-rate loans and 8.63 percent for adjustable loans. ``It's always encouraging to see rates decline a little bit, particularly to drop below the double-digit level,'' said economist Thomas Holloway of the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. ``The housing market certainly needs a shot in the arm.'' Sales of existing homes, as tracked by the National Association of Realtors, have declined in four of the first five months of the year to an annual rate of 3.29 million units in May. New home sales, meanwhile, rose in May for the first time in six months to an annual rate of 532,000 units, but were still depressed to levels not seen since the 1982 recession. Holloway said his trade group was forecasting continued sluggishness in housing markets and saw little prospect for further interest rate declines. ``Right now there is a huge inventory of homes available for sale. The economy is not collapsing but it's not going gang busters either,'' he said. ``This (recent) small move in rates is not likely to do that much.''

DOC.HEAD: Senators Want More Changes in Cambodia Policy
With AM-Cambodia-Next Step, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A bipartisan group of senators pressed the Bush administration Friday to make more changes in its Cambodia policy, including lifting a trade embargo and opening direct talks with the communist government. Lawmakers at a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee hearing said administration moves to rescind recognition for a three-party rebel coalition fighting the Cambodian government won't slow a resurgence by the Khmer Rouge rebels. ``The Khmer Rouge ... remain the primary beneficiaries of our policy,'' said Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass. An economic embargo imposed in 1975, when the Khmer Rouge were in power, is weakening the government that replaced that regime, Kerry said. The Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia from 1975 to 1979, undertaking a massive social experiment that forcibly scattered city dwellers through the countryside and resulted in the deaths of more than a million countrymen from execution, starvation and disease. ``It is time to rethink our policy,'' said Sen. Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska. ``It is necessary to go further.'' Murkowski, a member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, said the administration's policy changes have left a contradiction: opposition to a Khmer Rouge return to power but support for their participation in elections. He called for the United States instead to work with other governments to forge a coalition between the Phnom Penh government of Hun Sen and the U.S.-supported non-communist resistance factions, isolating the Khmer Rouge. The United States provides about $20 million a year through covert and open channels to the two non-communist groups fighting the Hun Sen government in a loose alliance with the Khmer Rouge. Murkowski said aid should be continued to keep alive a non-communist alternative that Cambodians could vote for in an election. But he said all U.S. aid should be given openly and should be primarily non-military. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., said military aid should end, with U.S. dollars channeled into support for building a democratic political opposition. He spending $64,000 to set up a training facility for 200 boys ages 12 to 16 at a resistance base camp was a misue of U.S. aid. The policy of supporting the rebel coalition is ``courting disaster,'' said Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. ``The potential for a tragic outcome is great.'' The Bush administration's intention to open talks with the Vietnamese government will only worsen matters, Kerrey said. Citing the intense hatred between Vietnamese and Cambodians, he said U.S. talks with Hanoi will only fan the nationalistic fervor that is the basis of the Khmer Rouge political appeal. The Khmer Rouge will be able to point to the talks and tell peasants: ``Look! The American imperialists and the Vietnamese are trying to take over your country,'' said Kerrey, a Vietnam veteran who visited Cambodia earlier this year. ``It is very risky.'' Cranston said 50 senators so far have signed a letter circulated by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, calling on President Bush to make stopping the Khmer Rouge the primary aim of U.S. policy. Fearing a comeback by the communist guerrillas, the administration said Wednesday it was withdrawing support for a United Nations seat for the three-party resistance that includes the Khmer Rouge, the Sihanouk forces and the faction of former Cambodian Prime Minister Son Sann.

DOC.HEAD: Friends Celebrate Birthday Of Vice President's Wife
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle's friends surprised her with an early birthday bash at a roller skating rink, where one of the guests fell while skating and broke both arms. French Wallop, wife of Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., broke her right arm and left elbow. She said only her right arm is in a cast. ``I was having a good time skating, and the next thing I knew I wasn't skating,'' she said. Mrs. Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, turns 41 on July 29. But her pals orchestrated the surprise pizza party on Wednesday at the Franconia skating center in suburban Alexandria, Va. The gifts included a pair of roller blades and a Nintendo Game Boy, Mrs. Wallop said. The guests included the wives of several congressmen.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Borders Tightened Because of Shelf-Stripping
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union is tightening its border controls because of smuggling and profiteering that has stripped store shelves in the western part of the country, Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov announced Friday. Also Friday, Mikhail S. Gorbachev's top advisers huddled in the Kremlin to outline long-delayed reforms for salvaging the Soviet economy. Gorbachev said his concept for a union of sovereign republics and the transfer to a market economy are linked. In a nationally televised address, Ryzhkov said the border restrictions, which were relaxed in September 1988, are being tightened temporarily because of the ``abnormal'' situation on the western Soviet border. He did not elaborate on what the tighter restrictions would entail. Ryzhkov said Soviets and residents of unspecified neighboring countries were taking advantage of the considerably cheaper-priced Soviet consumer goods and engaging in smuggling and rampant black-marketeering. He said the situation has the potential to become uncontrollable. Ryzhkov said he signed a decision Thursday to repeal the simplified rules for crossing the Soviet border until such time as border and customs services can ensure normal relations with neighboring nations. The simplified rules loosened restrictions on residents of border areas to cross the frontier and export goods. Recently, however, customs officials have been rigorously searching vehicles to look for goods being taken out of the Soviet Union. On Thursday, the Polish government said it was seeking the lifting of travel restrictions imposed on foreign visitors to the western Ukrainian city of Lvov, where authorities have barred tourists' cars and said scarce goods will be confiscated if foreigners try to take them away. In recent months, Poles have gained a reputation as voracious traders, buying up state-subsidized goods in the Soviet Union such as televisions, jewelry, caviar and gasoline. But many Soviets have gone West as well, buying clothes and other consumer goods not easily available in their country. At the Kremlin meeting of the Presidential Council and the Federation Council, Gorbachev's top two advisory groups, Ryzhkov outlined his government's plan for the transfer to a market economy beginning in 1991, the Tass news agency reported. The official news agency said the plan includes freedom of economic activities and enterprise, developing a system of protecting citizens from increasing prices and unemployment, decentralizing property and establishing anti-monopoly measures. No specifics were given. An economic program presented by Ryzhkov in May caused panic buying that made empty store shelves even barer. A new version of the plan was ordered, with the first phase of food price increases put off until 1991. Ryzhkov's new plan outlined Friday is to be presented to the Soviet parliament when it reconvenes in September. Gorbachev stressed that the transfer to a market economy and the drawing up of a new union treaty involving the 15 Soviet republics were ``two sides of the same coin,'' according to Tass. The treaty, which would ensure increased autonomy of the republics, would also create a single market-oriented system in which all component parts will complement each other, Tass quoted Gorbachev as saying. Separatist trends only make even more complicated the situation both in the republics and the nation in general, Gorbachev said, according to the news agency. To keep the Soviet Union from splintering, Gorbachev in June proposed the 15 republics agree on a new, looser union of ``sovereign states.'' Since Gorbachev began his reforms in 1985, many Soviet republics have sought to exercise more and more independence from Moscow. The Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have made outright moves toward independence. The Russian federation, the Ukraine, Moldavia and Uzbekistan have declared their sovereignty, proclaiming that local laws take precedence over Soviet law.

DOC.HEAD: Baker, Israeli Foreign Minister To Discuss Peace Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd to clarify that U.S. won't pay for the whole project; 4th graf new with cost of project.
DOC.TEXT: The State Department on Friday announced it had invited Israel's new foreign minister, David Levy, to talk about moving forward the stalled peace process between Israel and its Palestinian neighbors. The Defense Department, meanwhile, informed Israel that the United States would contribute to the second phase of the Arrow, an anti-missile missile being developed in Israel in cooperation with the U.S. Star Wars program. Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Arens said he was informed of the decision at a meeting with Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney. Israeli officials said Arens and Cheney did not discuss the amount of the U.S. participation in the $240 million second phase, but Israel was pleased by the U.S. commitment to support the project. The Arens-Cheney meeting came as the administration tried to defuse speculation that its decision this week to postpone defense-cooperation talks with Israel was an attempt to wrest concessions in the peace process. ``The postponement was an agreement between the United States government and the Israeli government,'' said State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. The annual talks will take place in September, instead, she said. The administration is busy negotiating future budgets with Congress and is uncertain about how much money it will have available for foreign aid in fiscal year 1992, Tutwiler said. The administration has already asked Congress for $3 billion in fiscal 1991 for Israel, which is the largest recipient of U.S. aid. ``The postponement is purely a practical matter. United States-Israeli relations remain strong. Our commitment to Israel's security and to the preservation of its qualitative edge remains unshakeable,'' Tutwiler said. Israeli officials also insisted Arens' brief visit, which was only announced Thursday, was unrelated to the postponement of the annual talks on the Joint Security Assistance Program. Nonetheless, the postponement caught Israeli officials by surprise and created unease in light of several expressions of impatience from Secretary of State James A. Baker III about what he described as Israeli foot dragging on the peace process. Baker's talks with Levy, who came into office when a government of the hard line Likud bloc was sworn in last month, will take place on Aug. 9 or 10, Tutwiler said. A U.S. official said Levy was still weak from surgery he underwent for a circulatory ailment and may break the talks with Baker into two sessions, one each day. Levy and Baker were supposed to meet last week in Paris but Levy was advised by his doctors to stay home. Last March, Israel rejected a formula devised by Baker for talks that would lead to elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. An internal Israeli dispute over the Baker plan led to the government's collapse. Baker, determined to try again, met here last month with Egyptian and Jordanian officials and also urged the new Israeli government _ in public and private _ to accept his plan. ``Secretary Baker wants to work with the new government of Israel to create a common and credible basis on which to move on the peace process,'' Tutwiler said.

DOC.HEAD: Home Prices Fall In Washington, D.C., Metro Area
DOC.TEXT: The median price of single family homes in the Washington, D.C., metropolitan area dropped 5 percent between April 1989 and April 1990, the first decline in the past decade. The median sale price of homes in the area dropped from $202,239 a year ago to $191,985, according to real estate transaction records compiled by Silver Spring, Md.,-based Rufus K. Lusk & Son. Rufus K. Lusk Sr., president of the company, said the decline was indicative of a readjustment in a real estate market that has become both unbalanced an overly expensive. He said home prices in the Washington area have risen so quickly in recent years they simply have outstripped people's incomes in many cases, he said. The median price _ the midpoint figure at which half the homes sold for more and half sold for less _ was considered statistically more significant than the average price, Lusk said. He said the average could easily skewered by a relatively few transactions, such as the sales of large estates. The survey found that the decline was most extreme in the District of Columbia, where median costs for single family homes dropped 9 percent, from $201,192 to $183,451. In Fairfax County, Va., home prices dropped 6 percent to a median price of $215,934; Montgomery County, Md., declined 3 percent to $216,446; and Alexandria, Va., prices fell 3 percent to a median cost of $203,960.

DOC.HEAD: Government Upgrades Engine Fire Probe
DOC.TEXT: Federal engineers are upgrading an investigation of fires in 77,000 truck and bus engines manufactured by Ford Motor Co., the government said Friday. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had reclassified the probe from a preliminary evaluation, which involves mostly paperwork, to an engineering analysis, in which the possibly defective parts will be studied. The investigation could lead to a recall. Consumers have reported 130 fires in trucks and buses with the Ford engine, including 12 on school buses, agency spokesman Tim Hurd said. No injuries have been reported. Ford spokeswoman Lynn Tuttle said, ``As has always been our policy, Ford Motor Co. will cooperate fully with these investigations.'' In its monthly auto defects report, the agency said it also had upgraded to engineering analysis status the investigations of: _Reports that safety belt retractor malfunctions in about 100,000 Chevrolet Corvettes from the 1985 through 1987 model years. There have been 58 complaints. Consumers have blamed the problem for five injuries and one death, Hurd said. _Hood latch failures in 22,554 Ford Thunderbirds and Mercury Cougars from the 1989 and 1990 model years. There have been seven complaints of hoods flying open because of latch failures. The government also said it had opened preliminary evaluations of: _Oil seal failures in Isuzu Troopers with turbo-charged diesel engines from the 1986 through 1990 model years. There have been three complaints of oil being sucked into the combustion chamber, causing the engines to surge. About 3,000 of the vehicles are on the road. _Brake lamp switch failure in General Motors ``W'' cars, which include the Oldsmobile Cutlass, the Buick Regal, the Pontiac Grand Prix and the Chevrolet Lumina. About 763,000 of the cars are on the road. There have been 12 complaints of brake lamps failing and failure of the cruise control to disengage when the brake pedal is applied. The same switch controls both functions. _Safety belt failure in Ford Mustangs from the 1984 and 1985 model years. About 274,000 of the cars are on the road. The agency discontinued an engineering analysis of seat belt retractor failure in the 1985 Subaru station wagon, finding no problem that posed an ``unreasonable risk.'' The same reason was given for halting a preliminary evaluation of spare tire carrier failure in 1982-89 GM Astros and Safaris. Preliminary evaluations discontinued because there was no evidence of a widespread safety problem included probes of: _Seat floor mounting failure in 1986-89 Mustangs. _Speed control failure in the 1990 Lumina. _Windshield wiper failure in the 1985-90 Isuzu Trooper, PU and Amigo. _Brake disc hub failure in 1986-89 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable.

DOC.HEAD: 194 Kosovo Radio-TV Employees Fired by Serbian Authorities
DOC.TEXT: Serbian authorities on Friday fired 194 ethnic Albanian employees of the radio and television company in Kosovo, the troubled province that has been a hotbed of ethnic violence. Yugoslavia's official Tanjug news agency said that the workers, mostly journalists, were dismissed for ``abandoning their jobs'' after Serbian police on July 5 took over broadcasting facilities in Pristina, Kosovo's capital. The police takeover followed Serbia's decision to dissolve the the troubled province's assembly and government. Both dismantled bodies were dominated by ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million people. Kosovo administratively is part of Serbia, but had been largely autonomous. Serbian authorities, explaining the crackdown, claim that ethnic Albanians are seeking independence from Yugoslavia, and that they want Kosovo to join neighboring Albania. Kosovo Albanians deny those claims. They say Serbia's hard-line Communist leader Slobodan Milosevic has used the issue, a highly emotional one for Serbs who consider Kosovo the ancient heartland of their culture, to gain popular support for his hard-line policies. At least 60 ethnic Albanian protesters have died in clashes with Serbian-led security forces in Kosovo since March 1989 when Serbia's authorities first introduced strict limits on the province's self-administration.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis' Bolts Tightened To Fix Leak; New Mishap on Discovery
DOC.TEXT: NASA workers tightened most of the 48 bolts on one of space shuttle Atlantis' fuel lines Friday, but the space agency won't know whether that fixed a hydrogen leak until a tanking test next week. The shuttle's classified Defense Department mission is on hold until the problem is resolved. All the bolts checked out fine, said NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone. ``Everything looked normal,'' she said. Discovery, meanwhile, has joined the other two shuttles with problems. One of 14 thrusters on Discovery's right orbital maneuvering system pad was dented when it fell off a work stand Thursday. A new $600,000 thruster, which weighs 20 pounds and is about the size of a football, will be installed. The accident occurred during routine maintenance work, Malone said. ``They're looking into how the whole thing happened,'' she said. The replacement of the thruster will not jeopardize Discovery's scheduled launch with the sun-probing Ulysses satellite in October, Malone said. The damaged thruster was being returned to the manufacturer for repairs. NASA officials believe that on Atlantis, hydrogen is escaping from a flange on the external tank side of a 17-inch-diameter valve. The valve is in a pipe that carries fuel from the tank to the main engines. Before tightening the bolts around the flange, workers made mold impressions to check the distance between each one and to measure the flatness of the bolts' heads. Everything appeared within specifications, Malone said. Technicians over-torqued 38 of the 48 bolts by 10 percent, Malone said. The remaining 10 already were over-torqued and so were not tightened, she said. The flange welds were to be checked late Friday and Saturday. A pressurized helium test on the massive tank Thursday showed no evidence of any leaks, said Malone. The leaks were detected in late June and again last week when supercold liquid hydrogen was pumped into the tank. Earlier tests with room-temperature helium had failed to uncover any problems. NASA plans to launch Atlantis in mid-August if the shuttle passes a third tanking test with liquid hydrogen on Wednesday. Officials are doubtful, however, that the problem will be resolved by simply tightening bolts at the launch pad. If hydrogen continues to escape from Atlantis, the shuttle will be returned to the hangar for repairs. If a new tank is attached to Atlantis, the shuttle could be rolled back out for a mid-September launch, said launch director Bob Sieck. The other alternative is to move Columbia back out to the pad for an early September liftoff with the Astro observatory. On shuttle Columbia, a hydrogen leak was detected during fueling for a May 30 launch attempt. The shuttle was returned to the hangar and received a 17-inch-diameter valve taken from the new shuttle Endeavour, under construction in California. Representatives of the company that makes the valves, Parker Hannifin, were inspecting the newly installed device Friday. The leaky component is undergoing laboratory tests in California by shuttle builder Rockwell International. Columbia's leak is believed to be in a small shaft seal on the orbiter side of the valve.

The following are excerpts from the House ethics committee's report on its investigation into Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., and his relationship with male prostitute Stephen Gobie.
Both (Gobie and Frank) agreed that there was a dimension to their relationship that transcended employment. Mr. Gobie spoke of his personal admiration for Representative Frank, and Representative Frank said that Mr. Gobie was good for his ego, and that the relationship was not entirely arms length.

Frank was not totally candid and forthcoming (in a 1986 memo to an Alexandria, Va., prosecutor) in describing either the nature of, or the events giving rise to, his relationship with Stephen L. Gobie; as well as Mr. Gobie's activities during probation. It is of critical importance that such issues were directly relevant to any consideration of whether Mr. Gobie's probation should have been extended. ... The misleading statements could be perceived as an attempt to use political influence to affect the administration of Mr. Gobie's probation. That the memorandum had apparently had no such effect does not detract from the inappropriateness of communicating misleading statements which could have affected the administration of Mr. Gobie's probation.

Frank either sought or received the administrative dismissal of 33 parking tickets for which Representative Frank himself instructs that there was no adequate basis indicating his automobile was being used for official purposes. The committee further concludes that Representative Frank should take steps to negate fully any such financial benefit.

(On Gobie's testimony that he and Frank had sex in the House gym, Frank testified:) ``The whole notion, the way they were describing it, out in the locker room, which is where the doors open from the swimming pool, that is the craziest notion. I will agree that I behaved in ways that were inappropriate and stupid, for which I feel very badly... But I never had sex in the gym with Mr. Gobie or anyone else.''
In numerous instances where an assertion made by Mr. Gobie ... was investigated for accuracy, the assertion was contradicted by third-party sworn testimony or other evidence of Mr. Gobie himself.

(The committee discounted as inconclusive testimony from a female prostitute who) stated that because she believed the individual with whom she spoke on the telephone was Representative Frank _ because she ``recognized the voice... maybe slightly a lisp and a northern accent,'' _ and based upon the conversation described above, she personally concluded that the congressman knew that his apartment was being used by Mr. Gobie for business purposes.

The committee has taken into consideration the fact that during his Dec. 11, 1989, interview, the congressman clearly and unambiguously expressed regret for his actions and accepted full responsibility for any parking tickets that were dismissed regardless of whether he initiated such administrative action.

DOC.HEAD: GAO Report Doubts PUREX Should Ever Be Restarted
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department has failed to prove that its plutonium processing plant near Richland, Wash. can be operated safely or that it should even be restarted, congressional investigators said Friday. The department has failed to show that the plant on the Hanford nuclear reservation is needed to produce plutonium or to help manage radioactive wastes, said the report by the General Accounting Office. The plant is called the PUREX plant, short for plutonium extraction. It uses chemical methods to separate plutonium for nuclear weapons produced by the irradiation of uranium nuclear reactor fuel rods. It has been shut to improve safety since December 1988. ``DOE has not demonstrated that a need exists for the remaining weapons-grade plutonium that could be extracted, and it has not fully compared PUREX with other waste processing alternatives to determine whether PUREX is the best approach,'' the GAO said. ``DOE's plans for restarting PUREX are inadequate,'' said the report requested nearly a year ago by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on environment, energy and natural resources. ``A more important question is whether PUREX should be restarted at all given the costs to operate PUREX, in combination with the costs to prepare a supplemental environmental statement, the time and costs associated with correcting identified safety and training deficiencies,'' the fact that most plutonium for new weapons will come from old weapons being retired and scrap on hand at weapons plants and ``the possibility that a better alternative exists to dispose of the fuel-grade plutonium'' in the unprocessed fuel rods at Hanford. ``If a decision is made to continue with plans to restart PUREX, we believe that a supplemental environmental impact statement should be prepared prior to restart of the plant,'' the GAO said. A spokesman for the Energy Department said Watkins had not seen the GAO report and would have no immediate comment. However, spokesman Tim Tomastik said the report ``makes the assumption that DOE has made a decision about restarting PUREX. The DOE has not made a decision at this time with respect to whether or not to restart PUREX.'' Synar said Friday his subcommittee estimates that putting the plant in mothballs would save the government more than $750 million over the next 15 years.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Durenberger Should Be Denounced Despite Impaired Judgment
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger should be denounced for abusing his office and misusing public funds even though ``emotional and traumatic events'' impaired his judgment, a report released Friday recommended. The Senate Ethics Committee's report explained the panel's recommendation, announced Wednesday, that the Minnesota Republican be denounced on the Senate floor by a vote of his colleagues. The committee found that Durenberger knowingly violated Senate rules and federal statutes in a book deal, in transactions involving the Minneapolis condominium he partly owned, by failing to report expense reimbursements and by accepting free limousine rides in violation of gift limits. The six-member panel also recommended that Durenberger make restitution of up to $122,780 _ $29,050 to the Senate for improper reimbursements for his condominium; and $93,730 to charity, less state and federal taxes already paid _ for exceeding limits on speaking fees. The charity figure is about $1,000 less than the amount announced Wednesday. Durenberger has admitted violating Senate rules, but said he never intend to do so. He contended also that he always followed the advice of his personal lawyers. The 12-year veteran senator also said his judgment was influenced by tragedies in his life: the death of his first wife, and the killing in Vietnam of his current wife's first husband. ``The committee finds that Sen. Durenberger did encounter severe emotional strain from events in his personal life,'' the report said. It found that the ``severe emotional and traumatic events ... impaired his judgment. The committee finds that these factors do not excuse the senator's conduct.'' The report said Durenberger generated $248,300 in speaking fees that he classified as promotions for his two books _ but the appearances actually were normal honoraria speeches subject to income limits. Durenberger, during a great many of these speeches ``did not mention'' the books he supposedly was promoting. When he did mention them, ``his only reference was extremely brief or was belittling of the book's contents,'' the committee found. While Durenberger contended the Federal Election Commission approved his book promotion speeches, the committee concluded the senator misled the agency. Durenberger did not tell the FEC he would be making book promotion speeches that were strikingly similar to honoraria appearances subject to earnings limits; and he did not say that his promotion appearances would result from invitations to deliver traditional honoraria speeches. The committee found that Durenberger placed his Minneapolis condominium in a partnership ``as a means of permitting'' him to claim Senate reimbursements. Durenberger took his name out of the partnership and ``as a result, the senator's ownership interest ... was concealed from the Senate ...,'' according to the report. When his lawyer cautioned Durenberger that he could not find a legal basis for the reimbursements under the partnership, the senator ``failed to take any action'' and only asked the Senate for advice after news articles surfaced on the condominium in 1989. Durenberger also arranged a ``purported'' sale of the residence in 1987 to a business operated by a personal friend and former campaign manager. The friend admitted that he would not have bought the unit but for Durenberger's agreement to rent it. This was an arrangement ``which both parties understood would be financed at least in part through Senate reimbursements,'' the report said. Durenberger's attorney, Jim Hamilton, filed a brief with the committee that called the recommended punishment too strong, and said a ``strong reprimand'' would be more fair. Hamilton called the book deal a ``good-faith venture'' and the condominium transactions legitimate real estate deals. ``They were not shams,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Charges Western Plot as More Cubans Enter Spanish Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Five more Cubans took refuge inside the Spanish Embassy in Havana on Friday, officials said, and Cuban news media portrayed the continuing of asylum-seeking in foreign missions there as a Western plot. Nine Cuban refugees now are at Madrid's embassy and four others are in the residence of the Italian ambassador. Five who spent a week in a Czechoslovak diplomat's apartment gave up their bid for asylum earlier after receiving assurances they would not be prosecuted, according to reports from Havana. Diplomats accused Cuban police of violating diplomatic territory to make arrests, and a bitter dispute developed between Spain and its former colony after Cuban police seized one refugee on Spanish Embassy grounds. In Washington, Michael Kozak, a deputy assistant secretary of state, called in a Cuban diplomat on Friday to protest Cuba's claims that the United States encouraged Cubans to seek asylum in embassies. The State Department has called such allegations ``outrageous.'' The official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina said the run on the embassies is being portrayed in Communist-ruled Cuba as part of a Western plot to undermine the Communist-ruled Caribbean island nation and tarnish its international image. The official Mexican news agency, Notimex, said the chief of the U.S. Interests Section in Havana called an emergency meeting Friday of all Western diplomats. Notimex said U.S. and West German officials in Havana denied Cuban allegations their countries were involved in a plot. The U.S. statement said Cuban agents tried several times to compromise U.S. officials in past months. Reports from Madrid and Havana, monitored in Mexico City, said the latest refugees entered the Spanish Embassy Friday morning. Two youths jumped an iron fence behind the mission, and shortly afterward, a couple with a child got through the main entrance, but another person was arrested by Cuban police, the Foreign Ministry in Madrid said. Spain recalled its ambassador from Havana for consultations, suspended $2.5 million in grants, and persuaded the European Community to put three ``symbolic'' aid projects for Cuba on hold after Cuba castigated Spanish Foreign Minister Francisco Fernandez Ordonez. Fernandez Ordonez suggested the hard-line Communist government of Fidel Castro would crumble if he allowed Cubans freedom to leave. Prensa Latina said state TV boradcast interviews Thursday night with two Cuban dissidents and three of those who had sought refuge in the Czechoslovak diplomat's residence. It said they accused foreign diplomats of plotting the wave of asylum-seeking.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Rock the Northeast, Produce Floods in Iowa
DOC.TEXT: A fierce storm overturned boats and tossed docks through the air at a crowded New Hampshire resort lake Friday as thunderstorms boomed over the East and the Gulf Coast. The storm that hit Lake Winnipesaukee also blew down huge trees and knocked out power there and in Moultonboro, Tuftonboro and Center Harbor, N.H., but no injuries were reported. The storm was part of a system developing along and south of a stationary front stretching from Indiana to Maine. Thunderstorms over western New York state produced high winds which downed power lines around Port Byron and felled a tree near the town of Throop. Showers and thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in the Ohio Valley, and deluged parts of Iowa with 2 to 5 inches of rain. Mount Ayer, Iowa, reported 5{ inches of rain. Flooding was reported along the Chariton River and the Thompson River in Iowa. The Thompson River was expected to crest at 14 feet, heavily flooding farmland. Showers and thunderstorms also fell over the central Gulf Coast and the southern Atlantic Coast, and a few scattered showers dampened the north-central Plains. Sunny, dry weather prevailed west of the Rockies. In the southern deserts of California, gusty, southeast winds churned up dust and sand, cutting visibility to one to three miles. The nation's hot spot was Death Valley, where the temperature hit a scorching 120 degrees. The low temperature Friday morning for the Lower 48 states was 46 degrees at Hibbing, Minn., and Jordan, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement to Clean Up Times Beach Announced
DOC.TEXT: Federal and state environmental officials Friday announced an agreement intended to pave the way for cleanup of the dioxin-contaminated ghost town of Times Beach after seven years of study and negotiations. Morris Kay, regional director of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, announced at a news conference that a cleanup agreement had been reached with Syntex Agribusiness Inc., a chemical and animal health company. The settlement is subject to a 30-day public comment period and then approval by U.S. District Judge John F. Nangle. But both Kay and Syntex spokesman Ray Forrester said preliminary work could begin within days of the judge's decision. Under the settlement, Syntex will build and later demolish an incinerator to burn the tons of dioxin-tainted soil from Times Beach and 27 other sites in eastern Missouri contaminated in the 1970s when waste oil containing dioxin was sprayed on roads to keep dust down. Syntex, based in Palo Alto, Calif., did not produce the dioxin. But the government considers Syntex a responsible party because the dioxin was produced by a tenant in a Verona plant owned by a company Syntex later acquired. ``I think this agreement is a good compromise,'' Forrester said. ``It allows the problem to be solved and allows the money to be spent on the solution, rather than litigation.'' The company declined to say how much it expects to spend on the cleanup, but Kay said Syntex would do at least half of work the EPA has estimated would cost $200 million. Under the agreeement, Syntex must pay the government $10 million over five years to cover part of the cost of prosecuting the case. In return, all federal and state lawsuits against the company will be dismissed. ``We believe that this is a safe, effective, permanent solution to this dioxin contamination and we certainly look forward to the day when we can say this cleanup is finished,'' said Missouri Department of Natural Resources spokeswoman Anita Randolph.
