Times Beach, about 20 miles southwest of St. Louis, has been deserted since 1983, when the federal government bought up all 801 homes and businesses and moved the people out. Guards patrol its fenced perimeter to keep vandals out of dilapidated buildings now taken over by weeds and wild animals. Announcement of the settlement brought angry words from opponents of the incinerator plan, who criticized the secrecy of the negotiations and who believe the incinerator will be unsafe and will become a permanent fixture. ``We will have created the central hazardous waste site of the United States if this goes through,'' said state Rep. Jim Murphy, who with several other opponents showed up at the news conference. A recently passed state law limits an incinerator permit to five years. The EPA's Kay, who said the agreement called for the cleanup to be completed in five to seven years, said all concerns had been met. ``We are very pleased with the agreement and we believe the agreement addresses the local peoples' concerns,'' Kay said. ``We're not going to allow anything that's unsafe.'' He said the EPA would continue to pursue other potentially responsible parties. Dioxin, an unwanted byproduct in the manufacture of chemicals like disinfectant, is suspected of causing disorders of the nervous system, liver, kidneys and bladder. It has been found to cause cancer in laboratory animals. The EPA says the incinerator would roast the contaminated soil so the dioxin molecules break up into carbon, oxygen, chlorine and hydrogen. The treated soil would no longer be hazardous and would be buried in a landfill on site. The area would then be safe again for habitation, although federal flood plain regulations enacted since Times Beach was founded would prohibit building houses there, Randolph said. As part of the cleanup agreement, Syntex will demolish all buildings on the site and restore it for public use, possibly as a park or walking trails.

DOC.HEAD: UNLV Becomes 2nd Basketball Champ in 3 Years Banned From Postseason Play
DOC.TEXT: The University of Nevada, Las Vegas, was barred Friday from defending its men's basketball title for recruiting violations originally detailed in 1977. The school immediately announced it would appeal the one-year ban on postseason play, which the the National Collegiate Athletic Association imposed as the final resolution of a bitter battle with head coach Jerry Tarkanian that stretches back 13 years. ``I think it's a miscarriage of justice,'' UNLV President Robert Maxson said. ``We're being penalized twice for the same offense and that violates one of the basic principles of justice.'' The sanction will have no effect on television appearances or the number of athletic scholarships UNLV is allowed to give. The postseason ban would also include the NIT tournament. After UNLV and Tarkanian were found guilty of recruiting violations in 1977, the school served a two-year probation and Tarkanian was suspended for two years by the school, as ordered by the NCAA. But he sued to block the suspension. The case reached the U.S. Supreme Court in 1988. In a 5-4 ruling, the high court reaffirmed the NCAA's right to discipline member schools, but ruled that only the school can discipline a coach. However, a Nevada state court injunction still effectively bars the school from taking any action against Tarkanian. Kansas was the first champion barred from defending its title by the NCAA. It received sanctions after winning the 1988 national championship. Tarkanian, reached at his San Diego vacation home, declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Probe Expands, Senate Records Subpoenaed; Source Says Lawmakers Taped
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury demanded campaign spending records from all 46 state senators Friday, expanding the scope of an investigation into allegations that lawmakers traded votes for cash. FBI agents delivered the grand jury subpoenas to the Senate Ethics Committee two days after asking for similar campaign records from all 124 House members. Those records were turned over Thursday. The probe involves an FBI sting operation in which a lobbyist working undercover offered legislators cash in exchange for votes on pari-mutuel betting legislation in the General Assembly. Agents videotaped some lawmakers accepting money, a source who requested anonymity told The Associated Press. ``It will cut deep _ both parties are involved. ... It crosses everything,'' an unidentified source told The Charlotte (N.C.) Observer for an article published Friday. The newspaper reported that sources called the probe one of the Justice Department's top white-collar investigations this year. The investigation apparently involves possible violations of the Hobbs Act, a federal anti-corruption law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or other favors. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel and Fred Verinder, the FBI's top agent in South Carolina, confirmed only that an investigation was under way into allegations of ``illegal conduct involving certain members of the South Carolina Legislature.'' ``There will be no further comment until charges are filed,'' they said in a statement. Ron L. Cobb, a former House member-turned-lobbyist, is at the center of the probe, according to lawmakers. They said Cobb offered at least three legislators money in exchange for their help on a bill that would have allowed pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. The General Assembly failed to act on the measure before adjourning in June. Cobb, who served in the House from 1977 to 1984, did not return telephone messages left at his office Thursday or Friday. His home telephone number is unlisted. Among Cobb's clients is Alpha Group, an Atlanta-based concern interested in promoting pari-mutuel betting in South Carolina. Campaign contributions to legislators from Cobb, Alpha Group and Cobb's company, Government Business Associates, totaled at least $12,950 since 1987. Contributions ranged from $100 to $3,000. Cobb failed to meet this week's deadline to file an expense report of his activities on Alpha's behalf, as required by law. The secretary of state's office, which monitors lobbying activities in South Carolina, is looking into the matter, Deputy Secretary of State John Stokes said. Just who is behind Alpha Group remains a mystery. The telephone at Alpha Group's office went unanswered Thursday and Friday; no street address is listed with directory information. The computer at the Georgia secretary of state's office, where all incorporated companies must register, was not working Friday, an official said. Rep. Paul Derrick, who accepted $1,000 from Cobb in a Columbia motel room earlier this year, said he now believes the cash payment was part of an FBI sting. The Republican said Cobb did not ask him at the time for his vote on pari-mutuel betting, but the lobbyist had earlier sought his support for that bill. Rep. Ennis Fant, a Democrat, said he also discussed pari-mutuel betting with Cobb, who told the lawmaker, ``Let me give you a little gas for your tank,'' and produced $1,000 from his briefcase. Fant said he accepted two cash contributions totaling $1,300 from Cobb in March or April and reported them on his ethics disclosure forms. Cobb is under investigation by Richland County prosecutors who contend the lobbyist received several checks from an account at the South Carolina Petroleum Marketers Association that may have been used to pay off legislators, Solicitor James Anders said.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Recommends Reprimand for Frank
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 10-13: ``In his,'' more comment from Frank
DOC.TEXT: The House ethics committee's recommendation Friday that Rep. Barney Frank be reprimanded for some of his help for a male prostitute prompted some Republicans to call for stiffer punishment, even expulsion. ``Barney Frank will certainly not consider it a slap on the wrist,'' said ethics committee Chairman Julian Dixon, D-Calif., at a news conference outlining the committee's findings. ``The committee certainly does not consider it a slap on the wrist.'' But Republicans said they would seek a vote to expel the Massachusetts Democrat or censure him for his official actions on behalf of male prostitute Stephen L. Gobie. Frank, a five-term liberal, said in a Newton, Mass., news conference: ``I accept the judgement of the committee report.'' The ethics committee unanimously reported that aspects of Rep. Barney Frank's relationship with a male prostitute ``reflected discredit upon the House'' and recommended that he be reprimanded before the full House next week. But the panel also sharply criticized the credibility of Gobie, Frank's chief accuser, saying that much of his testimony had been contradicted when investigators checked it out. Gobie's lack of credibility weighed heavily in the committee's conclusions, the report stated. The panel also gave Frank credit for expressing regret for his actions. Its report quotes the congressman as testifying: ``I will tell you again, with chagrin, that I did not handle the pressures of having a public life, of being a closeted gay man, nearly as well as I should have. I do think I managed to confine most of the damage to myself. But when you are in a public position, inevitably something spills over.'' Frank is one of two acknowledged homosexuals in the House. In his news conference, he said, ``I think I am justified in saying that this report bears out that ... I told the truth.'' ``I don't think anyone who has judged the way this process has gone, I don't think they'd say they're being soft on me.'' He noted that work of the committee led to the resignation of former speaker Jim Wright of Texas: ``This has been a tough group.'' Gobie, meanwhile, told Boston radio station WEEI he was pleased the committee was not harder on Frank. Frank paid Gobie $80 for sex and then hired him in July 1985 as a housekeeper and driver, paying Gobie with personal funds. Frank says he ended the relationship in August 1987 after learning that Gobie was operating a sex-for-hire ring out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment. The panel, which has been investigating the case since Sept. 11, unanimously concluded that Frank improperly fixed parking tickets _ some of them accumulated by Gobie using Frank's car on personal business. And the panel said Frank ``set in motion'' a memo containing misleading information about Gobie sent to a Virginia prosecutor and ``which could have affected Mr. Gobie's probation.'' Members of Congress do not have to pay parking tickets gathered on official business in Washington. The committee rejected Gobie's accusation that Frank knew of a prostitution ring that Gobie ran out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment. And the 12-member panel said it found no evidence indicating that Frank and Gobie had sex in the House gymnasium, as Gobie had alleged. The recommended reprimand is one of the milder sanctions available to the House. Censure, the next most severe punishment, would require that Frank stand in front of his colleagues while a resolution condemning his activities is read. ``Every member is going to have to vote his or her conscience,'' said Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., who said he would propose that the House expel Frank. ``The conduct of Mr. Frank failed to meet the standard all of us must, that we reflect creditably on the House of Representatives ... We live in a fishbowl in this business.'' Republican Rep. Henry Hyde of Illinois said he expected there would also be a motion to censure Frank. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., predicted that the lasting damage to Frank from the 10-month probe would be minimal. ``I think this matter will be soon put behind us,'' Foley said, adding that the House would begin debate on the committee's recommendation next week. ``Barney Frank remains one of the most effective and, I think throughout the House, highly regarded members here,'' Foley said. ``His abilities, his intelligence, his capacities are well respected and he's going to continue to be an extremely important and significant member.'' A summary of the committee's findings, outlined in five conclusions: _Despite Gobie's testimony, ``The weight of the evidence does not indicate that Representative Frank had either prior or concomitant knowledge of prostitution activities alleged to have taken place in his apartment involving third parties.'' _Neither a sex therapist nor a probation officer overseeing Gobie, who is a convicted felon on drug and sodomy charges, was pressured by Frank to be lenient toward Gobie, again despite Gobie's testimony. _Although Frank did not send the memo to the prosecutor in Alexandria, Va., he did ``set into motion a series of contacts resulting in that document being sent.'' The panel said the April 16, 1986 memo contained misleading statements favorable to Gobie. _``The committee concludes that Representative Frank acted improperly in connection with 33 parking tickets.'' The committee directed Frank to repay the tickets because ``there was no adequate basis indicating his automobile was being used for official purposes.'' _In another rejection of Gobie's testimony, the committee said there was no evidence indicating that the two had sex in the House gymnasium. The misleading statements in the 1986 memo focused on statements about how Frank met Gobie and false assertions that Gobie was obeying the law. What prompted Frank to prepare the memo is unclear in the committee's report. But the result, the committee said, was a document sent to a prosecutor which ``could be perceived as an attempt to use political influence to affect the outcome of the administration of Mr. Gobie's probation.'' Specifically, Frank said in the memo that he met Gobie ``through mutual friends,'' concealing the fact that he met Gobie through an advertisement for ``escort services'' in a gay publication. Frank also indicated in the memo that he believe Gobie was obeying the law while on probation. ``The congressman acknowledged to the committee that he was aware that during the period in question Mr. Gobie was engaging in prostitution,'' the committee said in its full report. ``It is therefore clear that Representative Frank was not totally candid and forthcoming in describing either the nature of, or the events giving rise to his relationship with Stephen L. Gobie; as well as Mr. Gobie's activities during probation.'' Frank told his news conference he was less than candid in the memo because he did not want to reveal his homosexuality. Frank is running for a sixth term from a suburban Boston district. He faces a lone Republican opponent who has never held elective office.

DOC.HEAD: ANC, Government to Hold Second Meeting Next Month
DOC.TEXT: President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela of the African National Congress met for an hour Friday and agreed the government and the black nationalist movement would hold a second round of talks next month. Friday's meeting was their first since just before Mandela left on a six-week, three-continent tour urging the world to maintain sanctions on South Africa until irreversible changes in apartheid have been achieved. The Aug. 6 meeting, announced by de Klerk's office, is to discuss obstacles in the way of formal negotiations on a new constitution and the end of white minority rule. The ANC and members of de Klerk's Cabinet reached preliminary agreements in their May 2-4 meetings on such issues as violence, political prisoners and returning exiles. A joint committee since then has made recommendations on how to overcome disagreements, such as defining political crimes and who would qualify for amnesty from prosecution. The two sides will consider the recommendations at the Aug. 6 meeting. De Klerk partially met one ANC demand by lifting the 4-year-old national state of emergency in three of the country's four provinces. He also signed executive orders allowing all members of the ANC executive committee and many other officials to return to South Africa without being arrested. The ANC says South African exiles number about 20,000, including about 5,000 guerrilla fighters who would be subject to prosecution under current law. The release of prisoners convicted of politically motivated crimes or of acts connected to their affiliation with the ANC has stalled recently after scores were freed earlier. De Klerk and his ministers have said they want speedy progress toward negotiations with the ANC and other groups representing the black majority. Mangosuthu Buthelezi's Zulu-based Inkatha party and some other groups say they are ready to negotiate now. The Pan Africanist Congress and some other groups insist on elimination of apartheid and other demands before they will agree to talks.

DOC.HEAD: A Role of `Personal Terror' for `Arachnophobia' Actor
With AM-Summer Movies Bjt
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The way Jeff Daniels tells it, his first reaction to the proposal of a film called ``Arachnophobia'' was negative. ``My agent called and said, `Well, it's about spiders,' '' the actor recalls. ``I said, `Oh great! `The Attack of the Killer Spiders.' Great! Terrific! I'll pass.'' When the agent explained that coproducers Frank Marshall, Kathleen Kennedy and Steven Spielberg were involved in the project, Daniels agreed to read the script. And liked it. His verdict: ``If anybody can do this in a first-class way, those guys can.'' After years of directing second unit on Spielberg films, Frank Marshall made his debut as director with ``Arachnophobia.'' Besides the human actors _ Daniels, John Goodman, Julian Sands, Harley Jane Kozak _ Marshall directed hundreds of spiders that invade a small California town. ``I don't mind the little guys,'' Daniels admitted. ``I'm pretty much a manly man when it comes to that sort of thing. But the big boys, nine inches across with the legs spread out, the kind that spit at you.'' ``They had a `spider orientation' on the second day of shooting. We were all supposed to go and basically learn how to become friends with the spiders and have them crawl on you as pets. I blew that off. If we're supposed to be afraid of spiders, let's be afraid of spiders.'' ``If there's any opportunity at all to eliminate acting I'm all for it. In the second half of this movie, there's not a lot of acting going on. It's personal terror.'' Danile said 90 per cent of the spiders in ``Arachnophobia'' are the real thing, the rest are mechanical. The actor was fascinated by the special affects _ ``that's one of the reasons I did this picture: I wanted to see how they did it. And I had the best seat in the house.'' With his gangly frame and bland, blond looks, Jeff Daniels often goes unrecognized for his solid contributions to films. He was fine as Debra Winger's errant husband in ``Terms of Endearment,'' but he was neglected in the shower of Academy nominations for the film (``I think even the guy who combed my hair was nominated''). He rationalized: ``When I saw `Rain Man,' I said, `Hoffman is great, but Cruise is the guy who makes the movie work.' The guys who win the awards are the guys who get the flashy roles. It's always been that way.'' ``It's the same thing with `Arachnophobia.' Somebody's gotta keep it all together. I'm the hub that goes through the movie. People see the movie through me.'' ``Hey, the whole point is to make a scene look as though it's not acting. The phone keeps ringing. People keep hiring me. I must be doing something right. It's okay. I'm glad to play the straight man for a spider.''

DOC.HEAD: Black Man Hit By Truck After Being Chased By White Man
DOC.TEXT: A black man walking with his white girlfriend was chased by a white man into the path of a truck that hit him, leaving him critically injured in what police said was a racially motivated attack. Daniel Porter, 21, of Baltimore was charged with assault and reckless endangerment for chasing Herbert Jennings, 38, also of Baltimore, on Thursday night. Porter was being held Friday pending a bail hearing. Jennings and his 32-year-old white girlfriend, whom police would not identify, were taunted shortly before 10 p.m. Thursday by two white men in a pickup truck as they walked on a street in the Highlandtown neighborhood of southeast Baltimore, not far from where the girlfriend lives, police said. Moments later, Porter and two other white men approached the couple and Porter yelled to the men in the truck, asking if they wanted him to attack Jennings, whom he called by a racial epithet, police said. A man in the truck yelled, ``Yes,'' and Jennings ran, with Porter in pursuit, said police spokesman Dennis Hill. After running a short distance, Jennings slipped and fell and was accidentally struck by another pickup truck, Hill said. The driver of that truck was not charged. The girlfriend was not injured. The first truck, whose occupants started the incident, sped away, Hill said. Hill said police don't believe that Porter, who lives about six blocks from where the incident occurred, knew either Jennings or the girlfriend. Jennings lives in a nearby neighborhood. Jennings was listed in critical condition Friday at the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center with a severe head injury and cuts and bruises. His girlfriend and several other people were questioned, and others may be charged, police said. Police community relations staff went to the neighborhood Friday to calm residents' emotions. Highlandtown, a predominantly white working-class neighborhood surrounded by predominantly black working-class neighborhoods, is a quiet area with no history of racial problems, Hill said. ``I was over there this afternoon,'' he said. ``People were expressing their regret that something like that would happen over there.'' Baltimore Mayor Kurt Schmoke, who is black, said race relations generally have improved in the city since the riots of the 1960s. In a separate incident early Wednesday, in a neighborhood several miles away, a black man was stabbed to death when he and a friend were attacked by a group of white men. Police had no clear evidence that that incident was racially motivated, Hill said, but he added, ``We are treating it as if it were.'' Thursday night's incident provoked comparisons with one in New York City, in which three white men were convicted in 1987 of manslaughter, assault and conspiracy for attacking three black men in the predominantly white Howard Beach section of Queens in 1986. One of the blacks was struck by a car and killed as he fled across a nearby highway. Another man was beaten with tree limbs and a baseball bat.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Leaders Urge Quebec Police to Withdraw
DOC.TEXT: Canadian Indian chiefs on Friday called for police to withdraw from barricades where they are locked in an armed standoff with Mohawks who claim land there as ancestral territory. The Indians from across Canada made the call at the end of a three-day conference at the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal. They called the conference to seek solutions for the crisis that has left one police officer dead, prompted Indians from around the nation to rally, and touched off an anti-Indian backlash. At the end of their meeting, the Indian leaders issued a resolution calling for provincial police to pull away from the barricades at Oka, a town 18 miles west of Montreal. The Indians are trying to block a plan by municipal officials to build a golf course addition on the disputed land. At Friday's conference, the Indian leaders also asked Prime Minister Brian Mulroney to reconvene Parliament immediately to deal with the ``national crisis.'' Mohawk Chief Joe Norton said both police and Indians should withdraw from barricades in Oka and from a bridge between Montreal and its southern suburbs, where a sympathy blockade has been set up by other Indians. The bridge blockage has set off angry protests by local residents, who have burned Indians in effigy and made anti-Indian slurs. Norton also said the Mohawks at the blockades must be assured of amnesty for a settlement to be reached. However, Quebec provincial Premier Robert Bourassa has already said officials will not agree to amnesty for Indians involved in a shootout at Oka on July 11. A provincial police officer was killed, but it is not clear if he was killed by gunfire from Indians or fellow officers. Tom Siddon, the federal Indian Affairs minister, added Friday, ``A federal minister cannot set aside the rule of law and deal with an element which is using weapons and raising blockades on public thoroughfares to achieve their ends.'' Indians have been manning their barricade at Oka for four months. On Thursday, federal officials said they would try to acquire the disputed land to block the golf course, but only if Indians agree to lay down their arms. One Mohawk negotiator in Oka, Mavis Etienne, said Friday that giving up their guns is ``out of the question.'' ``You wouldn't ask your army or police officers to lay down their arms. This has been done before, and they have put our young people into jail _ for defending their own land,'' the negotiator said. However, only a handful of Indians manned the barricade in Oka during the day. One was seen carrying a gun.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Archbishop Offers Resignation in Sex Abuse Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The Roman Catholic leader of Newfoundland offered his resignation after a commission he formed blamed him and the province's church for mishandling accusations that priests were sexually abusing boys. Alphonsus Penney, archbishop of Newfoundland, made a public apology Wednesday to the victims and their families after the report was made public earlier in the day. He tendered his resignation to Pope John Paul II. However, a Vatican spokesman said the pope was on vacation and no decision had been made on the resignation. Penney can resign only if the pope allows him to do so. Five priests or former priests have been convicted in the eastern province on sexual abuse charges the past three years. Several others are awaiting trial in the scandal, which first became public in 1987. ``We are very sorry for the times you were not believed, were not supported or were ostracized in any way in our community,'' the archbishop said, accepting full responsibility for failing to deal with the scandal. ``For every word and action which may have deepened your pain, we are profoundly sorry.'' For 2{ years, Penney refused calls to step down while more than 20 of his priests and lay members of the Newfoundland Catholic community were charged or convicted of sexually abusing boys for more than a decade. The five-member commission, created by Penney a year ago, said the church adopted a policy of ``minimal response'' to the scandal, even though it was receiving complaints about sexual misconduct by some priests from parishioners, police, social workers and other priests. It said church officials showed little compassion for the victims and rallied behind the accused. The report stunned the 120,000 Catholics of Newfoundland, an island province off the east coast of Canada. It said the boys were the victims of men who ``abused their position of priestly status and power by acting out their regressed sexuality with children.'' Penney, 65, had denied he was aware of the charges against priests before November 1987. But the report said there was evidence he had been informed of the accusations in 1979 and 1984. Among the recommendations made by the commission were that the church formally acknowledge its share of guilt and apologize to the victims; that it revise policies on reacting to sexual abuse complaints; that the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops be asked to examine the problems created by forcing priests to be celibate. The commission also proposed that a fund be established to compensate victims, but it gave no dollar amount. The 700-page document will be sent out to parishes for study. A public meeting is scheduled for Oct. 11.

DOC.HEAD: RTC Reaches Bond Accord with Keating Company Creditors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version is running on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: The Resolution Trust Corp. announced Friday that it has reached an agreement with some creditors of American Continental Corp. to recover some of the funds invested in bonds sold by American Continental, a holding company controlled by Charles H. Keating Jr. Keating is the target of a federal grand jury probe in Los Angeles and a defendant in a $1.3 billion civil fraud suit filed in Arizona by federal regulators. American Continental was the parent of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irvine, Calif., which failed last year at a cost to taxpayers of around $1.5 billion. Under the new agreement, which is subject to court approval, the unsecured creditors of American Continental would receive $21 million from the Resolution Trust Corp. to settle the claims they filed in American Continental's bankruptcy case. The corporation is the government agency set up last year to dispose of insolvent thrifts. The claims against American Continental by the bondholders and other unsecured creditors total some $350 million. The company's debts to them were not secured by any specific assets. The agreement also relieves Lincoln of any liability asserted by the bondholders outside of the bankruptcy reorganization case. However, the bail-out corporation noted in a statement, no settlement has yet been made with Keating and he will not be allowed to share in the new agreement. The agreement does not affect the lawsuit against Keating, who was the chief executive officer of Phoenix-based American Continental. ``The settlement preserves the rights of the RTC and creditors to pursue additional actions against Mr. Keating, other insiders, accountants, lawyers and other persons who have contributed to the insolvency of Lincoln Savings,'' the statement said. Keating's case has attracted great attention because of his involvement with five senators who met with regulators on his behalf after accepting political contributions. The so-called ``Keating Five'' are Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich., John Glenn, D-Ohio, and John McCain, R-Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Stealth Fighter Arrives in Ohio, Escapes Storm
DOC.TEXT: A $42.6 million stealth fighter made three quick passes and landed at its first air show Friday shortly before a thunderstorm packing 70-mph winds swept through the area, damaging two other planes. The F-117A touched down at Dayton International Airport at 3:45 p.m. and was safely in a hangar when the storm hit around 4:20 p.m. Two Soviet MiG-29 fighters were on display, but also escaped damage. The 10-minute storm caused five minor injuries, damaged two Air Force planes on display and knocked down some tents at the United States Air and Trade Show in this Dayton suburb, organizers said. The show was expected to open as scheduled Saturday. Organizers billed the arrival of the black, sharply angled stealth fighter as its first air show appearance. It was greeted by hundreds of onlookers who rushed past security guards to get a closer look. The fighter is not expected to perform aerial demonstrations at the show, which runs through Sunday. Also on hand were the two Soviet fighters, as well as a 33-member Soviet delegation, none of whom was injured in the storm. The F-117A is a tactical aircraft designed for ground attack and possibly air-to-air combat. It is designed to elude radar and was developed in near-complete secrecy by Lockheed Corp. The Pentagon first acknowledged its existence in November 1988. The program to develop the stealth fighter was managed at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton. Last week, the Air Force accepted the last of 59 fighters from Lockheed's ``Skunk Works'' operation in Southern California, nine years after the aircraft's first flight. The F-117A was not the only stealth aircraft getting attention at the show. Leroy Schroeder, test pilot for the B-2 bomber, conducted briefings Friday on the status of flight testing on that stealth aircraft. Schroeder said the B-2 has been in the air for 67 hours during its 16 flights. ``We've looked at how the airplane behaves ... and we're very, very pleased with it,'' said Schroeder, who works for B-2 builder Northrop Corp. More than 350,000 people are expected to attend the show.

DOC.HEAD: Nigerian Coup Soldiers Sentenced to Death
DOC.TEXT: A military tribunal has condemned 10 officers to death for leading a failed coup attempt, Lagos newspapers reported Friday. The trial was closed to the public and the verdicts were not published. The newspapers, quoting sources, said the sentences were subject to review by the Armed Forces Ruling Council, but 10 wooden stakes had already been set up at Kirikiri Prison on the spot where executions normally occur. The officers were charged with attacking Dodon Barracks, military headquarters and residence of President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, on April 22. Babangida barely escaped with his life, and his house was badly damaged. The coup leaders, who took over national radio headquarters for several hours, said they wanted to end the domination of the country by Moslem northerners. Forces loyal to Babangida put down the coup attempt. The Amnesty International human rights organization, with headquarters in London, and other groups have appealed to the military government to open the trial of the military men, and to commute any death sentences to prison terms.

DOC.HEAD: Dean of Louisiana Delegation Retiring
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf, `With the ...,' to UPDATE with comment by House Speaker Foley; picks up 11th graf, `Mrs. Boggs ...' SUBS penultimate graf with Jefferson scheduling news conference to announce candidacy.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NU2
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Lindy Boggs, the powerful, plantation-born dean of Louisiana's congressional delegation, announced Friday she won't run again for the seat she and her late husband held for 46 years. ``With my husband, I have devoted half a century to one of the most noble pursuits I know _ public service. ... Today I am announcing that this chapter in my service to the public is ending,'' Mrs. Boggs told 150 colleagues and supporters including former Archbishop Philip Hannan and former mayor Vic Schiro. Mrs. Boggs, her daughter Cokie Roberts, and politicians including Mayor Sidney Barthelemy and Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., spoke in a Tulane University building named after the Democratic congresswoman. The room was small, and less than half the audience was seated. Another crowd milled about and chatted in the lobby outside. A few people stood outside, looking through the floor-to-ceiling windows that made up two walls of the room, so they could see Mrs. Boggs. Mrs. Boggs, 74, wouldn't discuss details of her decision to retire after 17{ years in Washington. ``I don't think I can share with you all of the things that ran through my mind, because some of them are very personal,'' she said. It had been widely reported that she wanted to spend more time with her daughter, Princeton, N.J., Mayor Barbara Sigmund, who is suffering from cancer. Mrs. Boggs did not refer to Ms. Sigmund's illness. Asked if she was retiring because of the strain of travel between New Jersey, Washington and New Orleans, Mrs. Boggs said ``You've been talking to some of my family!'' but added, ``No.'' She did say the decision was a wrenching one because so many people offered to help run her office and campaign so she could take care of family obligations. And some of her colleagues appeared to refer obliquely to Ms. Sigmund's illness. ``With the dignity and grace that marked her outstanding career in the Congress, Lindy Boggs has announced her retirement from the Congress. Words cannot adequately describe how much all of us will miss Lindy, or the regret we feel at the reasons for her retirement,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. ``She'll be missed beyond my ability to say. There is no member whom I've served with in 25 years whose departure from Congress I more sincerely or deeply regret than Lindy Boggs,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley. ``With intelligence, grace, charm, commitment, compassion, she has served the people of her district, the state of Louisiana and the United States with extraordinary dedication.'' Mrs. Boggs took over the seat in March 1973 after winning a special election to succeed her husband, the powerful House majority leader, whose plane disappeared during a flight over Alaska six months earlier. Hale Boggs had won the seat in 1940, as a young lawyer. He lost a re-election bid in 1942 but reclaimed the job in 1946 after returning from military service, beginning a string of 22 straight victories by him or his wife. Mrs. Boggs, the only white representing a majority-black U.S. House district, said she hasn't decided whether to endorse anyone in the campaign for her seat. In a brief interview, she said she makes endorsements only ``in specific runoffs or where there's a huge difference between the candidates.'' ``I'm enthusiastically for Bennett Johnston,'' she added. Johnston is running for re-election this year against David Duke, an ex-Ku Klux Klan leader running as a Republican, and state Sen. Ben Bagert, the GOP's endorsed candidate and sponsor of Louisiana's new workfare law. Mrs. Boggs' announcement was interrupted by applause when she said, ``I am proud of my small role in opening doors to blacks and women.... ``The civil Rights and Voting Rights Acts that Hale and I supported were key to this progress, but so were the educational and economic opportunities we helped to create.'' She listed the Head Start program, her sponsorship of bills to guarantee access to credit for women and minorities, and her work to ensure participation of businesses owned by women and minorities in major federal projects such as the superconducting supercollider and the space station. ``I rejoice in my role in bringing about changes in the way we think about our environment,'' she said. ``Clean air, clean water, controls of hazardous materials, protection of our precious wetlands, and the acknowledgement of the global warming trend are now accepted policy objectives, not wishful thinking.'' Blacks have been reluctant to challenge Mrs. Boggs in the past, both because of her power _ she has taken 60 percent of the vote in every election since the special election in 1973, when she was first elected _ and her staunch support of civil rights throughout her career. As the moderator was about to end the session Friday, an elderly black stood up. ``You supported civil rights when civil rights was decidedly unfashionable. ... You worked for the first subdivision so blacks could own their own homes ... The black community says `Thank you, Lindy, for all you have done for us,'' said Phillip Baptiste, a businessman and longtime community and civil rights activist. Mrs. Boggs' power was not only at the polls. Johnston, Reps. Billy Tauzin and Jimmy Hayes, also Democrats, and other speakers told story after story of how the soft-spoken congresswoman won concessions that no other representative could get for his or her city and state. When Housing and Urban Development money was frozen during a scandal in the department, Mrs. Boggs got Secretary Jack Kemp to release money for two projects for senior citizens, said Barthelemy. Later, he said, one of Kemp's associates told him ``She asked so sweetly and so nicely that the secretary couldn't turn her down. He turned everybody else in the country down but Lindy Boggs.'' Ms. Roberts, who covers Congress for National Public Radio, said Rep. Jamie L. Whitten, D-Miss., chairman of the Appropriations Committee on which her mother sits, told her recently that ``your mama can get anything she wants out of me. ``I said, `Mr. Chairman!' He said, `Yeah, just like my wife ... I wouldn't dare say no to either one of them.''' However, at least two prominent black Democrats had already announced they were running in the district, which has a 60 percent black voting majority, and a third is likely to join them. State Sen. Jon Johnson kicked off his campaign for the Oct. 6 primary in April. Marc Morial, a lawyer and the elder son of the late Mayor Dutch Morial, had a gala reception Thursday night to formally announce his candidacy. State Sen. William Jefferson, who said earlier that he probably would enter the race if Mrs. Boggs stepped out, scheduled a Tuesday news conference to announce his candidacy, said his wife, Andrea. If no candidate gets more than 50 percent of the vote, a runoff would be held Nov. 6.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Settled; DOE Will Seek Permit Before Burning Rocky Flats Wastes
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Energy has agreed to not burn mixed plutonium and hazardous wastes in two incinerators at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant without getting a permit from Colorado or the Environmental Protection Agency. The consent agreement, approved Thursday by U.S. District Judge Lewis T. Babcock and announced Friday, settles a lawsuit brought by the Sierra Club against the federal agency. EG&G Inc., which operates Rocky Flats for the department, was added to the action later. ``The settlement and the court's order remove the threat that DOE will resume its `trial burn' plans without a hearing before the public,'' Eugene DeMayo, chairman of the Sierra Club's Rocky Mountain Chapter, said in a statement. ``We are happy that DOE agreed that a permit is necessary in this instance,'' he said. The DOE had said it had authority to operate the incinerators while awaiting a permit, but the Sierra Club challenged that claim in its June 1989 lawsuit. Rocky Flats, 16 miles northwest of Denver, makes plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. Plutonium processing there has been suspended until the plant's safety procedures are upgraded. David Simonson, DOE deputy director of Rocky Flats, said in a telephone interview Friday that the agency agreed to drop its contention that it did not need a permit before using the incinerators. The incinerators never have been used to dispose of wastes mixed with plutonium at the plant, and Simonson said there are no plans to use them for that purpose. The Sierra Club and DOE have been at odds since 1987, when the DOE first proposed a ``trial burn'' employing the incinerators, over whether the federal government needed to get a permit before burning the wastes. Following the announcement, the Sierra Club filed a lawsuit. It was settled later in 1987 after the DOE agreed not to use the incinerators until 45 days after completing an environmental assessment report. But the agency continued to maintain, even after that settlement, that it had authority to start up and operate the incinerators while it went about getting a permit, said Adam Babich, the Denver attorney who represented the Sierra Club. As a result, the Sierra Club brought its second lawsuit on June 2, 1989, just four days before scores of FBI and EPA agents raided Rocky Flats, looking for evidence of violations of hazardous waste disposal laws. A federal grand jury was convened in August 1989 to examine the allegations, but no indictments have been returned.

DOC.HEAD: Security Guard Says He Saw No Drugs During Virgin Islands Trip
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 6th graf: ``Mundy said,'' to add judge's last name, Jackson, and to CORRECT third reference of Mundy to Lewis _ it's Lewis that would have to be called as a witness, not Mundy
DOC.TEXT: A security guard for Marion Barry testified Friday that he saw no drugs during the mayor's 1988 Virgin Islands trip. The testimony by police Detective Ulysses Walltower contrasted sharply with that of prosecution witnesses who described heavy drug use and drinking by Barry during the four-day visit. However, Walltower said under cross-examination by the prosecution that he was not with Barry during much of the time convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis has said he used drugs with the mayor. In a related development, defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy alleged that Lewis had contacts with the family of convicted District of Columbia drug kingpin Rayful Edmond III. The jury was out of the courtroom when Mundy made his statements, which came as he questioned an FBI agent. Mundy said he brought up Lewis' alleged connection with Edmond to impeach Lewis' testimony. However, U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said Mundy could impeach the testimony only if he called Lewis as a witness. After the court session, Barry said he was happy with the way his case was proceeding. ``We are up against an awesome power _ the U.S. government,'' Barry said. ``But our strategy is to prove that the government has not proven, beyond a shadow of a doubt, the charges against me.'' Lewis testified earlier in the mayor's cocaine possession and perjury trial that Barry asked him on the first afternoon of the Virgin Islands trip to buy crack cocaine. The request came when there was no one else in the room, Lewis said. Walltower, testifying on the second day of the defense's case, said that on that afternoon he accompanied Barry's son, Christopher, and the boy's companion to a nearby beach. ``They went down several times, for 30 or 45 minutes,'' Walltower said. ``Then they would go back to the room, mess around, and go back down to the beach.'' Barry, Walltower said, spent his time on official business and playing with his son. Walltower also said he spent little time with the mayor in the evenings _ periods during which Lewis and other witnesses have said drugs were used. Lewis testified that he bought $300 worth of crack cocaine that he, the mayor and others smoked during Barry's four-day visit. Walltower, a 20-year police veteran, also said he saw Barry in the company of only two women. Lewis testified that he brought three women to Barry's hotel room. One of those women, Linda Maynard, testified that Barry sexually assaulted her. Another, Zena Mattias, said she rebuffed Barry's sexual advances. Walltower, who said he did not now the names of either woman he saw, also testified that he thought one of them was with Lewis. Mundy also said Friday he will show a videotape he said places Barry in a government meeting at a time when a government witness has testified she delivered drugs to the mayor in Washington. One possession charge against Barry stems from the testimony of Lydia Reid Pearson, who said she delivered cocaine _ and a city job application _ to Barry at a government office building Sept. 7, 1988. Mundy said the tape is of a meeting between Barry and top fire department officials that occurred at the time Pearson said she met with the mayor. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy count and three felony charges of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Shows Off Latest Catch to Press
With AM-Bush, Bjt
LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: President Bush showed up about a half-hour late at the Cheyenne Municipal Airport on Friday evening, sporting a big smile and a baseball cap and toting a 12-inch trout. The president showed off his catch to the press and spectators as he crossed the tarmac to Air Force One, which took off around 6:40 p.m. for Washington. When asked how his fishing went, the president gave the ``thumbs up'' sign and said, ``Good.'' He then reached into a plastic garbage sack and grabbed the trout to show to the press. Bush, who'd been scheduled to arrive at the airport at 5:50 p.m. but didn't show up until around 6:20 p.m., spent about three hours fishing in the Middle Crow Creek west of Cheyenne with U.S. Sens. Al Simpson and Malcolm Wallop and Rep. Craig Thomas, all Wyoming Republicans. Simpson and Thomas said Bush's fish was the last, biggest catch of the day. They said the president appeared hesitant to leave for the airport until he caught a fish. The delegation accompanied the president to the airport, where Simpson opened a plastic garbage bag to show off the six other trout caught by the group. The president was in Cheyenne to help celebrate Wyoming's centennial, where he joined in a parade and gave a speech to thousands of spectators.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Next Move Likely To Be Direct Talks with Phnom Penh
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to make it ``crossed' China sted ``infuriated''
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's next move to keep the Khmer Rouge from regaining power in Cambodia will likely be direct talks with the government in Phnom Penh _ not just with its longtime sponsor, Vietnam. That would mean going beyond this week's opening to Hanoi, a move that reversed U.S. policy; crossed China, the major supplier of the communist Khmer Rouge; and drew plaudits from Capitol Hill. It is a step, policy-making insiders said, urged by Secretary of State James A. Baker III but opposed by Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security assistant, when Bush considered his options at a White house meeting last Friday. Baker, backed by others in the State Department, proposed Bush deal with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, whose government the United States has tried to overthrew for years by helping a guerrilla coalition. Baker argued that dealing with Phnom Penh might help break the link between China and the Khmer Rouge, the murderous and most powerful of the three anti-government factions in the coalition. The Khmer Rouge, which massacred hundreds of thousands of Cambodians when it ran the country from 1975 to 1978, now holds much of the northern part of the country and is advancing toward the capital. Scowcroft supported holding talks with Vietnam but advised against going further at this time. He was willing, however, to leave that door open if doing so would speed up elections in Cambodia. To hold direct talks with Phnom Penh now, he cautioned, could have the opposite effect and draw China and the Khmer Rouge even closer together. Disagreements between the State Department and the National Security Council are not unusual. It's been said the only time a secretary of state and a national security adviser were in total accord was when Henry A. Kissinger held both posts under Presidents Nixon and Ford. Still, Baker and Scowcroft have been working in harmony since the administration took office 18 months ago. But the disagreement over direct talks with the Cambodian government is not upsetting officials at the State Department. ``I think at one point we will take that step,'' an official who requested anonymity said. ``Given (that) we got most of what we wanted, it wasn't so critical.'' While Bush's decision will mean talking to the Vietnamese about holding multi-party elections in Cambodia, it may also lead to U.S. recognition of Vietnam, lowering a 15-year trade embargo and, perhaps, a slowdown of the tragic exodus of ``boat people.'' For now, Bush has given up trying to isolate Vietnam diplomatically. Even though he isn't ready to normalize relations with Hanoi or authorize talks with the Cambodian government, he is no longer shunning the two countries as puppets of Moscow. Congress was moving to choke off aid to the Cambodian guerrillas when Bush acted. ``American foreign policy can succeed only when it enjoys bipartisan support,'' Baker wrote Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell of Maine on Wednesday. Bush and Baker also were guided by other practical considerations. One was successful cooperation with the Soviet Union, which also backs the Cambodian government, in other regional disputes. The next dividend could be an agreement on how to end the 12-year war in Afghanistan. The most practical reason of all, however, was to try to staunch the bloodletting in Cambodia. The guerrillas were unable to contain the Khmer Rouge, Baker said in announcing the policy shift Wednesday. ``The fighting continues. Cambodians continue to suffer and Cambodians continue to die.'' __ EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid is The Associated Press's chief diplomatic writer.

DOC.HEAD: NEA Revises Obscenity Pledge for Artists It Funds With Foundation
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts has agreed to let artists also funded by the Rockefeller Foundation sign a modified version of its controversial anti-obscenity pledge, both parties said Friday. Joint grantees can add wording to the current NEA pledge that they will comply with its provisions ``to the extent that such terms and conditions, and the requirement to accept them, are lawful under the Constitution and the laws of the United States.'' The Rockefeller Foundation opposes the NEA pledge, which requires grantees to promise not to create obscene works. In a letter to recipients released Friday, the foundation said it believed the pledges were ``unconstitutional, unfair and dangerous to artists, and that they limit the range of art produced.'' The modified language provided a measure of protection for artists funded by both agencies, it said. The foundation first disclosed the agreement in a friend-of-the-court brief filed late Wednesday on behalf of the New School for Social Research, which sued the NEA and refused to sign the anti-obscenity pledge to get a grant. The NEA confirmed the agreement on Friday; a spokesman said it agreed to the modified language late last month. ``Because of the co-mingling of private and public money, the endowment agreed to a modification of the guidelines,'' said spokesman Josh Dare. Only artists and organizations receiving money from the NEA and the foundation would be eligible to sign the revised agreement, he said. ``We aren't including it for any others,'' Dare said. ``It's a unique funding situation, so it turns into a unique compliance situation.'' The endowment decided earlier this month to use the definition of obscenity established in 1973 by the Supreme Court rather than broader language adopted by Congress last year, Dare said. The anti-obscenity language included in the endowment's fiscal 1990 appropriation forbids the NEA to fund work that might be deemed obscene, ``including but not limited to, depictions of sadomasochism, homoeroticism, the sexual exploitation of children, or individuals engaged in sex acts, which when taken as a whole, do not have serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.'' The endowment and the Rockefeller Foundation jointly fund the New Forms Regional Initiative, which gives grants to emerging artists; Meet the Composer, which sets up collaborations with composers; and the Fund for U.S. Artists at International Festivals, Dare said. The endowment's funding for these projects in 1990 totaled $540,00, while the foundation put up $791,000, he said. The Rockefeller Foundation expects to give out more than $90 million in grants this year, of which $15 million will be for the arts and humanities, said foundation spokesman Frank Karel. The NEA's appropriation for 1990 was $153 million.

DOC.HEAD: Famous Directors Petition MPAA to Reform Ratings
With AM-Movie Ratings
DOC.TEXT: Many of the nation's leading filmmakers _ including Francis Ford Coppola, Barry Levinson and Paul Mazursky _ will ask the Motion Picture Association of America to change its movie rating system. In a petition to be delivered to the MPAA offices here Tuesday, more than a dozen top directors ask that a new rating be established for adult-oriented films that are not pornographic, according to a copy of the letter. ``The taint of an X rating clearly results in massive and arbitrary corporate censorship,'' the petition says. ``Failure to address this problem will help foster a new era of `McCarthyism' in the arts as during the 50's, when the networks claimed it was not they who blacklisted artists, but the sponsors.'' The letter says the X rating ``has come to be universally recognized as pertaining simply to pornography. ... We therefore strongly suggest that a new rating of A (for adult) or M (for mature) be incorporated into the system to indicate a film contains strong adult themes or images and that minors are not to view them.'' A number of critically acclaimed films _ included ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' ``Portrait of a Serial Killer,'' ``Scandal'' and ``The Cook, the Thief, His Wife & Her Lover'' _ have been rated X in recent months. The petition also was signed by Spike Lee, Rob Reiner, Jonathan Demme, Jim Jarmusch, Ron Howard, John Sayles, Penny Marshall, John Waters, Edward Zwick and John Landis, among others. It follows a similar request made this week by the National Society of Film Critics to the MPAA asking they create a new rating for mature films. Mark Lipsky, the president of film distributor Silverlight Entertainment, said he organized the directors' petition because films with X ratings are denied newspaper and television advertisements and are refused by many theaters. Films carrying the X rating, he said, often are ignored by adult viewers who might enjoy them because the rating has such negative connotations. ``And that's censorship,'' Lipsky said. ``The MPAA is being irresponsible if they don't face the issue.'' A spokeswoman for the MPAA in Washington said the organization would not be able to comment on the letter until next week. Earlier in the day, Jack Valenti, the MPAA president, said the rating system works. A New York judge ruled Thursday that the MPAA's X rating unfairly brands films for mature audiences as pornographic, and called for the organization to devise a new rating system. Judge Charles Ramos, while saying he did not have the authority to change an X rating given to the acclaimed Spanish film ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!,'' called the MPAA ratings system ``an effective form of censorship.'' In a scathing 15-page opinion, Ramos wrote that unless the MPAA reforms the rating system, it might find itself subject to legal challenge. He called on the organization ``to consider the proposals for a revised rating system that provides a professional basis for rating films or to cease the practice altogether.'' He said the problem ``is the need to avoid stigmatizing films of an adult nature, which ought not to be seen by children, but which are clearly not pornographic.'' ``Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' features one sex scene and a brief masturbation scene, and was given an X rating. Many newspapers and movie theaters prohibit advertising and exhibition of X-rated movies.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Brennan Resigns
DOC.TEXT: In his 34 years on the Supreme Court, Justice William J. Brennan has left his mark in majority opinions that helped shaped the law and in dissents that offered tributes to individual liberties. Here is a sampling: In 1957, Brennan wrote for the court as it first attempted to define obscenity and ruled that obscenity is not constitutionally protected. He said material is obscene if ``to the average person applying contemporary community standards, the dominant theme of the material taken as a whole appeals to prurient interest.'' In 1962, the court established its one-person, one-vote standard of equal representation. Brennan said judges have authority to strike down state-approved legislative district lines. ``The right asserted is within the reach of judicial protection under the Fourteenth Amendment,'' he said. In 1964, the court granted constitutional protection to the news media when it is sued for libel. Brennan wrote, ``The constitutional guarantees require, we think, a federal rule that prohibits a public official from recovering damages for a defamatory falsehood relating to his official conduct unless he proves that the statement was made with actual malice _ that is, with knowledge that it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not.'' When the court ruled against prison inmates in a little-noted case during the 1986-87 term, Brennan wrote in dissent: ``Prisoners are persons whom most of us would rather not think about. ... It is easy to think of prisoners as members of a separate netherworld... Nothing can change the fact, however, that the society these prisoners inhabit is our own. When prisoners emerge from the shadows to press a constitutional claim ... they speak the language of a charter upon whicch all of us rely to hold official power accountable.'' When the court ruled that a former soldier who unknowingly ingested LSD in secret chemical warfare experiments could not sue due the government, Brennan dissented and said: ``The subject of experimentation who has not volunteered is treated as an object, a sample...Soldiers ought not to be asked to defend a Constitution indifferent to their essential human dignity.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebuilt Exxon Tanker Leaving Dry Dock
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with ship coming out of dry dock, comments; picks up 6th graf, ```The sea ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Planned
DOC.TEXT: The former Exxon Valdez inched its way out of dry dock Friday night after 11 months of repairs to the tanker's hull, which was shredded in the nation's worst oil spill. The ship, renamed the Exxon Mediterranean, was being maneuvered about a quarter-mile to a shipyard pier in San Diego Bay for systems tests. Winches on the deck of the 987-foot-long tanker pulled tow lines as the ship emerged bow first from the dock at National Steel and Shipbuilding Co. Several tugboats began towing the ship to the pier, where its engines, pumps and other machinery will be tested before two weeks of sea trials. ``They'll make sure everything runs and there's no leaks in any of the systems,'' shipyard spokesman Fred Hallett said. ``It's basic operating _ like idling a car. ``At sea, they'll go full speed ... putting her through her maximum paces and making sure not only that she works, but to'' specifications, Hallett said. The 24-hour process of flooding the dry dock and ballasting the ship began late Thursday, Hallett said. The ship is expected to remain pierside for about two weeks before embarng.

The judge who sent Pete Rose to prison for cheating on his taxes challenged him to become a hero again in the eyes of youngsters. U.S. District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel on Thursday sentenced baseball's all-time hit leader to five months in prison and three months in a halfway house. He also ordered Rose to pay a $50,000 fine and perform 1,000 hours of work at schools and a youth club when he is released on a year's probation. Rose's gambling already had gotten him banned from baseball for life, in August. In April he pleaded guilty to failing to report more than $354,000 in income from gambling, autograph signings and memorabilia sales. Spiegel said inner-city youngsters need someone to look up to _ and that Rose, whose baseball nickname was Charlie Hustle, still can be that person.

A newspaper cannot be held liable for breaking a promise of confidentiality to a source, Minnesota's highest court ruled today in rejecting a $700,000 award against the state's two biggest daily papers. Lawyers for both sides agreed the 4-2 ruling by the state Supreme Court has far-reaching implications for the nation's news organizations. The court rejected a jury's award of $200,000 in compensatory damages and $500,000 in punitive damages to Dan Cohen. Cohen had sued the Saint Paul Pioneer Press and the Star Tribune of Minneapolis for 1982 stories identifying him as the source of documents showing a Democratic candidate for lieutenant governor had been convicted of shoplifting 12 years earlier.

President Bush's savings and loan bailout fund will be nearly out of money if officials reach their goal of closing or selling 77 institutions by Sept. 30, a federal agency says. Figures provided Thursday by the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board indicate that, unless Congress authorizes more borrowing, regulators could have as little as $7.3 billion in borrowing authority left when the new federal fiscal year begins Oct. 1. ``The bottom line ... (is) it would cause us to very significantly reduce the pace of resolutions,'' said Peter Monroe, president of the oversight board. In addition to the $7.3 billion, the agency could spend any money it can get by selling repossessed real estate and sour loans inherited from previous S&L bailouts, he said.

United Flight 232 survivors wandered pensively about the runway where a year ago their crippled jumbo jet cartwheeled in flames, killing 112 of 296 people aboard. ``I want to see it without bodies and luggage and airplane parts strewn all over,'' Brad Bayless of Littleton, Colo., said during a reunion of survivors and victims' relatives on the crash anniversary Thursday. Little evidence of the crash remains. The cornfield where the wreckage came to rest is now planted in soybeans, the torn runway has been patched and pieces of the shattered United Air Lines DC-10 are locked away in a hangar. Bayless and other survivors walked around the crash site and into another cornfield, where they picked tassels as reminders.

DOC.HEAD: New, Moderate Left Develops in Latin America
DOC.TEXT: Moderate socialists are taking over from Latin America's doctrinaire communists, who were cast adrift when Eastern Europe threw out the old guard and the Moscow line was reeled in. Reform leftists say old models of socialism, based on such principles as one-party rule and state control of the entire economy, have become obsolete. ``That has created a tremendous shock for those of us who considered the past Soviet model to be a basic reference,'' said Luis Maira, a leading Chilean intellectual and member of a Christian Marxist group. Leftist guerrilla movements, common in the region 20 years ago, have all but disappeared. Only Peru, El Salvador and Guatemala have significant insurgent groups, and U.S. fears of Cuban-inspired revolutions have gone the way of the Cold War. ``The left is a thing of the past,'' said Guerino Andreoni, an Argentine labor leader. ``Ideologically, it expresses a feeling we all share, but structurally it has remained stagnant.'' Parties in the old Soviet style got no more than 7 percent of the vote, and usually far less, in elections held over the last few years in Argentina, Venezuela, Colombia, Peru, Paraguay, Ecuador, Brazil, Chile, Mexico and Bolivia. Left-of-center parties are springing up to carry the banner of the new, moderate socialism. ``The socialist models in Eastern Europe fell because they were centralized, bureaucractic and authoritarian,'' said Roger Capella Mateo, treasurer of Causa R, a Venezuelan party founded in 1983. It won three seats in the national congress last year. ``Our party anticipated perestroika by creating a grass-roots socialist model from the bottom up and not the other way around,'' he said, referring to the reform program of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In Colombia, former guerrilla leader Antonio Navarro finished third in this year's presidential election. He described his M-19 party, named for his former guerrilla group, as nationalist and committed to ``democratic capitalism.'' Leftist parties received 23 percent of the vote in the 1989 Chilean congressional elections. That was a decline from 40 percent in the 1970 election, the last free vote before the 1973 coup that overthrew President Salvador Allende, an avowed Marxist. Chile's Socialist Party, which got most of the left's vote last year, espouses moderate views similar to the Social Democrats of Western Europe. Only Nicaragua, Brazil, Mexico and Uruguay have well-entrenched leftist political movements. Nicaragua's Sandinista movement was voted out of office in February after more than 11 years in power, but is a strong force in opposition to the government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. In Brazil, Luis Inacio Lula da Silva of the Workers Party coalition of trade unionists, members of the progressive wing of the Roman Catholic Church and intellectuals, fell just short of defeating conservative Fernando Collor de Mello in the December presidential election. A Mexican ``new left'' was born during the 1988 presidential campaign when leftist parties formed an unprecedented alliance to back Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who ran a strong second to Carlos Salinas de Gortari, candidate of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party. Socialist and other leftist parties in Uruguay, allied in the Broad Front, won 21 percent of the vote in elections last year. Luis Alberto Lacalle, a conservative, won the presidency, but Broad Front candidate Tabare Vazquez became mayor of Montevideo, the capital. Many traditional Communist parties have suffered major defections in the past year. ``The Communist Party will no doubt continue to exist, but will have no future to speak of, since it continues to suppress ideas,'' said Angelino Carzon, head of a major Colombian labor union. He quit the party in April. In several other countries, liberal Communists inspired by Gorbachev have either taken control of the parties or are trying to do so. Sen. Jaime Perez, leader of the Uruguayan Communists, said the collapse of communism in Eastern Europe took his party by surprise. ``We believed those regimes were consolidated, but reality has shown the parties were isolated from the people,'' he said. Despite their more moderate approach, Latin America's new leftists remain convinced capitalism is largely responsible for the region's inequities and still put much of the blame on the United States. They see President Bush's recent call for increased economic integration in the hemisphere as an attempt to dominate Latin economies. ``His plan would submit our economies to the control of foreign capital and governments,'' said Joao Machado of the Workers Party in Brazil. Deciding what they are for seems more difficult for leaders of the new left than declaring what they are against. Socialists speak of a major redistribution of wealth, agrarian reform and stopping payments on the region's $400 billion foreign debt, but offer few specific plans. ``The position of the left based on its traditional discourse . .. has been completely weakened; unfortunately, the left has not come up with an alternative discourse,'' said Herbert Mueller, a Bolivian political consultant. Some signposts have emerged. Leftist reformers have expressed a commitment to Western-style elections, which old-guard Communists scorned as ``bourgeois democracy.'' ``We have to denounce the crimes of Eastern Europe, the crimes of the gulag and the lack of liberty,'' said Rep. Jose Genoino, a former guerrilla who fought Brazil's military governments of 1964-1985. Prominent socialists have even urged Fidel Castro to hold direct elections in Cuba. While leftists still seek a substantial role for the state, many say they also favor a role for private enterprise. ``Contemporary socialism doesn't sanctify the state or the market and looks for an equilibrium,'' said Sen. Enrique Bernales of the Socialist Left, a reformist Peruvian party. ``These days, we can't reject the similiarities with social democracy.'' Some leftists have shown an openness to foreign investment, which previously was considered a threat to national sovereignty. In the Brazilian presidential campaign last year, da Silva said foreign companies offered better conditions to workers than Brazilian firms. ``Foreign capital has to come to Brazil,'' he said. ``The only restriction we make is there has to be greater control.'' Even hard-liners recognize the need for change. ``Socialism has lost a battle because it underestimated the importance of democracy,'' said Patricio Echegaray, head of the Argentine Communist Party, which followed the Moscow line faithfully.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Monday July 30

For Release Fri PMs, Aug 3 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Laguna Beach Art Fest Needs No Help From NEA
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: While movie theaters on the main drag play the loud and violent films of summer, a quiet, gentle show called ``Pageant of the Masters'' is doing turn-away business a few blocks away. This annual stage spectacle, coupled with a colorful art festival, is such a box-office hit that it needs no help from the National Endowment for the Arts. Instead, it will be giving money back to the community which plays host to this cultural jewel. ``As far as I know, this is the only town that is paid by the arts,'' said Jacquie Moffett, president of the Festival of the Arts, who noted that the city of Laguna Beach receives about $300,000 a year from the seven-week art extravaganza which runs from July through Aug. 26. ``We're a non-profit organization and we do make money,'' she said, explaining why much of the income from admission tickets is given away both to the city and in scholarships to talented residents. The Pageant of the Masters, centerpiece of the Laguna Beach Art Festival, is an outdoor two-hour production in which great paintings, sculpture and even pieces of jewelry are reproduced larger than life size on a carefully lit stage. If the people in these art works appear lifelike, it's because they are real people. The concept of ``living pictures,'' once an entertainment of the French court, first came to Laguna Beach 58 years ago. Residents, their faces and bodies painted and costumed, pose in exact duplicates of famous works of art. In an outdoor bowl under the stars, these frozen images are accompanied by lyrical music and narration which tells the history of the art work on view. With advanced makeup and lighting techniques, it's often hard to tell that living, breathing individuals are wearing the paint and costumes of the scene, standing without visibly blinking or breathing. ``They are taught a shallow method of breathing, and you really can't see them breathe,'' said Sally Reeve, longtime public relations director for the festival who used to appear in the pageant herself. ``Staying still is stressed above everything,'' said Moffett, noting that this year's show features several small children who managed to not move a muscle. Sometimes the performers' ability to stand still is severely tested. ``Once a pigeon came and landed on a nude,'' Moffett recalls. ``She just stood there like she was a statue.'' Because the show is held outdoors, she said, there's the added problem of insects which sometimes land and get stuck in a performer's makeup. ``That's particularly difficult if it's one of the nudes,'' she said. The pageant is an all-year project for Laguna Beach residents who not only perform but help select the works to be depicted. A staff of ``detectives'' searches out the owners of paintings or sculptures to obtain permission for its use in the Pageant of the Masters. Moffett's own children appeared in the pageant in their younger years. Community participation increases every year, she said, noting, ``Everyone likes to be part of a success.'' As for audiences, many of them are perpetual fans. ``A lot of people love the show and come back every year,'' Moffett said. ``They are probably the same people who don't like to watch car chases in movies.'' The people who do like car chases, she concedes, find the pageant ``too static.'' Moffett, an artist who has exhibited on the grounds of the art festival for 23 years, noted that many Laguna Beach resident artists support themselves on the works they sell during the summer festival. The juried show selects the most talented members of the resort's huge art colony to exhibit here. Last year, one painting shown on the grounds sold for $15,000. Some of those who do not win admission to the festival show their works across the road at two commercial exhibits, the Sawdust and the Art A-Fair which cater to tourists and those wanting a less costly art souvenir. The Festival of Arts-Pageant of the Masters is the only non-profit exhibition in town. Its success is measured by the creation this season of the Festival of Arts Foundation, started with $1.5 million in festival money. The tax-exempt foundation will provide funding for the arts in Laguna Beach, including scholarships and grants to cultural institutions. Its first grants went to such groups as the Laguna Beach Chamber Music Society, the Laguna Playhouse and the Art Institute of Southern California. Moffett hopes that future plans will include construction of artist studios and residences for those unable to afford pricey real estate in this beach-front community. ``Some artists move here just to be part of the festival,'' she said. ``But lately some have had to move away because it's such an expensive place to live.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Pm Fri Aug. 3
