DOC.HEAD: Conference Committee Considers Host of Clean Air Disputes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 24th graf, The House ... new equipment., to show that environmentalists and industry both favor the House version on risk assessment of toxic releases by industry.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional negotiators must resolve a host of disputes over how far government and industry should go to clean the air, from placing emission restrictions on small factories to helping workers laid off because of tougher pollution controls. The sheer size of the 148-member House-Senate conference committee, more than a quarter of the Congress, points to the high stakes in the political battle. The legislation is expected to cost more than $21 billion a year in new pollution controls. ``There will be clean air legislation this year. I don't think anyone disputes that,'' asserts Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the conference. Baucus said in an interview that he considers separate clean air bills passed by the House and Senate ``by and large very similar'' with identical goals of significantly cutting urban smog, reducing acid rain and curtailing the industrial release of toxic chemicals by the end of the decade. But there remains much dispute over details of tergy and Commerce Committee. The Senate negotiators, on the other hand, number only nine. Four of them _ Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, Baucus, Sen. John Chafee, R-R.I., and Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn. _ led the Senate battle for clean air legislation. Seven of the nine are members of the Senate Environment Committee and they are expected to balk at any proposals that would significantly weaken the legislation. The separate bills that breezed through both the House and Senate last spring would impose stiff new requirements on industry to control toxic chemicals, on factories to reduce smog-causing pollution, and on electric power plants to curb sulfur dioxide, which causes acid rain. They also would direct automakers to build cleaner cars and oil companies to provide cleaner fuels to reduce urban smog. But the House and Senate versions often differ on how far companies should go to control toxic releases, what polluters should be covered, or in some cases what measures should be taken to comply. The final negotiations on these details will determine ``whether you have a good clean air bill or a bill that's not very good at all,'' said Richard Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition, an environmental umbrella group. Industry, meanwhile, makes no secret that it will push the congressional negotiators to scuttle some of the strongest requirements in either bill. ``We know the goals of the two bills are about the same. We're trying to make it the most affordable to the American business community and to the consumer,'' said William Fay, executive director of the Clean Air Working Group, the industry's lobbying coalition. Fay calls the government's estimated $21.5 billion price tag for the clean air bill unrealistic and maintains the cost will be much higher if some of the provisions found in either the Senate or House bills survive. According to lawmakers, congressional aides and lobbyists, here are a number of the most contentious issues that will have to be resolved by the House and Senate negotiators:
DOC.HEAD: REQUIREMENTS ON NEW AUTOMOBILES
DOC.TEXT: Both the House and Senate bills would require tougher tailpipe emission controls. But the Senate bill would trigger a second round of even tighter requirements automatically if air quality did not meet federal health standards in a dozen pollution-plagued cities by the end of the decade. The automakers argue they cannot meet the second phase of controls with current technology and hope the House version will prevail. They have a strong ally in Dingell. At the same time, however, the automakers plan to fight another House provision _ not in the Senate bill _ that would require them to build and market at least some alternative fuel cars.
DOC.HEAD: CONTROLS ON INDUSTRIAL POLLUTION Both bills would require large polluters emitting more than 100 tons a year to install new equipment to reduce smog-causing emissions. But the House would include factories that pollute much less _ as little as 10 or 25 tons a year _ in cities with the dirtiest air. Industry and the Bush administration have argued that the more sweeping controls in the House bill would force businesses to close, put people out of work and jeopardize economic growth.

CLEAN FUELS Both bills call for cleaner motor fuels to be used in cities with serious smog problems, but the language is under attack from the oil industry, which says the government is trying write its own recipe for gasoline. The oil companies and their congressional allies have vowed to get the provisions changed, arguing the requirement is aimed to boost the sale use of ethanol, which is made from grain.
TOXIC INDUSTRIAL RELEASES
DOC.TEXT: Both bills would require that industry adopt new technology to curb industrial releases of toxic chemicals into the air. But the Senate bill would go another step by establishing minimum cancer risk levels that would be allowed after the new equipment was installed. If those risks could not be achieved a plant could be ordered shut down. The House version, considered by industry to be less onerous than the Senate requirements, would leave it to the Environmental Protection Agency to establish ``an ample margin of safety'' beyond installation of the new equipment. Many environmentalists also favor the House version, fearing the plant-by-plant assessment of risk included in the Senate bill would be less effective.
DOC.HEAD: JOBS PROTECTION
DOC.TEXT: The House bill calls for a three-year, $250 million program to help workers who lose their jobs because of tougher pollution controls. The Senate bill would provide no assistance. While Senate leaders have expressed support for the House measure, the White House has threatened to veto legislation containing assistance for workers, saying it would be difficult to control the cost. While it is doubtful to many in Congress that Bush would sacrifice clean air legislation because of the labor assistance, the administration is expected to argue vigorously against the provision.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 22

DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's savings and loan bailout program could face a severe cash crunch this fall after regulators close or sell 77 institutions this summer, officials said. The Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board, headed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, said Thursday that unless Congress provides more money, regulators could have as little as $7.3 billion left for S&L deals when the new federal fiscal year begins Oct. 1. He also said the bailout agency would be able to spend any additional money it can get by selling repossessed real estate and sour loans inherited from previous S&L bailouts.

Personal incomes are growing fastest in western states and slowest in New England, the government said in a report indicating the 1980s phenomenon of the bi-coastal economy is ending. Eight of the 11 states with fastest income growth between the first quarter of 1989 and the January-March period of this year are located in the West, the Commerce Department said Thursday.

Japan's biggest computer maker, Fujitsu Ltd., is negotiating to buy a controlling stake in International Computers Ltd., Britain's leading computer manufacturer, ICL's parent said. A majority interest in ICL, likely to cost more than $1 billion, would give Fujitsu a bigger foothold in the European Community before the trade bloc dismantles its internal trade barriers in 1992. The parent company STC PLC, made the announcement Thursday.

Former Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas Chairman Edwin T. McBirney III pleaded innocent to bank fraud charges stemming from his efforts to finance a $700 million real estate deal in California. McBirney, 37, headed the Dallas-based thrift from 1982 until government regulators forced him out in 1986. Sunbelt failed two years later in a takeover estimated to cost taxpayers $2 billion. U.S. District Judge Robert Maloney on Thursday set a Sept. 4 trial date.

AT&T reported lower second-quarter earnings, a 6.4 percent drop it attributed to declining equipment sales and unexpectedly high startup costs for the company's new credit card. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Thursday it earned $657 million, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter ended June 30, down from $699 million, or 65 cents a share, in the same quarter of 1989. Revenue fell to $9.03 billion from $9.26 billion a year earlier.

Ford Motor Co. indicated it probably wouldn't eliminate plant overtime that the United Auto Workers claims is straining employees. Owen Bieber, president of the UAW, said Thursday after opening contract talks with the automaker that Ford was using extensive overtime so it could employ fewer hourly workers. UAW talks opened Wednesday with General Motors Corp. and begin Friday at Chrysler Corp. The three contracts expire at midnight, Sept. 14.

East Germany checked the pulse of its economy and released a grim diagnosis: industrial production has plunged and at least 9 percent of its workers have lost all or part of their wages. Industrial production fell by 15 percent in June and half a million workers have had their hours and salaries slashed since July 1, when the nation became a free market and merged its economy with West Germany's, the government said Thursday.

A former Citibank vice president whose job was to safeguard assets was sentenced to eight years in prison for embezzling securities worth $25 million from the bank's vault. Of the five $5 million certificates stolen, four were recovered when the defendant, Mario Rios Pinochet, tried to negotiate them three days after the Jan. 25 theft, prosecutors said Thursday. The fifth certificate, which matured in February, was never recovered.

Debt-plagued Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond, whose vast world holdings range from brewing to real estate, will resign as chairman of his company to appease creditors under an agreement. Bond's departure from Australia-based Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd, more than $6 billion in debt, could lead to important refinancing arrangements, company director Peter Lucas said Thursday in disclosing the pact after a bondholders meeting in London.

A late afternoon rally helped the stock market salvage a mixed showing Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down about 20 points at its midsession low, closed with a 12.13 gain at 2,993.81. The dollar ended mostly lower. Bond prices finished narrowly mixed. Frozen pork belly futures prices plummeted the 2-cents-a-pound permitted daily limit; livestock futures ended mostly lower; energy futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals retreated.

DOC.HEAD: New Nike Ad Offers Fanciful Explanation of How Bo Does It All
DOC.TEXT: When the baseball and football seasons collide later this summer, Bo Jackson may wish life was more like his new Nike commercial. In the ad, the pro football and baseball star is beside himself _ he plays 15 roles at once. Nike's commercial makers came up with the approach while trying to figure out a sequel to last year's ``Bo Knows ... '' ad in which athletes such as runner Joan Benoit Samuelson and basketball's Michael Jordan attested to Jackson's ability in their specialities. There were dissenters in last year's ad _ hockey's Wayne Gretzky and guitar man Bo Diddley to name two _ but a revised version of the commercial six months later indicated Bo made Diddley a believer as well. The ad catapulted Jackson to the top of the list of the year's most persuasive sports figures in a commercial, according to an annual survey of 22,000 people questioned by the research firm Video Storyboard Tests Inc. And it was the main reason consumers cited in making Nike the sixth most memorable admaker during the first quarter of 1990, another Video Storyboard Tests survey said earlier this year. But last year's success created a problem for Jim Riswold, associate creative director at Nike's ad agency Wieden & Kennedy in Portland, Ore. ``It was a hard act to follow,'' said Riswold, copywriter on both campaigns. ``We kept coming back to the question: How does Bo do all these things? And we decided, well, Bo is more than one person. We decided to use the dumbest joke in the history of advertising,'' Riswold said. For the new ad, Nike's admakers decided to have Jackson don gear used in a dozen different sports _ not only his Kansas City Royals baseball uniform and his Los Angeles Raiders football suit but tennis, cycling, surfing, soccer, cricket, golf, cricket and cross-training gear. Each of the Bo's were shot separately; skillful editing made it appear they were gathering one by one in a locker room. Bo Football tries to guess Bo Baseball's name. Bo Cyclist screeches to a halt and asks, ``Where's that Tour de France Thing?'' Bo Hockey sports ``Le Bo'' stitched across his jersey. Bo Golfer has a Bo Caddy to carry his clubs and search for his Jackson-autograph golf ball. Jackson put on a jockey's outfit to lead a horse across the set, and he got behind the wheel of an Indy-style racing car that was pulled across the set. Cher's onetime beau Sonny Bono wandered into the act. ``I thought this was another Bo Knows commercial,'' he said. By the time Bo Director joins the scene and calls ``cut'' at the end of the ad, the TV screen is full of Bo's. There is some method to all this madness. The ad showed off an array of Nike apparel as well as its shoes. Nike makes clothes for each of the sports Jackson demonstrated except horse and auto racing, hockey and cricket, according to Nike ad manager Bill Zeitz. He said Nike plans to spend about $10 million on buying television time for the new ad. He declined to say how much Jackson is being paid.

DOC.HEAD: Electronic Marketing Gives Farmers Space-Age Way To Balance Supply, Demand
Also in AMs report
DOC.TEXT: A new satellite-transmitted information system is beaming the names of buyers and sellers to farmers with too many green peppers or too little sweet corn. The pilot program by the Illinois Farm Bureau is seen as one possible solution to the eternal problem of balancing supply and demand in perishable produce, as well as possibly boosting profits. ``Sometimes we have too much and sometimes we don't have enough,'' said Ron Friend, who raises cantaloupe and watermelon near Havana in west-central Illinois, along the Illinois River. ``I remember one day in 1973 it came out exactly right.'' Fruit and vegetable growers scramble to find wholesale buyers when they harvest more fresh commodities than they can sell at their roadside markets or to regular customers. And they search for other farmers with extra produce when their own harvests are short. ``The growers seem to be very excited about the system,'' said Don Naylor, a specialist in fruit and vegetable marketing who manages the new project for the Farm Bureau. ``We're trying to bring farmers together who might be separated by hundreds of miles.'' The Farm Bureau already had the foundation of the new service _ its FarmDayta system for delivering weather, market information and agricultural news to about 5,000 Illinois grain producers. Farms receive the data via satellite dish and read it on a computer screen. Twenty-five fruit and vegetable growers were added to the system this summer to see if it could help them buy and sell produce. Those farmers call a toll-free number to list their names, locations, telephone numbers and crops they wish to buy or sell. They then must contact buyers or sellers and agree on terms. ``We don't raise our own fruit, and at times there are local shortages,'' said Don Zeldenrust, who grows vegetables and sells produce at his Chicago Heights roadside market. ``We might have to go to Michigan, Missouri or Arkansas when there are guys in Southern Illinois who have what we need,'' said Zeldenrust. ``It doesn't make sense to ship the fruit a long way. It's better for them and better for us.'' The buyer-seller information, along with prices being paid at Chicago's South Water Street wholesale produce market, is transmitted to subscribers who pay $100 for six months' service during the pilot stage of the project. ``I'm using it to keep up-to-date on the market,'' said Carl Weissert, who grows vegetables near Fairview Heights, in the metropolitan area east of St. Louis. He said when the system is fully operational, the speed at which the information is available should be a big plus to farmers. ``You won't find out next week what WAS available,'' said Weissert. Growers say a limited amount of information now is on the system. But they hope more farmers will sign up and that it will help all of them increase their profits. ``Right now, you just can't find sweet corn anywhere,'' said Dennis Harms, who raises and sells fruits and vegetables in McHenry County, northwest of the metropolitan Chicago area. ``If this system works, we can help each other, cut out the middleman, lower our prices and compete with the big chain stores _ they're killing us.''

DOC.HEAD: `Fast Eddie' Edwin T. McBirney Pleads Innocent To Bank Fraud Charges
DOC.TEXT: A Sept. 4 trial date has been set for former thrift executive Edwin T. McBirney III, but his attorney says publicity surrounding the case may make it difficult to get a fair trial in Dallas. ``To schedule two press conferences (to announce the indictment), we think that exacerbates an already bad situation,'' attorney Paul Coggins said Thursday. Earlier in the day, his client, the former chairman of Sunbelt Savings Association of Texas, was arraigned on charges of bank fraud, misapplication of funds, false entries and making false statements. Coggins has until July 30 to ask U.S. District Judge Robert Maloney to move the trial. McBirney, who entered an innocent plea, is one of several former thrift executives targeted for prosecution in investigations looking for fraud in the multibillion-dollar collapse of the savings and loan industry. He was indicted last week by one of three federal grand juries in Dallas hearing bank fraud cases. The charges were announced in simultaneous news conferences in Dallas and Washington, where U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh conducted the briefing. McBirney, 37, faces up to 85 years in jail and a fine of $4.5 million if convicted. He remains free on his own recognizance. Dallas-based Sunbelt, nicknamed ``Gunbelt Savings'' for its freewheeling deals, grew 5,000 fold from 1982, when McBirney and five associates bought the thrift, until 1986, when government regulators forced him out. Sunbelt failed two years later in a bailout regulators estimate will cost taxpayers $2 billion. The 17-count indictment accuses McBirney of promising another thrift a $6 million profit on one transaction in return for help in financing a $700 million real estate deal in California. Investigators say the deal was one of the reasons Sunbelt failed. According to the indictment, McBirney guaranteed Western Savings Association, also of Dallas, a $6 million profit on any property it wished to sell. In return, Western was to provide $30 million to help finance the $700 million deal by Sun Cal, a Sunbelt subsidiary. McBirney directed Sunbelt officials to loan $22.6 million to an unidentified purchaser to buy a 708-acre tract north of Dallas valued at $13 million, the indictment says. The indictment claims McBirney made additional loans to keep the original loan out of default, and then altered records to hide the deals from Sunbelt and government auditors. Thirteen former Sunbelt executives, borrowers or McBirney associates have been convicted as a result of the 2{-yearlong Sunbelt investigation. Sunbelt, Western and six other thrifts were declared insolvent in 1988, and packaged into a new institution, Sunbelt Savings, Federal Savings Bank, owned by depositors.

DOC.HEAD: Three Bidders For Ford Aerospace
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. has received three bids for its aerospace subsidiary and may choose one within a week, a spokesman said. Company spokesman Tom Rhoades said Thursday that one of the bids involves a subsidiary of archrival General Motors Corp. He declined to say how much money was offered in any of the proposals. ``We would narrow it down to a single bidder sometime next week,'' he said. ``It could be earlier.'' Ford Aerospace, which has contracts with the Defense Department and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, was put up for sale Jan. 12. Chrysler Corp. and Ford put their prime defense contracting subsidiaries on the block as speculation grew that the government would drastically cut back its purchasing because of reduced tensions with the Soviet Union. The automakers said they wanted to focus on their core businesses of making, financing and selling cars and trucks. Chrysler sold its Gulfstream Aerospace Corp. subsidiary in February for $825 million. GM has said it does not plan to sell its main defense subsidiary, GM-Hughes Electronic Corp., which includes Hughes Aircraft Co. and Delco Electronics Corp. Rhoades said one of the three bids came as a joint effort between GM-Hughes and Alcatel Co. of France. The others are from Loral Corp., a New York defense electronics company, and a consortium of Westinghouse Electric Corp., the investment firm Carlyle Group, and Aerospatiale of France, which is connected with the Airbus aircraft. Loral spokeswoman Elizabeth Allen confirmed the company had submitted a bid, but declined to disclose details or say when she expected a decision from Ford. Ford Aerospace's operations and products include the Sidewinder air-to-air missile, space vehicles including the INTELSAT communications satellite and computer programs. The company received an estimated $1.8 billion in contracts last year. The wholly owned subsidiary, based in Newport Beach, Calif., employs about 17,000 people.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher Against Yen, Nikkei Down
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against the yen in light trading today, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply following the arrest of the leader of a speculator group. The dollar closed at 148.35 yen, up 0.75 yen from Thursday's finish of 147.60 yen. It opened at 148.15 yen and fluctuated between 147.90 yen and 148.40 yen. Meanwhile, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 634.10 points, or 1.92 percent, and closed at 32.421.52. The benchmark index had gained 7.51 points on Thursday. It was the sharpest single-day decline since April 16, when the Nikkei index shed 750.74 points and fell to 28,463.18. Volume on the first section was estimated at 500 million shares, compared with Thursday's 600 million. In bond dealings, the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond stood at 86.14 points as of 5:00 p.m., down from Thursday's close of 86.54 points. The yield was 7.385 percent, up from 7.295 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar moved in a narrow range and dealing was slow. ``It's because there are no fresh incentives to make major movements in the last trading day of the week,'' said Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank. On the stock market, declining first-section issues outpaced advancing issues 738 to 224, while 159 others remained unchanged. Traders attributed the drop to Thursday's arrest of the leader of the speculator group Koshin. The leader and a former construction company executive were arrested on charges of engaging in stock price manipulation involving Fujita Tourist Enterprise Co. Arbitrage selling and a softened bond market also contributed to the lower share prices, said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities. ``Since the yen-dollar rates are stable, share prices might bounce back early next week despite the lower bond prices,'' Inoue said.

DOC.HEAD: House Democrats Pushing Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs after 12th graf bgng The administration ... to update with Thornburgh comment.
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats plan quick committee approval of a major civil rights bill for workers while remaining open to a compromise aimed at heading off a presidential veto over hiring quotas. ``We will listen respectfully'' to any administration proposals, Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., said Thursday as lawmakers laid the groundwork for action on the bill in the Judiciary Committee next week. He suggested, though, that changes designed to ease administration concerns could be fairly modest. ``We're going to be discussing one or two items that could make them feel a little better,'' he said. The measure, which tops the civil rights movement's legislative agenda, won Senate approval, 65-34, Wednesday night. The margin of approval was two votes short of the two-thirds needed to overturn a presidential veto. Despite the plan for quick committee action, House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said the measure probably would not reach the floor until September. He said the reason was a logjam of bills awaiting action. Provisions of the bill, which would effectively reverse five Supreme Court decisions last year, range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages for discrimination victims in extreme cases. The sharpest clashes have come over a provision designed to overcome a Supreme Court ruling that favors companies in certain discrimination suits. In these suits, companies are charged with discrimination because their percentage of minority employees is smaller than the percentage of qualified minority workers in the local labor force. Until last year, companies could win if they proved that the employment practices leading to the disparity were required by ``business necessity.'' The new ruling made it easier for employers, placing on those filing suit the burden of proving the practices in question were not business necessities. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., the chief Senate sponsor, said he and White House officials bargained for weeks over the definition of business necessity but could never fully cement an agreement. Kennedy said that in the final hours before the vote, they spoke of including two definitions but could not agree on which one would cover issues such as hiring, firing and promotions. The administration maintains that in its current form, the definition would force employers to hire by quota as a way of making certain that they comply with the law. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today the administration was ``regrouping'' and was prepared to continue negotiations with the bill's supporters to reach a compromise. The president wants ``to rule out quotas and rule in maximum employment opportunities for Americans,'' Thornburgh said on CBS ``This Morning.'' He added, however, ``The president will not sign a quota bill. That's not in the American tradition.'' President Bush has said repeatedly that he wants a bill to fight job discrimination but not one that would lead to quotas. ``I'm still hopeful that eventually we'll get something worked out _ I think it's important for the country,'' Kennedy told reporters. Republicans suggested that Democrats have to be concerned about the possibility that they could not override the presidential veto that has been threatened if the bill reaches Bush in its current form. ``It's obvious that 34 (Senate) votes are enough to sustain a veto,'' said Rep. James Sensenbrenner, R-Wis. Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said he expected the panel to approve the bill without any changes Tuesday but added there could be compromise eventually. ``They haven't worked out any compromise with me or Mr. Edwards,'' he said. ``I want it written down. I want to take a look at their suggestions.''

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Company Agrees to Pay $80 Million for Chromium Cleanup
DOC.TEXT: A chemical maker has agreed to pay New Jersey $80 million to clean up homes and businesses contaminated with chromium waste. PPG Industries Inc. of Pittsburgh also consented Thursday to pay a $2.5 million fine and $900,000 for administrative costs. ``The state is satisfied with this agreement,'' said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. ``Certainly it will go a long way toward revitalizing Jersey City.'' The state blamed the company and two other companies for the chromium contamination of homes and businesses in Jersey City, Kearny and Secaucus. Exposure to chromium can damage lungs, livers and kidneys, cause skin lesions and, in some cases, cause lung cancer. Chromium is a byproduct created in the extraction of chrome for bumpers, chemicals and electrical components. The three companies are successors to companies that ran chromium processing plants in the area from 1905 to 1971. They sold or gave away chromium-tainted slag for landfill. Occidental Chemical Corp. of Dallas agreed in May to pay the state $51.5 million for cleanup and a $2.5 million fine. The state was still negotiating with the third company, Allied-Signal Inc. of Morris Township. State officials estimate as much as 3 million tons of chromium is buried under houses and businesses in Hudson County.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Move Higher
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices advanced Friday with dealers reporting strong underlying investor support despite an explosion at the Stock Exchange building. The blast failed to interrupt trading in regular shares, which is conducted on a computer screen-based system. However, the explosion did close the floor-based London Traded Options Market. As a result, equity market makers were unable to use traded options as an aid to market direction, traders said. One dealer said that in the absence of options trading, market makers were moving prices more than usual to seek out buying and selling sentiment and gauge the market better. But traders also detected strong investor buying interest. ``It's probably the first time'' in several months that genuine buying interest has surfaced, a dealer said. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was up 11 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,398.3. Calculations of volume were unavailable while the Stock Exchange building was evacuated. However, traders described volume as light. By midday Thursday, 233.3 million shares were traded.

DOC.HEAD: Source: Kuwait Cancels State of Alert in Dispute with Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to RAISE HIGHER that Kuwaitis still fleeing Iraq, Baghdad hasn't retracted its charges. Pickup 5th, `Iraqi President...'
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait has canceled a state of alert it declared in an oil dispute with Iraq, a Kuwaiti source said. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, claimed Thursday that the crisis appeared to have passed like ``a summer cloud.'' However, officials in Baghdad reported that thousands of Kuwaitis visiting Iraq were heading home. And Iraqi dailies continued to accuse Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of ``usurping Iraq's rights.'' The alert followed Iraqi charges that Kuwait had stolen Iraqi oil worth $2.4 billion, and Iraqi threats of retaliation. Kuwait had appealed to other Arab states for support in the dispute with its much more powerful neighbor. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein on Thursday tightened his grip on power, winning support from his rubber-stamp parliament for a presidency for life. The developments underscored simmering tensions in the Persian Gulf. The region includes about two-thirds of the world's proven oil reserves, so instability can pose a threat to the world's oil supply. Baghdad in recent days had denounced Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for exceeding production quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, or OPEC. Iraq says falling oil prices brought on by the oil glut have robbed it of $14 billion in revenues the past year, and Saddam this week accused quota violators of stabbing Iraq in the back ``with a poisoned dagger.'' In seeking to defuse the crisis, Kuwait on Thursday solicited Arab League help in settling its longstanding border dispute with Iraq. The small sultanate enlisted the help of influential Saudi Arabia in easing tensions, and its diplomats fanned out across the Middle East. A major factor in the Kuwaiti and Saudi responses has been fears that the quarrel could disrupt an OPEC conference, set to begin next Thursday in Geneva, on production and pricing policy. Both Kuwait and the U.A.E. have promised to cut oil production in line with the quotas decreed by the 13-member cartel. Also, oil prices _ which had dipped to $14 a barrel recently _ have recovered to around OPEC's benchmark level of $18 a barrel. Some Kuwaiti officials and diplomats suggested that Saddam's accusations are aimed at winning a writeoff of a debt of $30 billion to Kuwait and Saudi Arabia. The two poured the money into Iraq during the 1980-88 war against Iran to prop up its economy and pay for weapons. Kuwait's appeal for help in settling the border dispute was made in a memorandum sent to the Arab League headquarters in Tunis. The Kuwait News Agency quoted the memo as suggesting that a committee be formed to resolve the question ``on the basis of treaties and existing documents.'' Iraq this week accused Kuwait of border incursions including the pumping of $2.4 billion worth of oil in the past decade from an Iraqi oil field near the boundary. Kuwait's foreign minister, Sheikh Sabah al-Ahmed, said Kuwait was producing oil from fields ``well within its territory.'' Meanwhile, the official Iraqi News Agency reported that the Iraqi Parliament had expressed support for Saddam becoming president for life. The Iraqi News Agency said the 250-member legislature, dominated by Saddam's party, called for changes in a new draft constitution that would have provided for presidential elections. Iraq has held no such balloting since becoming a republic in 1958. The constitution is subject to public vote expected later this year. Saddam, who has been in power since July 1979, exercises near-total rule over Iraq's 17 million people through his vast security apparatus. He has turned his reign into a personality cult that has reached the realms of near-mythology. Photos and posters of him are seen everywhere in Iraq, and it is a capital offense to insult him publicly.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Exchange Blast Did Not Disrupt Share Trading
With PM-Britain-Blast
DOC.TEXT: The explosion of a bomb in the building housing London's Stock Exchange did not disrupt stock trading today because share dealing takes place away from the exchange floor. There were no injuries in the blast, although it caused extensive damage. Share prices actually rose during the incident. By about 12:15 p.m. (7:15 a.m. EDT), the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 11 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,398.3. Options trading was disrupted, however. The exchange building's largely deserted, ground-level trading floor houses the London Traded Options Market. Options are the right to buy or sell shares at a fixed price before a specific date. Since Britain's huge ``Big Bang'' deregulation nearly four years ago, British and foreign shares have been traded by telephones and computers away from the Stock Exchange's modern tower in the heart of the City of London, the financial district. The explosion, in a restroom near the exchange's floor viewing gallery, came at 8:49 a.m. (3:49 a.m. EDT), 40 minutes after a telephone warning of an Irish Republican Army bomb, police said. The building on Broad Street was evacuated before the bomb exploded. Under the British stock trading system, ``market makers'' at scattered, designated investment firms track markets in different stocks. The exchange requires them to quote prices continuously through the official trading day, which runs from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. Trading also is allowed to take place outside official hours. The market makers' prices appear on the exchange's computerized price quotations system, SEAQ International. The London market is Europe's biggest and forms part of the so-called ``Golden Triangle'' with Tokyo and New York. On the New York and Tokyo stock exchange, specialists in stocks conduct buying and selling on the floor. The London exchange has been studying what it should do with its deserted floor. The options market plans to move out. Visitors still flock to the exchange's viewing gallery over the floor, where the familiar hexagonal stations, but not the bustling activity, remain. The visitors' entrance is separate from the exchange's main entrance. A security guard inspects' visitors' bags.

DOC.HEAD: S&L Bailout Fund May be Out of Money by October, RTC Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd pvs, bgng: The bottom, with bailout cost figures
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's savings and loan bailout fund will be nearly out of money if officials reach their goal of closing or selling 77 institutions by Sept. 30, a federal agency says. Figures provided Thursday by the Resolution Trust Corp. Oversight Board indicate that, unless Congress authorizes more borrowing, regulators could have as little as $7.3 billion in borrowing authority left when the new federal fiscal year begins Oct. 1. ``The bottom line ... (is) it would cause us to very significantly reduce the pace of resolutions,'' said Peter Monroe, president of the oversight board. Congress last year allocated $50 billion to cover S&L losses and the oversight board estimates that after the 77 resolutions are finished, $37 billion of that will have been used. However, the agency will hit a cash crunch before the $50 billion is exhausted because of legal caps on its short-term borrowing. In addition to the $7.3 billion, the agency could spend any money it can get by selling repossessed real estate and sour loans inherited from previous S&L bailouts, he said. If Congress doesn't provide more money before adjourning for the November elections, the government will be forced to slow the pace of the bailout or dramatically increase the pace of asset sales, Monroe said. His comments, combined with the new figures, are the clearest indication yet from the administration about the urgency of providing additional bailout funds. In appearances before congressional panels in May and June, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady roughly doubled the administration's August 1989 estimate of the bailout cost from $50 billion to between $90 billion and $130 billion. He had said additional money would be needed by the end of December or early next year. Monroe's figures indicate that, at the current pace, the bailout will run out of money soon after Sept. 30. So far, the trust corporation has ``resolved'' the cases of 210 S&Ls, leaving roughly 250 insolvent thrifts open and under government control. At least an additional 250 institutions still under private ownership are expected to fail. ``We're two-sevenths of the way through,'' Monroe said. Because money is scarce, officials will concentrate this quarter on closing the S&Ls that are losing money the fastest, he said. In any case, officials will ``never go back'' to the type of deals done in 1988 by the now-dismantled Federal Home Loan Bank Board, Monroe said. Because the bank board lacked cash to pay off depositors, it attracted S&L acquirers through guarantees and other subsidies extending up to 10 years. The 1988 transactions are coming under increasing criticism in Congress because they virtually ensured lucrative returns to S&L buyers who made only a small investment. The oversight board authorized the trust corporation to borrow up to $34 billion through the Treasury for the 77 resolutions in the July-September period. This ``working capital'' borrowing would be repaid as the government sells S&L assets. In other developments Thursday: _ Angry Northeastern and Midwestern House members said they were introducing a bill to force states with a disproportionate share of troubled thrifts, such as Texas and California, to pay a bigger portion of bailout costs. If a state declines to pay, its state-chartered thrifts no longer would be eligible for federal deposit insurance. Other legislation, sponsored by Rep. Joe Kennedy, D-Mass., would force wealthy Americans to pay more of the cost. His bill would raise $100 billion over five years by imposing new income taxes on individuals earning more than $100,000 a year and corporations earning more than $75,000 a year. It also would eliminate a provision that forgives inheritance taxes on capital gains at death. _The Justice Department said it had uncovered ``certain S&L cases'' where thrift institutions had swapped bad loans with each other to avoid regulatory scrutiny. But spokesman Doug Tillett said ``the department has no evidence at this time that suggests the existence of a large-scale conspiracy'' among thrifts to trade bad loans. _In Dallas, former Sunbelt Savings Association Chairman Edwin T. McBirney III, known as ``Fast Eddie,'' pleaded innocent to bank fraud charges. Sunbelt failed in 1988 at an estimated cost to the government of $2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, UAW Open Contract Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs with talks beginning; picks up 2nd graf pvs, The UAW ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: National contract negotiations between the United Auto Workers and the nation's Big Three automakers got into full swing as talks began today between the union and Chrysler Corp. UAW President Owen Bieber and Chrysler Motors President Robert Lutz reached across a large table to shake hands and both sides then got down to business. The UAW started negotiations for new three-year labor agreements on Wednesday with General Motors Corp. and Thursday with Ford Motor Co. All three current contracts expire Sept. 14. At Chrysler, the union will be dealing with the automaker in the worst financial shape of the Big Three. Since Oct. 1, Chrysler has been involved in a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program designed to boost profits. But car and truck sales for the automaker were running 13 percent behind 1989's pace at midyear, while Ford's sales were off 7.8 percent and GM's were down 3.5 percent. In May, the automaker reported it earned $71 million in the first quarter of this year, down 80 percent from the same time last year. In the second quarter, analysts expect Chrysler to make a little more than half of the $341 million it earned during the second three months of last year. In 1989, Chrysler made $359 million, far less than the $3.8 billion Ford made and the $4.2 billion GM earned. Chrysler's earnings were too small to kick in profit-sharing provisions for its hourly workers and, consequently, bonuses for salaried employees. Nonetheless, the union's initial demands are expected to be the same at Chrysler as at GM and Ford _ enhanced job security, wage and pension improvements and protection of health-care benefits. The reaction from Chrysler's management, however, is likely to be far different from responses at GM and Ford. Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John, who heads the company's negotiating team, has said if current contract provisions simply are rolled over for another three years, it would boost the automaker's labor costs by 16 percent. St. John said Chrysler can't afford that. His statements have given rise to theories that the death of pattern bargaining in the auto industry may be at hand. If tradition holds, sometime around Labor Day, the UAW will choose one company and focus negotiating efforts there. After an agreement is reached, that contract would be used as a model for talks at the other companies. But St. John's gloomy outlook for the talks may indicate the No. 3 U.S. automaker doesn't think it will be able to match contract provisions negotiated between the union and Ford and GM. There were no such dire economic predictions from GM or Ford management after hearing UAW statements earlier this week. As expected, the union said it was outraged at GM's closures of four assembly plants during the past three years, and it criticized Ford for its extensive use of overtime. The companies said they were looking for more flexibility in work rules, schedules and the way plants' work forces are structured. The contracts between the union and the Big Three cover more than 450,000 workers and nearly as many retirees. It's the first time since 1979 that all of the contracts have expired at the same time.

DOC.HEAD: Third Sprint Executive This Month Quits
DOC.TEXT: The architect of US Sprint's successful bid for a share of a $25 billion federal contract has resigned, the company said. Sprint confirmed Thursday the resignation of David C. Gergacz, chief operating officer of its government network systems division, but provided no other details. Gergacz, 41, could not be reached for comment. He is the third key executive to leave Sprint this month. Clifford R. Hall, who was credited with solving serious billing problems at Sprint, resigned two weeks ago. Jerry W. Cosley, vice president of communications at Sprint and United Telecommunications Inc., also announced his resignation. United Telecom is Sprint's majority owner. Earlier this week, Sprint reported a $42 million net operating loss in the second quarter. But Sprint spokesman Syd Courson said Gergacz's resignation was unrelatedto the earnings problems. ``Basically, he just resigned to look for other opportunities,'' Courson said. Gary Forsee, 40, has been appointed Gergacz's successor, Courson said. Forsee joined Sprint in December from American Telephone & Telegraph Co., where he was responsible for AT&T's part of the $25 billion FTS 2000 contract to upgrade the federal government's phone system. In late 1988 Sprint was selected to provide 40 percent of the service, with AT&T providing the remainder.

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Announces Earnings Slumped in 2nd Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. reported today its earnings fell 67 percent in the second quarter, a confirmation of the company's earlier projection of a sharp decline in profits. The construction equipment manufacturer said it earned $46 million, or 46 cents per share, down from $141 million, or $1.39 per share, in the same period of 1989. Revenue for the quarter totaled $2.95 billion, a 3 percent drop from the same period last year when Caterpillar recorded $3 billion in revenue. The company attributed the decline to an 8 percent drop in sales volume, which was offset in part by higher prices and a $19 million improvement in revenue from Caterpillar's financial subsidiaries. In a statement, the company blamed its sagging profits on a lower demand for machines among many industrial nations. On June 25, Caterpillar announced that new economic policies in Brazil were having a disastrous impact on the company's profits. The company projected a dramatic decline in second quarter earnings, which were less than half the $99 million earned in the first quarter. It also revised its economic outlook for the year, saying its profits for the entire year would be stagnant when compared to 1989. Sales inside the United States were $1.3 billion for the quarter, a drop of $59 million from last year. Sales outside the United States were $1.5 billion, a decline of $54 million from the second quarter 1989. For the first six months of the year, Caterpillar's profits stood at $145 million, or $1.43 per share, down from $282 million, or $2.78 per share, in the first half of 1989. Revenue for the first half totaled $5.8 billion, up from $5.72 billion a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Midwestern Rain Dampens Corn, Soybean Futures
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trades as beneficial showers in the Midwestern croplands dampened buying interest. ``It's very hard to support the market in July when it's raining,'' said Steve Freed, grains analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. Showers began in the region Wednesday night and were expected to continue at least through Saturday. Further selling in the soybean market reflected a weaker European market for soybean meal after several days of active trading that had been supporting the U.S. soybean complex. Wheat futures were mixed to higher in a slight rebound from Thursday's moderate decline. Contracts for all July deliveries of grains and soybeans expire today. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in July at $2.97 a bushel; corn was { cent lower to { cent higher with July at $2.69\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1{ cents lower with July at $1.16 a bushel; soybeans were 2\ cents to 6{ cents lower with July at $6.00\ a bushel. DOC.HEAD: Explosion Damages Stock Exchange; No Injuries Reported
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to description of bomb scene, type of bomb used, report of eight warning calls. Pickup 14th, `I am...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LON5,10,9,12,21
DOC.TEXT: An explosion in a restroom caused extensive damage at the Stock Exchange today, 40 minutes after a telephone warning of an Irish Republican Army bomb, police said. No injuries were reported. City of London Police said the building in the heart of London's financial district was evacuated before the blast at 8:49 a.m. The explosion tore a hole about 20 feet high and seven feet wide in the modern concrete building, about 10 feet above ground level facing Old Broad Street. Glass and hunks of concrete littered the street. Hugh Moore, commander of City of London Police, said warnings were telephoned to his department, the exchange and to the Reuters news agency. George Churchill-Coleman, commander of Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist unit, said there were eight warning calls in all. The bomb, which contained 5 to 10 pounds of high explosives, was in a men's restroom near the visitors' gallery, said Churchill-Coleman. Asked whether the IRA was responsible, he told reporters, ``That's a reasonable assumption.'' Churchill-Coleman said the visitors' gallery had not open at the time of the explosion. He said it was not known when the device was planted. ``People would have been killed if they had been in the building at the time,'' Moore said. A uniformed guard normally searches bags and parcels carried by visitors before they enter the gallery, which accommodates up to 100 people. The National Westminster bank, near the exchange, was cordoned off and searched following another bomb warning, police said. The Royal Bank of Scotland building across from the exchange was also evacuated. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, reported that one caller who telephoned a warning said: ``This is the IRA. The bomb is due to go off in half an hour at the Stock Exchange.'' The caller then gave a code word recognized by police and said, ``Clear the building,'' the news agency reported. The IRA is fighting to end British rule of Northern Ireland. ``I am horrified that any group would take the risk of so many people's lives in a public building,'' said Andrew Hugh Smith, chairman of the Stock Exchange. ``The timing of the bomb and the warning _ they all could have gone very wrong.'' The exchange's computerized stock trading system was not interrupted, but options trading was suspended. Smith said options trading would resume Monday. He said about 600 people normally work on the options floor. Share prices rose marginally following the explosion. Sharon Reilly, who was among those evacuated from the exchange, said: ``There wasn't panic. People were in high spirits, curious. They just thought it was a fire.'' Police initially reported that the explosion started a fire inside the structure, but a spokesman for the London Fire Brigade said: ``We believe there is no fire situation in the building.'' Joe Phillips, a 21-year-old options trader, said a recorded warning was broadcast inside the exchange. ``Normally they say this was a test, but a proper voice came on the tannoy (address system) saying, `This is not a test. Get out of the building,''' he said. There had been 30 to 40 people on the trading floor, standing around reading The Financial Times, looking at their screens and waiting for trading to start, Phillips said. A large proportion of the Stock Exchange's staff of almost 2,600 work in the building. There has been no stock trading there since the exchange was computerized in 1986, but options are traded in the building. On June 25, an IRA bomb injured more than 20 people, two of them seriously, at the Carlton Club, a gathering place for the ruling Conservative Party. On June 20, two British army sergeants were injured when a bomb ripped through a military van in Leicester in central England. The IRA wants the mainly Protestant province of Northern Ireland to unite it with the Irish Republic, which is predominantly Roman Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Defeats Effort to Amend Acreage-Reduction Program in Farm Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of government management of grain supplies fought off an effort in the Senate today to change the 1990 farm bill so farmers can plant more acres. The Senate voted 50-37 against a proposal by Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., to amend the acreage-reduction program in the bill. Boschwitz said the program would hurt U.S. ability to compete on the world grain market by requiring farmers to idle some of the most fertile land in the country. ``We have forgone production and in the process given the markets to the Europeans,'' said Boschwitz. But supporters of the bill's provision said it was needed to keep prices for grain stable by controlling the size of surpluses. Stability is the object of the farm bill, said Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., The Boschwitz amendment was the second major attack on the Senate Agriculture Committee's bill to set farm policy for the next five years. The first came Thursday when Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nev., tried unsuccessfully to eliminate subsidies to farmers with gross sales over $500,000 a year. ``The American taxpayer shells out $1.2 billion each year to millionaires who own farms,'' Reid said. ``Why are we concerned about protecting these farmer fat cats?'' He said his amendment would affect only one-half of 1 percent of the farmers in the country. But the idea was opposed by Senate Agriculture Committee members who said it would inevitably hurt family farms. Sen. David Boren, D-Okla., said farmers who gross $500,000 don't necessarily net any more than a factory worker once expenses are paid. Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the committee, added, ``It is not hard to see how farmers could subdivide their businesses to evade this amendment if they were so inclined.'' He said the amendment's requirement that farmers submit their tax returns to county agents as proof of gross earnings would be an invasion of privacy. ``It would also lead to an auditing problem that is very substantial if what was once a farm of $500,000 now becomes 10 farms of $50,000 and 10 returns where various relatives are involved,'' Lugar said. The amendment was defeated 66-30. The Senate did, however, reduce the overall cost of the bill to bring it into line with tight budget demands. An amendment offered by Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., and passed on voice vote, reduced proposed commodity supports in the Senate bill to a five-year cost of $54 billion. That's $8 million below the amount approved for agriculture in the Senate budget resolution last month. It's unlikely, however, that the cut will satisfy the Bush administration, which has threatened a veto unless ``substantial, multi-year savings'' are made. The administration doesn't want Congress to finish its bill until negotiations with White House over the budget are complete. Agriculture and defense are two key areas expected to be cut significantly. ``The administration expects the budget summit to achieve substantial, multi-year savings,'' said a statement from the Office of Management and Budget. ``It would be a mistake for Congress to complete action on a bill that gives producers the wrong impression by sending them inaccurate signals about likely program parameters.'' Leahy said he couldn't predict what would be included in a summit agreement. ``But this much is certain,'' he said. ``The senator from Indiana (Lugar) and I are committed to making necessary budget savings.'' Among major provisions, the bill would: _Freeze current target prices and loan rates. _Create mandatory marketing loans on wheat and feed grains. _Moderately increase planting flexibility. _Establish a new program for oilseed production. _Improve the quality of grain. _Ban the export of pesticides that are outlawed for use in the United States. _Give better protection to fragile wetlands. _Give farmers incentives to prevent contamination of groundwater. _Encourage reduced use of pesticides. _Establish a labeling system for organically grown products. _Change the foreign food aid program to make giveaways to needy countries easier. _Revise forestry laws.

DOC.HEAD: MCA Quarterly Net Up 7 Percent, Says It's Buying a Stake in Harvey Comics
DOC.TEXT: MCA Inc. reported its second-quarter earnings rose 7 percent and that it had agreed to buy a minority stake in Harvey Comics, creator of Casper the Friendly Ghost, Richie Rich and Baby Huey. The entertainment conglomerate earned $44.8 million, up from $41.9 million during the same period in 1989. Per-share earnings fell from 58 cents to 54 cents because of MCA's purchase of Geffen Records in April. MCA bought the company by issuing David Geffen 1 million shares of preferred stock, convertible to 10 million shares of common stock. That diluted the earning power of shares issued earlier. MCA's revenue reached record levels, jumping 15 percent from $828 million to $950 million. Heavy contributors were theatrical film revenue, which rose from $93 million to $143 million due to the successful ``Back to the Future III'' and ``Bird on a Wire,'' and music entertainment, up from $197 million to $250 million. MCA includes domestic home video fees in the latter category. Revenue from MCA's Universal Studios Tour in Universal City fell from $38.2 million to $35.9 million last year, when the popular ``Earthquake'' attraction opened. Notably absent were results from a $630 million studio theme park that MCA opened six weeks ago in Orlando, Fla. Some attractions, including the King Kong and earthquake rides, have been knocked out by software problems. MCA said it did not report results because the park was not fully operational. Its rival, Walt Disney Co., has run a separate studio theme park not far away for a little over a year, and MCA's attraction had been seen as possibly taking away visitors there. But Disney said Tuesday that attendance at its park was up 20 percent in May and June compared with the year before. For the first six months of the year, MCA's net income rose 10 percent to $76.4 million, or 96 cents per share, from $69.3 million, or 95 cents per share. Revenue rose 22 percent to $1.86 billion from $1.53 billion. MCA's agreement in principle to buy an interest in Harvey Comics Entertainment is a clear if minor example of how crucial well-known characters are to entertainment giants like MCA or Disney. Characters such as Casper, Richie Rich and Baby Huey can be exploited around the world in movies, TV, home video, theme parks and books, separately or in combination with characters to which MCA already owns rights, said Thomas P. Pollock, the chairman of MCA's motion picture group. In a telephone interview, Pollock said MCA was impressed with Jeffrey A. Montgomery, who was just 25 when he raised money to buy the dormant, family-owned Harvey last year. Pollock said MCA was supplying funds, marketing and distribution and some manufacturing as part of the deal. Exact terms weren't announced, but Montgomery reportedly paid $6 million for Harvey last summer. ``We're helping them to help themselves,'' Pollock said. ``We're a minority partner in the deal, making an equity investment. He owns the characters and he's running it.''

DOC.HEAD: Second-Quarter Profit Up at Media General, Off at McClatchy, Multimedia
DOC.TEXT: Media General Inc. said Friday its second-quarter profit more than doubled from a year ago, largely because of a gain on the sale of its West Coast weekly newspapers and its receipt of overdue newsprint royalties. But earnings for the quarter fell 22 percent at McClatchy Newspapers Inc. and were down 12.5 percent at Multimedia Inc. McClatchy, based in Sacramento, Calif., cited startup losses from a newsprint mill partnership and costs associated with its purchase of six newspapers in South Carolina earlier this year for its profit decline. Multimedia, based in Greenville, S.C., pointed to a sluggish environment for retail and automotive advertising as well as a onetime debt refinancing loss. McClatchy and Multimedia reported their results Thursday.

The Richmond, Va.-based Media General said it earned $12.5 million, or 48 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30 compared with $6.1 million, or 23 cents a share, a year earlier. Second-quarter revenue rose 5.4 percent to $158.0 million from $149.9 million a year earlier. The latest results included an after-tax contribution of $6.4 million, or 24 cents a share, from the sale of its Golden West-Highlander weekly newspapers and receipt of past-due royalty payments from its Mexican newsprint affiliate. The sluggish economic climate depressed both retail and classified advertising at the company's newspapers in Richmond, Tampa, Fla., and Winston-Salem, N.C., the company said. But strong growth in the company's cable operation in Fairfax, Va., helped lift the company's revenue and earnings from its broadcast division. The ad slump left ad revenues below expectations at the company's three TV stations. ``While it appears that the advertising environment will be troublesome through the rest of the year, we remain convinced that the restructured Media General is well positioned to benefit when the economic climate for advertising improves,'' said J. Stewart Bryan III, chairman and chief executive. For the first half, Media General earned $15.1 million, or 58 cents a share, down from $17.9 million, or 69 cents a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose 1.7 percent to $151 million from $148.4 million a year earlier. The first-half results for 1989 included a $5.7 million gain after taxes on the sale of a newsprint mill in California.

McClatchy said it earned $7.8 million, or 27 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with $10 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. Without the newsprint mill startup costs and newspaper purchases, the company said it would have earned 34 cents a share in the quarter. Second-quarter revenue rose 10.6 percent to $107.6 million from $97.3 million a year earlier. Operating income was up 4.3 percent to $17.1 million from $16.4 million a year earlier. For the first half, the company said it earned $10.2 million, or 36 cents a share, down 31.1 percent from $14.8 million, or 52 cents a share. First-half revenue rose 10.3 percent to $202.7 million from $184.3 million a year earlier. McClatchy publishes 11 daily newspapers and eight non-daily newspapers and a group of tabloids for senior citizens.

Multimedia said it earned $9.6 million, or 77 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30, compared with $10.8 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 2.4 percent to $123.9 million from $121.0 million a year earlier. The latest results reflected an extraordinary loss of $3.1 million from refinancing its longterm debt of $718 million on June 29. Newspaper and broadcasting ad revenues lagged last year's results because of a sluggish retail and automotive advertising environment, the company said. For the first half, Multimedia earned $15.7 million, or $1.26 a share, up from $15.4 million, or $1.24 a share, a year earlier. First-half revenue rose to $233.7 million from $227.3 million. Multimedia publishes 13 daily and 49 non-daily newspapers, owns and operates four TV and eight radio stations, operates more than 100 cable TV franchises and syndicates TV programs such as the Phil Donahue and Sally Jessy Raphael shows.

DOC.HEAD: American Brands to Buy Moen Group
DOC.TEXT: American Brands Inc., moving to take advantage of the lucrative home remodeling market, said Friday it would buy The Moen Group, a plumbing fixture manufacturer, for $975 million in cash. ``Repair and remodeling is what's become hot today,'' said Robert Rukeyser, spokesman for American Brands. ``People are staying in their homes longer and they are keeping them operating properly. ... The focus of improvement is in kitchen and bath.'' Repair and remodeling represents 70 percent of Moen's business, Rukheyser said. American Brands is a conglomerate of liquor, office products, tobacco and life insurance businesses. Its MasterBrand Industries Inc. subsidiary reached the tentative agreement to buy Moen from its owner, Forstmann Little & Co., late Thursday night, Rukeyser said. MasterBrand Industries includes Master Lock, makers of doorsets; Aristokraft, a manufacturer of kitchen cabinets and bathroom vanities; and Twentieth Century, a plumbing supply company. Moen, based in Elyria, Ohio, had earnings of $97 million last year before depreciation and amortization, interest and taxes. American Brands also announced it intends to sell its Waterloo Industries hardware business, which makes toolboxes, because it doesn't fit with MasterBrand's focus. American Brands on Friday reported its second-quarter earnings rose 31.8 percent, $158.4 million or $1.62 per common share from $120.2 million or $1.25 per common share a year earlier. Revenue in the quarter ending June 30 rose to $2.95 billion from $2.72 billion. For the first six months of 1990, American Brands said it earned $353.8 million, or $3.62 per share, up 21 percent from $292.4 million, or $3.05 per share, a year earlier. Revenue increased to $6.16 billion from $5.97 billion in the first half of 1989. Rukeyeser said the Moen purchase, which is subject to government approvals, gives American Brands a foothold in what it had defined three years ago as a core business. ``We've been making acquisitions now for just about 25 years, and I don't think that we'll ever be settled because the markets are changing and new opportunities are always arising,'' he said. ``But it's a very important step for us.'' American Brands' office products businesses have made it the largest manufacturer of office supplies in the world, Rukeyser said. Its divisions include Swingline and Day-Timers, he said. ``That's the kind of scale that we're trying to achieve in most of the businesses,'' he said. The company's cigarette brands include Carlton, Lucky Strike, Pall Mall, Tareyton and Malibu. In the liquor industry, American Brands owns Jim Beam bourbon, DeKuype liqueurs and Gilbey's gin and vodka.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Trading Carries On Despite Stock Exchange Bomb
With AM-Britain-Blast Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Although a bomb extensively damaged London's Stock Exchange Friday, it would take a large-scale computer failure to interfere with stock trading in London. Because stock trading no longer takes place on the exchange's floor but is now done via telephones and computers, the morning explosion in a restroom near the exchange-floor viewing gallery didn't disrupt business at the Stock Exchange's modern tower in the heart of the City of London. ``If the purpose of this callous act was to bring the City (financial district) to a halt, they have failed singularly,'' said Andrew Hugh Smith, chairman of the Stock Exchange. ``Our systems and services have functioned perfectly, and trading has continued as normal.'' Like other recent bombing incidents in Britain, this blast was linked to the Irish Republican Army's campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. Earlier attacks have been largely directed at police, army and government targets. The IRA, however, espouses a socialist future for a united Ireland, and stock exchanges are considered an obvious target for foes of capitalism. Exchanges employ entrance guards, bouncers and metal detactors to protect themselves from attack. Despite the explosion, prices rose. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 12.8 points, or 0.5 percent, at 2,400.1 at the close. Trading was active. Options trading was disrupted for the day, however. Although the exchange building is now largely deserted, the ground-level trading floor still houses the London Traded Options Market. Options are the right to buy or sell shares at a fixed price before a specific date. Since Britain's huge deregulation nearly four years ago _ known as the Big Bang _ traders no longer physically congregate in one place. Rather, designated investment firms make markets in different stocks and bonds via an electronic market run with computers. The exchange requires the 25 equities market makers to quote prices continuously through the official trading day, which runs from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. London time. Trading also is allowed to take place outside official hours. The market makers' prices appear on the exchange's computerized price quotations system, SEAQ International, which buyers and sellers can view on video display terminals. On the New York and Tokyo stock exchanges, trading physically takes place on the floor, conducted by market makers known as specialists. The London market is Europe's biggest and forms part of the so-called ``Golden Triangle'' with New York and Tokyo. There are more than 2,500 British and overseas companies listed on London's Stock Exchange. Average daily trading in domestic stocks is worth about $1.5 billion. Formally called the International Stock Exchange of the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland Ltd., it employs nearly 2,600 people who develop trading rules, list companies, record transactions and operate information systems. The tower, one of 14 buildings the exchange occupies, opened in 1973. Located in Broad Street, it is next to the Bank of England and across from the grand, columned Royal Exchange, which houses the London International Financial Futures Exchange. The London exchange has been studying what it should do with all its empty floor space. The options market plans to move out.
