DOC.HEAD: Australian Entrepreneur Can't Outrun $6 Billion in Debts
LaserPhotos LON22 and SYD1
DOC.TEXT: Financier Alan Bond has been making money on borrowed money since completing his first land deal in 1960 at age 22. It appears the bill finally has come due. Thirty years after he took out a loan on five acres of land at Perth in the first step toward building a multinational empire, the businessman and yachtsman has offered to quit as chairman of his flagship Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. to appease the company's anxious creditors, who are owed $6 billion. The agreement under which Bond will step down and relinquish control of his vast empire was reached Thursday. Although final details must still be worked out, the deal could clear the way for refinancing arrangements that could ultimately save many of Bond's businesses. It has been a long fall for Bond, known for brash and flamboyant dealings in business and elsewhere. He financed the Australian sailing team's stunning triumph over the United States in the 1983 America's Cup race. Only three years ago, he bought Vincent Van Gogh's ``Irises'' from Sotheby's for what was a then-record $53.9 million, a sale that the auction house helped him finance. In March, he sold the painting for an undisclosed amount amid reports he had taken a loss. Bond has never been lacking in confidence. After emigrating from Britain with his father to Perth, in Western Australia state, he quit school at age 14 and took a job with a sign-painting company, convincing the owner to take him on even though he did poorly on a spelling test. When things didn't work out, he and his father started a competitor, Nu-Signs, that provided the cash for some of his later deals. According to the biography released this week by journalist Paul Barry, ``The Rise and Fall of Alan Bond,'' the financier developed a strategy of keeping creditors at bay while buying and selling land in rapidly developing Perth. He reportedly was close to bankruptcy in 1962 after stringing along Nu-Signs' creditors too long, but managed to work out an arrangement at the last minute. The next day, he made a large purchase at a land auction. Barry wrote that with rising land prices, Bond often would agree to buy a plot, promising a small deposit, then have it immediately revalued at a higher price so he could borrow more money than had to be paid to the vendor. With a flair for picking the best development sites and promoting them well, he had been successful enough to make his first $1 million by 1969 at age 29. He took advantage of eager bankers peddling expensive credit, particularly after Australia's financial deregulation in 1983, and a stock market full of hungry investors. At its peak, Bond Corp. Holdings included interests in brewing, media, natural resources and property. He rode out the 1987 stock market crash on the cash-generating strength of his beer businesses. That actually may have led to his downfall, however, as Bond Corp. Holdings picked up steam and eventually ran up debts now estimated at about $6 billion. Rising interest rates and bad business decisions alienated Bond's bankers and creditors, put his Australian brewing interests into receivership and has forced him to sell assets ranging from a Hong Kong office development to a coal mine. There is speculation that the final straw for Bond may have come when he tangled with London-based financier R.W. ``Tiny'' Rowland. He bought 20.4 percent of Rowland's Lonrho PLC in 1988 in a move that appeared to presage a takeover attempt. He was forced to sell a year later, telling Australian television that he ``underestimated the venom on Tiny Rowland,'' who waged a campaign focusing on Bond's debt. Rowland is quoted in Barry's book as saying he decided to destroy Bond after the Australian tried to take his yacht's parking place on the French Riviera.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Talks in Full Swing
LaserPhotos DT14, DT15 of July 20
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. proposed a multi-employer health-care system Friday as it joined the rest of the Big Three automakers in contract negotiations with the United Auto Workers union. But the proposal drew a cool reception from General Motors Corp., which opened negotiations with the UAW on Wednesday, and Ford Motor Co., which began contract talks Thursday. The UAW offered no reaction Friday. Chrysler Vice President Anthony St. John said at a news conference following a ceremonial handshake to open talks that he proposes forming a trust to administer health-care programs for employees of several companies, including auto suppliers. Negotiators from each of the Big Three say containing health-care costs is a high priority in the current round of talks. In 1989, GM said it spent about $3 billion in health care costs, Ford spent about $813 million and Chrysler paid $684 million. St. John said under a multi-employer program, the size of the group covered by the plan could be huge, keeping costs down. He said participating companies could also avoid anticipated higher costs in 1993 when new Financial Accounting Standards Board regulations may take effect. The new regulations would require companies to set aside money for anticipated health costs. Chrysler figures that would be about $7 per hour per employee or just under $200 million a year. Chrysler says it currently pays for heath care and pension costs on a pay-as-you-go basis. Chrysler, in the worst financial shape of the Big Three, is expected to report by the end of the month that its second-quarter earnings were about half of the $341 million it made during the period last year. Wall Street analysts have speculated that Chrysler will lose money in the third quarter because its two minivan plants will be shut down for a month each to retool for 1991 models. The minivan is Chrysler's most profitable vehicle. Chrysler has acknowledged it expects a ``substantial'' third-quarter loss. GM, Ford and union negotiators so far have declined to talk about proposals which may have been advanced in the earliest stages of the talks. UAW contracts with each of the Big Three expire Sept. 14. In addition to the health-care proposal, St. John said he proposed an employee ownership plan, which he declined to detail, and something he called gain sharing, which would reward workers on a plant-by-plant basis based on the financial performance of that factory. In a separate news conference, UAW President Owen Bieber said the union issued the same broad proposals Friday as it had at GM and Ford the two days before. Those involved the need for more job security, wage and pension improvements and more time off. If negotiations proceed as they have in the past, the UAW will bargain with all three companies until sometime around Labor Day, and then select a strike target. Talks at the other two companies would be suspended. A contract reached at the target then would be taken to the other two companies in what is called ``pattern bargaining.'' There has been speculation Chrysler may break the pattern because of its financial problems. St. John has said simply rolling over the current contract would add 16 percent to the company's labor costs. Bieber said Friday the union had no intention of giving up its pattern bargaining strategy. ``Abandoning the pattern concept will not solve problems,'' he said. ``It will create even more. Chrysler would gain nothing, but lose a great deal of morale.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Restructuring of Parent Won't Solve Heileman's Financial Woes
With AM-Alan Bond
DOC.TEXT: G. Heileman Brewing Co., Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond's best-known U.S. business, has serious financial problems that a reorganization of its parent won't help, analysts say. Bond agreed to resign as chairman of his Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. to appease creditors, under an agreement announced Thursday. The resignation was part of a plan for refinancing arrangements, company director Peter Lucas said in disclosing the pact after a bondholders meeting in London. Heileman officials said Bond's financial problems do not affect Heileman directly because the brewer has its own loan arrangements, currently being renegotiated with creditors. Bond Corp. Holdings' Australian brewery assets will be sold for about $1.4 billion to Bell Resources, an independently managed affiliate of Bond Corp. Holdings. Heileman would not be included in the sale, Lucas said. ``Bell Resources has felt that the maximum capacity in the brewing industry that it could undertake ought to be restricted to the Australian assets at this time,'' he said. ``It (Heileman) is going to remain with Bond Corporation.'' New leadership at Bond Holdings won't help Heileman with its own debt problems, said George Thompson, an analyst with Prudential-Bache. ``There's nothing I can think of that is going to solve the problem at G. Heileman,'' Thompson said. ``No matter who it was, they're confronted with an extraordinarily difficult task and a change of management is not going to make a difference.'' The La Crosse, Wis.-based company has been strapped by debt created when Bond bought the company in 1987 for $1.3 billion. Analysts have said he paid too much for the brewer and cannot service the $850 million debt with Heileman earnings. The brewer has closed or sold several of its breweries over the past few months to pay its bills. Heileman _ which produces Old Style, Lone Star, Rainier, Henry Weinhard, Colt 45 and Special Export Light _ is the No. 5 U.S. brewer. The company also produces Kingsbury, a nonalcoholic brew, and La Croix sparkling water, the No. 2 domestic bottled water. Robert S. Weinberg, a St. Louis marketing consultant, said Bond's resignation and his company's restructuring may have an indirect impact on Heileman. ``If it has any impact, the Bond Company's reorganization would spur a reorganization of Heileman's assets,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Subject of Federal Probe Into Defense Contractors
DOC.TEXT: John O'Brien, who resigned suddenly as head of the Grumman Corp., is under investigation by a federal grand jury for possibly accepting loans from a Grumman defense subcontractor, a source said Friday. A grand jury at U.S. District Court in Uniondale has been hearing testimony for about a year, the source told The Associated Press. The case stems from a broader investigation by the U.S. Justice Department into wrongdoing in defense contracting. Records seized at the offices of the late James Kane, a Grumman defense subcontractor, indicated that O'Brien and family members accepted more than $450,000 in loans and loan guarantees from Kane, the source said. It would be a violation of federal anti-kickback laws for a defense contractor to accept loans from a subcontractor. The source, who is close to the investigation and spoke on condition of anonymity, called O'Brien a ``subject'' rather than a ``target'' of the grand jury investigation, and said no indictment was imminent. ``Being a subject doesn't mean that he won't ultimately be charged,'' the source said. ``But right now the net is very broad.'' Newsday, which reported the nature of the investigation Friday, noted that O'Brien denied wrongdoing in May when the newspaper asked him whether he or people closely associated with him had taken loans from Kane. ``Because this is a pending investigation, it is not prudent for me to discuss the facts,'' he said then. ``However, I want to assure you that I have every reason to believe that when all the facts are known it will be clear that there has been no wrongdoing on my part.'' O'Brien could not be located Friday to comment. Grumman spokesman Robert Harwood said he did not know where O'Brien was. A call to the offices of Brendan Sullivan, reported to be O'Brien's lawyer, was not returned. Harwood said he could neither confirm nor deny the existence of an investigation. He declined to comment on the reasons for O'Brien's departure from the aerospace giant, beyond the company statement. Kane, who died of cancer in February, was thought to be a central figure in a scheme to bribe Pentagon officials for defense contracts. Kane and O'Brien were friends, and Kane founded and operated the Long Island Aerospace Political Action Committee, a lobby group for Grumman. O'Brien, Grumman's chairman and chief executive officer for the past two years, was under pressure to quit from the Grumman board, the source said. That pressure increased as the investigation intensified in the last few months. ``They felt if charges were eventually brought against O'Brien it would do more damage to the company to have him in place than out,'' the source said. Newsday quoted a former Grumman board member, Orville L. Freeman, as saying that he was told the board wanted O'Brien out. O'Brien, 60, cited ``personal reasons'' in resigning Thursday at the board's regular meeting. He was replaced immediately by Renso Caporali, 57, a Grumman vice chairman. The source said the grand jury has subpoenaed ``many records'' from Grumman over the last few months. O'Brien has not been called to testify before the panel. ``Generally, the activity has been increasing,'' the source said. Mary Jo White, spokeswoman for Andrew Maloney, the U.S. Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Kerkorian Pockets $180 Million Toward Pathe Purchase of MGM-UA
DOC.TEXT: Kirk Kerkorian pocketed $180 million in deposit money Friday as part of his deal to sell MGM-UA Communications Co. to Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti. Kerkorian, a Beverly Hills billionaire who became rich buying and selling planes and casinos, received $4 per share for his MGM-UA stock, as did other MGM-UA shareholders. He owns about 35 million of MGM-UA's 51 million shares of common stock, and 10 million shares of preferred stock. He established a foundation last year to which he gave another 5 million shares of the common. Parretti's Pathe Communications Corp. has agreed to buy MGM-UA for $21.50 per share, or $1.3 billion. He had been making non-refundable down payments since March, for a total of $253 million. That money was sent to shareholders and holders of options to buy shares Friday, with the lion's share to Kerkorian. The remaining $17.50 per share is due in October. ``The money's good, and we're in the process of making the distribution,'' said Scott Tagliarino, MGM-UA's spokesman. MGM-UA's common stock was unchanged Friday at $18.25 per share on the New York Stock Exchange. MGM-UA has been on the auction block for two years. Australia's Qintex Group bid $1.5 billion for it last year, $100 million more than media magnate Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. But Qintex missed a $50 million down payment and the deal fell apart. Parretti desperately needs financing help for his purchase. Time Warner Inc. agreed April 9 to lend him $650 million in return for a lien on the valuable United Artists library and extensive movie distribution rights. But that agreement also collapsed, and Time Warner and Pathe have filed countersuits seeking hundreds of millions of dollars each for alleged breach of contract. Despite his $253 million in down payments, there is considerable skepticism that Parretti can come up with the rest of the money. ``He's waited four months and now we're into the fifth month and we're not any closer to the conclusion of the transaction than we were at the start,'' said Jeffrey Logsdon, an analyst with Siedler Amdec Securities Inc. in Los Angeles. Pathe had offered $20 per share, about $1.2 billion, for MGM-UA but was unable to raise the money in time for the closing date a month ago. In return for a four-month extension on the deal, Parretti raised his offer to $21.50 per share and to the $4-per-share distribution. Under the latest agreement, Parretti must make another $50 million deposit on Aug. 21, $50 million on Sept. 20, and come up with the balance by Oct. 23. The $100 million in additional down payments is to be put into escrow. Along with it goes 11.9 million new, unregistered shares of MGM-UA common stock in Pathe's name, 2.3 million after the August payment is made, another 9.6 million after the September payment. That money and stock would be the subject of litigation if the latest deal between Parretti and Kerkorian falls apart.

DOC.HEAD: Caterpillar Announces Earnings Slumped in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Caterpillar Inc. on Friday reported a 67 percent drop in second-quarter earnings, but said no layoffs or pay cuts are planned to offset the company's plunging profits. Caterpillar, the world's largest manufacturer of construction equipment, reported earnings of $46 million or 46 cents per share, down from $141 million or $1.39 per share in the same period of 1989. Profits slumped despite revenue levels that are the second highest for any quarter in the company's 75-year history. Revenue for the quarter totaled $2.95 billion, a 3 percent drop from the same period last year when Caterpillar had a record $3.04 billion in revenue. The company had projected plunging profits in June, but that made the results no easier to stomach. ``The quarter turned out about exactly the way we had said it would in the revised outlook,'' said Caterpillar spokesman Gil Nolde. ``Results are not satisfactory, no question about that. Forty-six million dollars profit on sales of $2.95 billion is not good.'' It was the fifth consecutive quarter in which Caterpillar profits have fallen below performance in the same period of the previous year. Nolde disputed rumors circulating the company about possible pay cuts or layoffs as cost-saving measures, labeling the employees' concerns ``absolutely unfounded.'' ``There are no such plans, I can say that categorically,'' Nolde said. On June 25, Caterpillar announced that new economic policies in Brazil, where Caterpillar employs 5,100 workers at two plants, were having a disastrous impact on company finances. The Brazil operations provided a reported 20 percent of Caterpillar's 1989 profits. Because of the Brazilian government's efforts to slow inflation and increase competition, Caterpillar said its second-quarter earnings would be less than half the $99 million earned in the first quarter. Nolde said Friday the Brazil turmoil accounted for about 25 percent of the company's reduced profits. The company said about half of its decline in profit was caused by an 8 percent drop in sales volume, which Nolde attributed to reduced demand for construction equipment in industrialized nations. Caterpillar's remaining troubles have resulted from a weaker Japanese yen and higher operating costs. One bright spot was a $19 million improvement in revenue from Caterpillar's financial subsidiaries. For the first six months of the year, Caterpillar's profits stood at $145 million, a decline of $137 million from last year. Profit per share was $1.43, compared to $2.78 for the first six months of 1989. Revenue for the first half totaled $5.8 billion, an improvement of $163 million, or 3 percent, from last year. Caterpillar also disclosed that a class-action lawsuit was filed in federal court on Wednesday by New York stockholder Dorothy Kas. The lawsuit accused the company of misleading investors by withholding pertinent information and lying about its financial condition in the first two quarters of this year to attract investors. ``Our lawyers have advised that we not discuss second-quarter results other than what's in the news release,'' Nolde said. ``We believe the suit is without merit, but we can't discuss it further at this time.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: New disappointments in high-technology profits helped send stock prices into a sharp decline Friday after the Dow Jones industrial average made another short-lived run past the 3,000 level. Dow Jones's average of 30 blue chips fell 32.67 to 2,961.14, finishing the week with a net loss of 19.06 points. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 585 up, 912 down and 513 unchanged. Late last week, Monday and Tuesday, and again at midsession Friday, the Dow Jones industrials crossed 3,000, only to turn back quickly. The earlier pullbacks proved to be shallow, and brokers said bullish traders weren't discouraged for long. But they seemed to run short on patience Friday afternoon as resistance at 3,000 remained stubborn. The late drop gathered momentum when Texas Instruments reported second-quarter earnings of 2 cents a share, down from $1.14 in the like period last year, marking another in a recent series of profit disappointments at technology companies. TI, citing sluggish conditions in the market for semiconductors, also said it faced the possibility of posting a loss in the third quarter. Texas Instruments shares fell 5} to 33[. Advanced Micro Devices, which posted a 10-cents-a-share loss for the second quarter, tumbled 1} to 7\. Storage Technology led the active list with an even bigger drop, down 8} at 25} after the company made a downbeat appraisal of its earnings prospects for the year. Among other prominent computer and technology stocks, International Business Machines fell 2] to 117|; Digital Equipment 1} to 81[; Compaq Computer 3\ to 60\, and Hewlett-Packard 1~ to 45]. Elsewhere in the blue-chip sector, Boeing dropped 1 to 58; General Electric 1 to 74; Exxon 1] to 48|; American Express } to 30{, and Ford Motor ~ to 43\. Browning-Ferris Industries, also among the volume leaders, dropped 1{ to 42[. The company reported slightly higher quarterly earnings on Thursday, but the gain was a shade smaller than had been expected. An exception to the general trend was Suave Shoe, up 1[ at 10[ on sharply higher quarterly profits. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 177.81 million shares, against 161.99 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 213.39 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $29.53 billion, or 0.85 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks dropped 1.73 to 197.65. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 4.51 to 428.69, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down 3.71 at 361.61. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slumped 2.90 to 455.27. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.45, down 1.39.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda Recalls '86 and '87 Cars
DOC.TEXT: Mazda Motor Corp. on Friday recalled 102,548 of its 1985 and 1986 model 626 cars because of potentially faulty ignition switches. The company said the switch could wear out after extended use and affect the operation of the windshield wiper and washer, engine cooling fan, heater blower and air conditioner compressor. Mazda is notifying owners of the vehicles and will fix faulty switches for free. The company said no injuries were associated with the problem.

DOC.HEAD: Farm Bureau Survey Reveals Consumer Concerns, Confidence About Farm Issues
DOC.TEXT: People in the heart of the Cornbelt believe farmers produce healthy food but don't think the farmers do a good job helping protect the environment, according to a survey released Friday. The survey found that 65 percent of the people surveyed think the dangers of pesticides outweigh their benefits and that 15 percent want all farm chemicals banned. The Illinois Farm Bureau commissioned the April telephone survey of 400 Champaign County residents. ``Farmers are interested in people's attitudes ... on using the technology that's been put into their hands,'' said Dennis Vercler, spokesman for the Farm Bureau. Vercler said farmers are concerned about food safety and the environment, and many have changed their farming practices to reflect that attitude. Yet, many people are unaware of such changes because farmers have not told them, he said. ``They should acknowledge that people's concerns are real, even if they don't feel they are justified by the actual risks involved,'' said Vercler. ``Farmers need to communicate better with consumers and deal with their perceptions.'' Vercler was joined at a news conference at the edge of a corn field by Champaign County farmers who are working to protect the environment. A display board showed photographs of their new practices. The Farm Bureau survey found that 51 percent of the people surveyed strongly agree that farmers produce healthy food but that just 16 percent strongly think farmers are protecting the environment. Farmers, though, have the most to lose if they are careless with pesticides or allow chemicals to pollute water and contaminate food, said Tom Wolf, who raises grain. ``I live here with my family, and I'm concerned about our safety,'' said Wolf. ``And I don't want the next generation to have any problems farming the land.'' The Champaign County survey was similar to a national poll conducted by the American Farm Bureau Federation and released earlier this week. Other findings in the Champaign County survey: _Sixty percent of the people said they were very concerned about pesticides in drinking water. _Forty-nine percent of the respondents said farmers use too large a volume of chemicals and 14 percent said they use far too much. _Twenty-nine percent said farmers are too easily persuaded by chemical companies to use more pesticides, and 26 percent said farmers favor economics over safety. _Thirty-seven percent said they think the trend among farmers is to use more chemicals. Actually, from 1978 to 1988, farmers cut their use of herbicides by 21 percent and insecticides by 60 percent in response to both environmental and economic concerns, the Farm Bureau said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar turned in a mixed performance Friday, ending slightly lower in domestic trading against every major currency but the Japanese yen and Canadian dollar. Gold prices were mixed in New York after falling overseas. Republic National Bank quoted a bid for gold of $360.75 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EDT, up 35 cents from Thursday's after-hours bid. Earlier, gold for current delivery lost 10 cents to $361.30 an ounce on the Commodity Exchange. Karen Gibbs, senior financial futures analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago, said currency trading was light and choppy largely because of uncertainty about the direction of the U.S. economy. The dollar turned in its strongest performance against the Japanese yen. Dealers said traders sold the yen for dollars and West German marks after Japanese money supply figures dashed hopes among some traders that Japanese authorities would move soon to lower the discount rate. Masayuki Takaura, senior foreign exchange manager at Sanwa Bank Ltd. in London, said the yen was due for a modest correction after recent gains. However, he said the dollar's move through 148.50 yen in early European dealings helped spark a flurry of stop-loss dollar buying. Dean Witter's Gibbs said she feels ``the path of least resistance is still down for the dollar.'' She said that the Federal Reserve's relaxation of credit conditions a week ago made U.S. interest rates ``unattractive globally'' and that Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan's expressed willingness to lower rates further if a budget compromise is reached and the economy remains weak keeps downward pressure on the dollar. She said Greenspan's remarks showed ``they are not going to tighten and that would be the only thing making the dollar more attractive.'' In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 148.35 Japanese yen from 147.60 yen Thursday. The dollar was quoted later in London at 148.90 yen. In New York, the dollar rose to 148.65 yen from 148.09 yen late Thursday. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8140 from $1.8155 late Thursday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.8185 from $1.8165. Late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.6385 West German marks, down from 1.6408; 1.4043 Swiss francs, down from 1.4060; 5.4965 French francs, down from 5.5045; 1,200.00 Italian lire, down from 1,201.75; and 1.15495 Canadian dollars, up from 1.15235. Selected late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late rates Thursday, included: 1.6410 West German marks, down from 1.6430; 1.4070 Swiss francs, down from 1.4090; 5.5045 French francs, down from 5.5100; 1.8485 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8500; 1,201.75 Italian lire, down from 1,203.00, and 1.1565 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1535. Gold fell in London to $361.25 a troy ounce, down from $362.75 late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to $361.50 an ounce from $362.20 late Thursday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell 66 cents to $361.63 per ounce. Silver for current delivery fell 0.003 cent to $4.848 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange in New York. Silver fell to $4.87 a troy ounce in London, down from $4.88 late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Crude Oil Futures Rise
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil futures prices were mostly higher Friday due largely to technical factors. The August contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, rose 62 cents to $19.61 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after rising 44 cents a barrel Thursday. But contract prices for later months were up by far less or down slightly. Frank P. Knuettel, an energy analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said this shows the trading was dominated by technical factors involving the August contract. Traders said rumors circulated that the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to limit production until crude prices reach $20 a barrel. The rumors may have helped boost prices. The OPEC ministers are to meet next Thursday to discuss production cuts. Also Friday, the United Arab Emirates rejected accusations by Iraq that it was exceeding its OPEC quotas. The two OPEC members have been involved in a dispute over Iraqi claims that the UAE is pumping oil from Iraqi territory. News that the flow of crude through the Alaska pipeline resumed at normal levels had a moderating influence on prices, but it soon was surpassed by concern about OPEC reaching an agreement on output, traders said. On Thursday, operators of the pipeline took steps to shut it down over an air quality dispute. But operations were restored to normal Thursday night after the operators and state regulators agreed to negotiate and after a federal judge temporarily blocked enforcement of a pollution-related ban on operating the pipeline. Prices for refined products traded on the mercantile exchange ended the day lower. Unleaded regular gasoline for August delivery fell 0.11 cent to 62.96 cents a gallon, while later contract months were even lower. The August contract for home heating oil fell 0.59 cent to close at 55.79 cents a gallon, with subsequent months down by lesser amounts. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.426 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.445 Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Approve Northeast Takeover of Public Service
DOC.TEXT: State regulators on Friday approved a $2.3 billion takeover plan and a new rate structure for Public Service Company of New Hampshire, paving the way for the utility to emerge from bankruptcy. The Public Utilities Commission's 200-page report, following 21 days of hearings ended in late May, found Connecticut-based Northeast Utilities' acquisition ``consistent with the public good.'' The reorganization plan's rate agreement projects seven annual rate increases of 5.5 percent beginning in 1990. Testimony during commission hearings that rates actually could go as high as 8.5 percent prompted a public criticism of the deal, which was approved by the state Legislature. Special Commissioner John Nassikas, appointed to oversee the hearings, said the commission was confident assumptions behind the 5.5 percent figures are realistic. ``I would hasten to add that there's no guarantee that this would be a 5.5 percent increase over the seven-year life,'' Nassikas said. ``It would be irrational to say ... that their projections are invulnerable and that you're not going to have an increase over 5.5 percent.'' Leading Democrats and the Campaign For Ratepayers' Rights said that's just what they were worried about. ``I think we will clearly see in the future rate hikes far in excess of the 5.5 percent,'' said state House Minority Leader Mary Chambers, D-Etna. She said commissioners ``clearly were going to rubber-stamp what has already been agreed to by the governor, Northeast and the Republican leadership in the Legislature.'' The Campaign for Ratepayers' Rights is considering appealing the decision to the state Supreme Court, said interim director Robert Cushing. Gov. Judd Gregg in a statement called the rate agreement ``a major victory for New Hampshire ratepayers that will save hundreds of millions of dollars.'' He said, with the Seabrook nuclear power plant now running, rates would have been significantly higher if there were no rate agreement. Commission approval was needed to allow Public Service to emerge from bankruptcy and pay back its creditors. Shortly after Northeast's plan was approved in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in April, the management of Public Service was taken over by a Northeast-appointed board. ``Clearly, we're going to spend a lot of hours combing the report, but our first indication is that it's a very positive development for ending this 2{ year bankruptcy,'' said Northeast spokesman Jeffrey Kotkin. ``It's a long, involved decision _ which is right because it was a long, involved _ and at times torturous _ process.'' The bankruptcy court approval is under appeal and the commission allows 20 days for appeals to be filed on its decision. Once both decisions are final, Public Service officially will be out of bankruptcy. The actual merger of Northeast with Public Service won't be complete until it gains necessary federal approvals, including that of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission expected by next spring.

DOC.HEAD: Bankruptcy Case Turned Over To Judge Critical of Asbestos Trust
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge highly critical of the Manville trust fund was granted broad powers Friday that could ensure his ability to overhaul the system for paying asbestos victims. In an order by the chief judge of federal courts in southern New York, U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein received the power to rule on any bankruptcy court appeal involving Manville Corp.'s 1988 reorganization or the trust. The future of the $3 billion trust, created as part of Manville's court reorganization, has been up in the air since it disclosed it had run out of money to pay 130,000 pending and any new claims. Asbestos lawsuits represent the largest product liability litigation in U.S. history. ``It's essential to get some case management going in these problems,'' Chief Judge Charles L. Brieant said in a telephone interview from his office in suburban White Plains. ``These cases have been pending a long time.'' Brieant said the bankruptcy case remained before U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland but that Weinstein now was supervising with power to transfer any appeal to his own courtroom. Weinstein last week ordered a plan to be drawn up by Aug. 6 to refinance and restructure the trust. He also froze all payments by the trust until the plan was ready. Separately, Thomas D. Lambros, chief judge for U.S. District Court in Cleveland, this week consolidated more than 100,000 pending lawsuits nationwide against the Manville trust and about 40 companies that made and distributed asbestos. Lambros on Friday clarified his interim order, saying it preserved current court jurisdictions pending discussions on ``the possibility of achieving a universal resolution through a national class action.'' Lambros scheduled a Nov. 1 hearing. He said judges, plaintiffs and defense lawyers, and claimants would meet before then to try and reach a solution. The order giving Weinstein expanded power over the Manville bankruptcy case and the reorganization of the trust rebuffs plaintiffs lawyers who don't want the trust's payment mechanism altered. Weinstein and Lambros both have criticized the amount of trust money that has gone to lawyers. One attorney, Eugene Locks of Philadelphia, filed a motion challenging Weinstein's authority Friday with the 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals in Manhattan. Another challenge was filed earlier this week in district court on behalf of 1,100 Virginia shipyard workers who already have settled with the trust and don't want $60 million in payments delayed. That motion also seeks to bar restructuring of the trust. ``Hasn't this Manville bankruptcy been consummated? If so, even the bankruptcy judge has no authority to restructure or refinance the (trust),'' said Richard Glasser, a Norfolk, Va., attorney representing the workers. Weinstein has called for replacing the trust's current scheme processing claims on a first-come, first-served basis with one that takes into account the severity of disease and the financial need of victims. Asbestos was widely used for decades in shipbuilding, construction and other industries for its natural insulation and heat-resistant properties. Workers who breathed asbestos fibers have contracted lung cancer and other severe and often-fatal diseases. Manville, once the nation's largest asbestos maker, sought bankruptcy court protection in 1982 because of thousands of lawsuits seeking compensation. Under its reorganization, Manville is separate from the trust but must contribute regular payments starting in 1991. The trust has paid $974 million to settle more than 22,300 cases so far at an average of $43,000 per claim but is out of cash to pay new claims. Manville spokesman Don Ferguson said the company would cooperate with the courts on all issues.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Tumble on Rain Forecasts
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices fell sharply Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid forecasts for a weekend of beneficial rain in the Midwest, where crop weather has been nearly perfect for most of the summer. Corn and wheat futures closed lower; oats were narrowly mixed. On other commodity markets, petroleum futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were mixed; copper futures rose; and precious metals slipped. Soybean futures settled 13{ cents to 19 cents lower with the contract for delivery in August at $5.91 a bushel, its lowest settlement since June 15. Wheat futures finished { cent to 4 cents lower with September at $3.00 a bushel; corn was 1 cent to 2{ cents lower with September at $2.59\ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with September at $1.21} a bushel. All contracts for July deliveries of grains and soybeans expired at 1 p.m. EDT on the Board of Trade. Crop prices have been falling since late June, largely due to a pattern of mild temperatures and frequent precipitation in the nation's midsection that has facilitated corn and soybean development. This week, showers began watering Midwestern croplands Wednesday night, continued into Friday and were expected to spread during the weekend into the Mississippi Delta region, a soybean production area that has been fairly dry. After the close, the National Weather Service issued a new six-to-10-day forecast predicting normal to above-normal temperatures and normal rainfall in the Midwest during the five days beginning next Thursday. The recent weather also been friendly to the corn crop, which is nearing the halfway point of its pollination phase, Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the exchange, said corn fields have received enough precipitation to get the crop through the critical period without harm. ``The corn crop is basically made,'' he said. ``The only thing that could hurt the crop now is an early frost.'' Near-term crude oil futures advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange on expectations that OPEC members will agree next week on actions to shore up crude prices. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 9 cents lower to 62 cents higher with the August contract, which expired Friday, at $19.61 a barrel; heating oil was .36 cent to .59 cent lower with August at 55.79 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .03 cent to .40 cent lower with August at 62.96 cents a gallon. Frozen pork belly futures rebounded from a steep opening drop to close moderately lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Bellies had fallen sharply in the two previous sessions due to slack demand for bacon, which is made from pork bellies. After the close, the Agriculture Department released a monthly cold storage report that was expected to prompt renewed selling of belly futures Monday. The report showed 88.1 million pounds of frozen pork bellies on hand as of June 30, about 1.8 million pounds more than the market had expected. The amount compares with 105.5 million pounds a month earlier and 126.7 million pounds a year ago. Cattle and hog futures ended mostly higher ahead of the USDA's monthly and quarterly cattle-on-feed reports. Both reports showed 1 percent more cattle on feed as of July 1 than on the same date a year ago, confirming industry expectations. The report was expected to have little impact on futures prices. Live cattle settled .13 cent to .35 cent higher with August 76.42 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .45 cent higher with August at 87.75 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .65 cent higher with July, which expired Friday, at 63.90 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .07 cent to 1.22 cents lower with July at 45.87 cents a pound. Copper futures rallied on New York's Commodity Exchange after the market refused to break on bearish news that representatives of striking miners at an Asarco Inc. mine in Arizona had reached a tentative labor pact to be voted on Saturday. The miners have been on strike since July 1. Copper futures settled 1.7 cents to 1.9 cents higher with July at $1.215 a pound. Precious metals edged lower on the Commodity Exchange. Gold settled 10 cents to 20 cents lower with August at $362 a troy ounce; silver was 0.3 cent to 0.9 cent lower with July at $4.848 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Talking with Aeritalia, Aerospatiale About Selling de Havilland
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co., which has never been content with its de Havilland commuter aircraft division, said Friday it is discussing selling the Canadian operation to Aeritalia of Italy and Aerospatiale of France. Boeing Canada's de Havilland Division, based in Downsview, Ontario, builds the Dash 8-series turboprop commuter plane. Boeing bought de Havilland from the Canadian government in 1986, and company executives have since made no secret of their disappointment in the subsidiary's performance. Boeing corporate spokesman Paul Binder declined to give revenue or earnings figures for de Havilland, which employs 5,400. But industry analysts say it has been a money-loser. In a news release, Boeing said any sale would involve an orderly transfer of responsibility to the buyers with continuing Boeing support. A sale would be subject to approval of the Canadian government, it said. Binder declined to elaborate beyond the company's two-paragraph news release. ``At any time we get anything more firm, we will make an announcement,'' he said. Representatives of Aerospatiale and Aeritalia, both government-owned, could not be reached for comment. Aeritalia has long worked with Boeing to produce parts for Boeing's 767 jetliners. Aerospatiale is one of the companies in the European consortium Airbus Industrie, one of Boeing's prime competitors for commercial jets. Aeritalia and Aerospatiale are partners in Avions de Transport Regional, a company that produces the ATR 42 and ATR 72 turboprop commuter planes. Boeing bought de Havilland for 90 million Canadian dollars, a price critics said was too cheap. But Boeing has since invested more than 400 million Canadian dollars in new plant facilities, equipment and research and development, said de Havilland President Ron Woodward. Boeing also brought millions of dollars of new business to de Havilland and other Canadian divisions, meeting a provision of the purchase agreement. Boeing officials believed de Havilland would be a good match, despite the Canadian company's longstanding economic and labor troubles. Boeing executives said de Havilland's commuter planes would complement the Seattle plane builder's broad line of jet aircraft. Boeing was able to boost de Havilland's production, but poor profitability, continuing labor problems _ including an 11-week strike in 1987 _ and needed improvements to the plant near Toronto soured some company executives on the acquisition. Dean Thornton, president of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, has said he personally regretted the purchase. Wolfgang Demisch, an aerospace analyst at Union Bank of Switzerland in New York, estimated de Havilland's 1989 revenues at $750 million, while Bill Whitlow of Dain Bosworth in Seattle pegged it at $700 million. Both said Boeing has been losing money on the division. ``I would guess that Boeing has come to the conclusion they're not going to be able to turn it around as they'd like to,'' Whitlow said. The commuter aircraft market ``has been ruthlessly competitive,'' Demisch said, and Boeing hasn't been able to get the prices it would like. Unlike large commercial jets, where only Boeing, Airbus and McDonnell Douglas dominate, the market has 16 or more players. Demisch and Whitlow said many of those companies are owned or heavily subsidized by their governments, making it difficult for private companies to compete. De Havilland builds the 36-40 passenger Dash 8-100 and the 50-56 passenger Dash 8-300. It plans to launch the 70-seat Dash 8-400 this December. It had a backlog of 125 aircraft as of June 30 and planned to deliver 73 planes this year. Its planes compete directly with ATR's aircraft, Demisch said. But he said Aeritalia and Aerospatiale may be seeking to broaden their product mix in addition to absorbing a competitor. In February, Boeing settled a lawsuit against the Canadian government over the de Havilland acquisition. The agreement, Canadian Industry Minister Harvie Andre said, called for Boeing to receive up to 161 million Canadian dollars in cash and incentives. It also settled Boeing's claim that it had to spend more than 110 million Canadian dollars to improve health and safety at the Downsview plant. Boeing had 1989 profits of $973 million on sales of $20.3 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Edge Up
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices rose slightly Friday in light trading as traders held ground because of uncertainty over the federal budget. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond rose 3-16 point, or $1.88 per $1,000 face amount. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, slipped to 8.53 percent from 8.55 percent late Thursday. The modest rally follows three consecutive declines in long-term bond prices that lifted 30-year bond yields from 8.45 percent earlier this week. Elizabeth Capo, a futures analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J., said prices moved up on speculation that chances may be improving for a compromise on reducing the federal budget deficit. But she also said traders were reluctant to stake out new positions because of uncertainty on whether a compromise could be reached before Congress recesses next month. Kathleen Camilli, chief economist for Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc., said a report by the Federal Reserve Bank in Philadelphia indicated regional economic conditions had softened considerably. That led to speculation that the purchasing managers survey due for release on Aug. 1 would point to economic deterioration. A declining economy makes it more likely that the Federal Reserve will push interest rates lower, a development that would boost bond prices. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose 1-32 point to \ point, intermediate maturities rose 5-16 point and long-term issues added as much as 3-16 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Hutton Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, gained 1.43 to 1,160.61. Yields on three-month Treasury bills fell to 7.77 percent as the discount dropped 1 basis point to 7.53 percent. Yields on six-month bills rose to 7.84 percent as the discount gained 1 basis point to 7.45 percent. Yields on one-year bills were unchanged at 7.84 percent as the discount held at 7.33 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 percent, unchanged from late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds up 3-32 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.41 percent from 7.42 percent late Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Instruments Earnings Continue Slide, Loss Possible Next Time
DOC.TEXT: Texas Instruments Inc., the second largest U.S. semiconductor manufacturer, Friday reported sharply lower second-quarter earnings and raised the possibility of a loss in the third quarter. The Dallas-based company said net income in the period ended June 30 fell from $106 million last year to $11 million this year. Provisions for preferred stockholders further sliced income to $1 million, or 2 cents per common share, from $96 million, or $1.14. Revenues dropped from $1.63 billion to $1.59 billion. The company blamed the results on ``sharply lower prices for semiconductor memories and substantially higher start-up costs for new products and capacity.'' The news sent TI's stock tumbling on the New York Stock Exchange, where shares closed at $33.12{, down $5.75. The second-quarter decline follows an 84.7 percent drop in first-quarter earnings, when profit plummeted from $85 million to $13 million as revenue went from $1.6 billion to $1.54 billion. TI said it avoided a loss then only because of the sale of its interest in another company. Chairman Jerry R. Junkins had warned stockholders in April results would be unlikely to improve in the second quarter, and in a letter Friday, he said the problems will continue. ``For TI, third-quarter results will be affected by continuing research and development and start-up costs for new products with minimal revenue ... and costs related to our Baguio plant,'' he said. The semiconductor plant in the Philippines suffered minor damage in this week's earthquake, but production was disrupted, Junkins said. ``These factors will create additional pressure on TI's financial performance in the near term and could cause a loss for TI in the third quarter,'' he said. Junkins said the company is deferring some expenses to lessen the impact, and will spend only $950 million in capital expenditures this year instead of the projected $1 billion. The company also has been hit by decreases in defense spending, and last month announced it would lay off 1,000 workers at its Defense Systems & Electronics Group, which employs about 22,000 people primarily in the United States. Junkins told stockholders Friday the defense market will continue to drop in the first half of the 1990s, but the layoffs should lessen the impact on company profits. For the first six months, TI reported earnings of $24 million compared to $191 million last year. After preferred stock dividends, income was $6 million, or 7 cents per share, down from $171 million, or $2.04 last year. Revenue in the first six months dropped from $3.23 billion to $3.13 billion.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Identifies 4 Germans, 3 Entities Suspected in Contel Probe
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators accused four West Germans and three European entities Friday of trading in the securities of Contel Corp. with inside information about a pending $6 billion merger with GTE Corp. The seven were identified in court papers filed in New York, one week after the original charges were brought against ``individuals or entities whose identities are as yet unknown.'' The identities of some defendants remained unknown, said the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington. Last week the SEC said the suspects stood to make more than $1 million in alleged illegal profits on investments of $205,125. The SEC identified the individuals accused of trading on inside information as: Ortwin Heider of Hofheim, West Germany; Hans-Jurgen Klisch and Hannelore Mirbach-Krahn, both of Meerbusch and Bodo Pawlik, of Ratingen, all in West Germany. They were accused of buying call options in Contel stock one-to-two days before Contel and GTE announced their merger plan. A call option is the right to buy 100 shares of a stock or stock index at a set price before a certain date. Call options are a way for an investor who thinks a stock's price will rise sharply to profit on a smaller investment than it would take to buy the stock itself. The merger was announced on Friday, July 13. The SEC alleged that the defendants accounted for over 2,800 of 6,546 Contel call options purchased on July 11 and 12. The total trading volume in Contel call option contracts for the three preceding trading days was 329 contracts, said the SEC. The call options were purchased through the New York offices of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in the name of a Dusseldorf bank, Simonbank, AG. Neither Dean Witter not Simonbank was accused of any wrongdoing. The new SEC complaint also identified three entities accused of violating insider trading laws: Union Investment, a Dusseldorf mutual fund; and two companies with offices in Switzerland, Nalasag Corp. in Geneva, and Sigesse, S.A. in Lausanne.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Sentence for Woman Convicted in S&L Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds:Duayne in 6th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: A savings and loan executive convicted of looting a failed thrift of more than $15 million and using the money to support a Rolls-Royce lifestyle was sentenced Friday to 20 years in prison. Janet Faye McKinzie, 41, of Newport Beach also was ordered by U.S. District Court Judge Alicemarie Stotler to make restitution of nearly $14 million taken from North America Savings & Loan of Santa Ana. ``It was a very, very appropriate sentence,'' said U.S. Attorney Paul Seave. ``Fair in a sense that it works as a deterrent in other S&L crimes and white-collar crime in general.'' Richard ``Racehorse'' Haynes, McKinzie's attorney, pleaded for leniency. ``You want to see a grown man cry?'' he told the judge. ``Janet McKinzie is paying the price for the S&L bailout.'' Haynes had portrayed his client as a ``washed-out zombie,'' hooked on prescription drugs given her by North America's chairman, dentist Duayne Christensen, and duped into following Christensen's orders. McKinzie had been the business manager for Christensen, who died in a car crash just hours after federal regulators took over the thrift in January 1987, declaring it insolvent. Christensen was named as an unindicted co-conspirator in McKinzie's case. McKinzie, the first person to be convicted under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act in connection with a West Coast savings and loan failure, appeared composed as her sentence was read. She wept in March when she was convicted of 22 counts of racketeering, conspiracy, bank fraud, wire fraud and interstate transportation of stolen property. She had faced a maximum 175-year prison term, but prosecutors asked for the term given. McKinzie, who held the title of consultant at North America, was denied bail pending an appeal. She will be eligible for parole in about seven years, Seave said. The North America case was considered among the top in the widespread S&L crisis ``in terms of how egregious the fraud was,'' William Davis, chief deputy of the California Department of Savings and Loan, has said. The S&L's collapse eventually cost taxpayers more than $120 million. Federal prosecutors had painted McKinzie and Christensen as a modern-day Bonnie and Clyde, stealing millions from North America to support their extravagant tastes. Each had a Rolls-Royce automobile, and they treated themselves to such baubles as a $125,000 gold eagle statue, an $18,500 letter opener and a $500 gold paper clip. McKinzie's 37th birthday was celebrated with a party at the Newport Beach Marriott, where hundreds of guests were entertained by Sammy Davis Jr. singing songs including ``Happy Birthday.'' Following criminal investigations into North America's operation, McKinzie was sued in February 1987 for acting with Christensen to defraud the institution and causing its collapse. In March 1987, federal regulators operating the thrift estimated the amount missing at $40 million. In June 1988, it was announced North America would be closed and liquidated. Federal prosecutors employed the RICO statute so the government could try to claim the proceeds from Christensen's $10 million life insurance policy, which named McKinzie as sole beneficiary. Three of McKinzie's associates have pleaded guilty to criminal charges in connection with alleged fraud at North America.

DOC.HEAD: Kellogg Reports Gain in Second Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Growing international sales of ready-to-eat cereal helped Kellogg Co. post a 4.2 percent increase in second-quarter profits, the world's largest cereal maker said Friday. Kellogg, which makes cereal in 16 countries and sells it in more than 130, said gains in those sales made up for sagging U.S. results. Kellogg reported net income of $135.7 million, or $1.13 a share, in the three months ending June 30, up from $129.7 million, or $1.06 a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Net sales edged up to $1.26 billion from $1.23 billion in the 1989 period, the company said. ``The performance of our U.S. ready-to-eat cereal business was down during the quarter,'' said William E. LaMothe, chairman and chief executive officer. ``Growth of the category has slowed and competition remains intense.'' Competitors with popular oat-bran products narrowed Kellogg's U.S. cereal market lead in 1989. LaMothe said the company expects new products to widen the lead again. Kellogg introduced two health-oriented oriented cereals, Heartwise and Oatbake, last fall, launched Kenmei Rice Bran in January, and introduced Bigg Mixx multigrain cereal, marketed mainly to children, in May. For the first six months of the year, Kellogg said it had net earnings of $232 million, or $1.92 a share, on net sales of $2.47 billion, compared with $289.2 million, or $2.36 a share, on net sales of $2.37 billion in the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Reports 10 Percent Jump in Second-Quarter Income
DOC.TEXT: McDonald's Corp. reported Friday a 10 percent increase in second-quarter net income, due in part to an increase in the number of overseas restaurants. Net income was $215.8 million, up from $196 million for the same quarter last year. Earnings per share rose 11 percent to 59 cents from 53 cents. Company officials also reported an increase in revenues in the second quarter, from $1.5 billion in the 1989 period to $1.7 billion this year. McDonald's said this was the 101st consecutive quarter that the company has reported record increases in operating results. ``Our growth strategy continues to focus on adding restaurants, building sales at existing restaurants and improving international profitability,'' said McDonald's chairman and chief executive officer, Michael R. Quinlan. Quinlan said sales in restaurants inside the United States did not increase as much as expected. ``Although U.S. sales are softer than expected, we continue to see strong growth outside of the U.S.,'' he said. For the first six months of the year, McDonald's reported net income of $373.9 million or $1.02 per share, up from $337.7 or 90 cents a share in the first six months of 1989. Revenues were $3.2 billion, up from $2.9 billion in the previous year.

DOC.HEAD: Investors Sue Sprint Parent Over Stock Price Drop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf to CORRECT spelling of spokesman's first name, Syd sted Csyd.
DOC.TEXT: Six class-action lawsuits have been filed against United Telecommunications Inc. accusing the company of failing to keep market analysts and investors informed of financial problems at the parent of US Sprint, a company spokesman said Friday. On Tuesday, United Telecom reported its earnings fell 55 percent in the second quarter, due largely to problems at Sprint, the long-distance phone company of which it is majority owner. The earnings report sent United Telecom's share price tumbling. Five of the suits were filed in U.S. District Court in Kansas City, Kan., while the sixth was filed in federal court in Kansas City, Mo., said Syd Courson, a Sprint spokesman. United Telecom had no comment on the suits, he said.
